title: Too Much of a Good Thing? Untangling the Relationship between R&D Volatility and Firm Performance
authors: Jiaojiao Qin, Annapoornima M. Subramanian, Haydar Yalçın, Tugrul Daim
abstract: Research indicates that R&D volatility is a significant predictor of firm performance. To date, however, answers on how this relationship manifests remain elusive, and practitioners have no clear guidelines for firms' R&D spending strategy. By incorporating the strategic change view into the R&D volatility research, this study proposes a nonlinear framework to revisit the effect of R&D volatility on firm performance. Since the performance implications of a firm's strategic change are determined by the strategic fit between it and internal capability, we also explore the contingency effect of technical capability in terms of firm digitalization and TMT technical experience. Based on a panel sample of Chinese listed firms from 2011 to 2023, we find that the impact of R&D volatility on firm performance is not simply linear, but follows an inverted U-shaped pattern. Moreover, firm digitalization moderates this curvilinear effect in a way that shifts it upward. A bibliometric analysis is conducted to situate our findings within the existing literature, and these research findings provide substantial theoretical and practical implications. In conclusion, our research introduces a nonlinear framework for exploring R&D volatility for the first time.

title: Hierarchical Prototype Learning with Uncertainty-aware Adaptation for Cross-domain Semantic Segmentation of Remote Sensing Images
authors: Jiawei Ning, Zhongle Ren, Biao Hou, Runnong Jiang, Shijie Liu, Weibin Li, Licheng Jiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Prominent domain discrepancies in Remote Sensing Images (RSIs), such as sensor types, geographical patterns, and land usage, significantly hinder the research and practical applications of cross-scene land classification. Unsupervised Domain Adaptation (UDA) fully exploits domain invariance between labelled source and unlabelled target domain, which alleviates the challenge of inaccurate land classification due to lack of labels in RSIs. However, most existing UDA methods for RSIs semantic segmentation are insufficient in exploring cross-domain features and have difficulty in modelling fine-grained domain-invariant features between inter-class. In this paper, we propose a novel self-training UDA method named Hierarchical Prototype Learning (HPL), which learns the inherent domain-wise consistency and class-wise invariance through progressive exploration of the prototypy, significantly alleviating the ambiguity in uncertain regions. HPL mainly consists of Domain-wise Progressive Prototype Interaction (DPPI) and Class-wise Dynamic Prototype Collaboration (CDPC). DPPI and CDPC specialize in hierarchically building prototype interaction architectures tailored to domain-wise alignment and class-wise calibration, respectively. This design not only mitigates the sensitivity to cross-domain scenarios but also allows for precise correction of uncertain regions. Furthermore, CDPC exhibits the capacity for pixel-level category restoration and promotes the correct and fine-grained updating of pseudo-labels. Extensive Experiments on two public datasets and a private self-build dataset demonstrate the superiority of HPL over other state-of-the-art methods for UDA semantic segmentation of RSIs.

title: SUIT: Spatial-Spectral Union-Intersection Interaction Network for Hyperspectral Object Tracking
authors: Fengchao Xiong, Zhenxing Wu, Jun Zhou, Sen Jia, Yuntao Qian
abstract: Hyperspectral videos (HSVs), with their inherent spatial-spectral-temporal structure, offer distinct advantages in challenging tracking scenarios such as cluttered backgrounds and small objects. However, existing methods primarily focus on spatial interactions between the template and search regions, often overlooking spectral interactions, leading to suboptimal performance. To address this issue, this paper investigates spectral interactions from both the architectural and training perspectives. At the architectural level, we first establish band-wise long-range spatial relationships between the template and search regions using Transformers. We then model spectral interactions using the inclusion-exclusion principle from set theory, treating them as the union of spatial interactions across all bands. This enables the effective integration of both shared and band-specific spatial cues. At the training level, we introduce a spectral loss to enforce material distribution alignment between the template and predicted regions, enhancing robustness to shape deformation and appearance variations. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our tracker achieves state-of-the-art tracking performance. The source code, trained models and results will be publicly available via https://github.com/bearshng/suit to support reproducibility.

title: Beamforming Design for Symbiotic Radios under ADC Dynamic Range and Quantization Noise Constraints
authors: Qing Tang, Hu Zhou, Ruizhe Long, Ying-Chang Liang
abstract: This paper investigates a symbiotic radio (SR) system composed of a multi-antenna radio frequency (RF) source, a backscatter device (BD), and a receiver. SR is an energy- and spectrum-efficient technology with great potential to enable passive Internet of Things (IoT). However, due to the double path loss in the reflecting link, the received BD signal is typically much weaker than the received RF source signal. As the dynamic range (DR) of the analog-to-digital converter (ADC) at the receiver is limited, it is challenging to recover the weak BD signal in the presence of a strong RF source signal after quantization. Additionally, when the low-resolution ADC is employed at the receiver, the introduced quantization noise (QN) will further deteriorate the bit error rate (BER) performance of the system. To mitigate these effects, we adopt optimal quantizers at the receiver and derive a linear quantized signal model, which considers practical modulation schemes and decoding processes. Based on this model, we define the DRs of both the ADC and the received signal, and derive analytical BER expressions for both the BD and RF source signals under the effect of QN. Subsequently, we formulate an optimization problem to minimize the BER of the BD signal via transmit beamforming, while accounting for the impact of ADC DR and QN. To solve the fractional optimization problem, we employ Dinkelbach’s algorithm in conjunction with the semidefinite relaxation (SDR) technique. Finally, simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed beamforming design method and the performance gains achieved by employing optimal quantizers at the receiver.

title: Magnet Design and Magnetic Measurements at Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati
authors: A. Vannozzi, G. Armenti, L. Capuano, A. Casamatta, S. Martelli, L. Petrucciani, L. Sabbatini, F. Sardone, A. Trigilio
abstract: The Frascati National Laboratories (LNF) of the National Institute for Nuclear Physics (INFN) have extensive experience in the design and measurement of electromagnets and permanent magnets for particle accelerators. In the last decades, LNF activities moved towards high-brightness electron sources with the SPARC_LAB linac test facility [1], where the current activities are focused on plasma-based acceleration techniques. This facility is the baseline for the future EuPRAXIA@SPARC_LAB accelerator [2]. According to the program needs of the LNF facilities, several designs of room temperature magnets have been carried out in recent years, covering a wide range of magnet types. A Magnetic Measurement Facility (MMF) is present at LNF; it is devoted to in depth magnet characterization thanks to a wide range of equipment for integrated magnetic measurement as well as 3D field mapping. In recent years, an upgrade of the instrumentation has been required [3] in order to keep pace with the evolving technologies in magnetic measurements and to ensure the preservation of expertise.. This revamping is oriented towards both the update of the existing infrastructure, and the purchase of new equipment. In this paper, recent and most relevant magnets design and magnetic measurement tests performed at LNF are presented, covering a variety of magnet types and measurement methods. The design and measurements for quadrupoles of BTF-2 [4], solenoids [5] and Permanent Magnet Quadrupoles (PMQ) for SPARC_LAB test facility [6] are presented in detail. Moreover, an overview of the magnetic laboratory equipment upgrade is given, highlighting the current and future instruments that will be hosted in the renewed facility. These improvements are aimed ensuring high flexibility in meeting measurement demands across many types of magnets, from both external users and for the future projects of LNF.

title: Cobweb Privacy: a Novel Mechanism for Comprehensive Association Privacy Protection in Data Aggregation
authors: Yanzi Li, Li Xu, Jiayin Li, He Fang, Shui Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: The issue of association privacy leakage has become increasingly critical during data release and usage. However, traditional privacy protection techniques often struggle to address privacy leakage resulting from implicit associations within the data. In this paper, we propose a novel mechanism based on Cobweb Privacy to safeguard association privacy more comprehensively. Firstly, we design the concept of ϵ-Cobweb Privacy (ϵ-CP) specifically to address association privacy leakage. This concept extends the traditional notion of differential privacy by incorporating associated prior knowledge, thereby offering more effective and comprehensive protection of association privacy. We further demonstrate its privacy guarantees through the theoretical analysis of the relationship between ϵ-CP, differential privacy, and pufferfish privacy. Secondly, we quantify the privacy leakage problem mathematically and examine the utility privacy trade off under various priors. Additionally, we present a universal framework for association privacy protection in data aggregation scenarios using the ϵ-CP mechanism. Finally, this framework is integrated with three different noise addition methods and compared against mechanisms based on differential privacy and pufferfish privacy, and its utility is validated through experiments on both non-temporal and temporal real-world datasets. The results show that ϵ-CP provides distinct advantages in the utility privacy trade-off.

title: Bio-immobilization of Plasma-Polymerized Heptylamine and Glutaraldehyde for K-SPR Glucose Biosensing
authors: Nur Akmar Jamil, Muhammad Feidhul Hakim Fatah Yasin, Kim Shyong Siow, Azrul Azlan Hamzah, Mohd Ambri Mohamed, Abdul Halim Abdul Gafor, Lydia Kamaruzaman, Noraidatulakma Abdullah, Lee Pey Yee, Syara Kassim, Ilmi Munirah Karim, Siti Nasuha Mustaffa, Azaham Abdul Rahman, P Susthitha Menon
abstract: The development of rapid, accurate, and label-free biosensing techniques for key biomarkers is crucial for early disease diagnosis and clinical monitoring. This study explores a novel approach for glucose detection using Kretschmann-based surface plasmon resonance (K-SPR) with a bio-immobilization platform based on plasma-polymerized thin films. We report the fabrication and characterization of biocompatible and functional thin films derived from the plasma polymerization of heptylamine (HA) followed by glutaraldehyde cross-linking. The resulting films were immobilized with glucose oxidase (GOx) to act as a biosensor for glucose sensing. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy, and atomic force microscopy were used to characterize the samples. The adsorption and interaction processes between the materials were analyzed using K-SPR. Our results for glucose detection in the range of 4 mmol/L to 20 mmol/L provide an average sensitivity of 7.8°/M and a limit of detection of 0.55 mmol/L. This study contributes to the early detection of diabetes via optical biosensing, plasma polymerization and enzyme immobilization techniques.

title: Digital-Twin-Assisted Fault Diagnosis for IMU in Rotational Inertial Navigation Systems
authors: Hui Li, Gongliu Yang, Qingzhong Cai, Yongqiang Tu
abstract: The rotational inertial navigation systems (RINS) is a type of inertial system designed for high-precision and long-duration navigation tasks. As a core component of inertial navigation systems, the inertial measurement unit (IMU) plays a critical role, and its malfunction can significantly degrade the accuracy of long-duration navigation results due to the cumulative nature of inertial integration. The introduction of the rotary mechanism in RINS enables rotational modulation, which effectively enhances long-term accuracy. However, this rotational modulation also introduces new challenges for IMU fault diagnosis. Therefore, researching IMU fault diagnosis tailored to the characteristics of RINS is of great significance for ensuring the long-term accuracy and reliability of the system. In this paper, a digital-twin-assisted IMU fault diagnosis method is proposed for RINS. Under static conditions, the proposed method achieves an overall fault classification accuracy of 97.99%, representing an average improvement of 28.04% over conventional data-driven approaches. In tests conducted under harsh vehicle conditions, the method attains a fault classification accuracy of 84.27%, which is about 25.08% average higher than that of data-driven methods. These results demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Let’s Get Physical: Rethinking the Static Partitioning Hypervisor Architecture for an MMU-less Memory Model
authors: Afonso Santos, José Martins, João Sousa, Manuel Rodríguez, Sandro Pinto
abstract: Many industries, in particular automotive, are undergoing substantial transformations in their underlying electrical and electronic architecture (E/E), pushing for a transition from traditional flat architectures to more decentralized and zonal systems. Moreover, this industry’s demanding constraints and regulations (e.g., ISO26262) limit the application of COTS technologies to support this shift. Seeing this gap, semiconductor designers, like Arm, have been pushing for the Armv8-R processor architecture with specific features to cover the automotive industry’s needs. To address these demands, Arm introduced a dual-stage Memory Protection Unit (MPU) that supports hierarchical memory isolation and enables hypervisor deployment, enhancing its suitability for mixed-criticality real-time environments. In this context, the hypervisor emerges as a solution for consolidating different subsystems onto the same hardware platform, allowing the system to meet SWaP-C (Size, Weight, and Power-Cost) requirements. However, most hypervisor implementations are not designed to run on MMU-less devices. This paper describes the journey of re-designing Bao, an open-source lightweight Static Partitioning Hypervisor (SPH), to the new generation of real-time Arm processors. The core contribution focuses on leveraging the dual-stage MPU and the Armv8-R virtualization extensions to establish a predictable virtualization infrastructure. We evaluated the hypervisor’s performance on a multi-core platform based on the NXP S32Z270 SoC. Bao MMU-less demonstrated high efficiency, with less than 1% performance degradation and only a negligible increase in memory footprint. Additionally, the system exhibited a short boot time of 2.95ms, satisfying a key requirement for real-time systems.

title: Ransomware Detection using Dynamic Behavior Monitoring based on Entropy Analysis and Frequency Analysis
authors: Ritesh, Arun Rathor, R.Chinnaiyan, Ragavendra T S, G.Sabarmathi, Vimal Kumar Khanna
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Cybersecurity faces mounting challenges due to the proliferation of ransomware, a sophisticated form of malware that encrypts user data, rendering it inaccessible unless a ransom is paid. Traditional detection systems often fail to counteract evolving threats effectively, creating an urgent need for innovative approaches. Introducing a novel hybrid framework for ransomware detection within IoT ecosystems, integrating entropy and frequency analysis with machine learning models, including Decision Trees (DT) and Random Forests (RF). Data augmentation techniques were employed to generate synthetic data, bolstering the models’ ability to generalize across diverse scenarios. Experimental results demonstrated superior performance of the DT classifier, achieving an accuracy of 98.89% and an F1-score of 98.81%. The proposed framework is optimized for real-time ransomware detection, leveraging dynamic analysis to monitor live system behaviors. This integration ensures a proactive defense mechanism against emerging ransomware variants. Future research directions include expanding real-time capabilities, enhancing cross-layer detection, and for collaborative threat intelligence. This work represents a significant advancement in ransomware detection methodologies, offering robust, adaptive, and scalable solutions to mitigate one of cybersecurity’s most pressing threats.

title: Intelligent Legal Documentation: Leveraging AI for Precision and Productivity
authors: Srabana Pramanik, Sahana Reddy R, Deepika R
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Legal documents tend to be complicated, costly, and time-consuming, posing difficulties for small enterprises and non-lawyers. This paper introduces an AI-powered Legal Documentation Assistant that simplifies legal processes through Artificial Intelligence (AI), Natural Language Processing (NLP), and Optical Character Recognition (OCR). The system allows users to generate, comprehend, and personalize legal documents, minimizing the need for legal professionals while maintaining compliance. Automation powered by AI facilitates legal jargon, opening legal procedures to greater accessibility. The article emphasizes advancements in legal automation through AI with examples from Colombia, Finland, and the UK, where AI enhanced contract examination, case handling, and legal investigations. With digitalization of legal documents and utilization of legal text analysis, the system ensures greater efficiency and accuracy in generating documents. Testing reveals that the assistant effectively generates legally binding documents, including contracts and agreements, enhancing ease of use for non-specialists. However, there are issues with periodic misinterpretation of intricate legal terminology, dependence on user input quality, and jurisdictional restrictions. Future development will address increased legal templates, improved AI legal understanding, multilingual support, and optional legal review. Automated compliance checks and real-time advice will further improve accuracy. In spite of its shortcomings, the AI-based assistant represents a major milestone towards legal democratization, cost reduction, and simplification of documentation. Subsequent developments, such as blockchain document authentication and AI-facilitated conflict resolution, will further enhance efficiency, accessibility, and authenticity. Through ongoing innovation, AI-based legal solutions can potentially revolutionize the way people and companies deal with legal intricacies.

title: Robotic Arm Teleoperation Through Recognition of Body Movements
authors: Marcos Barbosa Schettino, Aline Gabriela Loiola Almeida, André Luis Marques Marcato, Vinícius Barbosa Schettino
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: The teleoperation of robotic arms traditionally relies on specialized devices, such as wearable sensors or depth cameras, which increase costs and limit applicability in resource-constrained environments. This paper proposes an alternative approach to robotic arm teleoperation using a single two-dimensional RGB camera to recognize hand gestures and estimate body poses. Using the MediaPipe framework, keypoints are extracted in real time, enabling both the recognition of manual gestures for trajectory planning and execution, and the mapping of arm extension to determine movement directions and amplitudes. To validate the approach, the Panda robotic arm was simulated in the Gazebo environment. The operator interacts with the system through an intuitive interface, defining target poses and-based on real-time gesture detection-sending commands to the robot. Results show that execution times are comparable to those achieved with joystick-based teleoperation, demonstrating the feasibility and efficiency of the proposed method. This study contributes to the advancement of robotics by presenting an accessible and effective solution for robotic system teleoperation.

title: Therapeutic Chatbot for Suicidal Risk Teens Using Large Language Models
authors: Josef Romero-Florida, Alejandro Nolasco-Morales, Alvaro Aures-Garcia, Martin Bravo-Obando, Adelaida Balvín-Landeo
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Suicide poses a significant public health risk that disproportionately affects young people between the ages of 15 and 34. For this reason, this research proposes the development of an autonomous chatbot based on Large Language Models (LLMs) as a tool to detect and prevent suicidal thoughts in adolescents, in collaboration with the Peruvian Center for Suicidology and Suicide Prevention (SENTIDO). In addition, the chatbot integrates new advanced natural language processing technologies with cognitive-behavioral therapy to provide 80% emotional support in a personalized and accessible way 24 hours a day.

title: Revolutionizing Recycling: Blockchain and Green Credit Empowerment for a Sustainable Future
authors: Aniketh Patil, Shankaramma, Sidrah Saif, Chaithanya R, Harshitha Pradeep
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The rapid depletion of natural resources has only hastened the necessity to adopt sustainable practices on an industry-wide scale. Of these, recycling stands out as a key but not fully utilized step towards environmental protection and long-term sustainability. Its adoption in India is still limited by infrastructure shortages, lack of public awareness, and lack of incentives. Despite widespread campaigns for waste recycling and segregation, participation, particularly at the industrial and family levels, is erratic and low. This article introduces "Revolutionizing Recycling," a people-driven initiative to bridge these gaps with a blend of behavioral economics, real-world rewards, and digital technology. Drawing on the extended Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB), in which the interplay between attitude, social norms, and perceived control is emphasized, we build a model that utilizes localized engagement, economic rewards, and tech-facilitated openness to transform recycling behavior at scale. At the core of the system is a blockchain-based platform connecting vintage kabadiwalas (informal scrap vendors) with households and businesses in a digitally coordinated waste picking network. The consolidation guarantees each recyclable’s trajectory tracked and incentivized by smart contracts and eco-points—finally exchangeable as government-issued green credits under India’s Green Credit Programme. By integrating trust, traceability, and material rewards, this approach not only incentivizes participation but also encourages green innovation and helps make a positive contribution to protecting the environment. Most importantly, it provides a basis for replicable, technology-enabled circular economy systems that accrue benefits for all—informal waste pickers as much as policymakers.

title: Enabling Face Tracking in an Affordable Social Robot Using a Computer Vision Camera
authors: María Gaitán-Padilla, Elizabeth Sánchez R., Dionatas Brito, Maria José Pontes, Ricardo Mello, Carlos A. Cifuentes, Camilo A. R. Diaz
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Social robotics has been explored as a tool to support social interactions in various applications of human well-being. In therapies of children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) social robots have been included as motivational tools to perform activities within the therapeutic session. This work presents a contribution to the natural behaviours of the CASTOR robot, an open-source robot for assisted therapies of children with ASD. The project proposal involves using a camera with computer vision and implementing face recognition to improve the movements of the robot's neck and eyes. The tests were carried out in two phases; first, validating the functioning of the eye-contact tracking; and then, on the neck movement. The resulting improvements provided more natural and engaging gaze behaviour, where the responsiveness of the system obtained an accuracy of 96.11 % in the eyes and an RMSE of 3.62° of the tracking angle for the neck. Future work will evaluate user perception of the natural gaze system in a social interaction activity using standardized questionnaires.

title: Semantic Segmentation Network for Warehouse Indoor Environments from 3D LiDAR Point Clouds
authors: Gabriel do Pinho Martins, Kristofer Stift Kappel, Vinicius Leite de Garcia, Felipe Gomes de Oliveira, Nelson Duarte Filho, Paulo Lilles Jorge Drews
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Robust perception is paramount for autonomous systems that operate in real public environments. LiDAR sensors are known for their robustness, making them ideal for autonomous robots, which enable obstacle detection, reliability in adverse lighting conditions, and overall safety assurance. Most 3D LiDAR semantic segmentation networks are fine-tuned for outdoor and urban environments, overlooking other equally important scenes, such as industrial scenarios. In this work, we contribute to an open-source Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) pipeline for semantic segmentation of 3D LiDAR point clouds of indoor warehouse environments. Additionally, we introduce a dataset of simulated industrial point clouds for 3D semantic segmentation called WareSet. We evaluate the quality and viability of our network using well-defined quality metrics, including accuracy, Intersection over Union (IoU) per class, and mean Intersection over Union (mIoU), for both training and validation sets. The experiments were conducted in an unfamiliar warehouse environment, taking into account the proposed dataset and the specified quality metrics. The proposed approach yields satisfactory results of 98.49% and 90.59% for accuracy, and 90.64% and 49.49% for mIoU in training and validation, respectively, with good model convergence. Additionally, it achieves 89.7% accuracy and 50.4% mIoU on the unknown warehouse, emphasizing its generalization capability. The proposed dataset is open-sourced at https://github.com/DeskFanzin/WareSet.

title: Image Steganography Using Quantum Techonology
authors: Manikanta Prasad J, A N Karan Jith, Mohammed Aism Farahan, Diwakar N, Rathan M E, Anser Pasha C A
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Steganography based on the traditional methods, such as least significant bit (LSB) encoding, faces serious challenges including very poor security habits, reduced data capacity, and vulnerability to attacks. This paper, in particular, presents an innovative method inspired by quantum-like principles of randomness and superposition for image steganography that allows for higher levels of security. The development of user-end web applications based on the Flask framework allows the embedding of secret messages within an image using a form of a quantum-like transformation. Randomized manipulation of bits using Pillow, a library for Python programming, basically makes changes to the pixel highly unpredictable. To this end, the hidden data become increasingly resistant to detection and extraction. Thus, with regard to modern-day steganalysis techniques, the approach developed here will ensure secure and robust image steganography capable of handling confidential data transmission.

title: Federated learning Architecture towards Multimodal fake news detection in social media networks
authors: S. A. Abdul Kadhar, S. Brintha Rajakumari, Silvia Priscilla
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: On continuous development of the advanced technologies like artificial intelligences, synthesis video and imaging application is getting popular across the entertainment and education industries to increase visualizing capabilities of the various aspects on different age category of peoples. Especially GenAI popularization has increased the propagation of the synthesis image and video in the social network. Despite of the various advantages of those technologies, it leads to several challenges with respect to the fake videos and images propagation in the social media towards dissemination of the false information to carry out digital harassment. In order to mitigate those challenges, many traditional approaches have been carried out using machine and learning architectures to detect and mitigate the fake images or videos. However those architectures produces better detection accuracy but generalization ability of those models were still lagging in this performance due to increased volume of data streaming in the social media applications. Thus, it becomes mandatory to design a new centralized solution to social network concerns using federated learning model. Federated learning approach uses the deep learning architecture for detection and mitigation of the deep fake content in the social networks. Federated learning acts as decentralized approach which includes multiple users to train the model with hyper parameters. Federated model uses convolution layers of the convolution neural network for feature extractions and canonical correlation analysis for feature aggregation and fully connected layer for feature classification. Initially model training is performed with set of data preprocessing approaches composed of Gaussian filter and augmentation functions. Those preprocessed content is projected to convolution layer for feature extraction. Next, feature vector from each convolution layer is projected to pooling layer composed of canonical correlation analysis for feature aggregation. Finally those aggregated feature is projected in fully connected layer composed of the activation function, softmax function, and loss function. Activation function normalizes the aggregated feature vector and softmax function uses support vector machine classifier to classify the feature into real and fake images. Especially loss function of the model eliminates the over fitting and under fitting issues of the model. Furthermore model regularization is carried out in the federated learning effectively to increase the accuracy of the model. Experimental and performance analysis of the federated learning model is performed using DFDC dataset on python environment. In this analysis, test data is processed using confusion matrix to obtain the performance parameter value to identify model accuracy and efficiency. On evaluation, it is proved that federated learning architectures produces better results compared to state of art approaches identifying the manipulated content in the image or video efficiently.

title: A Multifaceted Approach to Reducing Automotive Air Conditioning Energy Consumption
authors: T V Manohar, Mohammed Mujeerulla
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The automotive industry faces a significant challenge in balancing passenger comfort with fuel efficiency. Automotive air conditioning (AC) systems, while crucial for driver and passenger well-being, are substantial energy consumers, significantly impacting fuel economy and increasing greenhouse gas emissions [1], [2]. This effect is particularly pronounced in urban driving conditions, where frequent stops and starts necessitate more frequent AC operation [3]. The energy consumed by AC systems represents a considerable portion of a vehicle's overall energy budget, especially in hotter climates and during peak usage periods. This necessitates the development of innovative strategies to minimize AC energy consumption without compromising passenger comfort. This study proposes a comprehensive framework that integrates adaptive sampling, machine learning, edge computing, and energy harvesting technologies to create a more energy-efficient automotive AC system. This integrated approach aims to dynamically optimize AC operation based on real-time conditions and predictive models, thereby minimizing energy waste. The framework's effectiveness will be evaluated through a simulation-based analysis across various vehicle classes (low-end, mid-range, luxury, and electric vehicles) under diverse driving conditions over a 24-hour period. The results will demonstrate the potential for substantial energy savings through the synergistic application of these technologies.

title: Robotics in Schools as a Way of Promoting Science and Engineering
authors: Aline Gabriela Loiola Almeida, William Alves e Coimbra, Dércio Manique Sanches Dos Santos, Luiz Felipe Lacerda Pimentel, Lindolpho Oliveira de Araujo Junior
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Maker culture and educational robotics are approaches that foster experimentation, creativity, and logical reasoning. However, a decline in young people's interest in scientific and engineering careers has been observed in Brazil. To reverse this trend, the ROBESC (Robótica Escolar) project proposes an innovative approach by integrating maker culture into robotics education in public schools and vulnerable communities. The methodology comprises two-day workshops introducing robotics concepts, the assembly and programming of LEGO®MINDSTORMS®NXT robots for a sumo competition, all guided by engineering students. Results-based on pre- and post-workshop surveys administered in three schools-indicate that most participants, who initially had no prior knowledge of the subject, reported being moderately capable of applying robotics concepts. Through the project, students developed different robot architectures and programming strategies, enhancing logical reasoning, programming fundamentals, and teamwork. It is concluded that ROBESC proves to be an effective tool for disseminating science and engineering, stimulating student interest, and strengthening both hard and soft skills, thereby forging a vital link between higher education and basic education.

title: Identification of Plant Leaf Diseases using RNN and Transfer Learning Approach
authors: S. Kalaiselvi, N. Sneha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Plant diseases endanger the lives of farmers and the supply of vital food resources for the world's expanding population, posing a major danger to food security and agricultural output worldwide. Early and precise identification of illnesses in crops is important when prompt action can help limit the spread of infections and reduce losses in crop production. Essential for reducing their harmful impact on agricultural output. This study suggests a novel method for efficiently identifying and categorising a variety of plant leaf diseases by combining transfer-learning techniques with recurrent neural networks. The novel approach described in this study seeks to offer a reliable, flexible, and all-inclusive solution for the timely detection and accurate classification of different plant diseases. The suggested technology aims to greatly improve sustainable farming practices by effectively detecting and diagnosing plant leaf diseases early on and the guarantee of global food security by utilising the potent feature extraction and sequence modelling capabilities of Recurrent Neural Networks in conjunction with the rich visual representations and learnt knowledge gained from pre-trained Convolutional Neural Network models.

title: Analysis of Ablated Accuracy on Features in Carnatic Music Raga Classification with improved Jaccard Similarity Index
authors: Swati Sharma, Bhanurekha K, Prafulla Kumari K S, Syed Abrar Ahmed, Ashwini B, Annapurna H S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The soul and essence of Indian Classical music may it be Carnatic music or Hindustani Classical Music are ragas. It is a melodic framework that structures the music and compositions. They are nothing less than the grammar of the Indian Classical Music. There is a multitude of ragas, all derived from the same set of seven notes but with different progressions. There has been a lot of traction in machine learning for classifying these ragas and generating a digital framework for their identification, recognition, classification and recommendation. In this paper, we have implemented a Fully Connected Neural Network to classify the Carnatic music 32 ragas. The work is extrapolated to find the ablated accuracies of the features, which can be used to determine dimensionality reduction candidature. The validation accuracy achieved in this work is 94 % which is an improvement of 14 % with reduced computational power and faster convergence, so it outperforms the work presented in the literature review. Also, the Jaccard Similarity index is calculated in this paper for identifying similarity between carnatic ragas for better understanding of parent and child ragas.

title: Mulberry Leaf Disease Detection using a Simple Convolutional Neural Network model
authors: Chaitra D B, Mohan G Kabadi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Moriculture plays a crucial role in procuring high quality silk from the silkworms. Mulberry plants are the primary source of food for the silkworms. Mulberry plants are usually prone to various diseases, thus making them unsuitable to feed the silkworms. The existing solutions to detect mulberry leaf diseases are just a handful and there is a huge gap between these solutions and the state-of-the-art technologies. In this research work, a simple Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model, to classify mulberry leaf diseases, implemented with two different datasets, with and without explicit preprocessing is presented. The results show that our CNN model is capable of classifying the input image with an accuracy of 85%. In this domain, there is a huge scope for developing innovative state-of-the-art models to classify other unexplored diseases of mulberry plants. Also, contribution could be done in the field of mulberry dataset creation.

title: Programming Challenges and Perceptions: A Study of Separate Groups Before and After the Release of ChatGPT
authors: Mireilla Bikanga Ada
abstract: Learning to program a new language presents persistent challenges, such as debugging, program design, and understanding advanced programming concepts, all of which contribute to high dropout rates and learning difficulties. Meanwhile, the emergence of Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT introduces new dimensions in programming education, offering personalised and interactive learning experiences that could mitigate traditional learning challenges. This study investigates students’ perceptions of programming learning difficulties before and a year after the release of ChatGPT. Through self-reported surveys, the study examines differences in perceived difficulties, evaluates the role of learning materials, including ChatGPT, and explores correlations between students’ perceptions of fairness, trust, and effectiveness of ChatGPT and their programming learning difficulties. Findings confirm that even in the era of ChatGPT, the challenges associated with learning programming are complex and continue to be deeply linked to understanding programming concepts, learning situations, and learning materials. There was no gender difference in programming learning difficulties, while students concerned about plagiarism from ChatGPT reported more programming learning difficulties. Students who trust ChatGPT report higher perceived effectiveness of its use in learning. These findings highlight the potential of ChatGPT to complement traditional learning resources while emphasising the importance of foundational skills and ethical guidelines. Educators and policymakers must consider these findings to develop programming curricula that leverage technological advancements and address the persistent challenges that hinder student programming learning.

title: Roll Angle Estimation for Spinning Projectile Based on Phase Lock Loop with Geomagnetic Sensor and Gyroscope
authors: Wei Wei, Hao Cheng, Hua Wang, Qingli Shi
abstract: Estimation of roll angle is necessary for precision-guided munitions.Geomagnetic sensors are widely used in roll angle estimation of spinning projectiles, but their accuracy can be compromised by interference from onboard electromagnetic devices. Therefore, a roll angle estimation for spinning projectile based on phase lock loop with geomagnetic sensor and gyroscope has been proposed. The roll angle data obtained by the gyroscope data in a slide time window(with width≥100) is used to generate cosine and sine sequences, which are respectively correlation integrated with the magnetic sensor data sequences within the same time window. The two integration results are subjected to four-quadrant arc tangent operation to obtain the phase difference between the gyroscope and the geomagnetic sensor, and then the roll angle of the projectile is obtained by Kalman filtering. In order to verify the roll angle estimation method, a semi-physical experiment was carried out, and the experimental results show that expectation of roll angle error of RAEPLL is 0.139 degree and the standard deviation is 0.512 degree while the two error characteristics of ESKF are 0.268 deg and 0.689 deg, indicatingthe method proposed in this paper can get higher roll angle estimation accuracy only using single-axis geomagnetic sensors and gyroscope comparing with the existing roll angle estimation algorithms.

title: Semidirect Drive Based on Tri-Contacted Plate Harmonic Reducer
authors: Seungbin You, Eunho Sung, Dongjun Kim, Juhyun Kim, Jaeheung Park
abstract: Robotic actuators face a performance gap between low-ratio quasi-direct drive (QDD) systems and conventional harmonic drives, which are typically limited to ratios above 30:1. This article presents a tri-contacted plate harmonic reducer (Tri-c PHR) that addresses this challenge by combining axial elastic deformation with a three-point tooth engagement system. The proposed design achieves a 16:1 reduction ratio—a range where conventional harmonic gears face significant design challenges—while maintaining high efficiency and low backlash. An initial prototype validates the design’s feasibility, demonstrating competitive positioning accuracy and backdrivability comparable to commercial harmonic reducers, despite operating at a significantly lower reduction ratio. The Tri-c PHR offers a compelling solution for applications requiring both torque transparency and moderate reduction ratios.

title: Unlocking Transmission Flexibility under Uncertainty: Getting Dynamic Line Ratings into Electricity Markets
authors: Zhiyi Zhou, Christoph Graf, Yury Dvorkin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Energy Markets, Policy and Regulation
abstract: Static transmission line ratings may lead to underutilization of line capacity due to overly conservative assumptions. Grid-enhancing technologies (GETs) such as dynamic line ratings (DLRs), which adjust line capacity based on real-time conditions, are a techno-economically viable alternative to increase the utilization of existing power lines. Nonetheless, their adoption has been slow, partly due to the absence of operational tools that effectively account for simultaneous impacts on dispatch and pricing. In this paper, we represent transmission capacity with DLRs as a stock-like resource with time-variant interdependency, which is modeled via an approximation of line temperature evolution process, decoupling the impacts of ambient weather conditions and power flow on transmission line temperature and thus capacity. We integrate DLRs into a multi-period DC optimal power flow problem, with chance constrains addressing correlated uncertainty in DLRs and renewable generation. This yields non-convex problems that we transform into a tractable convex form by linearization. We derive locational marginal energy and ancillary services prices consistent with a competitive equilibrium. Numerical experiments on the 11-zone and 1814-node NYISO systems demonstrate its performance, including impacts on dispatch, pricing, and marginal carbon emissions.

authors: Zhaowang Ma, Yiming Cai, Yicheng Zhou, Zejun Li, Junping Guo, Lingyu Liu, Xudong Jin, Yang Bu, Xing Ding, Qing Ye, Peng Zhang, Haiwen Cai
abstract: An isolation apparatus for far-infrared wavelengths was developed and integrated into a CO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> nanosecond laser system for performance evaluation. The apparatus uses a dual acousto-optic modulator (AOM) configuration combined with an image-relaying delay line to achieve high isolation of back-reflected light. This design is based on the Bragg diffraction mechanism of the AOMs to achieve a high isolation for back-reflected radiation along the primary optical path. The delay line's extended propagation distance and image-relaying properties effectively compensate for the slow switching speeds of the AOMs. Experimental investigation within the CO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> nanosecond laser system demonstrates an isolation of 31.82 dB for back-reflected light, with output beam quality factors of MX<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 1.070 and MY<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 1.017, an overall transmittance of 35.73%, and a power-handling capability exceeding 130.60 W.

title: Linearization Improvement of Space Traveling-Wave Tube Amplifiers Based on Automatic Matching System
authors: Weibo Huang, Wenkai Deng, Yujin Zhang, Yukai Zhou, Tao Huang, Yan Fang, Bin He
abstract: Analog predistortion (APD) represents a highly effective technique that can be employed to enhance the linearity of the traveling-wave tube amplifiers (TWTAs). This method has been recognized for its potential in rectifying the nonlinearities inherent to the TWTA, thereby optimizing its performance in various applications. This article proposes a nonlinear automatic matching system for TWTAs through the design of dedicated hardware and software. The system is designed to achieve the automatic tuning of traveling-wave tubes (TWTs) and linearizers at different temperatures, thereby improving the tuning efficiency of devices and the consistency of their performance. Furthermore, two Ka-band space TWTAs are linearized by the system, and the measurement results demonstrate that the linearity of the two TWTAs is enhanced. In addition, the voltages have good consistency, which also provides support for the development of dual-tube products.
