title: An integrated framework for Estimating the all-sky surface downward longwave radiation from FY-3D/MERSI-II imagery
authors: Qi Zeng, Wanchun Zhang, Jie Cheng
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: This study develops an integrated framework for all-sky surface longwave downward radiation (SLDR) estimate for the MERSI-II imager onboard the Fengyun-3D (FY-3D) satellite. The framework comprises a hybrid method for the clear-sky SLDR estimate and a cloud base temperature (CBT)-based single-layer cloud model (SLCM) for the cloudy-sky SLDR estimate. In-situ validation indicates that the hybrid method yields a bias/RMSE of -0.78/21.70 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, whereas the SLCM achieves a bias/RMSE of 5.79/23.61 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. The bias/RMSE of the all-sky SLDR is 3.37/22.93 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. The estimated all-sky instantaneous SLDR was combined with ERA5 temporal information to derive daily SLDR using a bias-corrected sinusoidal integration method, yielding a bias of 0.04 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and an RMSE of 16.77 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. These results demonstrate the robustness of the proposed framework and its substantial potential in generating both instantaneous and daily SLDR products at 1 km spatial resolution.

title: Deep Learning Framework for Classifying Whole-Slide Multiplex Immunofluorescence Images to Predict Immunotherapy Response in Melanoma Patients
authors: Priyanka Rana, Tuba N Gide, Nurudeen A Adegoke, Yizhe Mao, Shlomo Berkovsky, Enrico Coiera, James S Wilmott, Sidong Liu
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Immunotherapy has emerged as a prominent approach in melanoma treatment, however a substantial number of patients do not respond effectively. This highlights the critical need to accurately predict immunotherapy responses for designing personalised treatment strategies. Current practices rely predominantly on clinical data and the expertise of oncologists; however, a deeper understanding of molecular interactions through tissue-based biomarkers offers a promising avenue for advancement. Whole-slide multiplex immunofluorescence (mIF) images enable detailed analysis of cells/tissues in their microenvironment, deepening insights into disease mechanisms. However, numerous channels, an extensive image size, and spatially dispersed information of mIF images pose analytical challenges, requiring advanced techniques to effectively learn these intricate features for optimal performance. In this study, we introduce a novel deep-learning framework, Channel Optimisation with Multi-Instance Learning (COMIL), specifically designed to classify whole-slide mIF images for predicting immunotherapy response in melanoma patients. The study demonstrates that a feature extraction method that models inter-channel relationships and captures complex interdependencies among multiple channels of mIF images enhances classification performance. Additionally, incorporating this method within an MIL framework, optimised at both the slide and instance levels, further improves the classification performance of whole-slide mIF images. We evaluated COMIL on mIF images from the Melanoma Institute Australia, where it outperformed baseline methods with substantial improvements on both the internal (AUC increase by 28%) and external test sets (AUC increase by 20%), underscoring its potential for predicting immunotherapy response.

title: Introducing TrackEDT: A Tool to Accelerate Empirical Editing Research
authors: Jordan Smith, Matthew J. Baker, Lauryn Wilde, Scout McMillan
abstract: Introduction: The technical editing discipline stands in need of additional empirical research—particularly language-level research. However, the time- and resource-intensive nature of data collection and analysis may prevent some scholars from completing the needed research. Therefore, this tutorial introduces TrackEDT, a tool we have developed to ease the process of collecting and analyzing edits and comments from edited documents. Key concepts: TrackEDT extracts editors’ tracked insertions, deletions, moves, and comments from Microsoft (MS) Word documents—all elements of traditional editorial markup. It outputs the extracted data into an MS Excel format that affords easier analysis of the editors’ data than would be possible in the data’s original MS Word format. Key lessons: Researchers can download TrackEDT as an executable file at editingresearch.byu.edu/trackedt. To run the file, they select a folder containing edited MS Word documents that have tracked changes and comments. After TrackEDT processes the documents, the researchers can analyze the extracted tracked changes, comments, and metadata in the resulting Excel reports, which include information such as who made the edit, what type of edit was made, when the edit was made, how long the edit was, and what comments were appended. Implications for practice: Technical editing researchers can use TrackEDT and its reports to ease their collection and analysis of editing data, thereby answering important empirical research questions related to language-level editorial changes and processes.

title: TEENet: An Effective Clinical Detection Network for Identifying Spontaneous Echo Contrast Automatically
authors: Zhiwen Wu, Fei Gu, Jing Wu, Shikun Sun, Changsheng Ma
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Spontaneous Echo Contrast (SEC) is a swirling smoke-like echo phenomenon in Transesophageal Echocardiography (TEE) videos caused by slow blood flow and hypercoagulable states. It is a significant indicator for assessing thromboembolic risk. However, current SEC identification requires extensive manual intervention, leading to low accuracy, high costs, and subjectivity. To address these issues, we propose TEENet, an effective clinical detection network for identifying SEC in TEE videos. Specifically, TEENet first generates attention maps for the input clips to highlight important regions and integrates Convolutional Neural Network with the Multi-Head Self-Attention to capture spatiotemporal representations. Furthermore, to enhance the classification performance across different SEC severity grades, we introduce an auxiliary classification module, which simultaneously utilizes the main classification head and auxiliary classification heads. Notably, we constructed a comprehensive dataset of 1106 TEE videos collected during clinical examinations performed at the First Affiliated Hospital of Soochow University from 2018 to 2023, providing a solid foundation for the development and validation of TEENet. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that our proposed network achieves the highest SEC identification accuracy of 92.4<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>1.3% compared to other spatiotemporal representation networks such as SlowFastR50 (89.6<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>0.7%) and TimeSformer (74.9<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>1.8%), which shows strong potential for effective auxiliary diagnosis in clinical practice.

title: Active RIS Assisted Near-Field Integrated Sensing and Wireless Power Transfer
authors: Zhengyu Zhu, Changzhi Wang, Zheng Chu, Zheng Li, De Mi, Zhenke Ding, Inkyu Lee
abstract: This paper investigates a near-field integrated sensing and wireless power transfer (ISWPT) system, in which the transmitter with a large antenna array and an active reconfigurable intelligent surface (ARIS) join forces. Focusing on near-field transmission, we propose a joint optimization framework for ISWPT energy harvesting and sensing, which incorporates practical constraints including ARIS phase shifts, maximum amplification power budget, and per-antenna transmit power. To address the formulated non-convex problem, we propose an alternating optimization (AO) algorithm which employs successive convex approximation (SCA) to solve the decomposed subproblems. The simulation results demonstrate distinct advantages over benchmarks achieved by combining ARIS and the ISWPT system.

title: Natural Language- Based Assisted Navigation in a Smart Walker
authors: Gabriel Rodrigues de Castro, Elio David Triana Rodríguez, Fabiana Santos Vieira Machado, Anselmo Frizera Neto, Ricardo Carminati de Mello
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Mobility is a determining factor for maintaining quality of life of individuals, especially in a world where the overall population is continuously aging. In this regard, smart walkers (i.e., traditional walkers augmented with sensors and intelligent systems) emerge as a promising solution for gait monitoring and locomotion assistance. Human-robot interaction is a fundamental area in smart walker development and, with the rise of Large Language Models (LLMs), there is an opportunity to enable more natural and adaptive channels of communication for context-aware interaction. In this work, we propose an intelligent system for assisted navigation in smart walkers that integrates an LLM-based multi-agent with ROS 2 to dynamically set interaction modes. The system has three stages: command detection, operating mode definition, and secondary mode selection. To validate the proposed solution, two datasets were created: one with textual commands and another with voice commands transcribed using Whisper. The results demonstrate promising performance, with accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score values above 86 percent in all stages for both scenarios. The observed results pave the way for practical implementations on the robot itself and for validation on realistic scenarios.

title: Thermal Performance Optimization and Heat Dissipation Enhancement of Solar Photovoltaic Modules Using ANSYS CFD Analysis
authors: Jose Anthony Chamba Agurto, Jimmy David Yarleque Villegas, Bryant Rodolfo Valladolid Anton, Wisthon Javier Inga Periche, Nelson Omar Yangua Pinday, Daniel Marcelo Aldana
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: This study aims to enhance the performance and lifespan of solar photovoltaic (PV) modules by utilizing alternative materials and heat dissipation strategies under idealized steady-state conditions. The investigation focuses on silicon and CIGS PV cells, considering parameters such as solar irradiance, tilt angle, and ambient temperature. A numerical model based on Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) was developed, incorporating aluminum fins as thermal dissipation systems, to evaluate module performance. The CFD model was validated using analytical data to verify both the performance and temperatures achieved by the PV modules. The results show significant improvements in heat dissipation, increased module operational efficiency, and reduced average temperatures with the use of fins. These findings are crucial for the ongoing development of more efficient and sustainable solar technologies, offering insights into the potential of alternative materials for enhancing PV module performance.

title: Improving the End to End Purchasing Process in Indirect Procurement
authors: Rama Reddy, Ravi Ilkal, Snehal Soni
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Purchase orders are an essential component of procurement processes, serving as a record between buyers and sellers. Analyzing historical purchase order data can provide insights into procurement patterns and can help in optimization.

title: Atrous-CNN with Hierarchical-Based Training Strategy Approach for Decentralized Tasks
authors: Antoni Jaszcz, Agnieszka Polowczyk, Alicja Polowczyk, Katarzyna Wiltos, Dawid Połap, Marcin Woźniak
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Decentralized tasks use machine learning models with certain assumptions. The first is the sharing of weights and feature extractors. The second is maintaining the privacy of the data. The idea of learning using multiple models can also be applied in parallel training, where a given model is trained on a different thread. This has applications in creating models based on federated learning, the Internet of Things and Digital Twins. This paper proposes a new neural network model that uses the atrous technique and attention modules. In addition, we propose a hierarchical-based training strategy, where the best model shares weights and is omitted during further training. This reduces the number of training epochs and increases the model's adaptability to a given set. The tests conducted on a publicly available medical database indicate high learning potential for both the proposed model and the hierarchical learning strategy.

title: Cleaning the Oceans: A Pedagogical Practice of Environmental Awareness with Robotics in Early Childhood Education
authors: Vitor Carvalho Silva, Lucas Emanoel Ribeiro Santana, Raul Silva Tavares, Claudia Juliette do N. Araujo Maia, Waleska R. de L. Teixeira, Cristiane de Melo Ferreira, Leonardo R. de L. Teixeira, Luciane Terra dos Santos Garcia, Luiz Marcos Garcia Gonçalves
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: This article analyzes a pedagogical experience carried out with 3- and 4-year-old children from Early Childhood Education, through a pedagogical practice that addresses ocean cleanup, within the scope of the MandacaruBot extension project (EAJ/UFRN). The proposal integrates scientific, environmental, and technological knowledge with the use of sustainable Educational Robotics and unplugged robotics, seeking to promote scientific literacy and computational thinking in a playful and accessible way. The activities involved the construction of artifacts, interactive game, and group discussions, according to the guidelines of the Common National Curriculum Base (BNCC) and the Computing BNCC. In practice, hydraulic arms developed with syringes, gamification, computational thinking, and unplugged robotics were used. The results demonstrated the development of motor, cognitive, and socioemotional skills in children, in addition to engagement with issues of sustainability and citizenship.

title: Machine Learning-Based Item Recommendation for Flipkart Using SVD Technique
authors: Aswathy K Cherian, TejSrikar Reddy Ramachandra, Ishandev Upparwar, Kumar Sambhav
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: This paper introduces a machine learning-driven recommendation system tailored for Flipkart, India’s leading e-commerce platform, utilizing Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) within a collaborative filtering framework. Recommendation systems play a pivotal role in e-commerce, guiding users through vast product catalogs by predicting preferences to enhance their shopping experience. Using a simulated dataset mirroring Flipkart’s ecosystem, we preprocess user ratings, apply SVD to address data sparsity and predict unrated items, and evaluate performance with Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). Our model achieves an RMSE of 0.062, demonstrating robust predictive accuracy. A comparison with a popularity-based baseline underscores SVD’s strength in personalization. Drawing on Flipkart Commerce Cloud’s insights, this work proposes a scalable framework, offering practical implications and a roadmap for future enhancements.

title: Integration of Intelligent Fuzzy Controller and Sensor Module for Environmental Management in Solar Greenhouses
authors: K. Padmapriya, K. Kavitha, R. Senthamil Selvan, Basi Reddy.A, Manisha Bhimrao Mane
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Solar greenhouses may maximise crop productivity and ensure sustainable farming operations by maintaining ideal environmental conditions. This work combines an intelligent fuzzy logic control system with a sensor module to achieve balanced environmental management in solar greenhouses. Several ecological sensors, including those for humidity, temperature, and light intensity, are integrated into the proposed system to provide real-time data to a controller with fuzzy logic that controls actuators, including irrigation systems, fans, and vents. By processing inaccurate inputs, the fuzzy controller can provide adaptive & resilient control, beyond the shortcomings of conventional PID & manual control approaches. From what we can see from the experiments, there are major benefits in terms of minimising temperature and humidity variations by as much as 20% and improving energy efficiency generally. Solar greenhouses may benefit greatly from this integrated approach to environmental management since it is automated, accurate, and efficient.

title: Enhancing the Security of the Internet of Things by the Application of Robust Cryptographic Algorithms
authors: M. V. Sruthi, Gajula Lakshminarayana, Kondragunta Rama Krishnaiah, Ch. Bhagyalaxmi, K. Chithambaraiah Setty, K. Naveen Chakravarthi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) is becoming a crucial part of the Internet and the foundation for millions of intelligent, interlinked things that might subject to many types of assaults. Cryptographic algorithms are employed as a key solution to ensure integrity and privacy of the communicated data across the network. Due to the fast expansion of IoT devices across several applications like smart homes, healthcare sector and other industrial systems, ensuring protection is a significant part while reducing computing overhead. The Lightweight Encryption Algorithm provides an in-depth evaluation in solving security issues highlighting its applicability over Internet of Things. The proposed research on light weight cryptographic algorithm plays a crucial role on addressing major difficulties to ensure data privacy and distribution. The proposed cryptography algorithm proves to be superior in effectiveness and versatility when compared to several other encryption techniques with limited resources. The conventional cryptographic methods utilized by LEA performed weaker in side-channel attack vulnerabilities, key recovery approaches & limited cryptography resistance. To overcome these issues with new LEA's design, the research suggests hardware-oriented techniques such as pipelining & parallel processing, better key scheduling & the integration of S-boxes will enhance non-linearity as an alternative approach. Based on VHDL-based simulations, the research validates these improvements by measuring resource usage, system performance & cryptographic strength using programs like Intel® Quartus® Prime and Model Sim. The results obtained demonstrate that LEA is appropriate for deployment in a range of IoT applications & offers significant benefits in terms of security & operational efficiency.

title: A Graphical User Interface for Modeling and Assessment of Islanded Microgrids Operation
authors: Thais Souza Cruz, Francis Arody Moreno Vásquez
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This work presents an interactive platform for assessment of islanded microgrids with renewable generation. This tool allows to size the sources, the power converters and a battery bank from their mathematical models, and to define isolated loads in such a way to verify the compatibility between them. Also, a energy management logic was constructed to study the response of the microgrid in front of several scenarios, as different power generation levels, connected loads, state of charges (SOC) of battery bank, as well as for switching of generation units and loads. In order to do so, the developed platform needs information about the AC bus voltage, the wind and water speed, the irradiation, the initial state-of-charge of battery, as well as the simulation time to verify if maximum and minimum limits of SOC are reached. The validation of the detailed modeling of microgrid components and the energy management logic through simulations allows to consider this computational tool as an opportunity to facilitate the specification of components, and verify the technical viability of this kind of project. In addition, it can be used as a creative teaching mechanism for electric engineering students to learn about the subject.

title: Enhanced Tomato Plant Disease Detection Using Feature Interaction-Aware Graph Neural Networks and YOLOv7 for Precision Agriculture
authors: Suguna M K, Sheela Kathavate
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The capacity to determine tomato leaves correctly in a field environment is important in order to attain preliminary yield estimation, especially given the increase in the significance of Precision Agriculture. It can be challenging to identify precisely what diseases are inflicting the tomato plants since there is an overlap of symptoms among various diseases. These are the initial signs of disease that we observed in tomato plant leaves. This study looked at seven plant leaf diseases: light blight, leaf mold, early blight, mosaic virus, bacterial spot, Septoria leaf spot, and yellow leaf curl virus. The university greenhouse was utilized to collect tomato plant leaf data in order to create a testbed environment for data acquisition. In order to precisely identify and categorize tomato leaves in the field, this study proposes a target detection model utilizing the enhanced YOLOv7.To enhance the capability of the method's feature extraction, we initially introduce the detection process SimAM and DAiAM into the design structure of the baseline network YOLOv7. To minimize the loss of information when carrying out down sampling, the max-pooling convolution (MPConv) architecture is then enhanced. Then, these points are passed on to anExplicit Feature Interaction-Aware Graph Neural Network (EFIGNN) classifier, which has an accuracy of 98.8% and an error rate of 1.2%. Lastly, we compare our research with existing work in order to demonstrate how valuable the proposed work is and give support to the idea.

title: Dense 3D Reconstruction and 6D Pose Estimation for Robotic Tomato Harvesting using DUSt3R and Gaussian Splatting
authors: Aryan Rajesh, Ruhin Kouser
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The introduction of robotics into agriculture presents significant scope for improving efficiency and coping with labor shortages. High accuracy for complex tasks such as robotic tomato picking, however, requires advanced perception and accurate pose estimation—capabilities that conventional 2D detection methods fundamentally lack. This paper introduces a new pipeline using DUSt3R, a transformer-based method, for dense 3D reconstruction and 6D pose estimation of tomato clusters. Unlike traditional vision systems, our method utilises RGB-D imagery from an Intel RealSense D435i to generate dense point clouds and estimate interview poses, eliminating the need for explicit calibration, thereby making it resilient to calibration drift in dynamic farm conditions. To further enhance surface continuity, especially in fine-grained areas such as stems and calyx, we apply Gaussian Splatting as a refinement step, resulting in cleaner, more complete geometric models. The approach proves robust to real-world challenges such as heavy occlusions, non-uniform lighting, and closely packed tomato arrangements. Experimental evaluations across a wide range of tomato clusters demonstrate a 71 percent reduction in orientation error, a 72 percent drop in position error, and an improvement in cutting success rates from 72 percent to 91 percent compared to a state-of-the-art 2D detection pipeline. These results underscore the value of dense 3D understanding and calibration-free processing for reliable and scalable robotic harvesting in diverse agricultural environments.

title: E-Commerce and Supply Chain Challenges in Latin America: Opportunities and Complexities in the Digital Age
authors: V. Sanchez Padilla, Albert Espinal, John P. Geraghty
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The convergence of e-Commerce and supply chain dynamics presents both opportunities and challenges for businesses in Latin America. By adopting digital technologies, companies can improve logistics, adapt to consumer behavior trends, and strengthen regional trade flows. This paper reviews the current state of e-Commerce in the region, drawing on academic sources and industry reports to examine technology adoption, policy frameworks, and institutional efforts. It also analyzes key barriers to supply chain modernization, including trade finance limitations, infrastructure gaps, and the uneven use of digital tools. Based on these findings, the paper offers practical recommendations for improving connectivity, investing in infrastructure, and developing workforce skills to support sustainable digital transformation in logistics and commerce.

title: Detection of potability of drinking water using machine learning
authors: P Srihith Reddy, Shamitha Gaddam, Jayashree
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Ensuring the safety and quality of drinking water is crucial for public health. This study presents a machine learning-based approach to analyze and classify drinking water samples based on various physicochemical parameters. The dataset undergoes extensive preprocessing, including handling missing values, feature scaling, and train-test splitting, to ensure robust model performance. Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) is conducted to understand feature correlations and visualize data distributions. Five supervised learning models—Random Forest, Logistic Regression, XGBoost, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and Support Vector Machine (SVM)—are implemented to classify water samples as safe or unsafe. Model performance is evaluated using accuracy scores, classification reports, and confusion matrices. The results demonstrate that ensemble-based models, particularly XGBoost and Random Forest, achieve superior classification accuracy, highlighting their potential for real-world water quality assessment. This research underscores the applicability of AI-driven classification techniques in environmental monitoring and public health safety.

title: Comparison of Photovoltaic Power Generation between Monofacial and Bifacial Panels
authors: Juan Lata-García, Wellington Maliza, Garyn Ampuño, Kristy Vera Onofre, Lizbeth Flores-Bastidas, Patricio Reyes Romero
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Currently there is a considered increase in the implementation of renewable energy generation, however about 79 % of the energy consumed in the world comes from fossil fuels according to reports of REN 21 in 2022, innovation and improvement of the components of photovoltaic systems has led to achieve better efficiencies in electricity generation becoming an alternative for systems in remote areas even in systems with grid connection, this research compares the energy performance between a widely used single-facial panel and a bifacial panel, the first produces <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$568.29 \text{kWh} \cdot \text{yr}^{-1}$</tex>, while the second system generates <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$549.07 \text{kWh} \cdot \text{yr}^{-1}$</tex>. Bifacial panels can provide a more economical option for grid-connected systems and depending on the location of the panels, additional to requiring less land area. Taking advantage of the albedo is fundamental to improving the performance of photovoltaic systems when the type of implementation allows it.

title: Efficient Medical Analysis using High Resolution Images with Text and Image GAN
authors: Ayesha Anjum, Spoorthi C K, Sujeet Kumar, Swetha S, Veena
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: One of the promising recent advances in medical imaging is indeed the successful exploration of GANs for applications such as image super-resolution and text enhancement. Most GAN-based approaches, however, have been driven for a single modality: enhancing the quality of images or text clarity-while simultaneously eliciting little attention towards the two interrelated aspects. A new dual GAN framework is therefore proposed to overcome this limitation by combining the merits of both Image Super Resolution GAN and Text Enhancement GAN. In this merged approach, both the resolution of images and the adequacy of the textual annotation improved to enhance diagnostic accuracy as well as improve the visualization of small lesions and tissue structures in medical images. The system works on the principle of cross-domain benefit sharing; enhancement in either quality, the image, or the text, naturally boosts the quality of the other. The performance of the proposed dual GAN system is measured through some key metrics, such as Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) and Optical Character Recognition (OCR) accuracy to provide clear evidence of significant improvement in both image and text qualities as compared with other conventional methods. This innovation improves the process of clinical decision-making in the sense that clearer images and text are more accurate. The approach has tremendous potential for much wider practical applications: document scanning, surveillance, astronomy, and microscopy-all applications where textual and visual clarity are important for precision and analysis.

title: Machine Learning-Based Prediction of Photovoltaic Panel Soiling Using Satellite Images and Spectral Index
authors: Ricardo Arias Velásquez, Lissette Cabello Donaires, Jennifer Mejía Lara
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This paper developed a robust, data-driven methodology for predicting soiling levels on photovoltaic (PV) solar panels using high-resolution satellite data and a combination of machine learning techniques. The approach integrates multi-temporal Sentinel-2 Surface Reflectance (S2SR) data with advanced spectral indices to quantify particulate accumulation and atmospheric conditions that impact PV performance. The study area, located in northern Colombia in 2.16 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and Peru in Moquegua 1.00 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, Satellite images were extracted from the Google Earth Engine within a defined time range and filtered using day-of-year constraints to ensure the inclusion of only high-quality scenes. This methodological framework supports the scalable analysis of PV soiling across large areas and seasonal cycles, facilitating proactive maintenance strategies in tropical solar environments.

title: Multiattention Graph Convolution Network towards Cost aware partitioning for large graph processing in Geo distributed data center
authors: R. Myna, S. Nithya, S. Ramya, P. Brindha, M. Parimala Devi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Graph processing is a computation model employed to wide range of cloud based application while graph partitioning is significant towards optimizing cost and its performance towards processing task in the large scale geo distributed data centers. Recently, Cloud based application distributes their user data to geo distributed data centers for efficient access and sharing among interested user on employing graph partitioning approaches which as low latency. However heterogeneity of those data to the cloud has become challenging task to classify and share those data among user. In this paper, a graph processing approach using deep learning method named as multiattention graph convolution network is designed to classify and distribute cloud data among various users easily. Initially user data composed of multiple attribute is transformed into graph structured data. Graph structured data represented with node and its edge. In graph structure, user represents the node and related attribute relations of the user represent the edge which is obtained using Pearson correlation coefficients. Initially input layer of the graph convolution Network receives the user graph and its user specific attributes. Further graph convolution layer aggregates information of the neighboring user using degree normalized message passing to ensure balanced influence among users on minimizing sum of square distances to its least square fit. The graph pooling layer generates updated node embedding which includes user features and its neighbor information’s on reducing moment of inertia of the node. Finally dense layer with activation function for partition refined heuristics and soft max function classifies the integer features of user into multiple class partitions to organize data in the distributed data center as mixed integer quadratic optimization. Experimental analysis of the model is performed using EHR Dataset on python environment incorporating tensor flow to obtain GPU capabilities. On performance analysis, proposed model attains 98.4% partitioning accuracy which found to be better compared to conventional graph processing approaches

title: Study on thermal runaway of overcharged aged lithium-ion batteries based on electrochemical-thermal coupling model
authors: Jianbang Zeng, Lingzhan Guo, Yun Hu, Yifei Hu, Jiaxuan Zhai, Yufeng Luo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Equipment and Industrial Design (IEID)
abstract: The aging process of lithium-ion batteries has a significant impact on their safety performance. However, the quantitative relationship between aging parameters and overcharge-induced thermal runaway behavior requires further investigation. This study systematically quantified key aging parameters, including capacity fade, anode voltage loss, SEI film resistance increase, and charging temperature rise, to develop a multiphysics-coupled overcharge thermal runaway model incorporating aging effects. The results demonstrate that battery aging markedly reduces overcharge tolerance, as evidenced by an exponential decrease in the thermal runaway triggering SOC threshold with the degree of aging. Furthermore, the charging rate shows a significant negative correlation with overcharge resistance (each 1C rate increase reduces the SOC threshold by approximately 12%), while both the thermal runaway onset temperature and the electrolyte reference oxidation potential exhibit positive correlations (each 0.1V increase in oxidation potential expands the safety window by 5.6%).This research provides important theoretical foundations for understanding the thermal runaway mechanisms in aged batteries and enhancing the safety of power batteries throughout their lifecycle.

title: Assessing Performance and Scalability of Data Flows for an Urban Planning Application Using Apache NiFi
authors: Walter Gonzabay-Rojas, Francisco Teran-Cobo, Washington Velasquez, Nabih Pico
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: In the rapidly evolving field of urban planning, managing and analyzing vast amounts of data efficiently is crucial for creating sustainable and well-functioning urban environments. This paper investigates the application of Apache NiFi, a powerful data integration platform, in urban planning scenarios. It focuses on evaluating the performance, scalability, and data quality management capabilities of Apache NiFi in handling data flows essential for urban planning applications. Through a detailed case study, this research demonstrates how Apache NiFi can streamline data ingestion, processing, and distribution, ensuring real-time data availability and high data integrity. The findings indicate that Apache NiFi enhances the efficiency and scalability of data management processes and provides robust support for maintaining data quality, making it an ideal solution for complex urban planning needs.

title: Evaluating Automatic Code Generation for Generative AI Learning Models
authors: Rajesh Sura, Aravind Barla, Dilip Prakash, Sekar Mylsamy, Khoob Singh, Abhishek Jain
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Generative AI develops self-sufficient code creation models that offer an innovative approach for software development. Employing machine learning (ML) and data samples, these models develop code on their own. This research looks at fundamentals, uses, challenges, and possible futures of automatic code creation technologies that are connected to Artificial Intelligence (AI). This study examines the model-based software, domain-specific code as well as testing methods. The performance as well as the dependability of various automated code generation techniques are evaluated via performance analysis and evaluation. It is emphasized that such models have advantages and disadvantages as well as potential for development.

title: AI Supported Chronic Kidney Disease Prediction Using Machine Learning Classification Techniques
authors: T. Thangarasan, B Jai Kumar, S Jeelan, S Ramachandra Reddy, B Manohar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) progressively impairs kidney function, leading to severe health complications if not detected early. This study develops and evaluates machine learning models to predict CKD using clinical and laboratory parameters. The dataset comprises 400 patient records with features such as blood pressure, hemoglobin levels, specific gravity, and serum creatinine. Data preprocessing includes handling missing values, encoding categorical attributes, and applying oversampling to balance class distribution.Six classification techniques were employed: logistic regression, support vector machine, decision tree, random forest, k-nearest neighbors, and naive Bayes. Performance evaluation considered accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. Among these, random forest achieved the highest accuracy (99%), followed by decision tree (98.94%) and naive Bayes (97.89%), whereas support vector machine exhibited the lowest (65.26%). The findings suggest that ensemble-based techniques effectively enhance CKD prediction. This research demonstrates how machine learning can assist in early diagnosis, improving treatment planning and patient outcomes. Future work will focus on optimizing feature selection and incorporating deep learning techniques to further enhance predictive accuracy.

title: Implementing Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Navigation
authors: R. Santhoshkumar, D. Srinivasarao, M. Naga Triveni, Rehana Tabassum, Kondragunta Rama Krishnaiah, K. Nagaraju
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The reinforcement learning (RL) method is introduced for autonomous vehicle (AV) navigation at challenging circumstances utilizing the CARLA simulator, which is based on Deep Q-Networks (DQNs). In dynamic situations, traditional rule-based systems find it difficult to adapt, but the suggested approach makes it possible to acquire optimal driving techniques via interaction with the environment. Simulation-based data collection, preprocessing sensor data, DQN training using target networks and experience replay, and real-time policy implementation are all components of the technique. Integrated to integrated state representations are sensor inputs including cameras, LiDAR, GPS, along with collision detectors. Outperforming both conventional systems and similar RL approaches such as Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG), experimental findings demonstrate the accuracy level up to 95% in controlled situations and 55% in unexpected contexts. Although performance drops in dynamic environments, the system is resilient in the face of changing weather and traffic circumstances. Future research will concentrate on enhancing generalization and implementing DQN in the real world, but these results demonstrate its efficacy for flexible, scalable autonomous navigation.

title: A Machine Learning Case Study: Clustering, Anomaly Detection, and Protocol Classification for Network Traffic Analysis
authors: John Alexander Guzmán, Germán A. Montoya, Carlos Lozano-Garzón
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The exponential growth in global internet consumption has increased the complexity of wireless networks, making network traffic analysis and optimization more challenging. Efficient resource management across all network layers is essential to maintaining service quality and meeting increasing demand. Traditional analytical methods often struggle to adapt to the dynamic and high-dimensional nature of modern networks. In contrast, machine learning techniques enable automated network traffic analysis, real-time pattern detection, and predictive modeling, offering a more effective approach to network management. This paper explores the application of machine learning techniques for network traffic analysis using data captured from a local network router. Three approaches were implemented: clustering, anomaly detection, and classification. The clustering analysis categorized traffic into four main clusters based on protocol type and packet size, providing a detailed view of network usage patterns. The anomaly detection model identified that most anomalies shared a common destination port, offering insights into unusual or potentially malicious traffic. Additionally, the classification model demonstrated high accuracy in predicting packet transmission protocols, enabling automatic protocol identification even when metadata is incomplete. The findings underscore the potential of machine learning techniques to enhance network monitoring, optimize traffic management, and improve decision-making for network administrators.

title: Ensemble of Deep Neural Networks for Gastrointestinal Disease Classification in Endoscopic Images
authors: Kishore Kumar. B, G. Sahithi, CH.V.S.L. Harini, I. Snehitha, J. Rachel
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Gastrointestinal diseases pose a serious threat to health globally. Proper endoscopic diagnosis is a primary basis for effective treatment. Visual complexity and variability, however, question the consistency of reliable disease classification based on endoscopic images. This study aims to develop an ensemble of deep learning algorithms to distinguish between eight diseases within the gastrointestinal tract, including polyps and ulcerative colitis, from endoscopic photographs. We used transfer learning by pre-training VGG16, MobileNet, ResNet, and InceptionV3 models with 8,000 original images. The images were data augmented, which boosted the number of images to 36,000. Ensemble prediction was conducted through weighted averaging of the model outputs to improve the accuracy and stability of the gastrointestinal disease classification. It was proven that the ensemble outperformed all other models by achieving 98.18% accuracy on the test set. This research demonstrated the usefulness of ensemble techniques in providing reliable and automated deep-learning-based sophisticated medical imaging diagnostics. This method can be implemented in other areas of health care for the timely and precise detection of diseases.

title: Design of a Value Proposition for Pitahaya and Oat Cookies for Adults Aged 18 to 39 Suffering from Constipation, Using Design Thinking and the Value Proposition Canvas in Lima – Peru
authors: Lady Lucero Álvarez Pongo, Pamela Mercedes Tarazona Villanueva, Maribel Pérez Paredes, Carlos L. Torres Sifuente
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Constipation is a health issue that affects 20% of the population in Peru, impacting their quality of life. This project proposes a natural alternative to this problem through the creation of functional cookies made with oats and pitahaya, using the Design Thinking methodology for their development. To date, there are few local products aimed at addressing this specific health issue. The main contribution of this study is the formulation of healthy, fiber-rich food designed to promote proper intestinal transit. Product validation was carried out through sensory acceptance tests, analyzing taste, texture, and perceived effectiveness among consumers. The results show that the cookies not only helped improve digestion but also received good evaluations in terms of general acceptability. In conclusion, the combination of nutritious ingredients and marketing strategies focused on consumer education offers significant potential to position this product within the growing healthy food market in Lima.

title: Hybrid Federated Learning Framework with Client - Tailored Attentive Feature Extractor for Agricultural Health Monitoring
authors: Antoni Jaszcz, Agnieszka Polowczyk, Alicja Polowczyk, Katarzyna Wiltos, Dawid Połap, Marcin Woźniak
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Agricultural health monitoring is a critical task in ensuring the stability of modern agriculture. Many plant diseases share visual similarities, making manual inspection both time consuming and error prone, which is why robust and adaptable disease detection frameworks are not only desirable but essential to maintaining a resilient agricultural ecosystem. In this paper, we propose a hybrid federated learning (FL) framework that integrates a globally shared feature extractor with a client-specific self-attentive branch and classifier. The proposed framework uses a global model with both globally shared and client-tailored branches to achieve better performance for specialized tasks in decentralized training scenarios. The experiments were carried out on a Plant Village data set in a scenario, where each client represented a different crop type and faced a different leaf disease classification problem. The proposed solution revolved around the clients sharing the global weights, thus simultaneously contributing towards better feature extraction of the common leaf features, while the specialized segment of the model focused on proper interpretation of the extracted features (via cross-attention mechanism) and direct classification. The results obtained demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach over standard local training, as training with the proposed hybrid FL framework resulted in a perfect classification of the precision 100% of apple leaf disease.

title: Robohead: An educational Robot for Deep Robot-Student Interaction
authors: Pavel Kolesnikov, Konstantin Klimov, Vladimir Danilov, Dmitry Kapytov
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: This paper presents an educational robot called Robohead, it is designed for a wide range of students: from elementary school to senior university courses. Robohead allows you to study the multi-machine interaction of ROS, computer vision, speech recognition and speech generation, base algorithms of control joints, touch gestures and AI integration. The paper demonstrates the architecture of Robohead and the experience of its use in educational and competitive activities.

title: Coupling and controlling viewpoints in collaborative mixed reality: the (Point of View)* - PV* graphical notation
authors: Thomaz Fèvre, Adrien Chaffangeon Caillet, Cédric Fleury, Laurence Nigay
publish: Proceedings of the 36th Conference on l'Interaction Humain-Machine
abstract: Mixed Reality (MR) is increasingly being studied for synchronous remote collaboration in various fields, from industrial maintenance to education. It allows to combine virtual reality, augmented reality, and 2D interfaces to visualize and share real and virtual content. The notion of coupling of collaborative activities, central to studies of Computer-Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW) applications, takes various forms with MR due to its 3D and immersive characteristics, as well as the heterogeneity of interactive technologies. To cope with this diversity, we propose a graphical notation, PV*, that precisely describes the coupling relationships between multiple viewpoints on physical or virtual views, as well as their control by collaborators. We study the descriptive power of PV* by describing several collaborative situations from the literature and discuss its generative power by exploring several design possibilities described with PV*.

title: SDRS: Shape-Differentiable Robot Simulator
authors: Xiaohan Ye, Xifeng Gao, Kui Wu, Zherong Pan, Taku Komura
abstract: Robot simulators are indispensable tools across many fields, and recent research has significantly improved their functionality by incorporating additional gradient information. However, existing differentiable robot simulators suffer from non-differentiable singularities, when robots undergo substantial shape changes. To address this, we present the Shape-Differentiable Robot Simulator (SDRS), designed to be differentiable under significant robot shape changes. The core innovation of SDRS lies in its representation of robot shapes using a set of convex polyhedrons. This approach allows us to generalize smooth, penalty-based contact mechanics for interactions between any pair of convex polyhedrons. Using the separating hyperplane theorem, SDRS introduces a separating plane for each pair of contacting convex polyhedrons. This separating plane functions as a zero-mass auxiliary entity, with its state determined by the principle of least action. This setup ensures global differentiability, even as robot shapes undergo significant geometric and topological changes. To demonstrate the practical value of SDRS, we provide examples of robot co-design scenarios, where both robot shapes and control movements are optimized simultaneously.

title: Secrecy Energy Efficiency Optimization in Double-RIS-Assisted Wireless Powered Communication
authors: Yingxin Guo, Yi Guo, Gang Liu, Shaozhong Fu
abstract: Considering the importance of green and secure communications in the complex environments of the future Internet of Things (IoT), a secure wireless powered communication network (WPCN) assisted by double reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) is investigated. To maximize the system’s secrecy energy efficiency (SEE), we propose a Lagrange dual decomposition combined with double quadratic transformation and Riemannian manifold optimization (LDD-DQT-RMO) algorithm to jointly optimize the resource allocation, transmit and receive beamforming, and phase shifts at RISs. In particular, the DQT-RMO method is employed for the first time to optimize the phase shifts in the wireless information transmission (WIT) phase. Furthermore, an improved low-complexity algorithm is developed to directly obtain closed-form solutions for the phase shifts. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed LDD-DQT-RMO and its improved algorithm achieve much lower complexity and faster convergence compared to mainstream algorithms. Moreover, the proposed algorithms exhibit superior SEE performance compared to hybrid double-RIS-assisted WPCN systems in multi-antenna and large-scale RIS scenarios.

title: Large Language Models for Power System Security: A Novel Multi-Modal Approach for Anomaly Detection in Energy Management Systems
authors: Aydin Zaboli, Junho Hong, Alexandru Ştefanov, Chen-Ching Liu, Chul-Sang Hwang
abstract: This paper elaborates on an extensive security framework specifically designed for energy management systems (EMSs), which effectively tackles the dynamic environment of cybersecurity vulnerabilities and/or system problems (SPs), accomplished through the incorporation of novel methodologies. A comprehensive multi-point attack/error model is initially proposed to systematically identify vulnerabilities throughout the entire EMS data processing pipeline, including post state estimation (SE) stealth attacks, EMS database manipulation, and human-machine interface (HMI) display corruption according to the real-time database (RTDB) storage. This framework acknowledges the interconnected nature of modern attack vectors, which utilize various phases of supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) data flow. Then, generative artificial intelligence (GenAI)-based anomaly detection systems (ADSs) for EMSs are proposed for the first time in the power system domain to handle the scenarios. Further, a set-of-mark generative intelligence (SoM-GI) framework, which leverages multimodal analysis by integrating visual markers with rules considering the GenAI capabilities, is suggested to overcome inherent spatial reasoning limitations. The SoM-GI methodology employs systematic visual indicators to enable accurate interpretation of segmented HMI displays and detect visual anomalies that numerical methods fail to identify. Validation on the IEEE 14-Bus system shows the framework’s effectiveness across scenarios, while visual analysis identifies inconsistencies. This integrated approach combines numerical analysis with visual pattern recognition and linguistic rules to protect against cyber threats and system errors.

title: Privacy-Preserving Lightweight Federated Learning for Heterogeneous Data in Internet of Medical Things
authors: Saifur Rahman, Shantanu Pal, Chandan Karmakar
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: The Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) systems enable the continuous monitoring and collection of healthcare data from various medical devices and sensors, facilitating real-time analysis and timely interventions. One such example of the IoMT system is the early and accurate detection of arrhythmia using electrocardiogram (ECG) signals, which plays a crucial role in improving patient health. However, healthcare data contains sensitive information that raises privacy concerns for users. In recent years, Federated Learning (FL) offers a promising solution by enabling collaborative model training on distributed ECG data at the device level while preserving data privacy. However, FL is computationally expensive and suffers from data heterogeneity, which slower convergence, reduces performance, and hinders generalization across diverse client datasets. In this work, we propose a lightweight FL-based model designed explicitly for arrhythmia detection with data heterogeneity. We evaluate our model's performance on two publicly available ECG datasets (PTBD and MIT-BIH arrhythmia). The proposed model achieves high accuracy (between 0.95 and 0.98) while maintaining robustness against heterogeneous data distributions. Furthermore, the experimental results demonstrate significant efficiency gains compared to a baseline model (ResNet). Our proposed lightweight FL-based model requires substantially less mega floating point operations (MFLOPS) (0.07 vs. 2.14 for ResNet) and communication cost (1000 Mb vs. 7500 Mb for ResNet) to achieve convergence. These results indicate the potential of our proposed approach for practical and privacy-preserving arrhythmia detection in resource-constrained IoMT settings.

title: SVMB-Net: Local Global Fusion and Multi-Branch Cross-Feature Attention for Skin Lesion Segmentation
authors: Yuan Zhao, Jinlai Zhang, Wujiao He, Sheng Wu
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurate segmentation of skin lesions remains a key challenge for early cancer diagnosis due to complex morphological variations such as irregular shape, heterogeneous texture and low contrast. To address these limitations, we propose SVMB-Net, a dual-architecture framework that integrates SwinTransformer and CNN with the following innovations: first, the Super ViT-CNN (SViT-C) hybrid encoder employs a special global restoration module for extracting high-level semantics, whereas the dual-branch fusion module combines CNN's local feature extraction with SwinTransformer's global context modelling synergy. Second, our multi-branch deep cross-feature attention decoder introduces a multi-scale attention mechanism. Comprehensive evaluations on three clinical datasets show significant improvements: on ISIC2018, SVMB-Net improves <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$DSC$</tex-math></inline-formula> by 7.67% to 93.88% and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$ACC$</tex-math></inline-formula> by 2.21% to 96.97% against the current state-of-the-art segmentation method DINOv2. Experiments conducted at ISIC2017 and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$PH^{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula> show an <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$IoU$</tex-math></inline-formula> of 83.45% and an <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$ACC$</tex-math></inline-formula> of 97.08%, which largely outperforms 16 existing methods such as SAM2-UNet and VM-UNet. The architecture provides a powerful solution for automated lesion analysis in real-world clinical settings. Early detection and surgical treatment are crucial for the successful cure of skin cancer. However, the accuracy of detecting skin cancer is challenged due to its variations in shape, size, color, texture, hair, contrast difference, brightness, and irregular boundaries. To address these issues, a new skin cancer image segmentation method, SVMB-Net, is proposed in this paper. Our code will be open sourced at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/Sleepearlyy/SVMB-Net.git</uri>.

title: LLM-Driven On-Demand AI Service Provision in 6G Networks
authors: Nan Cheng, Yifan Guo, Tingting Yang, Jinglong Shen, Wei Quan, Tom H. Luan
abstract: With the continuous breakthroughs in the technical capabilities of large language models (LLMs), they have demonstrated exceptional technical efficacy across multiple application domains. Particularly in the field of task planning, this technological framework has proven capable of delivering systemic performance enhancements to communication systems. This paper focuses on the integrated application of LLMs in 6G network systems, adopting a hierarchical and progressive research paradigm for discussion. First, the technical advantages of LLMs are systematically elaborated, and a comparative analysis method is employed to deconstruct the functional demand disparities between the user side and the network side in 6G communication networks. Subsequently, an innovative LLM-driven on-demand artificial intelligence service architecture is proposed. Building upon this framework, simulation modeling is utilized to quantitatively evaluate its optimization effects on key performance metrics of communication networks. Finally, in the case study, the service architecture is empirically validated for its capability to meet differentiated network and user demands.

title: A Hierarchical Cascading Technique with Subpitch Finite Element Decomposition for 2-D Modeling of Acoustic Wave Resonators
authors: Hongliang Li, Julius Koskela, Balam A. Willemsen, Jackson W. Massey
publish: IEEE Journal on Multiscale and Multiphysics Computational Techniques
abstract: A hierarchical cascading technique with subpitch finite element decomposition is presented for 2-D modeling of acoustic wave resonators. This technique scans the structure and partitions it into thin slices. Unique unit blocks are identified and computed with the finite element method. The entire geometry is then translated into a sequence of unit blocks, and a hierarchical tree of cascading operations is built. Full solutions are obtained by combining smaller blocks into larger blocks. For the blocks that repeat in the cascading process, the matrix is computed only once and can be reused later. Numerical examples are presented to demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed method with over 70% time cost reduction and decreased memory usage than conventional HCT. Compared with FEM, over 100 times speedup can be achieved.

title: Membrane Potential-Driven Adaptive Threshold Plasticity for SNNs: A Bio-Inspired Mechanism Combining Inverse Depolarization Rate and Proportional Membrane Potential Dynamics
authors: Na Shan, Yibin Lin, Chuxi Xie, Kunlun Wu, Weidong Ma, Chaoxu Mu, Xiaorong Yan, Anguo Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: While spiking neural networks (SNNs) have demonstrated remarkable efficiency in neuromorphic computing by emulating biological neuronal dynamics, their learning capabilities remain constrained by predominant focus on synaptic plasticity. This limitation overlooks critical neurobiological evidence showing that intrinsic neuronal plasticity, particularly dynamic threshold adaptation, plays an essential role in balancing neural responsiveness and signal fidelity. Inspired by two neurophysiological principles governing threshold regulation: 1) the inverse correlation between spiking thresholds and preceding depolarization rates, and 2) the proportional relationship between thresholds and average membrane potentials, we propose a Membrane Potential-Driven Adaptive Threshold Plasticity (MPD-ATP) framework. This biologically grounded mechanism establishes a dual-pathway control system where instantaneous depolarization rates and sustained membrane potential states jointly modulate neuronal thresholds through an adaptive scaling factor. The instantaneous depolarization rate dynamically lowers thresholds during strong input bursts, while the sustained average membrane potential adjusts the baseline threshold to stabilize firing during sparse input. This complementary regulation improves precision and robustness. Extensive evaluations on static (CIFAR-10/100) and neuromorphic (CIFAR10-DVS, DVSGesture) benchmarks demonstrate that MPD-ATP-enhanced networks achieve superior classification accuracy with enhanced noise robustness. Systematic ablation studies reveal that the coordinated interaction between depolarization-sensitive and membrane potential-proportional threshold adjustments is critical for preventing signal saturation in high-activity networks while mitigating under-activation in sparse-input scenarios.

title: Impulsive Maneuver Detection with Radar Observation using LSTM Neural Network
authors: Jimu Ai, Rui Hou, Xueming Xiao, Qingxiang Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Spacecraft maneuver detection remains challenging due to limited observations, diverse maneuver profiles, and traditional methods’ reliance on predefined thresholds. This paper proposes a data-driven approach using Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks that processes orbit estimation residual sequences to automatically identify maneuvers without requiring threshold selection or predefined models. First, systematic feature engineering identifies a compact 7-dimensional statistical representation based on detection statistics that reduces input dimensionality by 79% while maintaining detection accuracy, improving computational efficiency for real-time deployment. Second, a track-aware temporal loss function is developed incorporating class balance weights, exponential delay penalties, and track-level detection suppression to address the extreme class imbalance and temporal bias introduced by temporal labeling. Third, comprehensive evaluations across diverse scenarios with maneuver magnitudes of 1.5, 3, and 5 m/s and realistic observation gaps demonstrate that while traditional threshold-based methods face inherent trade-offs between detection and false alarm rates, the proposed specialized loss function effectively breaks this limitation by reducing false alarms by 42.6% and detection delays by 53.2% compared to standard cross-entropy training. Finally, experimental results demonstrate superior performance with 89.64% detection rate at 5.34% false alarm rate and 0.73 frame mean detection delay, significantly outperforming traditional threshold-based detection (83.6% detection rate) and recent LSTM methods, validating the effectiveness of track-aware temporal modeling for real-time spacecraft maneuver detection.

title: Non-Invasive Glucose Sensing: Highly Sensitive 3D Ear-Conformed Sensor for Wearable Applications
authors: Nastouh Nikkhah, Rasool Keshavarz, Negin Shariati
abstract: Diabetes disrupts glucose regulation in both humans and animals, severely impacting liver and muscle function. Commonly used monitoring methods are invasive and cumbersome to implant, highlighting the need for non-invasive alternatives. This study focuses on developing a non-invasive, lightweight, and highly sensitive three-dimensional ear-conformed resonator (3D-ECR) sensor for glucose monitoring. Using a dielectric assessment kit (DAK), this work measures permittivity in standard aqueous glucose samples (35 to 110 mg/dL), covering the majority of the physiologically observed glucose range in humans and cattle. The 3D-ECR sensor analyzes resonance frequency and phase variations of S21, achieving phase sensitivities of 1°/(mg/dL) at 2.45 GHz and 0.7°/(mg/dL) at 4.3 GHz, and frequency sensitivity of 3.2 MHz/(mg/dL). This innovative sensor offers a promising solution for glucose monitoring in biomedical and agricultural applications. This work serves as a laboratory-level proof of concept using standard aqueous glucose samples, with future studies planned for tissue-mimicking phantoms and clinical validation.

title: Temporal Transfer Learning for Traffic Optimization with Coarse-Grained Advisory Autonomy
authors: Jung-Hoon Cho, Sirui Li, Jeongyun Kim, Cathy Wu
abstract: The recent development of connected and automated vehicle (CAV) technologies has spurred investigations to optimize dense urban traffic, maximizing vehicle speed and throughput. This paper explores advisory autonomy, in which real-time driving advisories are issued to human drivers, thus achieving near-term performance of automated vehicles. Due to the complexity of traffic systems, recent studies of coordinating CAVs have leveraged deep reinforcement learning (RL). Coarse-grained advisory is formalized as zero-order holds, and we consider a range of hold durations from 0.1 to 40 seconds. However, despite the similarity of the higher-frequency tasks for CAVs, a direct application of deep RL fails to generalize to advisory autonomy tasks. To overcome this, we employ zero-shot transfer, training policies on a set of source tasks-specific traffic scenarios with designated hold durations-and then evaluating the efficacy of these policies on different target tasks. We introduce Temporal Transfer Learning (TTL) algorithms to select source tasks for zero-shot transfer, systematically leveraging the temporal structure to solve the full range of tasks. TTL selects the most suitable source tasks to maximize the performance of the range of tasks. We validate our algorithms on diverse mixed-traffic scenarios, demonstrating that TTL more reliably solves the tasks than baselines. This paper underscores the potential of coarse-grained advisory autonomy with TTL in traffic flow optimization.

title: Enhancing Second-Life Battery Performance With Dynamic Equalization: A Residential Case Study
authors: Michele Martino, Riberto Di Rienzo, Federico Baronti, Roberto Roncellai, Roberto Saletti
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Industrial Electronics Society
abstract: The growing demand for energy storage in residential photovoltaic systems highlights the potential of second-life electric vehicle batteries. Their residual capacity offers economic and environmental benefits. However, their cells suffer from a significant capacity mismatch, which reduces the overall usable capacity of the battery. Dynamic equalization appears to be a promising solution to fully exploit the battery capacity. This work aims to present a simulation platform designed to evaluate the benefits of dynamic equalization in second-life batteries used for residential photovoltaic energy storage. Through the simulation platform, various scenarios were simulated based on real production and consumption data collected over a one-year operating period to account for seasonal variations. Simple control algorithms are investigated and compared with an improved one based on a digital twin of the battery. In addition, the effects of the equalization system efficiency, battery size, and cell capacity mismatch on the dynamic equalization behavior are discussed. This study demonstrates that the use of dynamic equalization increases energy utilization by up to 8%, even when the efficiency of the equalization DC-DC converter is as low as 70%. Finally, an economic analysis is performed to compare brand-new lithium-ion batteries and second-life batteries with and without dynamic equalization.

title: Identification and Prediction of Multiple Intelligence Patterns among University Students using Machine Learning for Personalized Learning and Instruction_supp3-3635866.docx
authors: Sonia Corraya
abstract: Humans possess seven types of intelligence for learning. However, conventional educational systems mostly rely only on the Linguistic and Mathematical types. This narrow focus leaves other intelligences unrecognized and unutilized in learners’ learning processes. The main challenge lies in holistically addressing diverse intelligence levels in typical educational settings. Prior research isolated dominant intelligence traits for personalization, which lack objectivity and fail to utilize the full spectrum of learning potentials. The goal of this research is to identify and predict underlying learning patterns in university students, enabling addressing all types of intelligence holistically at the group level. To achieve this, a multi-algorithm framework integrating unsupervised and supervised learning is developed to analyze Multiple Intelligences profiles and associated learner parameters from the Learning Meta-Learning dataset. MI profiles capture all seven types of intelligences. K-Means clustering identified three unique and interpretable MI profile patterns, outperforming the Two-Step clustering algorithm. For prediction, CatBoost achieved 92.20% accuracy across seven algorithms, including Random Forest, Extra Trees, XGBoost, LightGBM, K-Nearest Neighbors, and HistGradientBoosting. By incorporating Explainable Artificial Intelligence through Shapley Additive Explanations and optimizing features, its accuracy improved to 93.66%. The identified Multiple Intelligences profile patterns offer actionable insights. Beyond the high-level guidelines for personalizing instruction outlined in this paper, they can inform various personalized educational approaches and support further research by providing a structured understanding of learner diversity and a predictive framework.
