title: Design and Validation of a Body-Powered Lower Extremity Exoskeleton Featuring Explosive Locomotion Augmentation
authors: Wenpan Wang, Lei Deng, Guolin Yun, Wenbo Li, Linghao Yu, Shengfeng Zhu, Jian Yang, Weihua Li, Shiwu Zhang, Xinglong Gong, Shuaishuai Sun
abstract: Exoskeletons, designed to enhance human strength and mobility, hold the potential to revolutionize fields such as rehabilitation, sports, industrial work, and defense. However, current designs are limited in augmenting explosive locomotion and reducing dependence on external energy sources. Given these challenges, we proposed a body-powered lower extremity exoskeleton employing clutched parallel elastic magnetorheological actuators (CPEMAs). The CPEMA on the knee joint primarily comprises a high-stiffness torsional spring to recycle the human body’s kinetic energy, three high-torque magnetorheological fluid bearings functioning as clutches, and a gear reducer for torque amplification. When the torsional springs are engaged, the CPEMAs accumulate energy from the knee’s periodic flexion and extension with low power consumption. Then, the stored energy can be released in one burst for explosive actuation. Theoretical analysis and experimental evaluation demonstrate the capabilities of the proposed exoskeleton, including enhancements of around 53% in kicking force, 31% in lower extremity strength, and 12% in jumping ability. The system advances the understanding of exoskeleton-assisted high-performance locomotion, showcasing a substantial potential to transcend the human body’s limitations.

title: Closed Form Theoretical Model for Magnetic Sensors to Measure Currents in Power Distribution Systems
authors: Siva Alagappa Kulathuran, Sukumar Brahma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The modernization of distribution systems necessitates a sufficient number of inexpensive but accurate current sensors for effective monitoring, control, and protection. Recent research indicates that non-invasive, inexpensive magnetic field sensors are able to accurately measure the flux density existing at its location. However, in a distribution system the flux density measured by a sensor is a function of multiple currents. The novel contribution of this paper is to provide a closed-form mathematical solution to calculate individual phase currents from the total flux density, given the pole configuration of the distribution feeder. The model is first validated through COMSOL simulation. Then, it is validated through laboratory experiments using tunnel magneto-resistive sensors. The minimal errors resulting from both validations are explained.

title: The Norwegian SISU Project: History and Long-term Impact of an Early MDD Effort
authors: Stein Erik Ellevseth, Peter Herrmann, Emmanuel Gaudin, Juergen Dingel
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems (MODELS)
abstract: At the 15th System Analysis and Modelling Conference (SAM) in October 2023, a panel session was dedicated to the discussion of the past, present, and the future of Model-Driven Development (MDD). The session focused on the themes history, impact, lessons learned, and barriers to the adoption of MDD. In the context of history and impact, amongst others, the results of the Norwegian national R&D project “Supporting Integrated System Development” (SISU) were discussed, as well as recent development approaches akin to MDD. The panelists agreed that the quality of the systems produced within SISU was usually very high, since the used modeling concepts match reality well and made the models therefore easier to comprehend. Nevertheless, the adoption of SDL in the member companies did not progress as expected after project completion. This makes SISU a typical example of the circumstance that MDD has not developed as successfully as was assumed 30 years ago. The discussion of the panelists on barriers to MDD revealed key challenges in two perspectives: users' experience and tools' support. Besides some lessons learned, this paper presents a number of recommendations that might help to address the mentioned challenges leading towards a more prominent use of MDD in software engineering in the future.

title: SpInN: A Time Series Foundation Model for Spectral Indices Recommendation for Earth Observation Applications Using Satellite Data
authors: Arshveer Kaur, Poonam Goyal, Vansh Bansal, Deep Pandya, Navneet Goyal
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Spectral Reflectance Indices (SRIs) have emerged as a powerful tool for unraveling and deciphering critical information about land cover, vegetation health, water quality, soil characteristics, etc. This approach provides valuable insights for sustainable resource management, agricultural optimizations, etc. However, vast list of available spectral indices makes it challenging to choose most relevant ones for a specific application. Identification of relevant SRIs for an application needs domain experts to analyze the information obtained from indices. Existing studies have used SRIs in a limited way - 1) as a single value for a location (county) and thus suffer from loss of spatial information; 2) only few popular spectral indices e.g. NDVI, SAVI, NDWI, etc. are exploited; 3) have been used for applications like crop yield and snow cover prediction. To circumvent these limitations, we embarked on three novel ideas - 1) compute spectral indices at pixel level of the satellite image resulting in an SRI image for a region; 2) introduce a selection method which selects SRIs relevant to a given application; 3) design a model called Spectral Indices Network, SpInN, utilizing two transformers ViViT and BERT. We use ViViT innovatively on different SRI images treating them as video frames for spatio-spectral index learning. We also use BERT to exploit temporal patterns of the spectral index time series. The proposed model is applied to various prediction and classification earth observation applications such as prediction of crop yield, solar energy, soil moisture, land cover classification, etc., and obtained state-of-the-art results.

title: Prototype of a Web Platform that Identifies Levels of Critical Thinking in University Students, based on the PC-B Test & PC-A Test1
authors: Leiner Javier Viloria Genes, Hernan Velazquez Meriño, Maria Angelica Garcia Medina, David De Jesus Acosta Meza, Claudia Lengua Cantero, Jhon Édison Anaya Herrera
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The development of critical thinking skills is vital in higher education. To support this, a web platform powered by artificial intelligence was created at CECAR to assess these skills through the PC-B and PC-A tests, targeting basic and advanced levels. Built on a strong theoretical foundation from a systematic literature review, the platform integrates pedagogical and research functions. Technologically, it uses a microservices architecture and modern tools like Angular, NestJS, and Docker, ensuring scalability and a user-friendly interface. Developed using the agile Kanban methodology, it applies Onion and Hexagonal Architecture to ensure modularity. It offers customized reports and results visualization.

title: Strategic Foresight for University Curricula: Aligning Higher Education with Technological Labor Market Demands Towards 2035
authors: Daniel Leiva-Pérez, Boris Antonio Diaz-Huayanca, Roberto Flores-Rivero, Jesús Martín Del-Carpio-Pacheco, Carlos Guillermo Hernández-Cenzano
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The rapid advancement of emerging technologies is reshaping the structure and dynamics of labor markets, with significant implications for developing economies. In response, higher education institutions face the strategic imperative of aligning academic programs with the evolving demands of a technology-oriented workforce. This study employs a strategic foresight methodology to explore future curricular scenarios for Peruvian universities toward 2035. A mixed-methods design was implemented, combining quantitative trend analysis with qualitative expert input via a Delphi process. Thirty-three key drivers were identified and assessed based on their importance and uncertainty, leading to a structural classification and scenario development using the Schwartz matrix. Three internally coherent scenarios were constructed, from which one was selected as the normative target. A backcasting approach was applied to define milestones and strategic actions required to achieve this scenario. The findings highlight the need for enhanced coordination among universities, industry, and government to redesign curricula, integrate digital skills, and improve feedback mechanisms. The framework offers practical guidance for academic planners and policymakers seeking to strengthen institutional responsiveness and workforce alignment in the context of ongoing technological disruption.

title: Design and Internal Flow Study Using CFD of an Elliptic Vortex Gripper with Variable Geometry for Polyethylene Bag Packaging
authors: Italo I. Luque, Elihasid B. Echia, Julio Ronceros, Ayrton Nieves, Jose Carrizales, Luis A. Sampen
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This work presents a study of the internal flow in various elliptic vortex grippers designed to generate an air vortex, applying the operating principle of conventional vortex grippers but adapted to non-circular shapes. The study and design focus on a specific application in the counting and packaging process of folded polyethylene bags, with the aim of improving production efficiency without compromising the integrity of the packages or the bags and reducing count errors. Initially, a simplified vortex flow model proposed by a previous author is used to determine the basic circular geometry of the nozzle. Computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations are then employed to investigate how the pressure distribution changes in the elliptic nozzles, which maintain the same area as the initial circular nozzle. This is done by varying the ratio between the major and minor diameters, and adjusting the position of the air inlet, to identify the most efficient configuration in terms of achieving the lowest pressure and optimizing the pressure drop distribution along the major axis. The results guide the design towards an efficient and adaptable solution tailored to the specific requirements of vacuum gripping applications.

title: Next-Generation Smart Cities: Harnessing AI for Enhanced Pedestrian Protection
authors: Diego Alberto Guevara Amaya, Jairo E. Serrano, Juan Carlos Martinez Santos, Edwin Alexander Puertas del Castillo
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The invasion of crosswalks by vehicles during the pedestrian signal phase poses a significant risk to pedestrians in urban environments. This study develops a system based on computer vision and deep learning to detect these violations in real time. A YOLOv8 model is trained and validated using images from an urban surveillance video system, achieving a mAP@ 50 of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 8. 6 \%}$</tex>. The system integrates the Intersection over Union (IoU) metric to quantify the overlap between vehicles and crosswalks, allowing for precise violation detection. The results demonstrate the feasibility of this approach to enhance pedestrian safety and facilitate traffic law enforcement. Future research will focus on optimizing the model for adverse environmental conditions and improving traffic sign detection for a more accurate assessment of the road context.

title: Efficient Fine-Tuning of Large Language Models for Medical Chatbot Applications
authors: S Srinivas, Akshatha Y, Rakshitha K T, Prem Je Kalister, R Keshav, Bhavana A
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Accessibility to healthcare services in rural India faces significant challenges due to limited medical resources, shortage of healthcare professionals and geographical barriers, leading to delayed diagnosis and treatment procedures. To address these challenges, this study introduces MediTalk300, a fine-tuned large language model (LLM) trained on data of 300 plus commonly occurring diseases in India, which can be used an application for a conversational kiosk chatbot for rural India for effective and immediate healthcare assistance. By finetuning the state-of-the-art open-source pre-trained LLMs, including Mistral 7B, MediTalk300 achieves higher accuracy in terms of medical conversations. The fine-tuned Mistral 7B model demonstrates promising results, achieving a BERT Score of 87%, ROUGE-1 score of 38%, ROUGE-2 score of 8% and Rouge-L Score of 15%, which is comparatively 40% better than few benchmark models. This suggests that MediTalk300 has significant potential to address the lacking issue of immediate healthcare assistance services in rural India.

title: Chiplets Everywhere!: Opportunities and challenges
authors: Farhana Sheikh, Shuanghong Sun, Hui Julie Zhang, Dani Dakhil, Nij Dorairaj, Shawn Wang, Spencer Allen, Harrison Liew, David Kehlet
abstract: Chiplet based systems are now a reality with a significant number of products leveraging disaggregated architectures to enable high-performance compute, AI, and intelligent edge systems. As the need for such systems increases, their design and implementation must be made easier and less complex so that third-party IPs can easily be integrated into a multi-die platform such as the example presented in this paper. A templated FPGA-chiplet system to facilitate ease of entry into the chiplet ecosystem is described, where key chiplet infrastructure IPs are detailed–such as die-to-die protocols, die-to-die PHYs, communication peripherals, and a chiplet security engine. We highlight challenges related to the implementation and testing of the platform, which include constraints posed by micro-bumps, chiplet alignment, package and platform considerations, and security threats. The resulting platform frees the chiplet developer from infrastructure design tasks requiring engineer-years of effort and instead can focus on their own compelling IP.

title: Smart Tourism Routes Based on Real-Time Data: A Case Study in Riobamba-Ecuador
authors: Paola G. Vinueza-Naranjo, Luis Quevedo, Willigton Jiménez, Janneth Chicaiza, Yesenia Cevallos
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Mobile technologies have played a crucial role in the way people and organizations carry out their activities. Particularly in the tourism sector, mobile applications can help to reduce the negative impacts of tourist activities and contribute to the improvement of destination sustainability. In this paper, for suggesting routes and trails of various scales, encompassing itineraries with diverse durations and themes, the RioCicloRutas app has been successfully implemented. The mobile application was deployed considering cyclist routes in the city of Riobamba, Ecuador, receiving positive feedback from domestic and foreign tourists as well as sportsmen. RioCicloRutas effectively displayed routes recorded by users, enriched with audio and video, making it a more interactive alternative to traditional guide apps.

title: Toward Dependability Simulation for Intelligent Transportation Systems in Connected Vehicle Environments
authors: Saehoon Oh, Sangbeom Park, Gang Min Kim, Huy Kang Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE 30th Pacific Rim International Symposium on Dependable Computing (PRDC)
abstract: The Intelligent Transportation System for Connected Vehicles (ITS for CV) integrates diverse assets such as vehicles, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), roadside units (RSUs), and central servers to improve traffic efficiency and public safety via real-time communication and coordination. However, increased interconnectivity introduces potential vulnerabilities across communication, control, and sensing layers, making it challenging to assess system-level mission impacts against cyber-physical attacks. This paper presents a simulation-based framework to evaluate dynamic attack-defense interactions. The proposed framework integrates threat database construction, scenario modeling, simulation environment development, and impact-based evaluation to enable quantitative assessment of mission degradation. Current progress includes the development of a simulator-integrated testbed, and mapping of attack and defense techniques to standardized frameworks. Future work will focus on autonomous attacker and defender agent training using deep reinforcement learning and hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) validation for real-world applicability.

title: Machine Learning-Based Prediction of Customer Retention in Indian Banks Through AI Chatbot Interactions
authors: Gopalakrishnan Chinnasamy, Vinoth. S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The research explores the influence of AI chatbots in Indian banks on customer retention prediction through usability of interaction, trust, and loyalty. It seeks to establish drivers that drive preference of chatbot over human assistance and evaluates the effect of response time, accuracy, and personalization on customer satisfaction. The mixed-methods strategy was employed using stratified random sampling to investigate information from 289 bank customers. Statistical models like Logistic Regression, Bayesian Ridge Regression, Decision Trees, and Neural Networks were used to model retention and loyalty prediction. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) was used for extracting chatbot preference drivers and thematic analysis for giving qualitative results. Results show that chatbot efficiency, personalization, and trust have a significant impact on customer retention, implying banks must optimize chatbot responsiveness and accuracy. The research provides practical suggestions for improving AI chatbot conversations, creating long-term relationships, and building customer loyalty in online banking.

title: Predicting Liver Injury Risk from Chemical Properties and Drug Label Information Using Machine Learning Models
authors: Vyshali J Gogi, Balakrishna R, Ann Mathew
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: This research aims to create a drug-induced liver injury (DILI) severity prediction system based on machine learning to aid healthcare professionals in safety assessment. FDA’s Liver Toxicity Knowledge Base supplied a drug dataset of 1042 drugs, and later, after pre-processing and API data extraction, each drug was defined by 16 chemical features such as molecular descriptors and pharmacokinetic properties. To improve uniformity and get quality input for training, data preparation involved correcting missing values, encoding categorical values, and normalising numerical data. Various machine learning models were trained and evaluated to forecast the levels of DILI severity, i.e., Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and XGBoost. The importance of features was approximated for identifying the predictors that impacted the most. The best overall performance was recorded for XGBoost, and it had 81% accuracy when it was evaluated. Its acceptable discrimination was established for mild, moderate, and severe cases. The aptness of being applied to the medical sector is demonstrated by drastically lowering the principal misclassifications, especially from mild to severe. The application of machine learning in improving medicine safety assessment and reducing risks associated with pharmaceutical development is illustrated here.

title: Cultural Translation and Expression of Color Driven by Hybrid Kansei Engineering
authors: Yazhuo Zou, Yuan Yan, Mu Guo, Xiang Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Equipment and Industrial Design (IEID)
abstract: To enhance the spatial experience and cultural identity of rail transit while promoting cultural heritage and innovation in urban public spaces, this study proposes a method integrating the NCS system with hybrid affective engineering to incorporate Shanxi’s ancient architectural culture into rail vehicle color design. First, the NCS color system standardizes and extracts color elements from Shanxi’s ancient architecture to form color samples. These samples are then mapped to selected cultural affective imagery to establish a forward kansei engineering design model for conceptual design. Finally, a reverse kansei engineering evaluation model is established using fuzzy logic combined with grey relational analysis to derive the optimal color scheme, validating the model’s feasibility. This process successfully extracts color elements from Shanxi’s ancient architecture and constructs standardized color samples. A correlation model linking color to sensory imagery was developed for design evaluation and validation. This process ultimately selected a rail transit vehicle color scheme that embodies regional culture while meeting user sensory needs. This research provides an innovative theoretical framework and practical guidance for rail transit vehicle color design, validating the method’s effectiveness and utility in cultural translation expression and design evaluation.

title: Combined Approach using Multiattention Graph Convolution Network towards prevention, detection and classification of Phishing attack
authors: N. Nithya, S. Sakthimuneeswaran
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Phishing attack is becoming an important persistent threat in cyber security as it captures the sensitive information of the victims through establishing fraudulent website and website link. Trojan horse phishing attack is evolving and dynamically changing malicious website or software with attack characteristics. It is highly complex to detect and classify it as disguised as legitimate website or software. Those attack were launched by sending phishing email, email attachments containing fake software updates and websites links to gain access to sensitive information’s and to establish botnet through infected devices. Traditionally many researches have been performed defense and prevention mechanism to phishing attacks using natural language processing methods and machine learning methods to analyze, detect, classify and predict the unusual behavior of the website and software launched through emails. Despite of several advantages those models fail to prevent, detect and classify the evolving and dynamically changing attack characteristics through launching sources. In this paper, a new combined approach is designed using multiattention graph convolution network to prevent, detect and classify the evolving dynamic phishing attacks on analyzing webpages extracted from kaggle repository. Initially, Graph is constructed to process the webpage and its elements. Graph can represents multiple elements like URL, HTML elements. Each node in graph represents specific element such as URL component, HTML tag. Further each node has associated features such as URL characteristics and HTML attributes. Thus edge represents relationship among those elements using similarity computations, proximity computation and other criteria’s. Next, those graph structured data were projected to multiattention graph convolution network which includes attention mechanism and graph convolution network for data processing. Especially graph convolution layer extract the local and global features from the URL and HTML elements using different kernel function. Extracted feature is processed using multi attention mechanism as it is capable of assigning different weights to the local and global features. Finally Fully connected layer aggregates local and global weighted features based on relationship with neighboring nodes features and transform those features into unified attention map on mentioning network attack patterns and normal patterns along its characteristics through activation function. Further softmax function of the fully connected layer generates different strategies for prevention, detection and classification using random forest classifier on processing attention map. Random forest classifier performs attack detection and classification and those classified attack attributes implements weight matrix to compute the volume of attack. On rise in volume of attack, specified URL or program were blocked as mitigation or prevention strategies. Experimental analysis and performance analysis of the multiattention graph convolution network were performed towards Trojan phishing attack prevention, detection and attack prevention or mitigation and it is compared against conventional approaches on processing Phishing dataset on python environment. On its analysis, it is confirmed that proposed model achieves increased detection accuracy of 98.8% on determining the evolving phishing attack with high robustness while compared with traditional approaches.

title: Toward an Autonomous Purple Teaming Framework for Security and Safety in Large Language Models
authors: Leo Hyun Park, YoonSik Kim, Eunbi Hwang, Sangsoo Han, Hyoungshick Kim, Taekyoung Kwon
publish: 2025 IEEE 30th Pacific Rim International Symposium on Dependable Computing (PRDC)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have rapidly advanced in reasoning capability and accessibility, driving their deployment across diverse applications. Yet this progress has also widened the surface for safety and security vulnerabilities. Adversaries can exploit prompt diversity, dialog memory, or multimodal inputs to induce unsafe or confidential outputs, while continual fine-tuning and third-party integration render static assurance infeasible. This paper introduces our ongoing national R&D project on developing the AutoPT Framework-an Autonomous Purple Teaming architecture that extends the collaborative principles of purple teaming toward self-adaptive, continuously verifiable LLM assurance. AutoPT unifies autonomous adversarial exploration and adaptive defensive reinforcement through two co-evolving agents. The red module, AutoPT-Red, employs coverage-guided fuzzing and internal measurement metrics to autonomously uncover vulnerabilities. The blue module, AutoPT-Blue, performs self-healing adaptation by updating guardrails and detecting integrity or confidentiality violations using embedding-based feedback. Preliminary case studies on jailbreak fuzzing and backdoor-poisoning defense validate the feasibility of this closed-loop, self-adapting architecture. As part of a broader national initiative, this work lays the conceptual and technical foundation for transitioning industrial purple teaming into a fully autonomous, scalable, and measurable assurance paradigm for generative AI systems.

title: Diverse and Plausible Counterfactual Explanations for Time Series via Latent Space Optimization
authors: Peiyu Li, Omar Bahri, Pouya Hosseinzadeh, Soukaïna Filali Boubrahimi, Shah Muhammad Hamdi
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Understanding the predictions of time series classifiers is essential in high-stakes domains such as health-care, finance, and security. Counterfactual explanations, which identify minimal perturbations to input sequences that alter model predictions, provide intuitive and actionable insights. However, existing methods often struggle to generate realistic or diverse counterfactuals, especially for sequential data with strong temporal dependencies. In this work, we propose DiverseLCF, a post-hoc framework for generating diverse and plausible counterfactual explanations for time series classifiers. By optimizing in the latent space of a pretrained variational autoencoder (VAE), DiverseLCF ensures that generated counterfactuals remain temporally coherent and aligned with the data manifold. We formulate the generation process as a multi-objective optimization problem that balances validity, proximity, and diversity. Extensive experiments show that DiverseLCF consistently generates valid, plausible, and diverse coun-terfactuals with minimal proximity trade-offs, providing a robust and generalizable tool for interpreting time series models.

title: Design of a Seamlessly Integrated Dielectric Resonator Antenna Array with Self-Decoupling Property for Millimeter-Wave Applications
authors: Liang Zha, Jing Gao, Yong Mei Pan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: In this paper, a novel substrate-integrated millimeter-wave (mm-Wave) dielectric resonator antenna (DRA) array is investigated. Unlike conventional designs, all DRA elements are seamlessly integrated into a single piece of dielectric substrate, significantly easing manufacturing and markedly reducing fabrication and assembly errors. Moreover, this design achieves a self-decoupling effect by introducing additional surface-wave coupling to counteract the strong space-wave coupling. Benefiting from the loading effect of the surrounding dielectric medium, the −10 dB impedance bandwidth and half-power beamwidth (HPBW) of the DRA elements are also positively enhanced. For demonstration, a 1 × 8 substrate-integrated DRA (SIDRA) phased array was designed, simulated, fabricated, and measured. The prototype exhibits an 11.4% operating bandwidth, ranging from 23.51 to 26.35 GHz. Within this bandwidth, the average inter-element isolation is approximately 24.1 dB, and the array supports beam scanning up to ±64°.

title: Adversarial Attack Method Against SAR ATR Based on Superimposed Phase Modulation
authors: Junjie Hou, Feng Deng, Gengjiang Yao, Hai Lin, Xiaoyu Chen, Lijie Chen, Yuze Tian, Qijiang Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Adversarial attacks methods against Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) Automatic Target Recognition (ATR) can disrupt adversarial reconnaissance and protect valuable targets. In recent years, several adversarial attack algorithms have been proposed and achieved promising results in generating adversarial examples in the digital domain. Extending these attacks from digital domain to the physical domain remains a critical challenge. In this work, we propose a physically feasible adversarial attack method based on time-varying metasurface. A novel phase modulation technique is introduced to embed the global perturbation information into the radar echo signal, which will transformed into adversarial examples by the adversary’s SAR imaging processor. The resulting adversarial examples can mislead the neural network-based SAR ATR system, thereby achieving the intended adversarial attack. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through theoretical analysis and simulations, and its feasibility is further assessed under different radar operation band.

title: Automated System for the Sanding and Oiling Process of Cachimbo and Huayruro Wood in Dining Table Manufacturing
authors: Richard Bohorquez, Luis Lescano, Luis Sampen
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: In the woodworking sector, finishing operations are critical for ensuring product quality and durability, especially for high-value furniture such as dining tables. However, sanding and oiling of tropical woods like cachimbo and huayruro are still mainly performed manually, causing inconsistent surface finishes and significant health risks due to prolonged exposure to wood dust, a known human carcinogen. Although automation has advanced in cutting and assembly, few integrated finishing solutions are accessible to small and medium woodworking enterprises. Recent research on robotic sanding and UV-curable coatings has demonstrated improvements in finish uniformity and drying efficiency. This paper presents the design and validation of an affordable automated finishing system that integrates multi-stage sanding, precise oil application, UV-accelerated curing, and dust extraction. The system is controlled using a programmable logic controller (PLC) and human-machine interface (HMI) for safe, consistent operation. Laboratory tests with cachimbo and huayruro samples showed a cycle time reduction exceeding 60% compared to traditional methods, with improved finish quality and enhanced occupational safety. The results demonstrate practical feasibility for modernizing manual finishing processes in small tropical woodworking workshops.

title: Problem-Based Learning: A Study on Drone Trajectory Planning for Medical Logistics
authors: André Palharini Nascimento dos Santos, Gabriel Ramires Berle, Fernanda Pinto Mota, Leonardo Martins Brisolla, Daniel Fernando Tello Gamarra, Anselmo Rafael Cukla
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: The shortage of blood in hospital stocks is a critical challenge for the Brazilian healthcare system, especially during emergencies. In this context, the use of drones for blood transportation emerges as a promising alternative, capable of reducing response times and optimizing routes in both urban and remote regions. This paper presents a case study involving Engineering and Computer Science students from public institutions in southern Brazil, using a Problem-Based Learning (PBL) approach. Students were challenged to plan drone trajectories through manual calculations and computer simulations. The results allowed for a comparative analysis of accuracy between the methods and highlighted the pedagogical potential of emerging technologies in training professionals capable of addressing the challenges of medical logistics. The findings also demonstrate the technical and educational feasibility of using drones in the transportation of blood products.

title: ML Aided Dental Diagnosis and Recommendation System
authors: Apurva Shetty, Deepa N Reddy, Chetan Kumar MB, Rohit Chavan M, Roshan HV
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Malocclusion is an important part of dental practice, as it affects both the appearance of the teeth and patient’s ability to bite properly. These conditions may result in impaired mastication, speech problems and a high risk of caries and periodontal diseases. This research work proposes a new approach to malocclusion treatment based on applying such sophisticated computational methods to orthodontic practice. By using machine learning algorithms like; predictive modelling, clustering, and classification, the proposed approach increases diagnostic accuracy and aids in creating treatment plans for the client. They can be used to transport patient particular information comprehensively, enhancing accuracy and cost efficacy in orthodontic treatment. This work intends to combine classical approaches to orthodontics with contemporary computational techniques in an effort to improve efficiency in clinical practice, as well as the quality of treatments offered to patients, and increase the availability of efficient dental alignment correction procedures.

title: Beyond the Pipeline: Analyzing Key Factors in End-to-End Deep Learning for Historical Writer Identification
authors: Hanif Rasyidi, Moshiur Farazi
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: This paper investigates various factors that influence the performance of end - to-end deep learning approaches for historical writer identification (HWI), a task that remains challenging due to the diversity of handwriting styles, document degradation, and the limited number of labelled samples per writer. These conditions often make accurate recognition difficult, even for human experts. Traditional HWI methods typically rely on handcrafted image processing and clustering techniques, which tend to perform well on small and carefully curated datasets. In contrast, end-to-end pipelines aim to automate the process by learning features directly from document images. However, our experiments show that many of these models struggle to generalise in more realistic, document-level settings, especially under zero-shot scenarios where writers in the test set are not present in the training data. We explore different combinations of pre-processing methods, backbone architectures, and post-processing strategies, including text segmentation, patch sampling, and feature aggregation. The results suggest that most configurations perform poorly due to weak capture of low-level visual features, inconsistent patch representations, and high sensitivity to content noise. Still, we identify one end-to-end setup that achieves results comparable to the top-performing system, despite using a simpler design. These findings point to key challenges in building robust end-to-end systems and offer insight into design choices that improve performance in historical document writer identification.

title: Investigation of Enhanced Large-Signal Impulse Amplification in a Wideband TWT_supp2-3633168.txt
authors: Halil Topozlu
abstract: We present results of an investigation of bipolar impulse amplification in a wideband traveling wave tube (TWT), with particular emphasis on the large signal, nonlinear regime. Understanding nonstationary, transient waveform amplification is useful for numerous high-power microwave (HPM) applications. Using particle-in-cell (PIC) simulations and experimental measurements, we characterized and compared the amplification of continuous wave (CW) sinusoidal and bipolar Gaussian impulse waveforms. We measured small-signal gains exceeding 10 dB between 0.3 and 0.9 GHz using impulse excitation. The maximum measured peak instantaneous output power of a negative polarity impulse was almost <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$10\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> higher than the saturated time-averaged power for CW amplification, and almost <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> higher than the saturated peak instantaneous power for CW amplification, i.e., <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.4~\pm ~0.1$</tex-math> </inline-formula> kW versus <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$175~\pm ~25$</tex-math> </inline-formula> W and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$550~\pm ~50$</tex-math> </inline-formula> W, respectively. We also observed impulse polarity dependence of the large-signal impulse amplification, observing a maximum peak power output of a negative polarity impulse almost <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> higher than for a positive polarity impulse, i.e., <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.4~\pm ~0.1$</tex-math> </inline-formula> kW versus <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$550~\pm ~50$</tex-math> </inline-formula> W. These observations are linked to differences in electron trapping and deceleration dynamics. In particular, for the negative polarity impulse, the trailing edge field predominantly decelerates electrons catching up from behind the pulse, resulting in more effective energy extraction. In contrast, the trailing edge of the positive polarity impulse exhibits predominantly accelerating fields, reducing the efficiency of energy transfer. These polarity-dependent effects are not present in CW sinusoidal amplification, for which the electrons become trapped and reaccelerated within each bunch in saturation.

title: Unequal Content: search engine personalization influences exposure to information regarding the Israel-Palestine conflict_supp1-3635871.pdf
authors: Joana Goncalves-Sa
abstract: Search engines serve as primary gateways to information, and users tend to trust them, despite being algorithmic black boxes and customizing results in non-transparent ways. Personalization, such as tailoring content based on a user’s location, is useful for routine content searches (e.g., finding nearby restaurants). However, this same personalization becomes problematic - and potentially harmful - when users seek information on sensitive or contentious geopolitical topics. In this work, we present the first large-scale measurement of how search engine curation and personalization affect users across different countries with distinct regional, political, and cultural traits. We developed a novel, privacy-preserving, bot-based methodology that simulates online user profiles embedded with cumulative regional traits. These customized bots were deployed from different locations and conducted identical searches, either on the Israel-Palestine conflict (e.g. “Hamas”) or neutral queries (e.g. “dinner recipe”), using both Google and DuckDuckGo. Our study addresses two main questions: (1) How do search results for the same query differ across countries, and which factors drive these differences?; and (2) Does personalization vary more significantly for conflict-related or for general queries? Our findings show that search result rankings are significantly influenced by location, interface language, and simulated browsing context, with the strongest effects observed for conflict-related queries. In many cases, these differences led to non-neutral portrayals of the same event, depending on the user’s presumed region. These results highlight how search engine personalization can shape public understanding of global events, creating fragmented or biased informational environments. This underscores the importance of educating users about the invisible filters that influence their access to information and, from a policy standpoint, these findings reveal a pressing need for greater transparency and accountability in how search engines personalize politically sensitive content. This is especially urgent given their outsized role in shaping democratic discourse and public opinion worldwide.

title: Medical Vision-Language Modeling With Semantic Interaction and Adaptive Refinement Prompting for Bias Mitigation
authors: Cheng Li, Weijian Huang, Hao Yang, Jiarun Liu, Yong Liang, Shanshan Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Vision-Language Models (VLMs) have demonstrated impressive capabilities across various medical tasks, including report generation and visual question answering (VQA). However, pixel-level tasks such as image segmentation remain relatively underexplored, despite their critical importance for clinical decision-making, surgical planning, and model interpretability. Moreover, the scarcity of high-quality segmentation annotations in the medical domain often leads to biased data distributions, characterized by imbalances in disease types, anatomical coverage, and image quality. These biases are frequently overlooked during both model development and evaluation, limiting the robustness and real-world applicability of VLMs in healthcare scenarios. In this study, we propose a unified medical vision-language model applicable for a variety of clinical tasks, including report generation, VQA, and pixel-level image segmentation. Within the model, we propose a semantic interaction mechanism aimed at enhancing pixel-level vision and language representation learning. To mitigate the impact of biased data distributions, we explicitly develop an adaptive refinement prompting method involving the iterative re-prompting of hard samples. The proposed method is thoroughly validated through experiments on eight datasets and comparisons with nine state-of-the-art methods. The experimental results indicate that our model achieves superior performance in both medical VQA and segmentation tasks. These results highlight the potential of our approach in advancing the deployment of medical VLMs in real-world clinical applications. Code will be released at: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/SZUHvern/Unified-Medical-Vision-Language-Modeling</uri>

title: TD-SAM: Temporal and Distance-Guided Adaptations of SAM for Accurate Surgical Instrument Segmentation
authors: Cheng Xue, Shiyu Zhao, Danqiong Wang, Cheng Chen, Guanyu Yang, Yang Chen
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurate automatic surgical instrument segmentation plays a crucial role in robot-assisted surgery, but analyzing surgical videos remains challenging due to factors such as rapid instrument movements, high inter-category similarity, and frequent object occlusions. Current surgical instrument segmentation models struggle to capture both inter-frame variations and intra-frame details in complex surgical scenarios. The Segment Anything Model (SAM) has shown significant potential in various segmentation tasks. However, it has not fully addressed the unique challenges posed by surgical videos. To tackle these issues, we propose a Temporal and Distance-Guided SAM model (TD-SAM) for accurate surgical instrument segmentation. Specifically, we introduce a dynamic cross-frame attention module that effectively captures temporal information across frames, allowing the model to track the dynamic changes of surgical instruments and their environment, thus improving segmentation accuracy. In addition, we present a distance-guided instance refinement module, which enhances the model's ability to distinguish between similar categories, mitigating the class ambiguity caused by inter-category similarity. Extensive experiments on the EndoVis18 and EndoVis17 datasets show that the proposed TD-SAM model outperforms existing models, achieving state-of-the-art performance without using any prompts.

title: A unified approach to detect clouds, water and shadows in hyperspectral satellite images - a focus on PRISMA product enhancement_supp1-3635824.pdf
authors: Stefania Matteoli
abstract: The recent advancements in hyperspectral satellite missions have significantly expanded Earth Observation capabilities. Availability of high-resolution hyperspectral data and products thereof, such as those delivered by the PRISMA mission of the Italian Space Agency (ASI), provides unprecedented opportunities for monitoring Earth processes in a wide range of applications. Enhancement of hyperspectral image products plays a crucial role in further increasing data exploitation possibilities. In this work, we propose a unified, physics-based APproAch for joint detection of Clouds, water, and sHadows in hypErspectral images (APACHE), focusing on PRISMA L1 product enhancement. Unlike existing approaches that typically address detection of one individual surface type at a time, our methodology jointly extracts the three surfaces of interest in an automated, stepwise, and unsupervised manner. More importantly, there is no need for parameter tuning, labeled data, or multi-source images. APACHE only leverages spectral properties of clouds, water, and shadows combined with a non-parametric clustering technique. Experimental results on a variety of PRISMA images from diverse datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed methodology in accurately detecting the surfaces of interest, both with respect to state-of-the-art methods and enhancing PRISMA products. On average, APACHE achieves accuracies of 96.42% for cloud detection, 99.23% for water detection, and 97.55% for shadow detection, with improvements ranging from 2% to 30% over the best performing comparison method. These results highlight APACHE potential to improve hyperspectral satellite data exploitation across a wide range of remote sensing applications.

title: Hierarchical Aggregation-Embedded Emergency Scheduling of Coupled Electricity-Watershed Networks With Heterogeneous Flexibility Resources Under Extreme Drought Events
authors: Siyuan Guo, Bin Zhou, Chi Yung Chung, Siqi Bu, Zhihao Hua, Juan Liu, Wei Hu
abstract: This paper proposes a dynamic aggregation- embedded emergency scheduling strategy to coordinate massive heterogeneous flexibility resources of electricity and watershed networks for mitigating power shortages under drought events. Firstly, a thermodynamic model of coupled electricity-watershed networks is formulated to express risk interdependencies of power shortage and water curtailments under high-temperature climates. Then, a hypercube multi-directional inner approximation projection method is developed to evaluate variable water-dependent power dispatchable regions caused by strong couplings and heterogeneity of flexibility resources. Furthermore, a hierarchical interactive emergency scheduling strategy is proposed for coordinated water-energy flexibility enhancement within dynamic aggregated dispatchability boundaries. The proposed strategy has been fully tested and benchmarked on a practical 143-node distribution network coupled with a 14-junction watershed system to validate the effectiveness in mitigating load loss and water curtailments under drought disasters.

title: Learning Generalized Mapping Functions Via Deep-Unrolling for PET Image Reconstruction
authors: Hitesh D. Khunti, Bhaskar D. Rao
abstract: This paper presents a novel unified framework that synergically combines model-based iterative algorithms with deep learning-based approaches for tomographic image reconstruction. In particular, the proposed method integrates the interpretability and adaptability of model-based techniques with the expressive power of deep learning—enabling sophisticated non-linear and data-driven priors that enhance reconstruction quality. This synergy yields a framework that is interpretable, robust, generalizable, and produces higher-quality images, effectively addressing key limitations of model-based and learning-based approaches in isolation. First, we show there exists a simple approach to generalize and accelerate Expectation Maximization algorithms which can adaptively speedup convergence based on individual voxel values. We then introduce a key re-parametrization that enables viewing multiple reconstruction algorithms as special cases of a general mapping function between iterations. Building on these insights, we propose a novel model-based deep neural network architecture that effectively is a generalized deep unrolling of a family of algorithms. The proposed method learns to reconstruct high-quality images by systematically performing the required trade-off across the represented algorithms, or it can learn a specific algorithm through training without compromising its robustness and generalization. Furthermore, to address the scarcity of PET imaging data the proposed method can be trained both in supervised and self-supervised regime. Our approach demonstrates superior adaptation with limited training data across varying noise levels, scan duration and out-of-distribution data. Experimental results show significant improvements in image quality compared to both existing iterative methods and deep learning approaches, while maintaining computational efficiency and theoretical interpretability. The associated code is publicly available online.
