title: A Novel Multi-Granularity Clustering Algorithm Based on Grid Partition and Fuzzy Quotient Space
authors: Xinran Zhou, Qinghua Zhang, Fan Zhao, Yutai Wang, Longjun Yin, Guoyin Wang
abstract: Clustering is a significant technique in data mining, which can uncover the hidden correlation information and obtain deeper understanding of the inherent structure of data. However, when dealing with the data with extremely uneven density and increasingly complex structure, most current clustering algorithms only obtain results at a single granular level, resulting in a unilateral understanding of the data. Therefore, a novel multi-granularity clustering algorithm based on grid partition and fuzzy quotient space (MGCGF) is proposed in this paper. Firstly, by introducing the Gaussian kernel density function to characterize the distribution characteristics of data, a grid partition method is designed to select representative points for clustering. Secondly, based on the results of grid partition, the representative points composed of the maximum density values in each dimension of the grids are used for multi-granularity clustering to improve the clustering efficiency. Finally, a multi-granularity clustering algorithm is proposed by introducing fuzzy quotient space theory with representative points as input. MGCGF can be used to uncover the hierarchical structure of the data itself and form a multi-granularity space. And the clustering results with multi-granularity can be directly provided from multi-granularity spaces without re-clustering. By comparing with the other six clustering algorithms, the feasibility is verified in terms of both efficiency and accuracy.

title: The influence of wavelet vanishing moment order on intelligent detection of voltage swell
authors: Jing Gong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Equipment and Industrial Design (IEID)
abstract: The impact of voltage swell on sensitive equipment is fatal, and accurately detecting voltage swell disturbances is the key to ensuring high-quality electrical energy. When using wavelets for disturbance detection, the vanishing moment order (vmo) of the wavelet directly affects the detection results. The characteristics of vmo are analyzed, and the steps for detecting wavelet modulus maxima of voltage swell disturbance are given. The simulation model is established, and six types of wavelets, Sym3, Sym6, Sym10, Coif5, Bior2.8, and Bior6.8, are used to perform five-scale wavelet decomposition on the original transient disturbance signal. By comparing the modulus maxima under different conditions, it is proved that the vmo is the most important factor affecting the detection effect compared to orthogonality and support length, and the larger its value, the better the detection effect.

title: Condition Indicator Fusion and Machine Learning-Based Severity Assessment of Tooth Breakage Failures in Spur Gearboxes
authors: Antonio Pérez-Torres, René-Vinicio Sánchez, Bernardo Lagos-Álvarez, Susana Barceló-Cerdá
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Gearboxes play a critical role in the industrial sector due to their efficiency in power transmission. Therefore, detecting a failure in advance is essential. This study aims to determine the severity of a gear tooth failure in a spur gearbox through vibration signal analysis. Under laboratory conditions, a pinion's gear tooth break failure was simulated at different severity levels. Four accelerometers were installed vertically on the gearbox to acquire the vibration signal. Vibration signal features were initially extracted using condition indicators (CIs) in the time, frequency, and time-frequency domains. The CIs from the three domains were fused into a database, and dimensionality was reduced by eliminating highly correlated CIs and those with near-zero variance. The classification accuracy for failure severity level was then determined using the machine learning algorithms Random Forest and k-Nearest Neighbours on the reduced database. Finally, a factorial ANOVA test to asses whether classification accuracy differed significantly across the four sensor positions and two models. The results confirmed that the proposed methodology achieves high classification accuracy in determining the severity of a gear tooth break failure in a spur gearbox. Furthermore, sensor placement on the gearbox has a minimal impact on vibration signal feature extraction.

title: AI-Powered Smart Waste Management Systems Using Cloud Analytics
authors: Samit Kumar Singh, Amrita Chaurasia, Aybek Kalandarov Ruzimbaevich, Kavitha G L
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The increasing volume of trash and urbanisation has made it essential for waste management to be innovative, sustainable and effective. This study offers a smart waste management system that optimises garbage collection, sorting & recycling using AI, Internet of Things and cloud computing. Real-time monitoring, automated garbage categorisation, predictive fill-level forecasting & intelligent route planning are possible with a hybrid edge-cloud architecture. Technology improves operational efficiency & environmental sustainability over conventional trash systems by incorporating machine learning algorithms and real-time sensor data. Multi-modal data fusion, scalability, cloud analytics & adaptive feedback mechanisms enable system improvement. Sensor upgrades and staged implementation tactics assist in handling IoT adoption issues, including challenging trash categorisation accuracy and high startup expenses. This comprehensive strategy supports smart city development and global sustainability. Future improvements include blockchain for waste tracking and 5 G-powered edge AI for automatic garbage processing.

title: Multi Head Attention based Convolution Neural Network towards Multi Stage Classification of Alzheimer Disease using Structural Magnetic Resonance Imaging
authors: Mahalakshmi K, Ragul R, Sabarikaran D, Shalini. A
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Alzheimer disease is a serious Neurological disorder which is prevalent among the patients in the age above 60 years and causes chronic health issues in the brain. Especially it destructs memory and thinking skills of the patients. Thus early diagnosis of the disease prevents the patients from the complete destruction of the memory and thinking skills. However many researcher has carried out various approaches using Structured Magnetic Resonance Imaging approaches to observe the structures and its cognitive function in the hippocampus regions of the brain. Despite of several advantageous, those approaches fails to determine the stage of the Alzheimer diseases due to complex structure of the MRI. In this paper, a vision transformer has been employed to convolution neural network to consider deterioration of the brain regions in different stages of the Alzheimer diseases. Initially preprocessing step is employed to eliminate the noise and non-brain tissues like skull of the MRI slices. Next, convolution Neural Network is employed as feature extraction network to segment and extract the features of the entire brain regions. Extracted feature is represented in form of feature map representing the global relationship between different structures of the brain on its characteristics. Multi Head Attention mechanism is used to determine the discriminative features on its weighted representation to Alzheimer disease characteristics through its attention coefficient. Those attention coefficient is processed in the pooling layer to represent its attention map on reducing dimensionality and non linearity of the interactions in the feature map. Finally attention map is processed in the fully connected layer using batch normalization using activation function and disease classification on basis of its disease stages through softmax function. Softmax function uses multiclass support vector machine. It classifies the Alzheimer disease into Mild Cognitive Impairment, Moderate Cognitive Impairment and Severe Cognitive Impairment. Experimental analysis and performance analysis of the proposed architecture is carried out using structured magnetic resonance imaging acquired from GRAD dataset. Model efficiency is evaluated on basis of precision, recall and f measure against state of art approaches. Proposed model produces 98.9% accuracy in staging of the diseases.

title: Predictive Analysis of Consumer Dynamics and Its Strategic Implications for Modern Marketing Practices
authors: Roshan Kumar Shiva, Geetha Manoharan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: With a rapidly changing business landscape, the ability to predict customer behavior has emerged as a strategic requirement for marketers. This study explores the use of predictive analytics driven by artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) procedures in hypothetical marketing strategies. Adopting a descriptive research approach, we gathered primary data through a systematic questionnaire completed by 30 respondents and tested it via Pearson correlation analysis. The results show sharp positive correlations with predictive marketing effectiveness, purchase frequency, and loyalty to a brand, confirming the strategic value of predictive analytics as a means for enhanced customer interest and loyalty. The study also reveals key ethical concerns pertaining to data privacy, transparency, and the responsible use of AI. Marketers are called upon to adopt ethical data governance paradigms and strategically integrate predictive tools to build sustainable, consumer-centric marketing practices. The study proposes directions for future research to tackle sample diversity and investigate advanced predictive models to better understand consumers.

title: Stationary Wavelet Transforms with Binary Trees for Acoustic Emission
authors: Lucas Lisboa dos Santos
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: This work proposes a method for feature extraction from acoustic emission signals using a binary tree structure based on the Stationary Wavelet Transform (SWT). The objective is to differentiate corrosion levels in carbon steel pipelines through multiscale decomposition. Each signal is transformed into 62 components using a SWT tree of depth 5, and basic statistical features (mean and standard deviation) are computed from each node. To evaluate the discriminative capacity of these representations, dimensionality reduction techniques (PCA, UMAP, and t-SNE) and quantitative clustering metrics were applied. Results show that nonlinear approaches, particularly t-SNE and UMAP, are more effective in revealing the separation between low and moderate corrosion signals, highlighting the potential of the proposed method for structural health monitoring applications.

title: Dermoscopic Image-Based Skin Cancer Detection Using a CNN-Driven U-Net Model
authors: K. Guru Joshna Devi, Vamshi Krishna B
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Skin cancer is one of the most serious diseases that people can have. Skin cancer detection is frequently complicated by the present healthcare system, which can result in potentially fatal delays if not detected promptly. Early identification is crucial to a good recovery from skin cancer. Deep learning (DL) algorithms have been a popular approach for detecting skin cancer in recent years. The goal of this research is to use a DL model to create a multi-classification approach for the diagnosis of skin cancer. In this work, we introduce a novel deep-learning skin cancer classification network model, U Net, which is based on convolutional neural networks (CNNs). We evaluate it using three open-source standard datasets: ISIC 2020, HAM10000, and PH2. The Proposed U Net achieved an accuracy of 89.29%, a recall of 84.52%, a precision of 84.56%, and an F1-score of 88% in the classification of the various types of skin cancer. Our suggested UNet model fared better than baseline models, offering dermatologists and other healthcare providers significant support in the study of skin cancer.

title: Enhancing Touchless Sales Inventory and Operation Planning (SIOP) Using Machine Learning for Root Cause Analysis and Risk Mitigation
authors: Sayantani Ghosh, Sai Kumar, Niket Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Manufacturing companies often face complex Sales Inventory and Operation Planning (SIOP) processes involving sales forecasting, distribution planning, production commitments, and procurement across multiple locations. Disruptions like material shortages and synchronization issues can lead to backorders, excess inventory, and obsolete stock, impacting operations and financial performance. Traditional manual root cause identification methods are time-consuming and often ineffective. This paper introduces a Touchless SIOP process, using machine learning (ML) to predict risks, identify actionable areas, and reduce manual intervention. Advanced models like XGBoost and neural networks achieve high accuracy in risk prediction, providing actionable insights months in advance and improving decision-making at a granularity level of DC X Material

title: Quantum-Inspired Computing for Breast Cancer Classification
authors: D.E. Martina Jaincy, Pattabiraman V
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Patients at an early stage, which can help with prompt diagnosis and treatment of the condition. This study utilizes a retrospective cohort design, where health records of patients with and without breast cancer were obtained from a large healthcare database. The data were pre- processed to remove missing values, and feature engineering techniques were used to extract relevant features. The predictive models were created, QSVM, Classical ML models (SVM, Random Forest. The goal of this research was to develop a predictive model for detecting breast cancer early in patients. The models were able to achieve high accuracy, precision, and recall rates, indicating their effectiveness in predicting the likelihood of breast cancer in patients. The model can be used to pinpoint people at high risk for illness development who need additional diagnostic tests or early intervention. The creation of a Breast cancer predictive model using health information is the sole focus of this work. The model can be incorporated into clinical decision support systems. In order to examine the viability of adopting the model in clinical practice, more research is required to validate the model in a variety of demographics and situations.

title: Comparison of Tuning Techniques for PID Controllers in Mobile Robots Using the Empirical Method and the Firefly Metaheuristic Algorithm
authors: Lucas Marchesan da Silva, Enzo Fernando Simão Costa, João Pedro Azenha Righi, Lucas Teles, Thássio Gomes Silva, Daniel Fernando Tello Gamarra, Anselmo Cukla
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Trajectory tracking remains a fundamental chal-lenge in mobile robotics, particularly for non-holonomic differential-drive robots such as those used in the IEEE Very Small Size Soccer (VSSS) competition. This work investigates and compares two control tuning approaches aimed at improving the performance of a VSSS robot in following a predefined path: the Firefly Metaheuristic Algorithm (FMA) and a traditional empirical method. The Bernoulli Lemniscate is adopted as the reference trajectory due to its variable curvature and suitability as a benchmark path in motion control tasks. Simulations in a virtual VSSS environment were conducted to evaluate tracking accuracy and system responsiveness under both strate-gies. Results show that FMA-based tuning leads to significant improvements in trajectory adherence and system stability. This study contributes to a deeper understanding of how systematic optimization methods can enhance control performance in small-scale autonomous robotic systems.

title: An electric vehicle power battery SOH prediction method based on CEEMDAN-LSBoostELM
authors: Jianbang Zeng, Xin Hu, Haoyi Shan, Junyu Liu, Feng He, Xingbing Duan, Yushu Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Equipment and Industrial Design (IEID)
abstract: As the core component of electric vehicles, the SOH prediction of power battery is of great significance to the safety of the whole vehicle operation and battery life. Aiming at the problem of low prediction accuracy of traditional methods under small sample conditions, this paper proposes a CEEMDAN-LSBoostELM prediction model that integrates fully adaptive ensemble empirical modal decomposition of noise (CEEMDNA), least squares boosting (LSBoost), and extremum learning machine (ELM) based on real-vehicle operation data. First, the aging features are extracted based on the capacity incremental analysis, and the features that are highly correlated with SOH are screened by gray correlation analysis as model inputs; second, the SOH sequences are decomposed by using CEEMDAN to extend the feature dimensions; and finally, LSBoost is introduced to improve the stability and prediction performance of the ELM model. The experimental results show that the prediction accuracy and robustness of the proposed model on the real-vehicle dataset are significantly better than those of the CEEMDAN-ELM, ELM, RF, and MLP models, and the prediction errors are no more than 1.2%, which verifies the effectiveness of the feature enhancement and model integration strategy.

title: Enhancing Cybersecurity: Classification and Prediction of Significant Cyber Incidents with an Optimized Seq2seq Model
authors: Ajitha I, A. Devi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: In today's digital age, cybersecurity is of utmost importance to safeguard sensitive information and critical infrastructure from cyber threats. To effectively address this challenge, it is crucial to identify and predict significant cyber incidents promptly. Logarithmic neural networks excel in numerical data processing but struggle with sequential data, while seq2seq models, with their encoder-decoder architectures, are more adept at handling variable-length inputs/outputs, making them superior for sequential data tasks, particularly in NLP (Natural Language Processing) and its associated fields. With this motivation, this research suggests a novel methodology for the classification and prediction of such incidents using an optimized sequence-to-sequence (Seq2Seq) model and named as OSeq2Seq model. The Seq2seq model is a powerful deep learning architecture known for its proficiency in handling sequential data, making it well-suited for cybersecurity applications where understanding the temporal dependencies of events is essential. Furthermore, Orca Swarm Optimization (OSO) employ for hyperparameter tuning for enhancing the efficiency of the Seq2seq framework. The recommended methodology supports for the development of cybersecurity research and also provides valuable insights for developing proactive strategies to mitigate cyber threats and protect critical assets from potential security breaches. Through extensive experimentation and evaluation on real-world cyber threat datasets, the efficiency of the methodology is verified in accurately classifying and predicting significant cyber incidents (SCI) with high precision and recall.

title: Development of an Edge Device for Active Distribution Network Protection in a Multifunctional Laboratory
authors: Luis F. Molina-Antequera, Cesar Orozco-Henao, Mauricio Restrepo, Juan G. Marin-Quintero
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The increasing complexity of active distribution networks (ADNs), driven by the integration of distributed energy resources (DERs), requires advanced protection schemes capable of adapting to dynamic grid conditions. Thus, this paper presents the development and implementation of an AI-based edge device for fault detection and protection in ADNs within a multifunctional laboratory. The proposed system integrates real-time signal acquisition, digital processing, and machine learning techniques to enhance reliability and adaptability. The device effectively detects and classifies fault conditions while ensuring compliance with protection timing requirements. This research contributes to the advancement of intelligent protection systems, providing a scalable solution for modern power grids and a valuable educational platform for training future electrical engineers.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Firewalls to Prevent DDoS Attacks
authors: Gowtham Mamidisetti, C. V. Subhaskara Reddy, Nihal Singh, Kondragunta Rama Krishnaiah, B. Parvathi, Raghavendra Kulkarni
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The biggest threat to network privacy and accessibility right now is the Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack. This is important because online risks are rising and more and more people count in digital services which never stop. For a long period, traditional firewalls have served as border defenses. However, these threats have evolved, and traditional firewalls' strict, rule-based screening methods are no longer sufficient. In this study, firewalls will be tested on a computer in both normal and DDoS cases to see the extent to which they work and how strong they are. A new DDoS Resilience Index (DRI) was added to a Poisson-distributed traffic framework that was used to simulate both normal and attack traffic. Throughput, packet loss rates as well as DRI were used to quantify performance. Based on the calculated DRI of 45.13 percent, the firewall's performance lowered by more than 50% at the attack, indicating a high risk of traffic overload. To check how accurate the classification was, a confusion matrix was employed. The results showed that the accuracy was 75% overall, 63% precise, and 27% false positive, which means that legal traffic might be blocked by mistake. The research results show that traditional firewalls fail in high-attack intensity scenarios and offer credence to next-generation firewalls (NGFWs), which are better at detecting threats and can alter their analysis depending on user behavior. Researchers hope that cybersecurity professionals and network architects will find the study's methodology and evaluation framework for assessing firewall performance valuable as they seek to protect organizations against emerging DDoS assaults.

title: Educational Robotics Practices and Progress in Brazil and Peru
authors: Luiz Marcos Garcia Gonçalves, Luciane Terra dos Santos Garcia, Raquel Esperanza Patiño-Escarcina, Dennis Barrios-Aranibar
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Educational Robotics (ER) has emerged as a dy-namic tool to enhance learning in STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics) education, fostering com-petencies, creativity, and problem-solving skills. Latin America, particularly Brazil and Peru, has seen a growing interest in incorporating ER into school curricula. However, the scale and form of implementation differ significantly between these two countries, especially when looking at public and private educational institutions. This article presents a joint analysis of ER policies, practices, and results in public and private schools in Brazil and Peru. Through examining national initiatives, pedagogical methodologies, and teacher training programs, we elucidate the advancements and challenges in integrating ER into educational systems of both countries. We highlight the challenges, innovations, and educational impacts observed in both nations and provide recommendations for equitable and effective expansion.

title: Early Detection and Analysis of Potato Leaf Diseases Using Deep Learning based CNN Models
authors: Prince Kumar, Anuj, Ragavendra T S, Chinnaiyan R, G. Sabarmathi, Vimal Kumar Khanna
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Potato diseases pose a significant threat to global agricultural productivity, leading to severe economic losses. Early and accurate disease detection is crucial for effective disease management and improved crop yield. This research explores deep learning techniques for automated potato disease prediction using convolutional neural networks (CNNs). A large dataset of potato leaf images is used to train and validate the model, ensuring robustness and accuracy. The proposed deep learning model efficiently classifies common potato diseases, such as late blight and early blight, with high precision. Performance evaluation metrics, include accuracy, The integration of deep learning in disease prediction minimizes the reliance on manual inspection, providing farmers with a cost-effective and scalable solution. Additionally, we analyze the impact of transfer learning and data augmentation on model performance. The results highlight the potential of AI-driven approaches in precision agriculture, offering real-time disease diagnosis and early intervention strategies. This research contributes to the advancement of smart farming technologies, ensuring sustainable crop protection and food security. Future work will focus on optimizing the model for real-world deployment through mobile applications and IoT-based systems.

title: A Systematic Review of Ml in Its: a Taxonomy From Traditional Models to Federated Learning
authors: Mario Steven Vela Romo, Carolina Tripp-Barba, Xavier Calderón Hinojosa, Pablo Barbecho, Luis Urquiza-Aguiar
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Intelligent Transport Systems (ITS) have advanced significantly with the incorporation of machine learning (ML), enhancing vehicular operations, traffic management, and user-centric services. In this study, we present a systematic literature review (SLR) of recent ITS proposals, examining both traditional ML-based applications and those leveraging federated learning (FL). We categorize these applications into three functional areas-road, vehicle, and user-and further distinguish them as “system” (focusing on architectural and operational details) or “model” (emphasizing algorithmic and computational aspects). Additionally, we analyze existing FL-based ITS frameworks, highlighting their architectural choices. This taxonomy clarifies each subdomain's requirements, while the descriptive architectural analysis serves as a basis for evaluating potential transitions from centralized ML to federated approaches.

title: Beyond Charts: A Conceptual Framework for Sketch-based Data Visualisations
authors: Vincent Bonczak, Michel Beaudouin-Lafon, Theophanis Tsandilas
publish: Proceedings of the 36th Conference on l'Interaction Humain-Machine
abstract: Drawing is a direct and expressive way to represent data, limited only by the creator’s imagination. Hand-drawn data visualisations, such as those from the Dear Data project or Data Sketches, stand out for their creativity and for offering compact, original representations of data. However, manually encoding data can be tedious and error-prone. As a result, many creators turn to digital tools to produce their visualisations. Yet, these tools often impose constraints, such as a limited visual vocabulary, that can hinder creativity.

title: Super-Resolution Source Reconstruction Based on Time Reversal With High-Order Kurtosis
authors: Xiao-Yao Feng, Zhizhang David Chen, Yunqi Fu
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: Electromagnetic time-reversal (TR) has emerged as an effective method for source reconstruction. Various algorithms have been developed to address challenges encountered in practical applications. In our previous work, we proposed the electromagnetic kurtosis methods and examined their resolution capabilities with band-limited TR. However, the space and time kurtosis methods need to be more effective for narrowband signals. This letter introduces an extension to arbitrary-order kurtosis, demonstrating its potential to achieve super-resolution performances. Unlike other super-resolution techniques, the proposed method is algorithmically straightforward and does not require subwavelength structures. Numerical experiments demonstrate field concentration beyond the diffraction limit, confirming high-order kurtosis’s ability to enhance the accuracy of TR source reconstruction using band-limited fields. Additionally, its applicability to reconstructing multiple sources is established.

title: Hyperspectral Sensors and Autonomous Driving: Technologies, Limitations, and Opportunities
authors: Imad Ali Shah, Jiarong Li, Roshan George, Tim Brophy, Enda Ward, Martin Glavin, Edward Jones, Brian Deegan
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Vehicular Technology
abstract: Hyperspectral imaging (HSI) is a transformative sensing modality for Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) and autonomous driving (AD). By capturing fine spectral resolution across hundreds of bands, HSI enables material-level scene understanding that overcomes critical limitations of traditional RGB imaging in adverse weather and lighting. This paper presents the first comprehensive review of HSI for automotive applications, examining the strengths, limitations, and suitability of current HSI technologies in the context of ADAS/AD. In addition, we analyze 216 commercially available spectral imaging cameras, benchmarking them against key automotive criteria: frame rate, spatial resolution, spectral dimensionality, and compliance with AEC-Q100 temperature standards. Our analysis reveals a significant gap between HSI's demonstrated research potential and its commercial readiness. Only four cameras meet the defined performance thresholds, and none comply with AEC-Q100 requirements. In addition, the paper reviews recent HSI datasets and applications, including semantic segmentation for road surface classification, pedestrian separability, and adverse weather perception. Our review shows that current HSI datasets are limited in scale, spectral consistency, channel count, and environmental diversity, posing a challenge for perception algorithms development and adequate HSI's potential validation in ADAS/AD applications. This review paper presents the current state of HSI in automotive contexts and outlines key research directions toward practical integration of spectral imaging in ADAS and autonomous systems.

title: Optimal Feature Selection for Distributed Bearing Fault Detection Using Cost-Effective, High-Performance Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: Ramin Rajabioun, Hasan Hataş, Mojtaba Afshar, Özkan Atan, Bilal Akin
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Industrial Electronics
abstract: This study presents a highly accurate and cost-efficient machine learning framework for diagnosing distributed bearing faults by identifying an optimal and compact set of frequency-domain features. The analysis is based on a comprehensive dataset collected from an experimental testbed comprising a coupled induction motor operating under 50 distinct combinations of speed and load. The dataset encompasses both healthy bearings and those exhibiting various distributed faults-such as lubrication degradation, contamination, electrical erosion, and flaking-as well as a localized fault in the form of a single-point defect on the outer race. Data were acquired using a multi-sensor module integrating three-axis vibration, stray magnetic flux, and two phase current signals. The primary objective is to reduce an initial set of 102 frequency-based features to a minimal subset suitable for deployment on resource-constrained microcontrollers without sacrificing classification performance. Employing Mutual Information and Random Forest techniques for feature selection, the study successfully identifies a critical subset of five features. A Random Forest classifier trained on these features achieved an impressive test accuracy of 99.58%. Furthermore, the combination of top-ranked features from both MI and RF methods led to improved classification performance over using either method independently, thereby enhancing the robustness and reliability of industrial bearing fault detection.

title: A Reference-Free Broadband Characteristic Impedance Spectrum Method for Localization of Cable Minor Defects
authors: Yaqiang Deng, Bo Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Frequency-domain reflectometry is an effective technique for localizing minor defects in cables, with the broadband impedance spectrum and reflection coefficient spectrum as the primary analysis targets. A common approach to improve localization sensitivity is to compare the broadband spectra of defective and reference healthy cables. However, obtaining accurate reference healthy spectra is challenging: pre-installation data are not applicable to in-service cables; calculated spectra are highly sensitive to cable parameter accuracy; and for three-phase power cables, data from other phases may not represent the tested phase reliably. To overcome this limitation, this paper proposes broadband characteristic impedance spectrum, which is derived from the impedance spectra under open- and short-circuit terminations, and then a reference-free broadband characteristic impedance spectrum method is proposed to enables the localization of minor defects in cables without requiring a reference healthy spectrum. Minor defects are localized by extracting defect-induced equivalent frequency components from the difference between the broadband characteristic impedance spectrum and its mean-valued constant vector, and then transforming them from the frequency to the spatial domain. The proposed reference-free method is validated through simulation and laboratory experiments, respectively, demonstrating that minor defects can be accurately localized with an error of no more than 0.563%. Since the method relies solely on measurements from the tested cable, it eliminates the need for a prior healthy reference spectrum, thus enabling accurate defect localization under practical applications.

title: Asymptotically Optimal Lifelong Planning with Lazy Edge Evaluation under Expensive Collision Checks
authors: Lu Huang, Jingwen Yu, Jiankun Wang, Xingjian Jing
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Robotic systems operating in dynamic and uncertain environments require motion planners that can rapidly adapt to environmental changes while maintaining safety and efficiency. Frequent replanning is inevitable in such scenarios as obstacle configurations evolve and previously feasible trajectories become invalid. However, real-time replanning remains challenging for many applications due to the high computational cost of collision checking and graph maintenance, especially when edge evaluations are expensive or when the environment changes continuously. The paper introduces an asymptotically optimal lifelong sampling-based path planning algorithm that combines the merits of lifelong planning algorithms and lazy search algorithms for rapid replanning in dynamic environments where edge evaluation is expensive. The algorithm maintains an incremental search graph which is reused throughout the entire navigation process. By evaluating only sub-path candidates for the optimal solution, the algorithm saves considerable evaluation time and reduces the overall planning cost. It employs a novel informed rewiring cascade to efficiently repair the search tree when the underlying search graph changes. Theoretical analysis indicates that the proposed algorithm converges to the optimal solution as long as sufficient planning time is given. Planning results on robotic systems with SE(3) and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">7</sup> state spaces in challenging environments highlight the superior performance of the proposed algorithm over various state-of-the-art sampling-based planners in both static and dynamic motion planning tasks. The experiment of planning for a Turtlebot 4 operating in a dynamic environment with several moving pedestrians further verifies the feasibility and advantages of the proposed algorithm.

title: Trust, Governance, and AI Decision Making
authors: Leah Hoffmann
abstract: IBM’s Global Leader on Responsible AI and AI Governance, Francesca Rossi, arrived at her current area of focus after a 2014 sabbatical at the Harvard Radcliffe Institute, which inspired her to think beyond her training as an academic researcher and incorporate both humanistic and technological perspectives into the development of AI systems. In the intervening years, she helped build IBM’s internal AI Ethics Board and foster external partnerships to shape best practices for responsible AI. Here, we talk about trust, governance, and what these issues have to do with AI decision making.

title: Automated IER: Identification, Extraction, and Refurbishing of E-Waste
authors: Asaad Kaadan
abstract: We propose an automated Identify, Extract, and Refurbish (IER) system that uses old PCBAs and processes them to recycle some of their components. The IER technology can be integrated into traditional e-waste recycling pipelines to precede destructive metal extraction. This will capture more value from each PCBA and enhance recycling efficiency. The proposed system has the potential to bring mass recycling to the electronics industry by providing financial incentives to manufacturers. We estimate that each automated IER machine with 1440 components-per-hour capacity can recycle over six million components per year, pumping $300k+ of recycled value back into the economy and removing 6+ tons of e-waste from the e-waste stream. This paper introduced IER architecture and its components in detail. We discussed machine vision-based classification and identification of components on a PCBA and proposed multiple existing deep learning models as reliable classification methods to detect faulty components exhibiting physical damage marks. We also discussed how best to incorporate Blockchain in the IER system to enhance trust and transparency in the recycling pipeline and certify refurbished components through extensive testing. Finally, we calculated the estimated CapEx and OpEx values of the IER machines at various capacities. We utilized these calculations to perform a theoretical analysis of IER efficiency using real PCBA data and showed that IER can extract up to 100x more financial value than metal-extraction technologies.

title: A quantitative model of takeover request time budget for conditionally automated driving
authors: Foghor Tanshi, Dirk Söffker
abstract: In conditional automation, the automated driving system assumes full control and only issues a takeover request to a human driver to resume driving in critical situations. Previous studies have concluded that the time budget required by drivers to resume driving after a takeover request varies with situations and different takeover variables. However, no comprehensive generalized approaches for estimating in advance the time budget required by drivers to takeover have been provided. In this contribution, fixed (7 s) and variable time budgets (6 s, 5 s, and 4 s) with and without visual imagery assistance were investigated for suitability in three takeover scenarios using performance measures such as average lateral displacement. The results indicate that 7 s is suitable for two of the studied scenarios based on their characteristics. Using the obtained results and known takeover variables, regression models were trained under different conditions to estimate the time budget required. The applied algorithms include XGBoost, support vector machines, random forest, and linear regression. Three of the algorithms namely XGBoost, support vector machines, and random forest perform well with the full feature set alongside hyperparameter turning. When behavioral and performance features were eliminated, only XGBoost performed well on the applied data yielding an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of approximately 99 %. The results of this contribution are relevant to safety for takeover maneuvers in conditionally automated driving.

title: Absolute Distributed Temperature Measurement with $\upmu$K Noise Level and Fast Response via Raman/Rayleigh Backscattering DTS/DTGS Data Fusion
authors: Danilo Fernandes Gomes, Beatriz Brusamarello, Guilherme Heim Weber, Yannik Schick, Daniel Rodrigues Pipa, Marco José da Silva, Jean Carlos Cardozo da Silva, Sérgio Taveira de Camargo Júnior, Manoel Feliciano da Silva Junior, Cicero Martelli
abstract: This work presents a hybrid approach for distributed temperature measurement, integrating a DTS (Distributed Temperature Sensing) system, based on Raman backscattering, and DTGS (Distributed Temperature Gradient Sensing), based on Rayleigh backscattering. The proposed adaptive fusion algorithm integrates the accumulated average of the DTS signals with the fast variations captured by the DTGS, enabling the reconstruction of thermal profiles with enhanced accuracy and capacity for absolute measurements and fast temporal response. The approach was experimentally validated in a controlled thermal environment, demonstrating good agreement with reference sensors and standing out for its stability and sensitivity. The findings suggest that the DTS/DTGS fusion represents a promising solution for applications necessitating distributed thermal measurements with high reliability.

title: Graph Attention Networks-Enabled Load Balancing for 6G Heterogeneous Networks with Parallel Transmission
authors: Han Ji, Xiping Wu, Zhihong Zeng, Xiong Deng, Chen Chen, Cheng-Xiang Wang
abstract: Hybrid light fidelity (LiFi) and wireless fidelity (WiFi) networks are promising heterogeneous networks (HetNets) in 6G and beyond, attributed to the complementary physical properties of optical spectra and radio frequency. However, the current physical-layer deployment of such HetNets is mainly bottlenecked by the conventional serial transmission (ST) mechanism, which restricts each user equipment (UE) from connecting multiple access points (APs) at a time. While the ongoing investigation on parallel transmission (PT) can bring significant benefits, it complicates the network topology of HetNets, making existing load balancing (LB) learning models less effective. Driven by this, we propose a graph attention network (GAT)-based model to tackle LB in PT-supported HetNets (PT-HetNets), which results in a partial mesh topology. Such a topology can be modeled as a graph, embedding the channel state information and data rate requirement as node features, with the LB solutions deemed as edge labels. Compared to the conventional deep neural network (DNN), the proposed GAT-based learning model exhibits two key strengths: i) it can better interpret a complex network topology; and ii) it can suit various numbers of APs and UEs with a single trained model. Simulation results show that against traditional optimisation methods, the proposed learning model can achieve near-optimal network throughput within a gap of 11.5% while reducing the inference time by 4 orders of magnitude. In contrast to the DNN model, this novel method can improve the network throughput by up to 21.7%, at a similar level of inference time.

title: Operation and Design of Dirac-Source FETs Using Ab Initio Transport Simulations: Subthreshold Swing and Drive Current
authors: D. K. Nguyen, A. Pilotto, D. Lizzit, M. Pala, P. Dollfus, D. Esseni
abstract: This article investigates the operation and design of Dirac-source FETs (DSFETs), by using ab initio transport simulations based on the NEGF formalism, which seems appropriate given the novelty of the physics and of the device architecture introduced by DSFETs. In particular, we first discuss the limitations in terms of drive current of DSFETs based on a graphene-MoS<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> van der Waals heterojunction. Then, we propose a novel p-type DSFET based on hydrogenated graphene (HGr). Our simulation results suggest that the HGr-DSFET has a robust sub-60 mV/dec operation and an <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-current between <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$4\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> larger than the graphene-MoS<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> DSFET counterpart. Our study investigates the influence on the device operation of several material and design parameters, using either ballistic simulations or simulations accounting for electron–phonon scattering.

title: Electrochemical Non-Volatile Memory Based on MnO Electrochromic Windows_supp1-3635599.pdf
authors: Andrew C. Meng
abstract: Electrochemical non-volatile memory (NVM) devices are promising for neuromorphic computing applications due to their low power consumption and multi-functionality. We report a novel electrochemical NVM device based on reversible MnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> electrodeposition and dissolution that exhibits two distinct resistance states and multiple optical states. The device shows stable resistance states without any degradation for more than 500 cycles with more than 1 year data retention and capability for long-term device operation. UV-Vis absorption spectra through electrodeposited MnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> of different thicknesses demonstrate multiple optical states achieved through resistance changes in a photoresistor. The device shows excellent reversibility in electrical conductivity and optical absorption states between dissolution and deposition. Additionally, the device can demonstrate uni-polar potentiation and depression that closely resembles the gradual, tunable synaptic response of biological neurons.

title: A Tightly Coupled Adaptive EKF for Indoor 3D Positioning with Linear Acceleration Compensation
authors: Lei Yao, Leehter Yao, Shahaboddin Resalati, Yeongwei Andy Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This paper presents a novel and robust 3D localisation approach that tightly integrates ultra-wideband, inertial measurement unit, and magnetometer data to achieve high-precision attitude and 3D position estimation. In contrast to existing methods, which often fail to account for the impacts of significant translational motion or are only effective under small linear accelerations, this work introduces a linear acceleration compensation method that dynamically adjusts measurement uncertainties in real-time. This method addresses a critical limitation in previous approaches, enabling higher accuracy during significant motion. The proposed method leverages two extended Kalman filters (EKFs): six degrees of freedom EKF for attitude estimation and nine degrees of freedom EKF for 3D position estimation, which are coupled for enhanced performance. The experimentally validated results show that the proposed method significantly outperforms state-of-the-art techniques, achieving root mean square errors of 1.96 degrees for attitude estimation and 0.57 m for position estimation, while reducing computational complexity by 58.32%. This approach excels in challenging indoor environments with mixed line-of-sight and non-line-of-sight conditions, demonstrating its robustness and applicability to real-world scenarios. This work presents a significant advancement in the field of 3D localisation, offering both theoretical contributions and practical improvements over existing systems.

title: Calli-VA: A Visual Analytics System for Analyzing and Comparing Chinese Calligraphic Styles_supp2-3634633.pdf
authors: Jincheng Li
abstract: Chinese calligraphy is a quintessential element of Chinese cultural heritage. Analyzing and comparing calligraphic styles not only enhances the appreciation, learning, and advancement of calligraphy but also provides valuable insights into ancient China. However, such analysis remains challenging due to the limited scalability and possible inconsistencies of qualitative methods, as well as usability and misalignment issues in conventional quantitative approaches. We propose Calli-VA, a visual analytics system, to address these challenges. Calli-VA extracts character images and their corresponding strokes from original works and characterizes each character using systematic criteria. During analysis, the system defines the analysis scope by overview and uncovers relationships between characters. Explanation and recommendation mechanisms are integrated to help users understand patterns and guide further exploration. A documentation feature allows users to record and share their findings. We demonstrate the effectiveness of Calli-VA through three case studies and expert feedback.
