title: A Systematic Review of State-of-the-Art TinyML Applications in Healthcare, Education, and Transportation
authors: Chaymae Yahyati, Ismail Lamaakal, Yassine Maleh, Khalid El Makkaoui, Ibrahim Ouahbi, May Almousa, Ahmed A. Abd El-Latif
abstract: Tiny Machine Learning (TinyML) has emerged as a transformative paradigm enabling machine learning inference directly on ultra-low-power microcontrollers and edge devices. As AI expands beyond cloud computing to resource-constrained environments, TinyML offers promising solutions for latency-sensitive, bandwidth-efficient, and privacy-preserving applications. This paper presents a Systematic review of state-of-the-art TinyML applications across three critical domains: healthcare, education, and transportation. By analyzing 136 peer-reviewed publications from 2020 to 2025, we identify key trends, representative use cases, and the enabling technologies that support domain-specific deployments. Our review evaluates software frameworks, hardware platforms, model optimization techniques (e.g., quantization, pruning, and neural architecture search), and real-world deployment challenges such as energy consumption, memory limitations, and explainability. We further synthesize the metrics used to assess TinyML systems and highlight open research questions. Unlike previous surveys, our domain-centric approach offers a deeper contextual analysis of how TinyML is being adapted to solve real-world problems across diverse sectors. We conclude by outlining future directions and practical insights to guide researchers and practitioners in designing scalable, resilient, and ethically grounded TinyML systems.

title: An Information-Theoretic Analysis for Federated Learning under Concept Drift
authors: Fu Peng, Meng Zhang, Ming Tang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Recent studies in federated learning (FL) commonly train models on static datasets. However, real-world data often arrives as streams with shifting distributions, causing performance degradation known as concept drift. This paper analyzes FL performance under concept drift using information theory and proposes an algorithm to mitigate the performance degradation. We model concept drift as a Markov chain and introduce the Stationary Generalization Error to assess a model's capability to capture characteristics of future unseen data. Its upper bound is derived using KL divergence and mutual information. We study three drift patterns (periodic, gradual, and random) and their impact on FL performance. Inspired by this, we propose an algorithm that regularizes the empirical risk minimization approach with KL divergence and mutual information, thereby enhancing long-term performance. We also explore the performance-cost tradeoff by identifying a Pareto front. To validate our approach, we build an FL testbed using Raspberry Pi4 devices. Experimental results corroborate with theoretical findings, confirming that drift patterns significantly affect performance. Our method consistently outperforms existing approaches for these three patterns, demonstrating its effectiveness in adapting concept drift in FL.

title: Multi-UAV and Hybrid NOMA-Enabled Edge Learning System: Joint Resource Allocation and 3D-UAV Placement Design
authors: Rui Fan, Jianxin Liu, Zhiguo Xu, Zhigang Wen
abstract: The rapid development of technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI), mobile edge computing (MEC), and the Internet of Things (IoT) has given rise to the emergence of edge AI as a new communication paradigm. Edge learning (EL), a core component of edge AI, faces significant challenges due to limited computational and communication resources, particularly in the data-sharing mode. To address these two issues, this paper introduces the multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and hybrid orthogonal frequency division multiple access-nonorthogonal multiple access (OFDMA-NOMA) technologies into the EL system, resulting in a new system, namely, the multi-UAV and hybrid OFDMA-NOMA-enabled EL system. In the proposed system, each UAV is equipped with an edge-learning server to collect data from Internet of Things devices (IoTDs) and accomplish its respective learning task. The system aims to maximize the minimum F-measure — an effective metric for evaluating learning model performance — across all tasks by jointly optimizing IoTD transmit power, UAV working times, UAV three-dimensional placement, and the Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA) decoding order. In order to solve this intricate nonconvex problem, this paper decomposes it into four subproblems and solves them iteratively using an alternating optimization (AO) framework until converged results are obtained. The successive convex approximation (SCA) and grid search techniques are also employed in this process. The simulation results show the proposed scheme's convergence and reveal its superior performance against several other benchmark schemes.

title: The Software-Defined Vehicle: A Comprehensive Study on Current Trends and Challenges
authors: Johannes Stümpfle, Johannes Sigel, Matthias Weiß, Baran Can Gül, Falk Dettinger, Nasser Jazdi, Max Hoßfeld, Michael Weyrich
abstract: The automotive industry is undergoing an extensive transition from hardware-centric development to softwaredefined vehicles (SDVs). This paradigm shift requires innovative technical solutions and fundamentally different approaches for vehicle design. Together, these developments introduce substantial challenges for an entire industry, affecting both development processes and operations. Although SDVs have attracted considerable attention and widespread industry involvement, prior research has primarily emphasized systematic literature reviews identifying emerging academic trends. Consequently, little attention has been paid to industry and economic developments that influence how SDV technologies evolve in practice and are crucial for future advancement. In response, this paper provides a different, industry-oriented view of the current trends and associated challenges of SDVs. To achieve this, we conducted a comprehensive analysis of the SDV from an industry-based perspective. We analyzed three sources of information to identify the current trends in SDV development: expert interviews with automotive IT specialists, a study on major automotive trade fairs and workshops, and insights gained from the authors' professional experience. Based upon, we derive specific challenges arising from these trends. Our findings offer a comprehensive overview of the present SDV landscape, trends and challenges, and serve as a foundation for future research efforts in this rapidly evolving field.

title: A Multi-Sensor Fusion Localization Method to Enhance Autonomous Navigation in Off-Road Environments_supp1-3634116.mp4
authors: Bo Zhang
abstract: This paper develops a real-time localization framework based on multi-sensor fusion for the autonomous navigation of mobile robots in challenging off-road environments. The proposed framework employs a hybrid coupling strategy at its front-end, which integrates Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) data with Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) and LiDAR. As a consequence, GNSS Inertial Odometry (GIO) and Lidar Inertial Odometry (LIO) are created and these are crucial for achieving precise localization in real-time. The RGB-Height-Intensity descriptor is used to improve the precision of loop closure detection while maintaining search efficiency. This is achieved by integrating surface reflectance data from the LiDAR intensity channel and RGB data from camera images. Finally, in the back-end procedure of this framework, the accuracy of posture estimation is enhanced by the optimization of odometry and loop closure factors. Additionally, a framework of real-time localization and autonomous navigation is developed and implemented on a wheeled robot to verify the proposed real-time localization framework. The experimental results indicate the framework exhibited higher performance in off-road environments, where conventional localization techniques generally degrade.

title: Experimental Evaluation of DE-SPECT: A Hyperspectral SPECT System for Region-Selective 3-D Gamma-Ray Spectroscopy
authors: Yifei Jin, Elena Zannoni, Poopalasingam Sankar, Feng Zhang, Michael Streicher, Hao Yang, Zhong He, Scott D. Metzler, Chi Liu, Albert J. Sinusas, Lingjian Meng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radiation and Plasma Medical Sciences
abstract: This study presents an experimental evaluation of the Dynamic Extremity SPECT (DE-SPECT) system, specifically engineered for precise, regionselective gamma-ray spectroscopy in the diagnosis of Peripheral Vascular Disease (PVD) in lower extremities. The system incorporates Cadmium Zinc Telluride (CZT) imaging spectrometers and dynamic dual-field-of-view (FOV) collimators to facilitate comprehensive, multifunctional molecular imaging. The CZT detectors, with Depth of Interaction (DOI) capabilities, deliver an exceptional energy performance across a wide energy range up to 600 keV. The novel dual-FOV aperture system allows selective imaging with two configurations: a 28-cm diameter wide FOV suitable for dual-leg or scout imaging and a 16-cm diameter high-resolution, and high-sensitivity (HR-HS) FOV designed for single-leg or focused imaging. Utilizing uniform phantoms, resolution phantoms, and multi-tracer phantoms, we experimentally assessed the system’s sensitivity, spatial resolution, and multi-tracer imaging capabilities. Spatial resolutions were approximately 6 mm in HR-HS-FOV mode and between 8 mm to 10 mm in wide-FOV mode. Peak-to-Valley ratios, indicative of image clarity, improved with enhanced DOI resolutions, rising from 1.03 to 1.22. The system’s ability to perform multi-tracer imaging, essential for deriving multifunctional molecular information, further highlights its potential to significantly enhance diagnostic accuracy for PVD.

title: RDS-NeRF: Residual and Depth Supervision Neural Radiance Field for Multi-Scene 3D Reconstruction of Satellite Images
authors: Haiyan Pan, Guolin Wu, Zhonghua Hong, Shijie Liu, Huan Xie, Yusheng Xu, Zhen Ye, Yuming Xiang, Xiaohua Tong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Digital Surface Models (DSMs) extracted from multi-view satellite images have extensive applications in the filed of photogrammetry. Although Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF) has shown significant potential in 3D reconstruction, most existing NeRF methods for satellite scenes adopt an end-to-end single-branch network structure, making it difficult to achieve fine-grained modeling of multiple complex terrain simultaneously, and performs poorly in weak-texture regions. Meanwhile, deep MLP structures are prone to information degradation during feature transmission, further affecting the completeness and accuracy of DSMs. To address these challenges, we propose RDS-NeRF, a novel NeRF framework integrating residual feature enhancement and depth supervision. The method introduces a residual feature enhancement structure to alleviate the problem of information degradation during feature transmission in the network and improve the model’s ability to model local details and low-texture regions. Additionally, estimated depth maps are incorporated as global geometric priors to guide the network in constructing more accurate and complete 3D structures. Experiments on the WorldView-3 satellite imagery datasets across multiple typical land cover types (building, road, water body, and vegetation) and complex scenes integrating multiple land features demonstrate that RDS-NeRF outperforms mainstream methods in terms of DSM accuracy, completeness, and novel view synthesis quality. Ablation experiments further validate the complementarity and effectiveness of the residual enhancement and depth supervision mechanisms across different scene types. In conclusion, RDS-NeRF provides a new and effective solution for generating high-quality DSMs from satellite imagery with adaptability to multiple scenes. Code will be available at https://github.com/dfsvdgf/RDS-NeRF.

title: Automated Detection and Classification of Complex Non –Compliance practices in digital Terms of Service using Multi Attention Convolution Neural Network
authors: S. Kokila, D. Kerana Hanirex
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Due to exponential growth online platform and its service accelerates increase in wide range of user and business through digital terms of services, thus it becomes mandatory to identify legal and illegal practices in those digital terms of services. Traditionally many researchers has designed and implemented their solution on leveraging machine learning and deep learning architectures to identify and classify the illegal practices in digital terms of services between the user and platforms. Despite of many advantages, those models suffers to handle to evolving and complex legal aspects in the digital terms of services. In order to mitigate those challenges, a new deep learning architecture is designed and it is entitled as multi attention convolution neural network towards automatic detection and classification of the evolving complex non- compliance practices of digital terms of services of digital platforms. Initially dataset pre-processing is performed out using stop word removal, stemming, Tokenization and Token Weighting –Term Frequency. Weighted Token is organized as feature vector were employed to the Multiattention Convolution Neural Network. Convolution layer of the model processes feature vector using kernel function to extract the semantic and contextual features with respect to legal aspect and generates the feature map. Those contextual features were processed in max pooling layer of the model with attention mechanism to capture of the significant conceptual and semantic features to be get organized in form of the feature map. Attention coefficient of the attention mechanism calculates the weight of the feature on multiple aspects. Finally significant conceptual and semantic features in form of feature map is processed in activation layer to linearize the feature map and those linearized feature map is applied to softmax function composed of random forest classifier to detect and classify the evolving and complex non compliances terms of services along loss function utilizing cross entropy model to eliminate the over fitting and underfitting issues. Extensive experimental analysis of the proposed model using TOS dataset in python environment proves that model is high efficient in detecting evolving and complex non-compliance TOS statements and performance model of the proposed model against conventional model using confusion matrix to test data proves its increased accuracy of 98.7% and efficiency against evolving TOS.

title: YoloV10 based Graph Convolution Network towards Disease Stage Classification of Alzheimer Disease using Structural Magnetic Resonance Imaging
authors: Mahalakshmi K, Ragul R, Sabarikaran D, Shalini. A
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Alzheimer disease is a complex neurological disease occurs in brain which causes memory impairment and cognitive challenges. According of wealth health organization (WHO), it is considered as chronic disease as slowly degrade the brain function and it predominately affects the memory and thinking skills of the patients. Further it leads to loss of brain tissues on formation of amyloid plague and aberrant protein deposit which is considered as abnormal protein. Thus it requires special attention to discover the Alzheimer disease in early stages to reduce the oxidative damages. Those information causes continuous decline of cognitive function over time. In particular, many researchers have initiated early diagnosis methods of the Alzheimer diseases using Structured Magnetic Resonance Imaging to observe the structures and its cognitive function in the hippocampus regions of the brain. However those approaches fail to discover amyloid plague deposition as it helps to determine the stage of the disease accurately. In this paper, a yolov10 model has been employed to graph convolution network to consider the deposition of the aberrant protein and amyloid plague in the hippocampus regions of the brain which categories the stage of the Alzheimer disease. Initially preprocessing step is employed to enhance the contrast of image and to eliminate the noise and non-brain tissues like skull on the MRI slices. Those preprocessed image is applied to the Yolov10 model for segmentation of the disease region with bounding box representation. Bounding box of the disease region indicates the aberrant protein and amyloid plague deposits. Those segmented region is projected to the graph convolution network. In this architecture, segmented region is transformed into graph structure with node representing pixels and edges mentioning associations. Transformed graph data is processed using adjacency matrix in the convolution layer of the network to extract the features and establish a non-linear graph embedding. Further grapy pooling layer of the model process the non-linear graph embedded features to produce the linear high level graph features. Finally fully connected layer utilizes the softmax function to classify the linear graph embedded feature into diseases classes of Alzheimer disease into stages as Mild Cognitive Impairment, Moderate Cognitive Impairment and Severe Cognitive Impairment. Experimental analysis and performance analysis of the graph convolution network architecture is performed using structured magnetic resonance images acquired from GRAD dataset in the python environment. Model produces the 99.1% accuracy in multiple disease stages and it proved to be outperforming compared to conventional approaches.

title: Efficient Scheduling of Smart Contract Transactions via Conflict Graph Coloring
authors: Ankit Ravish, Yaron Hay, Piduguralla Manaswini, Rishabh Jain, Roy Friedman, Sathya Peri
publish: 2025 IEEE 30th Pacific Rim International Symposium on Dependable Computing (PRDC)
abstract: A smart contract is a special type of transaction designed for the execution of automated logic on blockchains. Alas, smart contracts transactions are one of the major hindrances to blockchain throughput. Hence, improving the execution time of smart contracts is a prime challenge for Blockchains at large. To that end, concurrent execution of smart contract is an appealing direction, which has been adopted by several contemporary Blockchains like Solana, Aptos, Sui, Sei, and Monad. Executing smart contracts in parallel requires applying deterministic concurrency controls based on ensuring consistent ordering of all conflicting transactions in all miners/validators. Existing implementations rely on the Block's total ordering to resolve this requirement. Recently, it has been suggested that relying on minimal coloring of the conflict graph corresponding to the Block's transactions can provide a better performance potential, yet without any evaluation. In this paper, we compare between approaches to smart contracts parallelization. Our study’ finds that in many situations, indeed the coloring-based ordering leads to significantly better performance than the Block order preserving approach. However, this gain has its limits, and it is not always guaranteed. In particular, the results are largely dependent on the conflict ratio in the conflict graph and the type of application.

title: Detection of Potato Crops in Advanced Vegetative Stage Using Sentinel 2 with Remote Sensing in the Peruvian Andes
authors: Patricio Pizarro Carrillo
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: In Peru, 9,856 hectares of potato crops were lost between planting and harvesting during the 2022/2023 agricultural season. This highlights the limited monitoring that occurs through traditional, labor-intensive methodologies that require significant human resources (surveyors), time (transportation), and financial resources (logistics) for conducting in situ agricultural surveys. Consequently, agricultural observation reports are restricted by the lengthy timelines associated with traditional methodologies, which impairs real-time monitoring capacity. Therefore, the objective of this research is to develop a machine learning classification model capable of detecting potato crops in advanced vegetation stages using Sentinel-2 spectral imagery. The study involved building an agricultural area dataset using georeferenced polygons. These polygons were subsequently used to compile a gallery of Sentinel-2 spectral images for the 2022/2023 season. Pixel processing methods were applied through spectral bands to filter out cloud cover, and vegetation indices were calculated as supplementary attributes. Finally, positive (potato crops) and negative (other crops and agricultural areas) classes were created to train the XGBoost, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machine models. The best-trained model was SVM with an F1-score of 0.85, demonstrating its robust ability to distinguish potato crop vegetation from other agricultural areas. This study represents an initial step toward the detection of georeferenced crops in Peru, aiming to establish a foundation for future research on plot-level productivity assessment and the formulation of precise agricultural policies to strengthen national production.

title: Eco-Friendly Thermal Panel for Low-Cost Housing in Cold Climates
authors: Lilian Ingaruca Paredes, Jesús Cardenas Quispe, Valkiria Ibárcena Ibárcena
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This research examines the artisanal use of local recycled materials to create an ecological panel with thermal properties, consisting of recycled cardboard, guaipe, gypsum, and an additive. Employing a quasi-experimental, quantitative methodology, the study analyzes the panel's physical, mechanical, and thermal characteristics. Results show that a panel made with 40% recycled cardboard and textile fibers, combined with 60% gypsum and water, demonstrates low thermal conductivity, which is advantageous for temperature regulation and heat loss reduction. The study demonstrated the effectiveness of the material in humid environments and its fire benefits, despite it being flammable. It also achieved better thermal optimization.

title: Analysis of the Automation of the Commercial and Distribution Process in the Footwear Sector of Ambato
authors: Brandon Trujillo, Germania Vayas-Ortega, Juan Carlos Suárez-Pérez, Marco Antonio Ríos
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Digital transformation integrates advanced technologies to optimize efficiency and enable automation without human intervention, thereby facilitating decision-making. Organizations rely on operational processes that structure and streamline internal activities, enhancing both productivity and performance. Currently, innovation and automation contribute to reducing errors, optimizing resource use, and ensuring quality in the delivery of products and services. This study analyzes the application of technologies, automation, and commercial and distribution processes, all of which are essential for managing sales operations and ensuring efficient product delivery. To assess the level of automation within organizations, an initial instrument comprising 40 questions was applied. However, it yielded a Cronbach's Alpha of 0.764, leading to its rejection due to insufficient reliability. Following a literature review, relevant technologies and tools used in organizational, commercial, and distribution processes were identified. Based on this analysis, a new instrument was developed, consisting of 32 questions and 172 items. This revised instrument underwent expert validation and achieved a reliability coefficient of 0.862, indicating high internal consistency. The instrument's applicability was tested through a pilot study involving 35 footwear companies located in Ambato, Ecuador. The results reveal that, although the use of technology demonstrates a positive correlation with customer growth (0.242), the influence remains modest. Moreover, the automation of commercial and distribution processes does not exhibit a statistically significant relationship with customer growth. These findings suggest that digitalization efforts alone are not sufficient to drive business expansion. Instead, they must be complemented by more effective marketing and commercialization strategies to fully capitalize on the potential of digital tools and automation.

title: Novel Algorithm For Diverse Artist Recommendation Using Artificial Intelligence Techniques
authors: Palavadi Baleeshwar, Yerramsetty Venkatasai Madhav, Voluvolu Pranathi, Sharanya Tirunagari, Shanmugasundaram Hariharan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Major labels along with mainstream artists currently dominate the present music areas leading underrepresented independent musicians and artists to face constant difficulties in visibility. A recommended system will use music metadata alongside user listening behaviors and social media patterns to find hidden independent musicians. A recommendation system applies both content-based filtering to music items and contextual data examination throughout its operation. Content-based filtering stands as the main component in the proposed recommendation system because it uses music tracks' fundamental features to build personalized recommendations. Tests and user surveys confirmed that the system fulfilled its objectives by raising access for minority artists along with maintaining user contentment ratings. The research introduces a scalable musical recommendation system capable of supporting diverse music while encouraging inclusivity to the field of music recommendation systems. Through the proposed system listeners can discover underrepresented musical talent as the system provides them with access to a more diverse listening experience.

title: Business Project for the Creation of a Multivitamin Product for Children with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder Using Design Thinking, Lean Startup, and Scrum in Metropolitan Lima
authors: Annie Samantha Arcelles Saavedra, Clarisse Alina Danieli Saldarriaga, Mercedes Cano Lazarte
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is a neurodevelopmental condition that becomes evident from childhood through adulthood. In recent years, the prevalence rate of ADHD has increased by approximately 8 %. People with this condition experience various symptoms such as difficulty staying focused on a task for extended periods, trouble socializing, lack of coordination, impulsiveness, among others. Some of these symptoms are not properly treated according to the specific type of disorder. Therefore, this study aims to improve the well-being of children through a multivitamin product by applying methodologies such as Design Thinking, Lean Startup, and Scrum. These approaches allow for strategic focus by understanding the user's needs and problems, and by developing an innovative and impactful solution. As a result, a business model was created that includes nutrients which help reduce symptoms in neurodivergent children.

title: Transforming Engineering Education with Hands-On Robotics: The IEEE RAS-UNB Experience
authors: M. A. Pastrana, Nícolas Y. Gomes, Roberto De Souza Baptista, Daniel M. Muñoz
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: The growing disinterest of engineering stu-dents in control theory and robotics, combined with the gap between theory and practice in traditional teaching methods, motivated the creation of an innovative approach by the IEEE RAS student chapter at the University of Brasilia. The goal was to develop and imple-ment a practical STEM-based methodology integrating teaching, research, and outreach through the use of real, accessible robotic platforms. The methodology was applied in four distinct projects-VSSS, EVAIMARIA, Edubot, and UnBeatables-involving undergraduate and graduate students in activities such as prototype con-struction, participation in robotics competitions, and scientific production. As a result, there was a significant increase in student engagement, membership growth, the publication of seven papers at IEEE international conferences, and the development of low-cost educational robots with high replicability potential. The implemented methodology proved effective in promoting interest in the field and can be adapted by other institutions, contributing significantly to strengthening engineering education and training new researchers.

title: Agile Business Intelligence for Dynamic Market Conditions
authors: Somesh Kumar Sahu, Senthilkumar Ranganathan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: In the rapidly evolving business environment of today, conventional Business Intelligence (BI) systems are not agile enough to support real-time decision-making. Agile Business Intelligence (Agile BI) fills this gap by combining Agile principles with BI practices, allowing organizations to react promptly to changing market conditions. This paper discusses the ideas, advantages, disadvantages, and facilitating technologies of Agile BI, based on real-world implementations in industries like retail, finance, and healthcare. It illustrates how Agile BI enables proactive, data-driven decision-making and ongoing improvement. Two case studies show its effect: a multinational FMCG company turned around falling regional sales with fortnightly sprints and iterative dashboards, gaining an 18% increase in sales and a 75% decrease in reporting latency. A healthcare startup applied Agile BI throughout the pandemic to refresh hospital resource dashboards in real time, reducing patient admission delays by 40%. These examples highlight the potential of Agile BI to provide real-world benefits using adaptive planning and interactive analytics.

title: Support System for Creating Medical Incident and Accident Reports Utilizing Two Types of Medical Accident Databases
authors: Koichi Bando, Kenjiro Inaba, Sachiko Honda, Tetsuro Yumoto, Atsunobu Sagara, Kenji Tanaka
publish: 2025 IEEE 30th Pacific Rim International Symposium on Dependable Computing (PRDC)
abstract: In numerous fields, accident information is collected and utilized to prevent accidents that have a significant impact on society. In the medical field, numerous hospitals have been collecting and accumulating accident information to prevent medical accidents and their recurrence. However, owing to the large volume of collected information, it is difficult to say that safety management personnel are making sufficient use of it. This study aims to develop a system that allows reporters to easily utilize accumulated previous cases when creating incident and accident reports. The past cases used in this system are a large-scale medical accident database created based on the Japan Council for Quality Health Care's medical accident database, and a hospital's own database. Using these two databases, incidents and accidents can be compared to determine if they are unique, new, or similar, aiding in improvement measures. As a deep learning model, we implemented our own Near-Miss BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers), confirming the contextual advantage of BERT. This paper presents an overview of this system, the advantages of using these databases, and the evaluation results and their analysis.

title: Mini Autonomous Car Driving Based on 3D Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Pablo Moraes, Monica Rodriguez, Kristofer S. Kappel, Hiago Sodre, Santiago Fernandez, Igor Nunes, Bruna Guterres, Ricardo Grando
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Autonomous driving applications have become increasingly relevant in the automotive industry due to their potential to enhance safety, efficiency, and user experience. Nevertheless, building reliable systems remains challenging because of the complexity of neural models, long training times, and difficulties in generalization. Mini Autonomous Cars (MACs) provide a practical and cost-effective testbed, enabling rapid prototyping and evaluation of learning-based driving algorithms in scaled-down environments. In this work, we present a methodology for MAC autonomous driving based on RGB-D data and Three-Dimensional Convolutional Neural Networks (3D-CNNs), evaluated against Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) in two simulated tracks with distinct levels of complexity. Each model was trained and tested over 30 autonomous laps and assessed by lap time, variability, and track deviations. The results indicate that a reduced 3D-CNN architecture delivers the best performance on the visually complex Mini Monaco track, whereas a GRU-based RNN achieved the fastest times on the simpler Generated track. To further analyze robustness, we conducted an ablation study on the 3D-CNN. Interestingly, the version with fewer convolutional layers outperformed deeper variants, highlighting that reduced complexity can improve stability and generalization in challenging environments. These findings provide practical insights for selecting neural architectures in embedded implementations, balancing performance, robustness, and computational cost. title: A Theoretical Exploration of Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) in E-Commerce Fraud Detection: Paradigms, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: Meghana K A, S. Aarif Ahamed
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The meteoric rise of e-commerce has brought unparalleled convenience to consumers but also opened the floodgates to sophisticated fraud schemes. In this rapidly evolving digital marketplace, traditional fraud detection methods often fall short. Artificial Intelligence (AI) has stepped in as a game-changer, yet its "black-box" nature leaves critical questions unanswered: Why did the AI flag this transaction as fraudulent? Can we trust its decision? This is where Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) emerges as a beacon of clarity. This paper embarks on a theoretical journey into the role of XAI in e-commerce fraud detection, examining Its potential to transform the way fraud is detected and mitigated. We explore leading-edge techniques like SHAP (Shapley Additive Explanations) and LIME (Local Interpretable Model-Agnostic Explanations), unravelling how they transform opaque models into transparent decision-making allies. Beyond just theory, we analyse the real-world integration of XAI, emphasizing its ability to enhance user trust while preserving the high accuracy demanded by e-commerce platforms. However, the road to adopting XAI is not without hurdles. From computational complexities to ethical dilemmas surrounding fairness and bias, and the challenge of making explanations accessible to non-experts, the journey is complex. Looking ahead, we chart a future where XAI becomes indispensable— powered by innovations in hybrid modelling, ethical AI frameworks, and collaborative development across industries. Through this exploration, we illuminate XAI’s profound promise: a future where fraud detection is not only intelligent but also transparent, fair, and deeply human-centric.

title: Solar PV: A Promising Solution to Meet Energy Demand in Isolated Communities
authors: Kristy Vera Onofre, Lizbeth Flores-Bastidas, Juan Lata-García, Gary Ampuño
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The world's population has increased at an unprecedented rate in the history of humanity, to meet energy needs fossil fuels have been used, increasingly scarce, with volatile prices, not to mention all the environmental pollution caused by the use and emission of greenhouse gases. One of the problems of population growth in developing countries is poverty, health and lack of access to electricity, especially in rural or isolated communities. In this work the use of a new source of renewable generation such as photovoltaic solar is proposed, for the specific case of Ecuador the current situation, public policy, regulations and statistics are reviewed together with the SWOT analysis where the privileged position of the sun with respect to the country receiving a high energy potential is highlighted. To complete the study, 4 locations with the highest energy potential are selected according to the Solar Atlas, the simulations are carried out in the PVsyst software to meet a demand of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$56.9 \text{kWh} / \text{mth}$</tex> belonging to a family in a rural community, despite being close to the equator, one of the locations receives <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1741 \text{kWh} / \mathrm{m} 2 / \text{mth}$</tex>, while Loja receives 2309.3 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{kWh} / \mathrm{m} 2 / \text{mth}$</tex>. The study serves as a basis for decision- making and change of the energy matrix, especially for communities that are isolated, being the starting point for its development.

title: Design of a Robotic Arm System for Pipetting and Sample Handling in Drug Susceptibility Experiments with Mycobacterium Tuberculosis Bacteria
authors: Santiago Baldeon, Roberto Furukawa
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: The increasing prevalence of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR- TB) has intensified the need for laboratory systems capable of handling Mycobacterium tuberculosis samples with high biosafety standards. This paper presents the design of a mechatronic system for automating drug susceptibility tests (DSTs) through the manipulation and pipetting of bacterial samples using a robotic arm. The system integrates a robotic arm mounted on a linear rail, a custom-designed gripper for sample tube and Petri dish handling, and an automated pipetting module. The entire process is enclosed within a Class II biosafety cabinet. 3D models of the mechanical components were developed and analyzed with a finite element analysis software to ensure structural integrity under operational loads. The control system, based on a PLC architecture, coordinates the interaction between subsystems and provides a user-friendly interface via an HMI. Preliminary simulations confirm the system's operational feasibility, indicating a significant reduction in biohazard risk and an increase in process repeatability. The proposed system offers an innovative approach to automate high-risk microbiological procedures in TB diagnostics.

title: Data Science Framework for Evaluation of Entrance Exams and Identification of Academic Patterns
authors: Luciana N. Huertas-Condori, Silvana B. Cabana-Yupanqui, Israel N. Chaparro-Cruz, Americo Chaparro-Guerra
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This study proposes a machine learning-based data science framework for evaluating the predictive validity of university entrance exams, focusing on first-semester academic performance across multiple cohorts. Using admission and academic records from 4,534 students at Jorge Basadre Grohmann National University (2017–2019), we constructed supervised learning models that control for instructor grading bias by engineering bias-resilient performance indicators. A broad set of classification and regression algorithms was benchmarked under 8-fold cross-validation, and feature importance analyses were applied to extract interpretable academic patterns. Results confirm that entrance exams, when evaluated through bias-controlled models, exhibit strong predictive capacity, with the overall entrance test score consistently emerging as the most influential feature. Subject-specific importance varied systematically by academic discipline, reinforcing the validity of track-specific cognitive profiles. This framework demonstrates how machine learning methods can enhance the fairness, validity, and analytical depth of entrance exam evaluations, offering a scalable and interpretable methodology for data-driven admission process improvement.

title: A New Technology for Termite-Proof Underground Cables: Proposing Novel Solutions
authors: Gianfranco Di Lorenzo, Erika Stracqualursi, Rodolfo Araneo, Riccardo Cecere, Paolo Audisio, Elisabetta Bragagni Capaccini
abstract: This article highlights the significant termite damage problem affecting buried power lines in utility-scale photovoltaic (PV) plants. It emphasizes the risks posed by insulation failures, which can lead to service interruptions and damage to equipment, as documented in a real example plant in Brazil. The article outlines the required tests to identify the failure points critical for preventing further damage. The authors propose various solutions to mitigate the problem, including Tratos’ development of a reinforced medium-voltage (MV) cable designed to withstand damage from termites and rodents. This cable includes a specialized fiberglass covering, which has been tested at the solar facility. It showed promising results in preventing damage and improving the overall durability of the system. By addressing this issue, the article contributes to advancing infrastructure resilience in solar energy systems, making them more reliable.

title: A high quality factor QCM humidity sensor based on liquid damping isolation strategy of silica supported GO film
authors: Xinglin Yu, Kun Tang, Xinpeng Chen, Xiaoyu Li, Deng Long, Sihan Ma, Wentao Li, Xing Ding
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) sensors have garnered significant interest in humidity sensor filed due to the excellent advantages of nanogram-level theoretical mass resolution and digital frequency output, etc. However, a key limitation is the substantial energy dissipation in high humidity detection, which results in a low quality-factor (Q-factor), thereby restricting sensitivity and measurement accuracy. To address this issue, we developed a high-Q humidity sensor utilizing a liquid damping isolation strategy. In this design, the graphene oxide (GO) humidity-sensitive layer is supported and isolated by hydrophobic SiO₂ spheres, forming a SiO₂/GO bilayer structure. Experimental results demonstrate that the SiO₂/GO bilayer QCM humidity sensor achieves a high Q value of 66,084 at 97% RH, which is three times greater than that of the pure GO QCM sensor and surpasses previously reported values, demonstrating the excellent stability and the effectiveness of the proposed liquid damping isolation strategy for fabricating a high Q-factor QCM humidity sensor. In addition, the SiO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>/GO bilayer structure QCM humidity sensor suggested an ultrafast recovery time (＜1 s), good short-term and long-term stability. Based on the outstanding high humidity resistance, the sensor was applied for stable human breath monitoring. This work not only provides a novel idea and valuable reference for high performance QCM sensor fabrication, but also provides a reliable way for human health monitoring based on QCM humidity sensors.
