title: Proposed Model to Improve Efficiency in a Textile SME Through the Application of TPM Tools with an IoT-Based Approach
authors: Axel Leonardo Huallpa-Palomino, Joseph Geanpierre Sanchez-Chiza, José Luis Alvarez-Arteaga, Luis Enrique Peña-Mendoza
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: The textile industry plays a critical role in the global economy. In this context, small and medium-sized manufacturing enterprises (SMEs) have shown notable growth, yet they continue to face significant operational challenges-particularly delays in order fulfillment. These delays are primarily attributed to recurrent machinery breakdowns and high rates of defective products. To address these issues, this study proposes an integrated model that combines tools from Planned Total Productive Maintenance (TPM) with an Internet of Things (IoT)-based approach, along with Autonomous TPM to reduce failure frequency, and Standard Work to minimize variability and product defects. The implementation of this model aims to enhance machine availability and standardize production processes. The effectiveness of the model was measured using the Production Efficiency indicator, which improved significantly from 66.6% to 78.1 %. Beyond solving the specific challenges of the case study company, this work aims to serve as a replicable framework for addressing operational inefficiencies and improving delivery performance across the textile sector.

title: Data Sharing Scheme in 6G VANET Along with Private Set Intersection for Privacy Protection
authors: S. Menaka, B Santhosh Kumar, Pothala Mutyalu Naidu, R. Senthamil Selvan, Basi Reddy.A
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks (VANETs) are vital for enabling real-time communication between cars, hence enhancing safety, traffic management as well as autonomous driving. With the development of sixth generation (6G) wireless networks, which offer ultra-reliable low-latency communication (URLLC), immense connection & high information throughput, VANETs' data-sharing skills have greatly enhanced. Nevertheless, there are significant privacy and safety concerns linked with the routine transmission of susceptible sensitive data in contexts including fast-moving vehicles. Traditional cryptographic methods are either ineffective or insufficient when applied to the limits of 6G virtual area networks (VANETs). To resolve this problem, the study suggests a way to share data safely & privately that relies on Private Set Intersection (PSI). This would allow cars to safely discover things that are similar in their data, like occurrences & dangers without providing information that isn't correlated. The approach integrates reward systems to encourage truthful data exchange with an adaptive feedback model to identify and detect harmful behavior. Additionally, the system employs cryptographic primitives that are well-suited to resource-constrained automotive contexts for data deduplication of data transactional validation as well as lightweight certification. The result of the proposed study shows that our method reduces the communication overhead by 38% as well as storage by 31% compared to other methods. The system ensures end-to-end latency remains under 80 Ms in environments with 1000 cars, while attaining a misinformation detection accuracy of 92% using Integrated trust scoring & voting mechanisms. These findings provide information on the scalability of the method, as well as its efficiency in real time and its strength in privacy. This research demonstrates that PSI, when integrated with incentive-aligned distribution and verification methods, provides a feasible option for safe & efficient data transmission in 6G VANETs.

title: Technological Surveillance for Sustainable Innovation in the Dairy Industry: Trends, Challenges, and Strategic Pathways Toward 2030
authors: Gary Davis Plasencia-Terán, Carlos Guillermo Hernández-Cenzano
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: This study applies a structured technological surveillance methodology to examine global scientific and technological trends in dairy production and alternative products, focusing on their implications for the Peruvian dairy sector by 2030. Using a sequential explanatory mixed-method design, the analysis draws on patent data, peer-reviewed publications, and market reports to identify key drivers of disruption, notably the rise of plant-based and synthetic milk alternatives. The findings reveal a marked increase in research and development activities related to sustainability, nutritional enhancement, and production efficiency. The study also identifies emerging technologies with high potential for local adaptation and competitive advantage. Based on this evidence, a strategic action framework is proposed, integrating sustainability principles, innovation in processes and products, and alignment with public policy. The results underscore the relevance of technological surveillance as a decision-support tool for anticipating sectoral shifts and guiding adaptive strategies in response to global trends.

title: Decarbonization of the Fertilizer Industry Through Process Innovation
authors: Lina Maria Guevara Marin, Jorge Luis Del Rio-Cortina, Rita Cecilia De La Hoz Del Villar
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The global fertilizer industry faces a dual challenge: maintaining innovation to ensure agricultural productivity and reducing its carbon footprint in line with sustainability commitments. This tension forces the sector to rethink its production strategies through clean technologies and more efficient processes.

title: Modal Abstractions for Smart Contract Validation
authors: Javier Godoy, Margarita Capretto, Martín Ceresa, Juan Pablo Galeotti, Diego Garbervetsky, César Sánchez, Sebastián Uchitel
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems (MODELS)
abstract: Smart contracts manage valuable assets, and their immutability hinders bug fixing. Therefore, pre-deployment verification and validation are critical. In fact, auditing has become mandatory in the pipeline of smart contract development. Auditors usually combine manual inspection with automated tools in their auditing work, looking for issues that may be domain dependent (i.e., pertaining to the correct implementation of requirements-which are often informal, partial, and implicit) or independent (e.g., reentrancy, overflow, etc.), To identify domain dependent issues, it is important to understand the non-trivial behavior of the implementation over sequences of calls made by callees playing different roles in the contract. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that combines predicate abstraction with modal transition systems to build abstractions that can help auditors in the smart contract validation process. The required inputs are a set of predicates provided as code and, optionally, constraints over smart contract function parameters. The output is a modal transition system that captures the contract's behavior. We report on a prototype that builds modal abstractions and an evaluation on two established benchmarks where we identified four previously unreported issues.

title: Operational Evaluation of Algorithms for Online Streaming Continual Multi-Label Classification
authors: Hugo Peuzet, Pascale Kuntz, Frank Meyer, Vincent Lemaire, Killian Le Mau
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Recent progress has been made in the field of multilabel streaming classification, where an instance can be associated with several labels simultaneously. Most recent research has focused on adapting models to the dynamic distribution of nonstationary data streams. However, continual learning is not only adaptation to concept drift: phenomena such as catastrophic forgetting, as well as forward and backward transfers, appear when new classification tasks are introduced in the data stream. This paper aims to develop a standardized and operational evaluation protocol specifically adapted to the study of these phenomena, in order to identify the most promising strategies for this new multi-label, multi-task learning problem on tabular data stream. This protocol, which is reproducible, fair, and flexible enough to allow the simulation of a large number of scenarios, includes the creation of multi-label and multi-task streams, and an evaluation protocol for measuring (a) online performance, (b) phenomena linked to continual learning and (c) resources consumed. It is tested to compare 18 continual multi-label classification strategies on 6 open literature datasets and 3 simulated datasets. This exploratory analysis has enabled us to identify the promising nature of neural networks coupled with data replay.

title: Cyber Threat Intelligence Analytics: Leveraging Machine Learning
authors: Rekha C, Usha J
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Integrating Machine Learning (ML) into modern threat intelligence enhances organizational readiness against cyber threats. ML utilizes data analysis and predictive analytics to detect and mitigate threats effectively. ML's deep learning techniques detect anomalies and deviations from normal system behavior, aiding in threat prevention. However, challenges such as data quality issues and privacy concerns exist. Addressing these challenges through Explainable AI and advanced behavioral analytics can improve ML's transparency and effectiveness in cybersecurity. Organizations should leverage ML in cyber threat intelligence for automated risk identification and response.

title: Scaling CodeSourcerer: Cloud-Native Test Generation with Kubernetes and Helm
authors: Manikanta Prasad J, Puneeth Yogeesha, Archana P, Anser Pasha C A, Keerthishree B T, Shruthi G K
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The increasing complexity of software systems demands efficient and scalable solutions for automated testing. CodeSourcerer, an AI-driven test generation system, addresses this need by integrating seamlessly into GitHub CI/CD pipelines. Unlike traditional approaches that focus solely on test quality, this paper emphasizes the deployment and operational scaling of CodeSourcerer. We detail its architecture, highlighting containerized deployment models, webhook-based GitHub integration, and retry-driven resiliency mechanisms. Our system ensures that generated tests are not only accurate but also efficiently produced and delivered within CI/CD workflows. We further explore strategies for concurrent handling of multiple pull requests, dynamic resource allocation, and system robustness under varying workloads. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that CodeSourcerer maintains high reliability and fast turnaround times even under load, making it a practical and scalable choice for modern DevOps pipelines. This paper provides critical insights into designing and deploying AI-based automation tools at scale in software development environments.

title: Development of a Magnetic Climbing System in Ventilation Ducts for Internal Cleaning Purposes
authors: Herber Aquiño, Fabrizio Chunga, Ayrton Nieves, José Carrizales, Luis Sampen, Mirko Klusmann
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of an autonomous climbing robot aimed at the internal cleaning and inspection of rectangular ventilation ducts in healthcare facilities (like HVAC system). These ducts, often neglected due to inaccessibility and operational constraints, accumulate particulate matter and biological contaminants that can compromise indoor air quality and increase the risk of hospital-acquired infections (nosocomial infections). Existing cleaning methods are labor-intensive, costly and require system shutdowns. The proposed robot integrates a magnetic adhesion system optimized for vertical surfaces guided by a LiDaR sensor for autonomous travel. A comparative analysis of various magnetic adhesion mechanisms informed the development of a hybrid design capable of adapting to duct curvature and irregularities. Preliminary tests demonstrated that each magnet exerts a magnetic force of 2.52N, and that a force of 29.43N is required to properly attach the system to the duct. This requires 12 magnets in constant contact for the system to function properly. This work offers a cost-effective, scalable, and minimally disruptive solution for duct sanitation in critical infrastructure, contributing to better air hygiene in high-risk healthcare environments.

title: Robotics and AI as Resources for Teaching Geometry in Argentine Secondary Schools
authors: Verónica Parra, Ana Corica, Juan Manuel Toloza, Luis Berdún, Silvia Schiaffino, Daniela Godoy
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: This work presents a proposal for Geometry teaching in secondary schools in Argentina using robotics and Artificial Intelligence (AI) as class resources. This proposal is materialized via a Mathematics problem that involves concepts such as distance, symmetry and turn angles. The algebraic solution to this problem, in its most general version, is complex for the secondary school level, since it involves two variable functions and their derivatives. However, a simplified version can be used at this level enabling the use of robots to explore the problem as well as to provide a solution in the learning context and according to the background of students.

title: The Disruptive Impact of Artificial Intelligence in the Mexican Labor Market: Barriers and Opportunities
authors: Jessica Lopez-Garcia, Esperanza Marique Rojas, Eduardo Ahumada-Tello, Rodolfo MartínezGutiérrez, Juan Antonio Meza-Fregoso
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is redefining the dynamics of modern workplaces across multiple industries, transforming tasks, roles, and required competencies. While global reports highlight both the opportunities and challenges brought by AI, the contextualization of its impact in emerging economies like Mexico remains limited. This study addresses this gap by analyzing how professionals perceive the influence of AI on labor performance, job security, and readiness in various industrial contexts. As the adoption of AI accelerates across sectors, it becomes crucial to understand not only the technological aspects but also the human perceptions associated with this transformation. This paper focuses on employee experiences and attitudes toward AI implementation, offering insights that can guide corporate strategy and public policy across a range of industries.

title: Literature Review on Use of Chatbots as an Internal Work Tool in Organizations
authors: José Ramón Blanco Espinoza, Dra. Nora del Carmen Osuna Millán, Carlos Alberto Flores Sánchez
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Chatbots are increasingly recognized as powerful tools in organizational contexts, yet academic literature has largely concentrated on their external, consumer-facing applications. This systematic literature review assesses the extent of research dedicated to internal chatbot applications aimed at enhancing employee productivity, reducing costs, and optimizing operational processes. A sample of 500 articles from the IEEE Xplore database, classified using advanced Natural Language Processing (NLP) models (GPT-3.5 Turbo, GPT-4o mini, GPT-40, and BART), revealed a significant research gap: only 17% of articles focus on internal applications, while 83% prioritize external uses such as customer service. The analysis further demonstrated the superior accuracy of the GPT-4o model in classifying chatbot application types, indicating a potential methodological direction for future research. This study highlights the under-explored potential of chatbots as internal tools within organizations and suggests avenues for future investigation into their application and effectiveness.

title: A Comparison of Different Architectures for AI-Powered Virtual Assistants
authors: Kenneth Barrios Quiroga, Adrián Pabón Mendoza, Samuel Solano Celis, César Viloria-Núñez, Christian G. Quintero M
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: This paper presents NAIA, an AI-powered virtual assistant designed for university environments. NAIA integrates large language models, computer vision, voice processing and 3Ddigital avatars for immersive interactions across five roles: researcher, recepcionist, skills trainer, personal assistant, and university guide. To define the most suitable architecture to build an assistant, two solutions are proposed: 1. own architecture implementing multiple technologies that allow the proposed tasks to be carried out. 2. OpenAI assistant architecture called Realtime in which the platform is responsible for performing other processes, which simplifies the architecture and deployment of the system. Parameters such as cost, latency and memory management are evaluated in this study. Results demonstrate that Redis-based caching reduces response latency by 23.8 % compared to traditional database operations, while the Resume method achieves optimal token reduction for efficient context window management, offering significant performance improvements for real-time virtual assistant interactions.

title: UniNorte STEM Campus Experience: Practical Strategies to Foster Engineering Vocations
authors: Jose D. Soto, María G. Calle, Diana Rueda-Delgado, Ingrid Oliveros, Margarita Narducci, Lacides Ripoll
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: This paper presents the implementation and impact of the UniNorte STEM Campus Model as a strategy to promote STEM education among high school students. The initiative aims to increase enrollment in electrical and electronics engineering programs through interactive workshops, school visits, and collaboration with educational institutions. The methodology involves hands-on learning experiences and skill-based competitions, fostering interest in STEM fields. Results indicate a significant increase in student engagement and enrollment rates. The study highlights best practices for designing effective STEM outreach programs.

title: An Integrated Anime Streaming and Merchandise Platform: Enhancing User Experience Through AI and Community Engagement
authors: Dhanalakshmi B K, Ayush Kumar Mahato, Bikram Agrawal, Aditya Dhanraj, Farhan Ahmed
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The anime industry is rapidly evolving, with millions of fans engaging in streaming and purchasing related merchandise. This paper proposes the development of a unique anime streaming platform that enhances viewer experience by integrating AI-powered object recognition and merchandise recommendations based on scenes in the anime. This innovative approach allows users to shop for featured products without interrupting their viewing experience. Unlike traditional platforms that rely on advertisements or subscription fees, our revenue model is based on affiliate merchandise sales. In addition to streaming, the platform incorporates social features to foster community interaction, including forums for discussions, a reels section for sharing favorite scenes, and customizable merchandise inspired by trending anime moments. The ultimate goal is to create a comprehensive ecosystem where fans can watch, shop, discuss, and share, thereby boosting user engagement, increasing merchandise sales, and cultivating a loyal, interactive fan base.

title: Satellite-Connected Buoy for Environmental Monitoring in Remote Andean Reservoirs
authors: Jonathan G Catari-Alanoca, Monica C. Santa-Maria, Felipe de Lucia Lobo, Ronny Gonzales, Renato D. N. Ardiles, David C. Ardiles-Saravia
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This work describes the design, construction and testing of a floating system (BUOY), containing electronic instrumentation, control software, satellite communications, and an autonomous power system, to measure various variables associated with water quality in high altitude water reservoirs. The system was design and tested in lotic systems around the city of Arequipa, Peru. Sensors were installed to measure dissolved oxygen, conductivity, temperature, and pH, as basic water quality parameters, and set to introduce phycocyanin and chlorophyll a in a future development. Data was recorded in real time and stored in a memory system. This information was simultaneously transmitted via satellite telecommunication to be made available in real time via the World Wide Web. The system was estimated to operate autonomously for 5 days on battery alone, or indefinitely with at least 1–2 hours of effective daily solar irradiation, sampling hourly for 15 min. On-field measured parameters were comparable to those obtained with an YSI Exo1 multiparameter.

title: Travel Itinerary Generator: A Web Application for generating itinerary using ML
authors: Raja Himana, Vishnubatla Akhila Sree, Yellannagari Bhanu Prakash Reddy, Sesadri U
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Traveling across is a chance to clear our mind, embrace new tradition, culture. It helps us to adapt to new surroundings and gain insights from experiences of different people. For many, travelling is a passion, But the planning process can often be complex that we might end up cancelling it. So having a travel itinerary helps us in many ways. Traditional itinerary generators mostly refer to the online reviews which may not meet our individual constraints. Having a personalized itinerary generator is more effective, because we mention our preferences, budget and also availability of time. When an itinerary is generated on user’s preferences, one can enjoy the trip to the fullest. This project uses a Hybrid model to present an itinerary generator. The system integrates content-based filtering for new users and collaborative filtering to deliver personalized recommendations achieving a balanced accuracy of 90-95% and it outperforms the K-means (60 -65 accuracy). A personalized itinerary generator is the best way to ensure a satisfying and seamless travel experience for users.

title: Stock Movement Prediction with Artificial Intelligence-Based Cognitive Analysis
authors: K Sasi Kala Rani, M Anirudhan Prisha, Rajesh Sharma R, Sujan Prakash P, Sonali N, Akey Sungheetha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: One of the most important research areas in financial markets is stock trend prediction. Stock trend prediction: predicting the future price ups and downs of a stock. The traditional models that were used mainly depended on previous price data, but recent studies have shown that combining external factors with these models significantly improves the prediction. This research intends on showing how sentiment analysis can be used to predict stock trends. In these case, news articles, social media posts, or financial statements are the NLP tools analysis these and come up with a few steps. In casual language, the understanding of sentiments from all these sources of unorganized texts is the basis for affective and psychological impacts on investor behavior. The amazing concept explains in detail to combine sentiment signals with already going-on price of data for the purpose of predicting stock trends. Thus, it is still possible for companies to come up with even better stocks prediction strategies that are consistent and adaptable, because both quantitative and qualitative inputs are used.

title: Scalable Deep Subspace Clustering Network
authors: Nairouz Mrabah, Mohamed Bouguessa, Sihem Sami
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Subspace clustering methods face inherent scal-ability limits due to the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O(n^{3})$</tex> cost (with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> denoting the number of data samples) of constructing full <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n\times n$</tex> affinities and performing spectral decomposition. While deep learning-based approaches improve feature extraction, they maintain this computational bottleneck through exhaustive pairwise similarity computations. We propose SDSNet (Scalable Deep Subspace Network), a deep subspace clustering framework that achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{O}(n)$</tex> complexity through (1) landmark-based approximation, avoiding full affinity matrices, (2) joint optimization of auto-encoder reconstruction with self-expression objectives, and (3) direct spectral clustering on factorized representations. The framework combines convolutional auto-encoders with subspace-preserving constraints. Experimental results demonstrate that SDSNet achieves comparable clustering quality to state-of-the-art methods with significantly improved computational efficiency.

title: Data Extraction Techniques in Social Media to Detect Public Opinion on Forced Migration: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Katherynne Plessmann, Margarita Ramírez Ramírez, Josue-Miguel Flores Parra, Miguel Lopez-Montiel
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Social media has evolved into a crucial source of data for analyzing opinions and social trends. However, the application of data extraction techniques to study public perception of forced migration remains an underexplored field. This study conducts a systematic literature review to identify the most commonly used methodologies for data extraction from social media to analyze public opinion on migration. A total of 35 selected articles were analyzed using a structured search process inspired by Kitchenham's methodology, with well-defined inclusion and exclusion criteria. The results indicate that official APIs have been the predominant method for data extraction, although Web Scraping has emerged as a complementary technique, enabling the extraction of data from platforms that do not provide open API access. These findings can support the development of data-driven strategies to monitor migration trends and inform public policies aimed at refugee integration.

title: Impact of Primary Tasks on Soft Shape-Change Perception on a Smartwatch
authors: Fouad Gasmi, Zhuzhi Fan, Céline Coutrix
publish: Proceedings of the 36th Conference on l'Interaction Humain-Machine
abstract: Smartwatches have become integral to receiving notifications during everyday tasks, helping users stay connected, reduce anxiety about missing important information, and support their well-being. While emerging technologies offer novel notification experiences, how effectively they perform when users are engaged in primary tasks remains unclear. This study examines the notification performance of a recently developed pneumatic soft curvature-changing smartwatch. Through an experimental investigation, we measured users’ absolute detection threshold (ADT) for notifications while they performed cognitive and physical tasks. Results show an ADT of 5.70 psi (round curvature) and 6.22 psi (pointy curvature) during a cognitive task and an ADT of 8.07 psi (round curvature) and 10 psi (pointy curvature) during a physical task. These findings provide valuable insights for designing future shape-changing notification smartwatches to improve user experience and enhance task compatibility.

title: From Supervision to Manual Operation: Towards Flexible Control of Drone Fleets for Search and Rescue
authors: Lorélia Latarche, Christophe Jouffrais, Jérémie Garcia
publish: Proceedings of the 36th Conference on l'Interaction Humain-Machine
abstract: Fleets of drones are actively being explored for search and rescue (SAR) missions to accelerate the exploration of large areas and support the delivery of supplies. However, the dynamic and unpredictable nature of these operations makes the automated planning and control difficult. We conducted interviews with four SAR professionals to identify critical scenarios and interaction needs at different levels of control. We then designed a virtual reality prototype allowing the planning, supervision, and manual takeover of a drone fleet during search missions. An exploratory study with five drone pilots evaluated the proposed interactions and helped identify design opportunities for such systems. Our results highlight the importance of enabling smooth manual takeover and the challenges of monitoring and controlling the fleet simultaneously. We discuss implications for the design of future SAR multi-drone systems.

title: Passive Intermodulation Prediction and Cancellation Based on Nonlinear Compensated LSTM
authors: Yingyi Lang, Tuanjie Li
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: Aiming at the problem of passive intermodulation (PIM) interference in communication system, this letter proposes nonlinear compensation long short-term memory (NCLSTM) based on long short-term memory (LSTM) for PIM prediction and cancellation. NCLSTM designs hybrid gate and nonlinear compensation gate. The hybrid gate can avoid the gradient conflict by regulating the dynamic fusion ratio between the historical state and the current input. The nonlinear compensation gate explicitly integrates the generalized memory polynomial (GMP) into the NCLSTM unit, which enhances the ability of NCLSTM to capture high-order nonlinear features. The experimental results show that the prediction accuracy of NCLSTM is better than the existing prediction methods, and the best prediction accuracy can be obtained by adjusting the memory depth and nonlinear order in NCLSTM. The PIM cancellation system based on NCLSTM can effectively suppress PIM interference by 41 dB.

title: CAFNet: Complementary Attention Fusion with Class-Level Alignment for Land Cover Classification
authors: Ke Yu, Gongbo Zhao, Feng Wang
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Multimodal land cover classification has become a research hotspot in remote sensing image interpretation, where optical and synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imagery are widely studied due to their complementarity. However, existing methods suffer from over-reliance on fused features and overlook single-modality representations. This limits their adaptability to varying observation conditions. To address this, CAFNet is proposed, which integrates channel complementary coordinate attention (C3A) and cross-spatial fusion (CSF) to enhance spatial-channel feature modeling and improve the ability to capture complementary information between modalities. Additionally, class-level feature alignment (CLFA) introduces auxiliary supervision to improve unimodal feature learning and model robustness. Experiments on WHU-OPT-SAR and PIE-RGB-SAR datasets validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, achieving the best overall performance compared with representative approaches.

title: Mutual Masking and Perceptual Simultaneity in Electrical Muscle Stimulation and Vibration Haptics_supp1-3635040.pdf
authors: Hasti Seifi
abstract: Multimodal haptic feedback that combines electrical muscle stimulation (EMS) and vibrotactile signals can create richer, more immersive experiences than those using a single modality. EMS delivers kinesthetic feedback by inducing muscle contractions, simulating force sensations that complement tactile stimuli from mechanical vibrations. However, presenting these stimuli concurrently can lead to perceptual interference, where one modality masks or alters the perception of the other. Temporal alignment between stimuli is also critical, as asynchrony can affect the perceived quality of haptic sensations. To investigate these phenomena, we conducted three user studies with a total of 40 participants (12, 12, and 16, respectively), focusing on mutual masking effects and temporal order perception between EMS and vibration. Our findings suggest that vibration can alleviate the tingling and discomfort commonly associated with EMS, effectively mitigating these unwanted sensations. Conversely, the presence of EMS increases the Just Noticeable Difference (JND) in vibration frequency discrimination, indicating a decrease in sensitivity to vibratory changes. Additionally, participants generally perceived the stimuli as simultaneous when EMS preceded vibration by 100 to 200 milliseconds. We discuss these findings and present four design guidelines for multimodal haptic rendering with EMS and vibrations in user applications.

title: WgANet: A Wavelet-Guided Attention Network for Remote Sensing Image Semantic Segmentation
authors: Yan Wang, Li Cao, He Deng
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Semantic segmentation of remote sensing images plays a crucial role in geospatial applications including land cover classification, disaster assessment, and environmental monitoring. While deep neural networks have significantly advanced segmentation performance, most existing approaches neglect frequency-domain information essential for capturing complex textures and boundary details. To address this limitation, we propose WgANet, a novel three-branch network incorporating wavelet-guided attention (WgA). The architecture comprises a spatial Mamba branch built upon visual state space (VSS) blocks for global context modeling, a spatial convolutional branch for fine-grained local feature extraction, and a frequency band branch constructed with WgA blocks to capture frequency-aware representations. Furthermore, a dynamic aggregation module (DAM) at each encoding stage adaptively fuses complementary features across all branches, enhancing semantic consistency and detail preservation. We comprehensively evaluate WgANet on two widely used high-resolution remote sensing datasets, namely ISPRS Vaihingen and ISPRS Potsdam, as well as on a more challenging dataset, LoveDA Urban. Experimental results verify the effectiveness of joint spatial–frequency modeling. Specifically, WgANet achieves 91.45% OA, 90.50% mF1, and 83.04% mIoU on ISPRS Vaihingen, and 91.31% OA, 92.28% mF1, and 86.01% mIoU on ISPRS Potsdam, indicating consistent superiority over representative state-of-the-art methods. Even on LoveDA Urban, WgANet achieves the best segmentation performance, further demonstrating its effectiveness and generalization capability across complex urban scenes. The source code is available at: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/YanWang-WHPU/WgANet</uri>.

title: Channel-Gated Transformers With Affinity CAM for Weakly Supervised Multi-Class Brain Tumor Segmentation
authors: Yan Han, Kai Liu, Lingling Yuan, Md Rahaman, Marcin Grzegorzek, Hongzan Sun, Chen Li, Huiling Chen
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Precise tumor localization and sub-region identification are critical for disease diagnosis. However, current Weakly Supervised Semantic Segmentation (WSSS) methods for brain tumor segmentation are primarily single-class, neglecting differences between tumor sub-regions. We observed that when mainstream transformer-based WSSS methods are applied to multi-class brain tumor segmentation, they encounter two major challenges: sub-region discrimination errors and over-segmentation of small lesions. To address these challenges and advance multi-class WSSS methods for brain tumor analysis, this paper proposes Channel-gated Transformers with Affinity CAM (CTAC). CTAC first employs channel-gated multi-head self-attention to overcome the over-smoothing tendency of the transformer, thereby enhancing inter-class discriminability and improving the model's subclass differentiation capability. Then, CTAC uses multi-scale smoothed affinity to adaptively suppress low-confidence responses in the Class Activation Map (CAM), mitigating over-activation in the CAM, and alleviating the over-segmentation phenomena of small lesions. The proposed CTAC significantly outperformed the baseline method on the BraTS2021 glioma and BraTS2023-MEN meningioma datasets. On Brats2021, it achieved a multi-class mean IoU (mIoU) of 61.718%, an increase of 4.964 percentage points (pp), with the whole-tumor mIoU reaching 79.798% (+6.882 pp). On Brats2023-MEN, CTAC attained 72.887% mIoU (+4.676 pp) for multi-class segmentation and 75.394% (+7.839 pp) for whole-tumor. Furthermore, CTAC surpasses recent state-of-the-art methods. Code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/yhan94-lab/CTAC</uri>.

title: Visibility Region-Aware NOMA in XL-MIMO Systems
authors: Chiza M. Christophe, Abuu B. Kihero, Hüseyin Arslan
abstract: This paper introduces two novel non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) configurations tailored for extra-large MIMO (XL-MIMO) systems, leveraging non-stationary channel characteristics to improve multi-user separation and spectral efficiency (SE). Specifically, a visibility region (VR)-aware scheduling strategy is proposed, allowing the superposition of near and far-field users through both partial and full NOMA approaches. Low-complexity, VR-aware detection techniques are developed for each NOMA configuration. In this design, near-field users with distinct, non-overlapping VRs share frequency resources with a far-field user occupying a larger VR, with the proposed detection techniques ensuring effective multi-user separation. This approach enhances system capacity and supports massive connectivity within the XL-MIMO framework. Simulations demonstrate significant gains in bit error rate (BER) and SE across all users, while maintaining low complexity.

title: Cost-Efficient ADC Linearity Testing Based on Maximum Likelihood Partial Polynomial Segmentation Method
authors: Dengquan Li, Yexin Zhu, Longsheng Wang, Shubin Liu, Zhangming Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Linearity testing, including differential nonlinearity error (DNL) and integral nonlinearity error (INL), is of great significance to evaluate the performance of an analog-to-digital converter (ADC). However, high precision signal source and large number of samples are two challenges in conventional histogram testing method. This paper proposes a maximum likelihood partial polynomial segmentation method for linearity testing of binary Nyquist ADC like SAR or Pipelined ADCs. Segmentation model with partial polynomial fitting reduces the testing parameters and required samples. The source nonlinearity removal scheme relaxes the precision requirement of signal source. Maximum likelihood estimation which considers the influence of noise and quantization error is used to improve the testing accuracy. Measurement results of 16- and 18-bit ADCs show that the proposed method reduces the signal source resolution by 7-bit compared to the histogram method. The number of samples is decreased by more than 50 times. Meanwhile, the maximum INL estimation errors are less than 0.75 and 0.8 LSB, respectively.

title: PixelatedScatter: Arbitrary-level Visual Abstraction for Large-scale Multiclass Scatterplots
authors: Ziheng Guo, Tianxiang Wei, Zeyu Li, Lianghao Zhang, Sisi Li, Jiawan Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Overdraw is inevitable in large-scale scatterplots. Current scatterplot abstraction methods lose features in medium-to-low density regions. We propose a visual abstraction method designed to provide better feature preservation across arbitrary abstraction levels for large-scale scatterplots, particularly in medium-to-low density regions. The method consists of three closely interconnected steps: first, we partition the scatterplot into iso-density regions and equalize visual density; then, we allocate pixels for different classes within each region; finally, we reconstruct the data distribution based on pixels. User studies, quantitative and qualitative evaluations demonstrate that, compared to previous methods, our approach better preserves features and exhibits a special advantage when handling ultra-high dynamic range data distributions.

title: BiKT: Unleashing the potential of GNNs via Bi-directional Knowledge Transfer
authors: Shuai Zheng, Zhizhe Liu, Zhenfeng Zhu, Xingxing Zhang, Jianxin Li, Yao Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Based on the message-passing paradigm, there has been an amount of research proposing diverse and impressive feature propagation mechanisms to improve the performance of GNNs. However, less focus has been put on feature transformation, another major operation of the message-passing framework. In this paper, we first empirically investigate the performance of the feature transformation operation in several typical GNNs. Unexpectedly, we notice that GNNs do not completely free up the power of the inherent feature transformation operation. By this observation, we propose the Bi-directional Knowledge Transfer (BiKT), a plug-and-play approach to unleash the potential of the feature transformation operations without modifying the original architecture. Taking the feature transformation operation as a derived representation learning model that shares parameters with the original GNN, the direct prediction by this model provides a topological-agnostic knowledge feedback that can further instruct the learning of GNN and the feature transformations therein. On this basis, BiKT not only allows us to acquire knowledge from both the GNN and its derived model but also promotes each other by injecting the knowledge into the other. In addition, a theoretical analysis is further provided to demonstrate that BiKT improves the generalization bound of the GNNs from the perspective of domain adaptation. An extensive group of experiments on up to 7 datasets with 5 typical GNNs demonstrates that BiKT brings up to 0.5%- 4% performance gain over the original GNN, which means a boosted GNN is obtained. Meanwhile, the derived model also shows a powerful performance to compete with or even surpass the original GNN, enabling us to flexibly apply it independently to some other specific downstream tasks.

title: Gear Tooth Crack Detection Method Using Bayesian Neural Network
authors: Weiwei Lu, Zhipeng Wang, Liang Zhao, Mohamed Hatem, Yuanjin Ji, Yuejian Chen
abstract: Gearbox fault detection plays a crucial role in implementing proactive maintenance strategies and reducing economic losses. Fault detection can be addressed by modeling baseline monitoring data and subsequently detecting faults through deviations between the baseline model and newly acquired monitoring data. In the field of deep learning, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) have been widely applied to nonlinear time series modeling. This paper attempts to combine Bayesian Neural Networks (BNN) with LSTM, aiming to fully exploit the ability of LSTM to capture complex long-term dependencies as well as the strong regularization and generalization capabilities of BNN. Specifically, we propose two fault detection methods: the fault detection method based on Bayesian LSTM (BLSTM) and the fault detection method based on traditional LSTM combined with Bayesian fully connected layer (LSTM-BFC). Comparative and anti-noise experiments were conducted using data collected from a gearbox test rig. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed Bayesian Neural Network-based approaches outperform traditional LSTM models in terms of fault detection performance. Among them, the LSTM-BFC method shows particularly outstanding performance in training time, time series prediction capability, fault detection accuracy, and noise robustness.

title: DeepBHMR: Learning Bidirectional Hybrid Mixture Models for Generalized Global Rigid Point Set Registration in Computer-assisted Orthopedic Surgery
authors: Zhengyan Zhang, Ang Zhang, Rui Song, Yibin Li, Max Q.-H. Meng, Zhe Min
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper presents a novel robust and accurate normal-assisted learning-based rigid point set registration approach, i.e., Deep Bi-directional Hybrid Mixture Registration (DeepBHMR), where normal vectors are used in both correspondence and transformation computational stages while the bi-directional registration processes are considered. DeepBHMR consists of three components, (1) the correspondence estimation network that predicts the correspondence probabilities; (2) the posterior estimation module that computes the HMMs parameters; (3) the transformation estimation module that calculates the rigid transformation matrix by utilizing the bidirectional optimization mechanism. DeepBHMR has been extensively validated on various medical data sets, outperforming state-of-the-art registration methods. For femur bones, the mean rotation error value is approximately 1° (i.e, 1.01°) and the translation error is less than 1 mm (i.e., 0.30 mm) respectively, which meets the requirement of computer-assisted orthopedic surgery. Furthermore, even (1) trained with femur data and tested on distinct shapes and (2) under the large transformation, the mean RMSE values of registration are 2.60 mm and 3.05 mm respectively, demonstrating DeepBHMR’s favorable generalizability to different data shapes and great capability to handle global registration. Additionally, the individual significant contributions and computational efficiency of adopting normal vectors and utilizing the bidirectional mechanism have been validated in ablation studies. The results demonstrate the DeepBHMR’s favorable generalizability from femur bones to hip bones and that DeepBHMR can successfully handle the large transformation or partial-to-full registration simultaneously. The code implementation of DeepBHMR has been made publicly available at https://github.com/zzyrobot/DeepBiHMM.git.

title: Interact, Instruct to Improve: A LLM-Driven Parallel Actor-Reasoner Framework for Enhancing Autonomous Vehicle Interactions
authors: Shiyu Fang, Jiaqi Liu, Chengkai Xu, Chen Lv, Peng Hang, Jian Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) have entered the stage of commercialization, yet their performance in interactive scenarios remains unsatisfactory due to challenges such as decision interpretability, human driver (HV) heterogeneity, and scenario diversity. Recent advances in Large Language Models (LLMs) provide a promising avenue to enhance AV interaction capabilities, but their high computational demand hinders practical deployment. To address these challenges, this paper introduces a parallel Actor–Reasoner framework designed to enable explicit and real-time bidirectional AV-HV interactions. First, the Reasoner employs a localized LLM with CoT reasoning and human instructions to progressively infer HV intent, style, AV action, and eHMI displays during the training stage. During testing, it continues to infer he above information except AV action. The Actor, in turn, is constructed as an interaction memory through the Reasoner’s interactions with heterogeneous simulated HVs across diverse scenarios, where the memory partition and two-layer retrieval modules are employed in the construction process. During testing, the Actor is used to retrieve feasible actions for the AV. Ablation studies across multiple scenarios demonstrate that the proposed modules improve interaction success rates by an average of 15% and 12%, respectively. Moreover, comparison studies in multi-vehicle scenarios further show that the proposed Actor–Reasoner framework achieves superior safety while simultaneously improving efficiency. Finally, with the integration of external Human–Machine Interface (eHMI) information derived from the Reasoner’s reasoning and feasible actions retrieved from the Actor, the framework is validated in real-world field interactions. Our code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/FanGShiYuu/Actor-Reasoner</uri>

title: High-Resolution Underwater Creature Segmentation
authors: Huiyang Wu, Qiuping Jiang, Zongwei Wu, Runmin Cong, Cédric Demonceaux, Yi Yang, Xiangyang Ji
abstract: Underwater creature segmentation (UCS) is critical for marine research and robotics but faces unique challenges: environmental distortions and biological traits that distinguish it from terrestrial segmentation. While deep learning advances exist, current UCS models are constrained to low-resolution inputs, losing critical details when processing high-resolution (HR) imagery and degrading segmentation precision. To bridge this gap, we introduce UCS4K, the first large-scale HR dataset for UCS, containing 4,096 images with pixel-wise annotations. UCS4K offers 4 times higher average resolution than existing datasets, covering diverse species, habitats, and environmental complexities essential for robust model training. Additionally, we propose a Resolution-Asymmetric Dual-branch Alignment and Refinement (RADAR) network to address the efficiency-receptiveness trade-off in HR-UCS. RADAR decouples context and detail processing: a CNN branch preserves HR spatial details, while a Transformer branch models global semantics on downsampled inputs to avoid quadratic complexity. Crucially, it resolves the inherent semantic misalignment issue between branches via the Global Semantic Alignment (GSA) module in the encoder and the Bidirectional Collaborative Refinement (BCR) module-embedded decoder that progressively integrates multi-scale encoding features to sharpen boundaries. This asymmetric design ensures efficient long-range context capture without sacrificing spatial precision. Extensive benchmarks demonstrate that RADAR sets new state-of-the-art performance on UCS4K and other existing datasets. Our contributions establish the first HR benchmark for UCS and deliver a scalable framework for high-precision segmentation. Dataset, code, and models will be made available.

title: Joint Trajectory Design and Power Optimization in Adversarial UAV Communications: A Game Theory Framework
authors: Jinyue Liu, Peng Gong, Haowei Yang, Jihao Zhang, Liehuang Zhu, Xiang Gao
abstract: To address the challenges of dynamic jamming and resource optimization in Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) confrontation communication networks, this paper proposes a hierarchical game framework for joint trajectory design and power allocation. These elements are inherently coupled: jamming degrades channel quality, prompting UAVs to adapt both their trajectories to improve spatial positioning and reduce jamming exposure, and their power allocation to maintain communication effectiveness under interference. The framework captures this interplay through a differential game for trajectory optimization and a Stackelberg game for power allocation, with the Nash equilibrium (NE) rigorously defined and its existence proved. To overcome the complexity of solving the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation, an adaptive dynamic programming algorithm is employed to approximate the value functions for both trajectory and power optimization. Simulations validate the effectiveness of the proposed framework, demonstrating that it accurately captures the strategic interactions between UAVs and provides robust decision support for resource optimization in dynamic adversarial environments.

title: Deep Feature Prior-Guided Conditional Diffusion Model for Underwater Image Enhancement
authors: Junhao Zhu, Linwei Zhu, Tao Tian, Wenhui Wu, Jingchao Cao
abstract: Underwater imaging always suffers from color distortion and reduced visibility due to light absorption and scattering, severely hindering visual perception and analysis. In this letter, we propose an underwater image enhancement framework based on diffusion model augmented with two lightweight guidance modules. The first module is a conditional branch that extracts structural features from a coarsely enhanced version to guide the denoising process toward more faithful restoration. While the second module retrieves high-quality features from a pre-constructed feature dictionary as priors, effectively restoring colors and fine details in degraded regions. Extensive experiments on public underwater image datasets demonstrate that our proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art approaches both quantitatively and visually. It also generalizes well across various underwater environments, highlighting the effectiveness of incorporating structural and feature-level guidance into the diffusion process. The source code and pre-trained model are available at https://github.com/Juneit/PGUIE.

title: Research on Feeding Rate Measurement Method for Combine Harvester Based on Multimodal Information Fusion
authors: Qian Wang, Yanxin Yin, Zhijun Meng, Chunjiang Zhao, Xiaofei An, Junjie Zhao, Wuchang Qin, Duanyang Geng
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Signal Processing
abstract: The feeding rate is a critical reference parameter for the efficient and low-loss operation control of grain combine harvesters. Current feeding rate measurement technologies face challenges such as low accuracy, poor stability, and delayed measurement results. Rapidly and accurately obtaining the feeding rate during the operation of combine harvesters has become a key focus and challenge in the field of agricultural machinery research. This paper proposes a feeding rate measurement method based on multimodal information fusion, including crop visual perception and harvester cutting load. This method first uses an image sensor to capture crop images in the working area in front of the combine harvester and proposes an improved Deeplab image segmentation algorithm to achieve accurate crop height measurement. Then, the real-time load information of the combine harvester's cutter is used to calculate the cutting area. Finally, by combining the operational speed information of the harvester, the precise feeding volume is calculated, effectively addressing the interference caused by complex working conditions in feeding rate measurement. To reduce the interference of combine harvester vibrations and electromagnetic environments on sensor signals, an M-E fusion filter is proposed to extract effective cutting resistance information, achieving accurate and stable calculation of header resistance information. Using the ROS communication mechanism combined with the Python 3.6 programming language, an intelligent measurement system software for the feeding rate of grain combine harvesters was developed. This system realizes functions such as sensor data acquisition, multi-sensor data fusion computation, and human-computer interaction. The results of the field tests showed that at various operating speeds of 2 km/h, 3 km/h, 4 km/h, and 5 km/h, the average relative errors of the feeding rate measurement results are 1.46%, 1.77%, 1.76%, and 1.53%, respectively, with an average relative error of 1.64% and a root mean square error average of 0.103×10⁻³ m³·s⁻¹. At various crop densities of 553 plants/m², 415 plants/m², 277 plants/m², and 138 plants/m², the average relative errors of the feeding rate measurement results are 1.77%, 1.5%, 2.39%, and 1.91%, respectively, with an average relative error of 1.89% and a root mean square error average of 0.061×10⁻³ m³·s⁻¹. The feeding rate measurement system developed in this study has high accuracy and strong stability, providing important measurement technology support for intelligent control research of combine harvesters and has high practical value.

title: Trajectory Planning for Autonomous Driving in Transportation Systems Based on Deep Reinforcement Learning and Spatio-Temporal Voxels
authors: Gang He, Hai Yu, Guofa Li, Keqiang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Trajectory planning is crucial for ensuring safety, efficiency, and comfort in autonomous driving, particularly in highway environments, which are critical components of intelligent transportation systems and require vehicles to navigate complex and uncertain traffic conditions. However, related methods are lack of adaptive decision-making capabilities and suffer from high algorithmic complexity. To this end, this paper proposes a novel trajectory planning framework based on deep reinforcement learning and spatio-temporal planning, aiming to improve the adaptability and overall performance of autonomous driving systems in complex traffic environments. First, a data-driven decision-making method based on deep reinforcement learning is developed to establish a stable and human-like decision system. At the planning level, a variable voxel structure is designed to handle different decisions and scenarios, with the spatio-temporal feasible region constructed based on vehicle dynamics model and transportation safety regulations. Trajectory planning is then carried out using piecewise Bézier curves, incorporating various constraints. Finally, a new decision detection module is developed to ensure decision feasibility, while enhancing the self-learning ability of the DRL agent and fully leveraging the performance of the planning layer. Our proposed trajectory planning method is established based on forward decision guidance and backward optimization feedback. Experiments conducted on the highway-env simulator and the CQSkyEyeX real-world dataset show that the proposed framework outperforms the compared reinforcement learning and spatio-temporal planning methods in terms of decision-making efficiency, safety, and human-like planning.

title: Small and Fast LLMs on Commodity Hardware: Post-Training Quantization in llama. cpp
authors: Lorenz Sparrenberg, Tobias Deuβer, Armin Berger, Rafet Sifa
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities but their significant computational and memory demands hinder widespread deployment, especially on resource-constrained devices. Quantization, the process of reducing the numerical precision of model parameters, has emerged as a critical technique for compressing LLMs and accelerating inference. This paper provides an overview of LLM quantization, with a particular focus on the Post-Training Quantization (PTQ) methods implemented within the popular llama. cpp framework and its GGUF file format. We begin by covering quantization fundamentals, including the distinction between PTQ and Quantization-Aware Training (QAT). We then describe the specific PTQ schemes employed by llama. cpp, including legacy methods, advanced K-quants, and recent IQ-quants, along with their underlying mathematical principles. The paper also discusses the impact of these techniques on model fidelity, hardware requirements, inference speed, and traces the adoption of GGUF as a de facto standard in the open-source community. This work serves as a practical guide and comprehensive reference for researchers aiming to deploy LLMs on resource-constrained hardware. By systematically documenting and comparing the PTQ methods within llama. cpp, we provide the necessary insights to navigate the trade-offs between model fidelity, inference speed, and memory footprint. This enables informed decision-making for real-world applications, from local CPU-based inference to efficient edge deployment.

title: Traffic Volume Analysis and Reduction Strategies in Urban Environments
authors: Nihitha R Haresamudram, Priyam Badyal, Shivansh Gautam, Sashi Pritam Manandi Anand, Ignisha Rajathi G, Sapna R
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Traffic congestion is one of the leading issues in urban environments. It causes an increase in travel time, air pollution, etc. Efficient traffic management is crucial for improving time management and accidents, as well as minimizing environmental impacts. This study provides a method to analyze traffic volume trends and explore various machine learning methods to predict congestion levels. Using the datasheet collected from Bangalore, we implement various predictive models. These models are tested based on the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score. The findings demonstrate that integrating machine learning algorithms can enhance smart city traffic management through data-driven methodologies. From the study, we conclude that the AdaBoost Regressor performs the best, achieving an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.8042, a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 0.0397, and a Mean Squared Error (MSE) of 0.0053.

title: Deriving Trajectory Tracking Requirements for a Small Size League Robot
authors: Gabriel B. Farias, Marcos R. O. A. Maximo, Rubens J. M. Afonso
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: In the development of an engineering project, it is common to face many design choices in order to achieve a final solution. The earlier such choices are made, the greater the influence in the design and the more impactful it is to change the decision later. Therefore, these decisions must be accompanied by a thorough analysis to assure that the solution is adequate to the project. In this paper, we contribute with a method to obtain design requirements using a Monte Carlo approach in the context of the design of a team for the RoboCup Small Size League competition. Focusing in the task of following trajectories, we analyze the impact of parameters that drive the robot design, the feedback control information, and the auxiliary computer software.

title: Hydrogen as an Alternative to Storage Energy in a Microgrid
authors: M.P. Arrieta, J.L. Villa
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The energy transition is a central axis in the fight against climate change, driving the development of nonconventional renewable energy sources. In this context, hydrogen has emerged as a key energy vector to optimize energy storage and reduce dependence on electrochemical batteries, whose environmental impact is significant. This article performs a systematic review of the literature on the feasibility of hydrogen in microgrids, analyzing its storage efficiency, its ability to stabilize energy systems, and its contribution to the reduction of CO2 emissions. The integration of hydrogen in hybrid microgrids is examined, highlighting that its adoption allows a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 0 - 5 0}$</tex> percent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and a 40 percent optimization in the management of renewable energy surpluses. The economic viability of hydrogen is also addressed, highlighting its potential to reach competitive costs of USD <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 / \text{kg}$</tex> by 2030. Based on the findings, it is concluded that hydrogen represents a sustainable and scalable alternative for decarbonizing the energy sector and strengthening energy resilience.

title: Physics-Guided and Explainable Anomaly Detection for IEC 61850 Sampled Values
authors: Sunoh Ryu, Ryangsoo Kim, Hark Yoo, Hyuk Lim, Seunghyun Yoon
publish: 2025 IEEE 30th Pacific Rim International Symposium on Dependable Computing (PRDC)
abstract: The IEC 61850 Sampled Values (SV) protocol lacks built-in security, exposing substations to cyber risks. We present a physics-guided, explainable anomaly detector combining statistical descriptors with ensemble-based meta-features and an interpretable classifier. On the QUT-ZSS 2023 SV dataset, it achieves 98.2% F1 and 99.8% accuracy with 1.4 μs latency. An integrated alert parser provides feature-level explanations for actionable operator feedback without harming real-time performance.

title: Data-Driven Agriculture: A Unified ML and DL Framework for Smart Crop Yield Forecasting
authors: Mohammed Mudasser, Mohammadi Akheela Khanum
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Agriculture is essential for global sustenance, yet it faces challenges such as low productivity, inefficient resource utilization, and the prevalence of crop diseases. This paper presents a novel, unified framework that integrates advanced machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) techniques to enhance crop yield forecasting and provide real-time, localized decision support for farmers. Our system consolidates three core modules—a Crop Recommendation Engine, a Fertilizer Suggestion System, and a Plant Disease Detection Module—by leveraging ensemble methods (e.g., Random Forest, XGBoost) and a fine-tuned Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) based on ResNet-50. Detailed discussions cover data preprocessing, feature extraction, batch-wise model training, mathematical formulations, and comprehensive model evaluation. Experimental results, illustrated via performance graphs, interface screenshots, and conceptual diagrams, demonstrate the robustness and scalability of our approach. Future work will focus on integrating IoT-based real-time data and expanding dataset diversity to further advance precision agriculture.

title: Optimizing VLSI-Based Quantum Computing Performance in Digital Image Processing Using Modular Energy-Efficient Posit Multipliers for Enhanced Computational Precision and Reduced Power Consumption
authors: Ishani Mishra, Mahadevaswamy, Pavithra G, Swapnil S. Ninawe
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: In this research paper, some novel developments in the optimization of digital image processing efficiency by conducting a simulation study on modular posit multiplier architectures, design and improving the energy efficiency to boost computational performance of energy efficient posit multipliers is presented along with the simulation results. The Posit number system, an emerging alternative to IEEE floating-point arithmetic, offers notable benefits in deep learning and image processing due to its ability to efficiently handle non-uniform data distributions.
