title: Financial Technologies (FinTech) Disrupting Traditional Banking
authors: CS Jyoti Arora, Chinnapareddy Venkata Krishna Reddy, Manjunath Menedhal, Himanshu Agarwall, P.R. Sudha Rani
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The traditional banking environment has been severely shaken by the rapid rise of Financial Technologies (FinTech), which provide customer-focused, digitally enabled, and flexible alternatives to traditional financial services. This research looks at how much FinTech innovations like peer-to- peer lending, blockchain, digital payment platforms, and robo-advisory services have affected conventional banks' performance. The study measures the association among FinTech growth indicators as well as banks' key performance indicators (KPIs) such as cost-to-income ratio and client retention using a comparative analytical technique and a recently created FinTech Activity Index (FAI). Using visual analytics for interpretability, a model based on multiple linear regression was used to examine longitudinal data from 2015 to 2024. An R2 value of 0.82 indicates good predictive potential, and the results show a statistically significant adverse association between FinTech activity as well as conventional banking performance. To maintain competitiveness in a financial ecosystem driven by digital technology, this study believes that FinTech is a transformational disruptor rather than just a complementary force, requiring aggressive government and deliberate bank adaptation.

title: Revolutionizing Schizophrenia Care for the Elderly: Blockchain-driven Predictive Models for Personalized Support
authors: Poornima N V, Resmi K R, Rohini V, Himank Khatri, Prabhusundhar P
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The escalation of mental health challenges encountered by the elderly community, novel research is carried out by adopting twin cutting-edge technologies, artificial intelligence (AI) and Blockchain, which are proposed in this study, focusing on schizophrenia, which is a complex mental disorder, to raise awareness of the disease, reduce negativity, and ensure positive support. symptom prediction and disease classification models have been developed using Machine learning (ML) algorithms and symptom datasets for schizophrenia prediction. Natural Language processing is also employed to find the speech patterns for mental health illness indications. The outcomes predicted with AI models are transformed into a detailed report by leveraging Llama 3.3, ensuring understanding and encouraging people to have community conversations. The generated reports are stored in the decentralized file system to achieve more security and privacy. It ensures the tamper-free nature of Blockchain, with an interactive user interface and multilingual capabilities. This research outcome allows individuals to know the early disease symptoms and get timely assistance; it ensures an illuminating way toward improved mental well-being for senior citizens.

title: Retrieval Augmented Generation Optimized Large Language Model based Legal Virtual Assistant for Legal Self-help
authors: Anil Sharma, Renu, Arsh Rumi, Ujjwal Sharma, Arsalan Khan, Raghib Waquar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Generative Artificial Intelligence has an influential impact on the world. It has changed the way we did certain things. It doesn’t sit right with many to compare the competitive, cunning and brutal realm of law with the new age technology of Artificial Intelligence, they seem miles apart in terms of their nature and very foundations. But what is synonymous throughout in these two fields, is the aim to do progress by the second and have a meaningful contribution in the world. Lawyers spend much of their day jostling through files that may or may not contain data relevant to their work, or maybe they need to fetch some document from an online resource and, compare it with another document, summarize or even analyse some legal data. These legal professionals have a lot on their plate and the last thing they want is to be stuck in the middle of a vortex meagre tasks that hinder their progress towards the more important tasks of the day. Hence, to counter this issue we have tried to review the work done in the field of AI Legal Assistants, an AI assistant which shall be equipped with an arsenal of skills that enable it to tackle any previously mentioned task sent its way using the concepts of RAG and LLM. The amalgamation of Law and Gen AI might come off as a juxtaposition of opposite poles, but it truly is the pair that shall lead the future of both Law and Generative AI with its beguiling impact on the world.

title: Impact of Government Expenditure on Economic Growth in India: An Econometric Analysis
authors: Anoop Tripathi, Pushpak Sharma, Arzoo Chopra, Harwinder Kaur
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The liberalization and globalization programs implemented as part of the 1991 economic reforms have had a major impact on the substantial structural change that the Indian economy has seen over the last few decades. While fiscal policy has become an increasingly important tool for guiding development, however relationship analysis between public expenditure and economic growth has often yielded inconsistent results, particularly in establishing a clear, long-term connection. This study examines the expenditure by government and Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth in Indian economy, examining time series dataset from 1990 to 2023. To analyze the underlying dynamics, the analysis employs co-integration techniques along with the vector error correction mode (VECM). This approach determines both long run equilibrium and short run adjustments between the two economic variables.Empirical analysis indicates a significant long run relationship between government expenditure and economic growth, with capital expenditure playing a key role in driving economic performance. Furthermore, the findings support the relevance of Wagner’s Law in the Indian context, highlighting a unidirectional causal relationship from public expenditure to GDP Growth. This study adds to the continuing scholarly conversation on fiscal policy and development by providing new insights for the relation between govt. expenditure and economic growth across time. The current study recommends to develop more growth-oriented and successful public finance and economic planning strategies.

title: Development Respiratory Auscultation Device Supported by Augmented Reality and Artificial Intelligence Aimed for Clinical Training
authors: Antonio Rienzo, Togo Arredondo, Omar Acevedo, Alvaro Huirimilla, Daniel Ciudad, María Rubio
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This development aims to provide a tool to improve the learning of auscultatory maneuvers, reducing dependence on direct supervision; assisting the student through augmented reality to guide the auscultatory maneuver and using artificial intelligence to support the identification of respiratory sounds to support diagnostic learning. In the preliminary studies stage, several theoretical aspects were analyzed, and the state of the art included the analysis of several current models, and even patents of current devices. The work describes the prototype and some images of the device and the mobile application. Results, conclusions and future work are discussed.

title: Comparative Analysis of Mechanical Properties of Banana Peel-Based Biocomposites Through ASTM Standardized Mechanical Testing
authors: Javier Chavez, Rodrigo Vargas Machuca, Jose Carrizales, Jose Becerra, Julio Ronceros, Nain Ramos
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This study develops biocomposites from pulverized banana peel, gelling agent (gelatin), glycerin, and glacial acetic acid as a sustainable alternative to petroleum-derived synthetic textile materials. A controlled experimental design was imple-mented to evaluate the effect of varying glycerin concentrations (+20% and +40%) and different gelatin-to-water ratios (30/70%, 40/60 %) on the mechanical properties of the material. The samples were molded into Type IV specimens according to ASTM D638 and subjected to tensile testing using a universal testing machine (UTM). Experimental results revealed that the formulation with an additional 20 % glycerin, a 30 % gelatin to 70 % water ratio, and reinforcement with pulverized banana achieved optimized mechanical properties: Young's modulus of 7.84 Nzmm”, maximum tensile stress of 2.22 Nzmm-, and elongation at break of 28.35 %. Validation through finite element simulation in ANSYS Mechanical showed acceptable correlation with experimental data, with experimental stresses of 2.22 MPa compared to 2.43 MPa in the simulation.

title: Enhancing Expressive Communication in Children with ASD Through a NAO Robot-Mediated PECS-Adapted System
authors: Luiziane Paulino dos Santos, José Fagner da Silva, Sebastião Emídio Alves Filho, Anderson Abner Souza, Raul Benites Paradeda
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) often face significant challenges in verbal communication and social interaction, impacting their educational inclusion. This project paper outlines a proposed intervention to address these challenges by integrating social robotics with an adapted Picture Exchange Communication System. We propose the use of the NAO V6 humanoid robot as a mediator for a PECS-Adapted system, wherein children utilize visual cards featuring QR codes to express actions, desires, and feelings. The robot is designed to recognize these QR codes, verbalize the corresponding message, and provide interactive feedback. This research, grounded in the Design Science Research framework, will involve a qualitative, exploratory study with five children with ASD, aged 5–10 years, over a two-month period. The intervention aims to enhance expressive communication, increase communicative spontaneity, and facilitate social interaction, ultimately promoting more effective school inclusion. This paper details the system architecture, proposed methodology, and expected contributions of this novel approach within the Brazilian educational context.

title: Blockchain Technology: Transforming Supply Chain Management
authors: Sunit Kumar, CS Jyoti Arora, Prathap Kumar K, Sathish Krishna Anumula, S Neelima
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: A significant transformation has arisen in the industry in recent years, with demands and dynamics both increasing, leading to fierce competition. Businesses rely significantly on supply chain functions, which encompass collaboration, integration, and adaptation, to help them adapt to this ever-changing environment. Several company owners have taken an interest in supply chain apps that has resulted in the creation and deployment of specialist apps that improve supply chain flow control. Because of its flexibility to adjust to changing market situations and business environments, blockchain technology is drawing a lot of interest from company owners as a notable new use in the supply chain. After doing this, you will have a better grasp of how blockchain technology has changed this field. To enhance supply chain security, flexibility and transparency, the study report recommends that firms use blockchain technology. Without a doubt, blockchain technology is vital in building confidence among those involved in the supply chain. The paper concludes by outlining some of the potential positive outcomes that might result from implementing blockchain technology in areas such as increased competitiveness, flow management, and cooperation and integration.

title: XGBoost Based Day Ahead Solar Energy Generation Forecasting Using Trends and Periodicity Features in Historical and Weather Data
authors: Noman Shabbir, Kamran Daniel, Argo Rosin, Hadi Ashraf Raja, Muhammad Jawad, Joao Martins
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Accurate short-term forecasting of solar energy generation is vital for the optimal integration of photovoltaic (PV) systems into smart grids and for efficient energy management. This research presents a novel approach for 24-hour-ahead solar energy generation forecasting by employing the XGBoost algorithm, which is known for its robustness and ability to handle non-linear relationships in complex datasets. The model incorporates feature engineering techniques that extract temporal trends and periodic patterns from historical solar generation data, weather, and seasonal cycles. By focusing on relevant time-series characteristics, the proposed methodology enhances the learning capability of the XGBoost model. Performance evaluation using standard metrics, including Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Mean Square Error (MSE) demonstrate that the proposed model delivers high forecasting accuracy and outperforms several conventional prediction methods. The results highlight the potential of XGBoost-based models in delivering reliable short-term forecasts for solar PV generation in residential and distributed energy settings.

title: Process Flow for Material Recovery and Sustainability Assessment About Recycling Ultra Thin Photovoltaic Panels
authors: Ricardo Manuel Arias Velásquez, Jennifer Vanessa Mejía Lara
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive Life Cycle Assessment of a 1 m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> ultra-thin photovoltaic solar panel using the Environmental Footprint 3.1 methodology, with a focus on quantifying key environmental impacts across all life cycle stages. The analysis identifies the manufacturing phase as the primary contributor to environmental burdens, particularly in climate change (48.27 kg CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> -eq), acidification (0.328 mol H+-eq), and terrestrial eutrophication (0.467 mol N-eq). Freshwa-ter ecotoxicity reached 30,754 CTUe, predominantly driven by organic solvent emissions, while fossil resource consumption totaled 700.54 MJ. The study also reports low mineral and metal depletion (0.0097 kg Sb-eq) and moderate water use (2.11 m 3 deprivation-equivalent). Human toxicity indicators were negligible or negative, likely influenced by system boundaries and data cutoffs. Results highlight that despite their reduced material mass, ultra-thin panels exhibit non-negligible environ-mental impacts due to energy-intensive processes powered by fossil-based grid electricity. The findings support the need for mitigation strategies, including renewable energy integration, solvent recovery, and efficient resource use, to improve the sustainability performance of emerging PV technologies.

title: Deep Dive into Marine Pollution Segmentation: Unveiling the Power of Deep Learning for Effective Trash Detection
authors: P. Vijaya Kumari, S. Jessica Saritha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Marine pollution, particularly plastic debris, poses a significant threat to marine ecosystems, requiring efficient and accurate methods for detection and mitigation. Traditional methods for identifying marine trash have limitations in scalability and precision, especially in underwater environments. This paper explores the application of deep learning-based segmentation models, with a specific focus on YOLOv8, for the segmentation of marine debris in underwater imagery. The study investigates the potential of YOLOv8 to not only detect but also segment various types of marine trash in complex environments. Through extensive experimentation, we evaluate the model's performance based on metrics such as precision, recall, Mean Average Precision (mAP), and accuracy. The results demonstrate that YOLOv8 excels in real-time applications, making it suitable for scalable and automated environmental monitoring. This research highlights the potential of YOLOv8 in enhancing marine pollution monitoring, providing a foundation for real-time, efficient environmental assessments.

title: A Comparative Study of Non-Linear Modelling Capabilities of T-S Fuzzy Models and Back-Propagation Neural Networks
authors: Linxiang Li, Kainan Liu, Xiaojun Ban, Shengkun Xie
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: In the era of data-driven decision-making, selecting appropriate nonlinear modeling techniques is critical for building robust and interpretable predictive systems. While both Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy models and Back-Propagation (BP) neural networks are well-established universal approximators in the data science domain, their fundamentally different structural characteristics lead to varied performance across application scenarios. This paper presents a systematic comparative study of these two modeling approaches through a series of simulation experiments designed to reflect key tasks in predictive analytics, including static function approximation, dynamic system modeling and forecasting, and real-time state tracking of time-varying systems. By evaluating performance across multiple dimensions modeling accuracy, robustness to noise, and adaptability to temporal dynamics, this work provides actionable insights into the practical strengths and limitations of each model type. The results show that T-S fuzzy models offer superior accuracy in clean, stable environments, while BP neural networks demonstrate strong resilience to noise and generalization ability in uncertain conditions. Additionally, T-S fuzzy models exhibit higher adaptability in real-time, dynamic contexts, making them valuable for time-sensitive predictive applications. This study contributes to the broader data science community by offering a structured framework for model selection based on application-specific demands, helping practitioners and researchers alike to optimize predictive modeling strategies for complex, nonlinear systems.

title: QTree-RRT: Improving RRT Through Quadtree-Guided Sampling for Path Planning
authors: Jhorlen Souza Bianor, Lucas Matos de Abreu Dias, Paulo L. J. Drews-Jr, Daniel Fernando Tello Gamarra, Anselmo Rafael Cukla, Felipe Gomes de Oliveira
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Path planning plays a crucial role for autonomous vehicles operating in complex environments, where efficient and reliable navigation is of paramount importance. Traditional path planning algorithms, such as the Rapidly-Exploring Random Tree (RRT) and its variants, are widely used but often suffer from inefficient exploration and suboptimal path generation, particularly in cluttered environments. This work introduces QTree-RRT, a hybrid approach designed to improve path planning by guiding the exploration process through a hierarchical spatial decomposition. The method first decomposes the environment using a Quadtree representation, then computes an initial coarse path through the free regions using a graph search algorithm (e.g., Dijkstra or A*). This preliminary path defines the relevant regions in which RRT sampling is then concentrated, leading to a more focused and efficient exploration. Experimental evaluations in simulated environments with varying obstacle densities show that QTree-RRT consistently outperforms classical RRT and its variants RRT* and RRT-Connect. The proposed approach achieves lower execution times (1.6s), reduces the number of required samples (295), and generates paths with better cost (475.39) and quality, demonstrating its effectiveness as a path planning solution for mobile robots.

title: Beyond Gross Domestic Product: through Artificial Intelligence-A Holistic Economic Measurement Model with reference to the United Arab Emirates
authors: Gowri Arun Menon, Asmaa Fawas Hudeifi, Sangheethaa Sukumaran, Arun Korath
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Economic metrics like Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and unemployment statistics are not able to capture key dimensions of resilience in economies, such as employees' sentiment, social cohesion and well-being. The current research introduces a measuring system based on Artificial Intelligence(AI), making use of Machine Learning (ML), Natural Language Processing (NLP), and real-time big data analysis thus moving beyond traditional backward-looking frameworks. The sentiment analysis application based on AI has increased power of prediction by about 35-50% compared to typical models (OECD, 2023), thereby mitigating limitations related to backward-looking economic appraisals. This study presents a novel computational methodology involving Job Market Sentiment (JMS), Mental Health Index (MHI), Social Cohesion Index (SCI), and Economic Growth (EG) in designing a contemporaneous Economic Stability Index (ESI). It enhances the quick response of policies, maximizes labor market performance, and builds resilience in economies by providing contemporaneous economic information enriched by artificial intelligence. The research contributes to the discipline inasmuch as it reveals how analytics with AI can correct limitations in economic analyses, thus supporting sustainable and inclusive growth. This research represents a proposed framework and conceptual methodology.

title: Ambient Advisory Models: Augmenting Runtime Models Into Distributed Reasoning Agents
authors: Demetrius Hernandez, Jane Cleland-Huang
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems (MODELS)
abstract: As autonomous systems increasingly demonstrate more sophisticated reasoning capabilities and make higher-level decisions, the need for interpretable runtime guidance becomes critical. Traditional Models@Runtime serve as abstractions that reflect system state to support adaptation and decision-making by external actors. We extend this paradigm by introducing Ambient Advisory Models, where model components such as classes, agents, or behavioral specifications are augmented with embedded reasoning capabilities that observe, interpret, and advise. Unlike conventional runtime models that provide passive structural or behavioral representations, each model component in our approach becomes an active advisory entity, continuously monitoring its domain of concern and generating contextual guidance. These advisory components operate without direct actuation authority, functioning as cognitive guardrails that provide guidance on safety, regulatory, ethical, and other relevant concerns, while enabling multi-perspective reasoning. Rather than a monolithic reasoning model, we distribute advisory intelligence across individual model components, each maintaining its own reasoning context and concern-specific knowledge. We demonstrate Ambient Advisory Models in autonomous multi-UAV emergency response operations. This approach transforms selected runtime models from reflective artifacts into proactive advisors, enabling a new form of human-AI collaboration where model components actively participate in system governance rather than merely representing system state.

title: Enhancing Industrial Equipment Reliability through Predictive Maintenance: A Big Data and Machine Learning Approach
authors: Dhanya N C, Bhavish R, Bhavana R Gowda, Harshavardhan Reddy, Harshith Reddy
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Predictive Maintenance (PdM) represents a transformative approach to industrial asset management, leveraging IoT sensors, artificial intelligence, and big data analytics to anticipate equipment failures before they occur. This paper examines the core methodologies of PdM— including vibration analysis, thermal imaging, and oil analysis—and evaluates their financial and operational benefits, such as 20–40% reductions in emergency repair costs and 45–55% fewer unplanned downtimes. We also address implementation challenges, such as data imbalance and legacy system integration, and propose solutions like edge computing and SMOTE. Through case studies from aviation, energy, and manufacturing, we demonstrate PdM’s role in Industry 4.0 and its potential to redefine maintenance strategies globally.

title: A Comprehensive Simulation Platform for Image-Based Visual Servoing: Unity 3D and ROS 2 Integration with Performance Analysis
authors: Bruno L. Lima, Hugo T. M. Oliveira, Glauber R. Leite, Andressa M. Oliveira
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Testing visual servoing algorithms in real robotic systems can be costly, time-consuming, and often limited by hardware availability and safety constraints. To address these challenges, this work presents a simulation platform that inte-grates Unity 3D with ROS 2 to enable the development and validation of image-based visual servoing (IBVS) strategies in virtual environments. The platform simulates a 6-DOF robotic manipulator with a calibrated RGB-D camera and allows real-time communication through the ROS-TCP-Connector. Feature extraction, control computation, and joint actuation are per-formed using ROS 2 packages, while Unity enables the cre-ation of realistic scenes with configurable lighting and image noise. Three simulation scenarios were designed to assess the system's performance, covering both ideal and visually degraded conditions. Results show that the platform provides a reliable, reproducible, and accessible solution for research and education in visual control of robotic manipulators.

title: Effective Malware Classification with Minimum False Negatives Using Optimized Sequenced CNN and FNN Models
authors: Hemamalini V, Jagathrajah R
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Malware Classification is quintessential in the cybersecurity community through recognizing models of malicious software by avoiding huge false positives (FPs) and false negatives (FNs) rates. The paper, therefore, proposes that the combined approach of a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Feed Forward Neural Network (FNN) to improvise on the accuracy classification results in order to minimize the rate at which the number of FNs for malware detection occur. The experimental results confirm that this approach of sequentially processing misclassified samples from FNN through CNN significantly reduces FPs, while initiating classification with FNN effectively minimizes FNs. Accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and ROC-AUC evaluations all validate the proposed technique. Visualization will provide insight into the performance regarding model performance and, finally, present a strong solution to the most realistic challenges in cybersecurity when it regards both accuracy and security.

title: Automatic Egg Chicken Classifier Applying Artificial Vision and Mechatronic Design
authors: Diego Geri Supo, Darwin Morales Supo, Eduardo Rodriguez Canales, Javier Mendoza-Montoya, Arturo Velasquez Cruz, Oswaldo Banda Sayco
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Egg grading is a critical stage in the poultry production chain, especially when considering visual features such as shell color, which can influence consumer perception and commercial acceptance of products. Currently, small producers do not have access to current technology because of its high cost. This study aimed to propose a low-cost mechatronic classifier prototype that can automatically distinguish eggs based on their shell color. The mechanism uses diabolo rollers to move the eggs without damaging them at a controlled speed, which provides sufficient time for machine vision to detect the shell color. As a result, the mechanism classifier transported six eggs with an angular speed of 19 RPM, and the shell color recognition exhibited a precision of 97%. In conclusion, the prototype has good performance and can be improved to support small producers.

title: Synergies Between Nuclear Energy and Green Hydrogen: Potential for a Sustainable Energy Transition
authors: Estefany Valencia, Julissa Batres, Manuel Cardona
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: This paper analyzes the synergy between nuclear energy and green hydrogen production, highlighting thoriumbased nuclear fission as a stable, low-carbon energy source to power electrolysis processes. It assesses the viability of green hydrogen in hard-to-decarbonize sectors such as the steel industry, ammonia production, heavy transport, and industrial and agricultural machinery. The analysis emphasizes benefits in energy efficiency while also identifying key challenges, including high initial investment, the need for strong regulatory frameworks, and public acceptance of nuclear energy. Finally, future research directions are proposed to validate and optimize this technological alternative.

title: Fast Training on Dynamic Heterogeneous Information Network for Fake News Detection
authors: Jinho Go, Aldhytha Karina Sari, Jiaojiao Jiang, Shuiqiao Yang, Sanjay Kumar Jha
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have attracted significant attention for their effectiveness in fake news detection, particularly due to their capability to leverage the social context embedded within news dissemination. Most existing studies, however, operate on static heterogeneous information networks (HINs), assuming these graphs adequately capture the complex interactions among social entities. In practice, the dynamic nature of real-world social networks presents a substantial challenge, as training on suboptimal or outdated graph structures can severely limit the expressiveness of GNNs. Although various approaches have been proposed to model dynamic HINs, they often rely on computationally expensive message-passing mechanisms to update node embeddings, which hinders scalability to large social graphs. In this paper, we introduce DHGNN (Dynamic Heterogeneous Graph Neural Network), a novel model designed to address these challenges. DHGNN simplifies traditional GNN message-passing by employing a dynamic propagation scheme inspired by the personalized PageRank tracking process in HINs. Extensive experiments on three real-world benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of DHGNN in detecting fake news.

title: Cross Polarization in Asymmetric Sixteenth-Mode SIW Antennas: Source Identification and Reduction
authors: Meha Agrawal, Ravi Yadav, Slawomir Koziel
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: High cross-polarization (XP) levels in compact antennas with irregular triangular geometries primarily originate from asymmetric apertures, leading to degraded polarization purity. In this paper, the sources of XP are identified and reduced in sixteenth-mode substrate-integrated waveguide (SMSIW) antennas based on irregular triangular configurations—right-angled (RT-SMSIW) and scalene (ST-SMSIW) structures. A theoretical model is developed by formulating radiation pattern equations for each aperture to gain insight into H-plane XP sources. Based on this model, an L-shaped stub is strategically integrated at a key aperture, simultaneously influencing both polarization components (E<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">θ</sub> and E<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">φ</sub>) to achieve a larger overall XP reduction. The proposed designs are validated through simulations and measurements, demonstrating a peak H-plane XP reduction of −32.0 dB at 3.0 GHz and −25.0 dB at 2.9 GHz for the RT-SMSIW and ST-SMSIW antennas, respectively. The antennas also maintain ultra-compactness with frequency tuning without added complexity, making them well-suited for wireless applications.

title: Design of 3D Steerable Frequency-Invariant Beamformers With Concentric Circular Superarrays
authors: Xueqin Luo, Xudong Zhao, Jilu Jin, Gongping Huang, Jingdong Chen, Jacob Benesty
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Superarrays refer to microphone arrays that combine both omnidirectional and directional sensors, enabling higher array gain or additional functionalities that traditional arrays with the same geometry cannot achieve. In our previous work, we demonstrated that concentric circular superarrays (CCSAs) can achieve directivity and three-dimensional (3D) steering capabilities comparable to volumetric arrays, but with a more compact, two-dimensional geometry. This makes CCSAs particularly promising for high-fidelity speech signal in compact devices. However, prior CCSA designs have been limited to omnidirectional and bidirectional sensors, restricting their flexibility and broader applicability. Additionally, the theoretical conditions required for effective array configuration remain unclear. This paper introduces a generalized framework for designing CCSAs and their corresponding fully steerable, frequency-invariant beamformers in 3D space. The contributions are twofold: 1) a method is proposed for designing 3D steerable, frequency-invariant beamformers using CCSAs equipped with directional microphones of arbitrary types; and 2) the necessary and sufficient conditions for array configurations are derived to enable effective design of first-, second-, and third-order frequency-invariant beamformers. We further summarize the construction of first-, second-, and third-order beamformers. Extensive simulations and real experiments validate the proposed method and demonstrate the practical efficacy and theoretical novelty of our approach.

title: A remote optical fiber dosimeter for environmental radiation based on GAGG:Ce radioluminescence
authors: Diantao Luo, Liye Wang, Nan Yu, Qiong Ma, Qiangyu Cai, Haiyang Sun, Hongxiang Kang
abstract: To monitor environmental radiation dose rates, a cerium-doped gadolinium gallium aluminum garnet (GAGG:Ce) fiber-coupled dosimeter was developed for the first time. The dosimeter utilized three optical fiber parameters: core diameter of 400μm with a length of 113m, core diameter of 400μm with a length of 1m, and core diameter of 1000μm with a length of 1m. Within the dose rate ranges of 0.1–998mGy/h, 0.04–980mGy/h, and 0.01–982mGy/h, all three optical fiber dosimeters exhibited linear responses. The net count rate variation coefficient of a single remote measurement experiment using the fiber dosimeter with a 400μm core diameter and 113m length at a dose rate of 200mGy/h was 0.56%, while the average variation coefficient from 10 repeated irradiation experiments was 0.76%. These results indicate that the remote optical fiber dosimeter achieved stable dose rate measurements from 0.1 to 998mGy/h at a distance of 113m. The GAGG:Ce optical fiber dosimeter met the requirements for remote real-time monitoring of environmental radiation dose rates.

title: Toward Pareto Optimal Voltage Distribution in Power Efficient Low-Noise Amplifiers
authors: Bo Lindstrom, Jesse Moody
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This document details the design of a low-power, high-gain low-noise amplifier (LNA) in 45-nm CMOS. The superb RF metrics and small footprint of the device make it an excellent candidate for integration into ultrawideband impulse radio (IR-UWB) and 6G satellite communication systems. Exceptional performance is obtained by carefully optimizing voltage and current distributions for each transistor in the multistage amplifier, specifically at the input, where an extremely power efficient topology is adopted. The input stage leverages two complementary current reuse amplifier cells stacked in series between the supply rail and ground. Sharing a common dc bias current, their RF currents are summed in parallel through capacitive coupling. This allows for a fourfold power savings with no penalty to voltage gain when compared to a conventional approach. At each gain stage, a degree of device stacking is chosen to progress toward a Pareto optimal voltage distribution (POVD), which considers the available supply voltage, expected RF signal swing, and minimum operating voltage of the FET devices. Judicious consideration of these factors can yield power savings at no cost to gain, linearity, or noise. Adhering to this design methodology enables an LNA, which consumes 6.5 mW of power, and demonstrates a peak gain of 24.1 dB, 2.9-GHz bandwidth (BW), a 4.3-dB noise figure (NF), and an IP1dB of −22.9 dBm. This equates to an excellent LNA figures of merit (FOM) when compared to similar devices in the C- and X-bands.
