title: Modulation Strategy for Dual-Active-Bridge Converter with Mitigated Voltage Oscillation
authors: Yueyin Wang, Zhan Shen, Wu Chen, Zewei Hao, Xuhao Zhu, Haozhe Jin, Siyi Luo, Bin Cui, Yushuo Chen
abstract: The dual active bridge (DAB) converter is promising for DC systems since it provides galvanic insolation and high efficiency. In most situations, the full-bridge AC output and DC voltage are observed, while overlooking the possible high frequency voltage oscillations (HFVOs) at the transformer port. HFVOs threaten the insulation of transformers. The causes of HFVOs have not yet been clarified. This paper finds that HFVOs are caused by the harmonics within the series-resonance frequency band, rather than the single frequency. Moreover, existing solutions mostly rely on optimizing transformer winding structures, which causes a tradeoff between HFVOs, efficiency, and insulation performance. To address this issue, this paper proposes a modulation method that reduces HFVOs by optimizing the output harmonic content in the resonance band. The root mean square (RMS) current of the inductor is also optimized simultaneously to ensure efficiency. The proposed strategy is validated on a 12kW/50kHz/750V prototype. Compared to the method that only optimizes the RMS current, the proposed one achieved the optimal RMS current while reducing voltage oscillations by 77%.

title: Shared-Exclusive Disentangled Representation Learning With Channel Attention for Incipient Fault Detection in Multimode Power Inverter Systems
authors: Shuihui Rao, Yu Shuai, Zhihua Xiong, Min Wang
abstract: Inverter systems play a critical role in modern power conversion and energy management applications, where they often operate under diverse and complex modes. The presence of multiple operating modes leads to varying data distributions, posing significant challenges for accurate fault detection across different working scenarios. Existing methods struggle to disentangle mode-invariant and mode-specific features that effectively represent incipient faults, while also lacking selective attention across the disentangled feature spaces. To address this issue, this article proposes a shared and exclusive representation learning model (SERLM) for fault detection in multimode inverter systems. SERLM leverages shared and exclusive modules to extract mode-invariant and mode-specific features, respectively, and employs a novel multi-scale regularized channel attention (MRCA) strategy to enhance feature fusion. Additionally, two statistics are designed: one based on shared features to detect global anomalies across modes and another derived from reconstruction error to capture localized deviations. The effectiveness of feature extraction in SERLM is rigorously analyzed from a theoretical perspective. The proposed approach is validated through experiments on a power inverter system, demonstrating its superiority in detecting incipient faults under multiple modes, achieving a fault detection rate that is 6.25% higher than state-of-the-art methods.

title: XAPT: eXplainable Anomaly-driven Prediction of Threat Stages in APT Campaigns
authors: Wei Lu, Issa Traoré, Isaac Woungang, Eric Brown, Marcelo L. Brocardo, Qiaoyan Yu, Ornella Lucresse Soh
abstract: Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) are long-lived, targeted cyberattacks that progress through multiple stages, characterized by strong stealth and intent. To achieve accurate and interpretable stage-level prediction, we propose XAPT, an eXplainable, anomaly-driven framework for APT campaign analysis. XAPT is centered on three key innovations. First, we derive PCA-based reconstruction errors and transform them into calibrated probabilistic anomaly scores, enabling principled quantification of the event abnormality. Second, these calibrated scores are incorporated into a Bayesian Network-based multiclass classifier for cyber-kill-chain stage inference, capturing uncertainty and inter-feature dependencies. Third, SHAP-based feature attribution reveals how anomaly scores and other features contribute to classification outcomes, offering transparent and analytically friendly explanations. Evaluation of two public datasets shows that XAPT achieves high stage-level detection accuracy while producing actionable feature-level interpretations that support operational analysis. By unifying calibrated anomaly scoring, Bayesian inference, and SHAP explanation, XAPT offers a comprehensive and interpretable solution for advanced threat detection.

title: VCHAR: A Variance-Driven Framework for Complex Human Activity Recognition with Vague Label
authors: Sun Yuan, Salami Pargoo Navid, Ortiz Jorge
abstract: Complex human activity recognition (CHAR) remains a pivotal challenge within ubiquitous computing, especially in the context of smart environments. Existing studies typically require meticulous labeling of both lower-level and higher-level activities—a task that is laborintensive and prone to errors, focusing on datasets that precisely label simple activities or their sequences. These approaches are often impractical in real-world settings due to the scarcity and inaccuracies of available datasets. In response to these challenges, we introduce VCHAR (Variance-Driven Complex Human Activity Recognition), a novel framework capable of detecting both low-level activities and their corresponding high-level activities without requiring precise temporal or sequential labeling of the lower-level activities.We introduce a novel approach by applying KL divergence as the objective function, modeling the outputs of lower-level activities as distributions over target time intervals while concurrently detecting higher-level activities. This method only requires vaguely labeled activities, removing the need for precise, second-by-second annotations.Additionally, to enhance the layperson’s understanding of our model’s results, we are the first to apply a novel generative method that explains result of the sensor model through video, making the information more accessible and understandable.Our evaluation across three publicly available datasets demonstrates that VCHAR uses KL divergence to model the lower-level activity distribution over specific time intervals, enhancing the accuracy of complex activity recognition. Furthermore, user studies confirm that VCHAR’s explanations are more intelligible compared to existing methods, facilitating a broader understanding of complex activity recognition among non-experts.

title: ITER Central Solenoid Manufacturing and Assembly Progress
authors: Y. Miyoshi, A. Bruton, C. Cormany, T. Schild, I. Rodin, A. Campbell, K. Freudenberg, N. Martovetsky, J. Rathbun, D. Vandergriff, K. Wooley, B. Fledderman, K. Khumthong, N. Norausky, E. Ortiz, J. Sheeron, J. Smith
abstract: ITER Central Solenoid (CS) system manufacturing, after ten years, completed all coil modules manufacturing and testing to full current 40 kA at 4.5 K. Meanwhile the assembly work at ITER has progressed steadily since its start five years ago. A summary of characteristic technical challenges found in manufacturing and assembly, and an outlook of what is expected towards the completion of CS assembly are presented.

title: Large-Scale IoT Sensor Network Planning Based on Empirical NB-IoT and LTE CAT-M Measurements for Underground Water System
authors: Priit Roosipuu, Ivar Annus, Alar Kuusik, Nils Kändler, Muhammad Mahtab Alam
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: The planning of low-power wide-area network (LPWAN) access technologies NB-IoT (Narrow-band Internet of Things) and LTE CAT-M based sensor network for underground water systems have been evaluated in this study. Large-scale empirical measurements of these technologies at 800 MHz and 1800 MHz have been conducted to assess the commercial network signal coverage and quality levels. More precisely, we show how to evaluate measurement samples against enhanced coverage level (ECL) repetitions. We consider signal strength and quality distributions as inputs for planning and evaluating a large-scale Internet of Things (IoT) sensor network. Three different types of typical city environments have been considered for these purposes. The analysis shows that, in most cases, CAT-M will outperform NB-IoT when implemented at 800 MHz, considering sensor energy consumption per single transmitted message. ECL repetitions on a lower frequency (800 MHz) implementation are caused mainly by low signal quality, where less than 2% of measured signal level samples are in the ECL2 and 1 range, but more than 30% of measured signal quality samples are in the ECL2 and 1 range. Repetitions on higher frequencies (1800 MHz) are dictated by signal level and quality, with more than 40% of signal level samples and 50% of signal quality samples in the ECL2 and 1 range. Signal level and quality distributions will provide a basis for sensor lifetime estimation and support efficient integrated IoT asset management system management.

title: ·Embedding Porous Structure Electrodes into T-Shirt for ECG Monitoring: Combining Low Impedance and High SNR for Optimized Comfortability and Performance
authors: Ke Xue, Tianxu Hao, Cheng Zhang, Jiaqi Ding, Xiaoyuan Chen, Jing Wang, Lei He, Min Wang, Jun Xu
abstract: This study proposes a customized design T-shirt embedded with a porous structured dry electrode for ECG monitoring. The porous electrodes are based on graphene nanoplatelets (GNP-3A) and polyamide 66 (PA66) materials. First, through electrical performance testing, it is demonstrated that the proposed dry electrode has high conductivity, with a skin contact impedance of 17.6 kΩ at 100Hz, significantly lower than commercial Ag/AgCl wet electrodes. In addition, the electrode can accurately capture ECG signals with a high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of 34.76 dB, which is an 8% improvement over traditional Ag/AgCl wet electrodes. Additionally, the design optimizes wearability by using soft and highly elastic fabric and integrates electrodes using metal snap buttons to reduce the discomfort typically caused by traditional wet electrodes, thereby enhancing comfort during prolonged use. Subsequently, to evaluate the performance improvements of the smart ECG T-shirt in terms of comfort and signal acquisition, a self-constructed ECG monitoring system was used to record single-lead ECG signals from adult males wearing the smart ECG T-shirt, under different motion states such as resting, walking, and jogging. The P-Q-R-S-T characteristic peaks, motion artifacts, and noise were assessed and compared with commercially available ECG monitoring T-shirts. The comparison results indicate that the integrated design of the electrode and T-shirt effectively balances comfort and performance in practical applications, with no skin irritation or discomfort observed during prolonged use. This work offers an innovative and practical solution for daily, comprehensive, wearable, and scalable ECG monitoring, showing great promise for future applications.

title: Design and Optimization of Array Structured Active Layer Geometry for Enhanced Sensitivity in Flexible Piezoresistive Pressure Sensor
authors: Neeraj, Navneet Gupta
abstract: Flexible and wearable piezoresistive pressure sensors (FPPS) are attracting great attention for applications in healthcare monitoring, human-machine interfaces, soft robotics, and human motion detection. Developing an efficient sensor with maintained high sensitivity and a wide sensing range remains a significant challenge. In this study, active layer geometry based Flexible Piezoresistive Pressure Sensor (FPPS) are systematically optimized using a finite element method (FEM) based on COMSOL Multiphysics 6.0. Graphene is employed as an active layer with different geometries such as rectangular, trapezium, and pyramid array on a polyethylene naphthalate (PEN) substrate. Simulation results shows that the FPPS integrated with pyramid-array structured (PAS) of graphene layer exhibits a maximum sensitivity of 785 kPa⁻¹ under an external pressure range of 0 to 0.1 kPa, due to its superior stress distribution and deformation characteristics. The proposed FPPS with a PAS graphene layer has excellent potential for wearable and biomedical applications, including rehabilitation monitoring, human-machine interaction, soft robotics, artificial electronic skin, respiration monitoring, and sports monitoring.

title: Feynman Meets Turing: Computability Aspects of Exact Circuit Synthesis, Gate Efficiency, and the Spectral Gap Conjecture
authors: Yannik N. Boeck, Holger Boche, Frank H.P. Fitzek
abstract: We consider exact quantum circuit synthesis, quantum gate efficiency, and the spectral gap conjecture from the perspective of computable analysis. Circuit synthesis, in both its exact and its approximate variant, is fundamental to the circuit model of quantum computing. As an engineering problem, however, the practical and theoretical aspects of quantum circuit synthesis are far from being fully understood. Particularly, this concerns explicit methods for gate-agnostic circuit synthesis and questions of gate efficiency. More than 20 years ago, Harrow et al. published their famous spectral gap theorem – given a suitable family of quantum gates, it is possible to approximate any unitary transformation by means of a quantum circuit whose length is proportional to the required accuracy's logarithm. Moreover, Harrow et al. suspected that all universal gate families allow for this type of approximation, a hypothesis that became known as the spectral gap conjecture and remains unproven until today. Being an entirely classical task, quantum circuit synthesis must be considered in the context of digital computing – that is, in the context of Turing computability and computable analysis. Using the relevant mathematical framework, we establish no-go results concerning exact quantum circuit synthesis and quantum big-O analysis. Our findings relate to the theory of approximate t-designs, which has recently received notable attention through the literature. Moreover, as follows from our findings, the existence of an algorithm that computes leading big-O coefficients would prove the spectral gap conjecture true within the computable special unitary group.

title: Identification and Prediction of Multiple Intelligence Patterns among University Students using Machine Learning for Personalized Learning and Instruction_supp4-3635866.docx
authors: Sonia Corraya
abstract: Humans possess seven types of intelligence for learning. However, conventional educational systems mostly rely only on the Linguistic and Mathematical types. This narrow focus leaves other intelligences unrecognized and unutilized in learners’ learning processes. The main challenge lies in holistically addressing diverse intelligence levels in typical educational settings. Prior research isolated dominant intelligence traits for personalization, which lack objectivity and fail to utilize the full spectrum of learning potentials. The goal of this research is to identify and predict underlying learning patterns in university students, enabling addressing all types of intelligence holistically at the group level. To achieve this, a multi-algorithm framework integrating unsupervised and supervised learning is developed to analyze Multiple Intelligences profiles and associated learner parameters from the Learning Meta-Learning dataset. MI profiles capture all seven types of intelligences. K-Means clustering identified three unique and interpretable MI profile patterns, outperforming the Two-Step clustering algorithm. For prediction, CatBoost achieved 92.20% accuracy across seven algorithms, including Random Forest, Extra Trees, XGBoost, LightGBM, K-Nearest Neighbors, and HistGradientBoosting. By incorporating Explainable Artificial Intelligence through Shapley Additive Explanations and optimizing features, its accuracy improved to 93.66%. The identified Multiple Intelligences profile patterns offer actionable insights. Beyond the high-level guidelines for personalizing instruction outlined in this paper, they can inform various personalized educational approaches and support further research by providing a structured understanding of learner diversity and a predictive framework.

title: RSG-SLAM: A Robust, Enhanced Semantic and Geometric Visual SLAM for Dynamic Environments
authors: Jianhao Bo, Wei Sun, Changhao Sun, Ruofei He
abstract: Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) technology is fundamental to enabling autonomous driving. However, invariant environment represents a robust assumption in many visual SLAM systems, and this assumption constrains the operation of many visual SLAM systems in dynamic realistic environments that are the target of intelligent robotics, autonomous driving, and many other related applications. To address the issue that the existence of dynamic objects within environments seriously damages visual SLAM systems, we propose RSG-SLAM, a visual SLAM system built upon ORB-SLAM3 for visualizing dynamic scenes, using a dynamic mask compensation method and geometric association constraint method to enhance the accuracy of visual SLAM trajectory. First, a dynamic mask compensation method built upon the constant velocity model, feature affine constraints and mask boundary refinement is proposed to realize the accurate segmentation of dynamic objects in terms of semantics. Secondly, for dynamic entities that are not detected by semantic segmentation, a geometric correlation constraint model built upon the invariant characteristics of the absolute positions of static points is proposed, which removes feature points that do not satisfy motion consistency. In dynamic realistic environments, RSG-SLAM demonstrates sufficient accuracy, robustness, and real-time performance. RSG-SLAM supports both stereo and RGB-D sensors. Experimental results on the TUM, Bonn, KITTI datasets and real environments illustrate that RSG-SLAM is capable of enhancing the performance of the benchmark method in challenging dynamic scenarios.

title: True-Amplitude Gaussian-Beam Migration: An Extension of the Application to Viscoacoustic Media and to the Common-Offset Domain
authors: Wei Ouyang, Xingchen Shi, Qianru Xu, Weijian Mao, Yubo Yue
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Traditional viscoacoustic migration methods effectively compensate for amplitude loss and phase distortion caused by viscous attenuation. However, these methods predominantly focus on achieving accurate structural imaging. Preserving relative-amplitude information in migrated images is crucial for accurately restoring medium properties while imaging geometric structures under viscous attenuation conditions. In this paper, we present an efficient and stable method for viscoacoustic true-amplitude Gaussian beam migration in the common-offset domain, specifically designed to tackle this challenge. Our approach utilizes the multiparameter viscoacoustic Born scattering mechanism to recover the velocity and quality factor Q. The incorporation of Q into the migration process is achieved by defining Q-related complex-valued traveltime to compensate for attenuation effects. We illustrate the forward single scattering integral for the central beam component of the viscoacoustic common-offset scattered pressure wavefield, using attenuation-compensated Gaussian-beam expansions of the viscoacoustic Green’s function. This description, along with the estimation of the kernel of the single-scattering Hessian operator, enables us to develop a viscoacoustic Gaussian-beam pseudoinverse migration operator for common-offset data. This operator includes a Beylkin determinant and an invertible normal matrix associated with a causality term. Employing this derived pseudoinverse operator enhances subsurface structure imaging accuracy and preserves amplitude response information of material parameters throughout the viscoacoustic migration process. Numerical experiments and field data tests demonstrate that, with the proposed attenuation compensation method, it is possible to align the estimated parameters with their true values, yielding more accurate imaging and parameter estimations in viscoacoustic media compared to the traditional acoustic approach without attenuation compensation.

title: To Disclose or Not? Disclosure of Manufacturer Identity in Store Brand Supply Chains with Brand Spillover Effect and Online Reviews_supp1-3635663.pdf
authors: Yang Tong
abstract: The increasing prevalence of store brands has attracted both retailers and national manufacturers to participate in store brand operations. However, retailers face a strategic decision regarding whether to disclose the national manufacturer's identity information, especially considering the impacts of the brand spillover effect and online reviews. This research investigates the retailer's disclosure strategy by developing a two-period model and exploring how this decision impacts online review ratings. Our findings illustrate that although the brand spillover effect of disclosing the national manufacturer's identity information can elevate consumers' quality expectations for store brands, the influence of online reviews may diminish or even reverse this benefit. Specifically, a stronger brand spillover effect may adversely affect both parties and thus inhibit the retailer from disclosing such information, which is different from the conventional wisdom. Moreover, we demonstrate that disclosing the national manufacturer's identity is not advantageous for the retailer when the degree of the brand spillover effect is relatively low, consumers are more reference-dependent and rely more on online reviews to formulate quality expectations, and the quality level of the store brand is perceived as moderate. Finally, we consider several extensions, including strategic consumers, distinct pricing power structures, the effect of the national brand's online reviews, asymmetric consumer numbers, and heterogeneous consumer ratings, which either confirm the robustness of our findings or enrich the basic findings.

title: A Graph Attention Network-based Spatial Decomposition Method for Drug Repositioning
authors: Xiao Kang, Licai Zhang, Xinxing Yang, Lin Wang, Genke Yang, Jian Chu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Computational drug repositioning technology can identify potential uses for existing drugs and reduce the time and cost required in the drug development process. How to find appropriate representations of drugs and diseases to predict the associations between the two is the main objective of such tasks. With the emergence of graph neural networks in recent years, researchers learned drugs and diseases via graphs in a bid to improve the prediction accuracy. However, there are three key problems that have not been adequately studied: 1) They usually place drug disease association graphs, drug-drug similarity graphs, and disease-disease similarity graphs under the same se mantic space for learning, which lose the higher-order features of the different graphs. 2) They assign equal weight to each neighbor node when aggregating based on the drug disease association graph, but the effect and mechanism of a drug in treating different diseases are not consistent. 3) They adopt residual connections to enhance the role of the root node without considering that this operation amplifies the effect of anomalous features. In view of this, we first propose a graph attention network-based spatial decomposition method for drug repositioning. Specifically, we reduce the dimensions of the feature space by spatial decomposition and initialize the drug and diseaseem bedding in the drug-similarity subspace, disease-similarity subspace, anddrug-disease association subspace, respectively. The representations of drugs and diseases are jointly captured in the corresponding subspace based on similarity and therapeutic associations. Moreover, the extent of the associations is measured through the graph attention mechanism to explore higher-order neighborhood relationships between drugs and diseases. Finally, we introduce a targeted residual connection for personalized propagation of node features. Experiments on four benchmark datasets show that our proposed architecture outperforms current state-of-the-art approaches. The code of this paper can be accessed at https://github.com/shaoqiezi/GATSD.

title: A Design Space for Multiscale Visualization
authors: Mara Solen, Matt Oddo, Tamara Munzner
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Designing multiscale visualizations, particularly when the ratio between the largest scale and the smallest item is large, can be challenging, and designers have developed many approaches to overcome this challenge. We present a design space for visualization with multiple scales. The design space includes three dimensions, with eight total subdimensions. We demonstrate its descriptive power by using it to code approaches from a corpus we compiled of 52 examples, created by a mix of academics and practitioners. We demonstrate descriptive power by analyzing and partitioning these examples into four high-level strategies for designing multiscale visualizations, which are shared approaches with respect to design space dimension choices. We demonstrate generative power by analyzing missed opportunities within the corpus of examples, identified through analysis of the design space, where we note how certain examples could have benefited from different choices. We discuss patterns in the use of different dimension and strategy choices in the different visualization contexts of analysis and presentation.

title: FedCLD: A Federated Contrastive Learning Approach for Detecting Stealthy Attacks on Smart Grid with Unlabeled Data
authors: Xiaohan Huang, Zhenyong Zhang, Zhibo Yang, Chao Ren, David K. Y. Yau, Ruilong Deng
abstract: The smart grid is a critical infrastructure that must function reliably in a geographically decentralized structure. However, this structure renders the smart grid vulnerable to stealthy cyberattacks, and data silos further limit the sharing of datasets needed to train an effective attack-detection model. Moreover, most existing methods rely on the availability of enormous amounts of labeled data, which is scarce due to the need for domain knowledge. To address these issues, we propose FedCLD, a federated contrastive learning approach for detecting stealthy attacks using unlabeled data. FedCLD leverages Bootstrap Your Own Latent (BYOL), a contrastive learning model, to enhance its ability to learn robust representations from unlabeled data. With the federated learning paradigm, FedCLD enables local centers in different areas to collaboratively train local models without sharing raw datasets. Although the global representation is enhanced, the regional characteristics should be preserved. Therefore, a strategic local update scheme based on the exponential moving average is proposed. Furthermore, we theoretically prove the convergence of FedCLD with this modified update strategy. Experiments are conducted in the industry-level PowerWorld simulator to evaluate the performance of FedCLD.

title: Application of the Internet of Things (IoT) to Increase the Perfect Order Fulfillment Index in an Air Cargo Company Through the Integration of SCOR, TPM, and SLP Approaches
authors: Shirley Maza-Rodriguez, Edson Quispe-Chuquispuma, Rosa Salas-Castro
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: The perfect order fulfillment rate (POF) is a key indicator in global logistics. Its decrease affects the accuracy and punctuality of shipments, negatively impacting customer satisfaction and operating costs. This article presents a case study of a Peruvian company that transports air cargo, which during 2023 reported an average POF of 93.9%, evidencing a 4 % gap with respect to the expected optimal level of 98%. The root causes are identified as: errors in cargo handling, inaccurate manual records, lack of order traceability, and incomplete dispatches, which ultimately generate penalties and reprocessing. Therefore, the article proposes a comprehensive model that combines emerging technologies, such as the Internet of Things (IoT) for real monitoring, complemented by the SCOR approach for process standardization, TPM, and SLP, to optimize logistics processes and improve the indicator. The proposal was validated through a simulation under real-life operating conditions, the results of which demonstrated a 97.84% increase in the indicator, demonstrating improvements in efficiency and error reduction. Based on the results, the solution is intended to be replicable not only in air cargo transport but also in other logistics sectors, helping to maximize the profitability and sustainability of operations.

title: From Trust to Code: A Comparative Performance Analysis of Ethereum and Polygon for Decentralized University Research Funding
authors: Ruben Fernando Cuadros Mieses, Adolfo Jorge Prado Ventocilla, Edwin Jorge Montes Eskenazy
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Traditional university research funding is frequently undermined by high transaction costs, bureaucratic friction, and information asymmetries that erode donor trust. Blockchain technology, particularly through smart contracts, offers a new paradigm for transparent and efficient fund management. This study investigates the practical viability of this paradigm by developing a decentralized funding platform and conducting a rigorous comparative performance analysis of two leading blockchain infrastructures: Ethereum's Sepolia testnet (a Layer 1 analogue) and Polygon's Amoy testnet (a Layer 2 solution). In 50 consecutive executions per network, the smart contract maintained 100% success on both, yet with Polygon maintaining an average confirmation time of 2.1 seconds versus Sepolia's 5.3 seconds. Furthermore, a preliminary usability study (N=20) confirms that users perceive the Polygon-based platform as significantly higher in performance and overall satisfaction. These findings provide robust quantitative and visual evidence that Layer 2 scaling solutions are not only viable but essential for creating decentralized applications that meet the practical requirements of speed, cost-efficiency, and positive user experience in domains like academic funding. This work contributes a critical empirical benchmark for the emerging field of Decentralized Science (DeSci) and offers a validated architectural model for transparent, automated, and globally accessible research financing.

title: Evaluating Defensive Influence in Multi-Agent Systems Using Graph Attention Networks
authors: Gregory Everett, Ryan J. Beal, Tim Matthews, Timothy J. Norman, Sarvapali D. Ramchurn
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Evaluating individual contributions from team members is a critical challenge across many domains, such as security and team sports. While progress has been made in valuing contributions, such as target defence in security or on-ball performance in football (soccer), many aspects of performance, such as off-ball football actions, remain difficult to quantify. We introduce GAPP, a Graph Attention Network model that predicts football pass reception probabilities and provides interpretable insights into off-ball defending. Using attention mechanisms, GAPP captures player interactions and introduces two new metrics to quantify defender contributions. We tested GAPP on 306 English Premier League matches, and showed it reduces binary cross-entropy loss by 6.4 percent compared to multiple baselines for pass reception prediction, while offering unique insights for off-ball defender evaluation for coaches, scouts and teams. This work shows the potential of graph attention networks for analysing complex multi-agent systems like football.

title: Proposal to Improve Service Level in HDPE Barge Deliveries Using TSM-IoT, DDMRP, and Digital Twins
authors: Gianella Denisse Hermoza Portugal, Alonso Akiro Pardo Tanamachi, Fernando Noriega Bardalez
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This paper presents a proposal aimed at improving the service level in the delivery of floating barges made of high-density polyethylene (HDPE) at the Peruvian company SIGECO S.A.C., a project-based manufacturing company. The analysis identified the main obstacle as the poor performance of the OTIF (On Time In Full) indicator, caused by the lack of planning for distribution routes, insufficient logistics oversight, shortages of materials for final assembly, and delays in passing safety inspections. To address these challenges, the adoption of three technological tools aligned with Industry 4.0 principles is proposed: an IoT-enhanced Transportation Management System (TMS), the DDMRP methodology for materials planning, and the use of Digital Twins. The feasibility of the proposal was assessed through a quantitative analysis, the development of a technical design, and a review of its economic impact. The results showed improvements in the traceability of logistics operations, a reduction in assembly times, greater availability of input, and an increase in the level of customer service. In conclusion, the technical gap identified was mitigated, and the proposed solution demonstrates potential for replication in other industrial contexts with similar challenges in managing complex deliveries.

title: Performance Improvement Model Based on TPM-IoT, SMED and Process Standardization in a Metalworking Line
authors: Camila Alesandra Cuadros-Isidro, Kevin Leonardo Dextre-Ocrospoma, José Luis Álvarez-Arteaga
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This study seeks to optimize the performance of a metalworking line by applying TPM, SMED and process standardization, also integrating the Internet of Things (IoT) into the TPM to monitor the status of the equipment in real time. The objective is to reduce downtime, improve maintenance and increase productivity, especially in the company's most profitable product. Currently, there is a performance gap of 19.91%, which has generated a loss of 11.61% of annual profits in 2023. The implemented proposal achieved an improvement in overall performance by 8.70<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>, addressing specific root causes: rework (CR1) with an improvement of 19.45%, availability (CR2) with 6.35%, operational efficiency (CR3) with 3.04% and productivity (CR4) with 0.36 bowls / hr. These results demonstrate a positive impact on the efficiency and profitability of the process, bringing it closer to the goal of achieving a minimum efficiency of 95%.

title: Emerging IOT Cybersecurity Threats in Machine Learning
authors: Venkata Ramanaiah Chintha, Suresh Kumar R. Akkemgari, Venkata Naga Ravi Kiran Nizampatnam, Ramanjeet Kaur, M Sudagar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The development of Internet of Things (IOT) devices has led to new danger routes in our connected society in recent years. Meagre IoT security practices make all these devices interesting targets for attackers, even though they bring automation and real-time feedback. This work presents a comprehensive analysis of how to detect and mitigate cybersecurity threats in IoT, leveraging statistical anomaly detection with machine learning (ML) techniques. A combination of the RF (Random Forest) technique and packet size analysis to detect unusual behaviours and classify them as network intrusions was employed. Additionally, a CIAE risk matrix was applied to estimate the exposure degree of device-level vulnerabilities. That item stands for CIAE or confidentiality, integrity, availability and exploitability. On benchmark datasets, the recommended technique beat traditional models with 96.3% accuracy and 0.98 AUC. These results suggest combining strategies to improve IoT cybersecurity.

title: Investigating Relationships Among Fintech Drivers Using PCA-DEMATEL Approach
authors: Shyam Sunder Agrawal, Suchita Gupta, Neha Sahu, Kuljeet Chourey
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The research work is devoted to investigate a compact set and finding interrelationships among FinTech Drivers. For this purpose, the two well-known techniques, namely Principal Components Analysis (PCA) and Decision-Making Trial and Evaluation Laboratory (DEMATEL) along with reliability testing, were used. First of all, with the help of expert’s opinions (a group of 15 experts) and literature survey, the list of 20 drivers was created. In the next step, a systematically designed 5-Point Likert’s scale-based questionnaire, containing 20 drivers, was circulated to 250 respondents around the country for providing responses for investigating their intensity of importance. Based on their responses, reliability testing as well as identification of principal components, using principal component analysis, was accomplished. then, again a questionnaire was sent to the same group of 15 experts for investigating the importance of investigated 5 principal components, and their responses was fed to the DEMATEL algorithm, which yielded the degree of impotence of drivers as well as cause effect relationships among them. As the results of research work, principal components, Willingness to change, Skill factors, Technology factors, Organizational factors and financial factors were investigated along with their importance and relationships among them. The research work represents the original work of the researcher for investigating a compatible set of FinTech Drivers as well as finding out the relationships among them.

title: A Systematic Review on Solar Trees: Design Efficiency and Sectoral Applications
authors: Fiorella Melissa Zevallos Vargas, Crysstal Nickole Medina Cruces, Edwar Andrés Velarde Allazo, Gerson Márquez
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Solar trees have emerged as an innovative renewable energy technology aimed at addressing climate change and the decline of conventional electricity generation. This study systematically reviews the development, structural typologies, and sectoral applications of solar trees, with a focus on their energy performance. A structured search was conducted using the PICO framework, and the selection of information sources followed the PRISMA guidelines, applying predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria. Forty studies published between 2019 and 2024 were selected from Scopus, EBSCOhost, and Google Scholar databases. The results revealed four main structural typologies (spiral, single-trunk with branches, flat, and spherical) with spiral models being the most prevalent. Among them, the 3/8 phyllotaxy design demonstrated up to 53.9% higher efficiency than conventional flat panels. Applications were predominantly found in the education sector (56%), followed by agriculture, urban infrastructure, residential areas, transportation, and healthcare. Most implementations were experimental, limiting large-scale deployment. A site-adapted design for Arequipa is proposed: a bifacial spiral solar tree on a 3/8 phyllotaxis helix with a seasonal tilt gradient, passive trunk ventilation, and low-energy automation. In conclusion, solar trees offer significant potential for energy generation in limited spaces and diverse contexts, but further research is needed to standardize performance evaluations and promote their adoption across sectors.

title: Effects of Model Merge on Developers' Brain Dynamics: An EEG Microstate Analysis
authors: Willian Bolzan, Robson Keemps, Kleinner Farias
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems (MODELS)
abstract: Model merging in model-based engineering imposes high cognitive demands, as developers must identify, reconcile, and integrate changes across parallel artifacts. To explore the neural dynamics of this process, we conducted a controlled experiment with 35 developers performing merge tasks in two representational formats—sentential (Java code) and diagrammatic (UML class diagrams)—while EEG was continuously recorded. We clustered EEG signals into the four canonical microstate classes (A–D), which are well-established in cognitive neuroscience and represent recurring large-scale brain activity patterns. In alternating cycles of eyes-closed rest and task execution, we analyzed microstate dynamics and found diametrically opposite patterns depending on representation: in the sentential format, microstates A, C, and D increased significantly in duration, occurrence, and coverage, whereas in the diagrammatic format, A and C decreased, B declined moderately, and D showed reductions in occurrence and coverage. These findings reinforce the feasibility of microstate metrics as fine-grained biomarkers of cognitive overload in model-integration operations, paving the way for cognitively aware tools and adaptive environments capable of automatically adjusting abstraction levels or issuing high-load alerts.

title: Reasoning with Knowledge Graphs for Trustworthy Course Recommendation
authors: Md Akib Zabed Khan, Dongsheng Luo, Agoritsa Polyzou
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Course recommendation systems (CRS) are essential tools that help university students navigate their academic journey and select appropriate courses. Most of the existing models function as black boxes, offering little transparency in their recommendations. This lack of explainability reduces students' trust and willingness to adopt these systems, as they often want to understand the reasoning behind course suggestions. To address this issue, we introduce a knowledge graph-enhanced explainable course recommendation framework to provide personalized course recommendations to students in the upcoming semester. Our model, GGCR, integrates multiple techniques, including feature (keywords) extraction from course descriptions, graph attention networks (GAT) to build high-quality embeddings, and gated recurrent units (GRU) to capture session-based and sequential patterns over multiple semesters. We also explore the explainability capabilities of the best-performing models. We utilize course embeddings to offer course-similarity-based explanations. In addition, using the attention weights of the GAT module, our approach provides more detailed path reasoning-based explanations for each recommendation. In our experiments, conducted on real-world data, the proposed GGCR model not only exceeds existing state-of-the-art models in performance but also enhances explainability. This highlights that explainability does not have to come at the cost of accuracy. Furthermore, we assess the quality of different types of explanations using the Fidelity measure, large language models (LLMs), and human experts to ensure that our framework provides meaningful and interpretable recommendations.

title: Estimating the Effectiveness of Test-Driven Development to Reduce Bugs
authors: Vamsi Krishna Gottipati, Sourabh Sanghi, Prem Nishanth Kothandaraman, Lucky Jha, Akshit Kohli, Shailendra Tiwari
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Modern technology developments and data research are used to figure out whether Test-Driven Development (TDD) works at reducing software problems. This research examines TDD, a programming process that involves creating test cases prior to implementing code, using an orderly Red-Green-Refactor cycle. Modern strategy utilizes two techniques: a mathematical modeling structure that assesses the quantity of defects experienced whether or not it utilizes TDD, and the organizational diagram which graphically depicts how TDD operates. The case presents a scenario along with 100 software functions to demonstrate that TDD can reduce the number of problems from 10% to 5%. This reduces the bug count by half. A regular testing-feedback loop helps this outcome by guaranteeing code correctness and encouraging early error investigation. The study shows that TDD improves program security and code quality and maintainability. The results presented here give an excellent rationale to add TDD to the way software engineers work now, and they also help the organization learn more about the way agile methods work recently.

title: Development of a Low-Cost Phantom for Quality Control of B and Doppler Modes in Ultrasound Systems Installed in Peruvian Health Centers
authors: Pedro Martin Lastres Soriano, Kevyn Arnold Visso Campomanes, Paul Anthony Alfaro Purisaca
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This article presents the development of a Low-Cost Phantom for Quality Control of B and Doppler Modes in Ultrasound Systems Installed in Peruvian Health Centers. Given the resource limitations and metrological challenges in the country, this prototype aims to provide an accessible solution for evaluating the precision and reliability of ultrasound equipment. The phantom combines accessible materials such as paraffin gel, distilled water, glycerin, and silicone tubing to mimic the acoustic properties of biological tissue and blood flow. Additionally, it incorporates an automated flow control system for Doppler testing. Test results on five different sonographs demonstrate that the phantom can effectively evaluate parameters such as spatial resolution, image uniformity, measurement accuracy, and velocity in Doppler mode. With an estimated manufacturing cost of $186, this prototype represents a viable alternative to commercial phantoms, which can cost around $3,000. Opportunities for improvement include adding more complex vascular structures and evaluating pulsed flow. This work contributes to improving ultrasound diagnosis in resource-limited areas by providing an affordable and easily reproducible quality control tool.

title: Lean Waste Prioritization in Integration with Sustainability and Circular Manufacturing
authors: Jhoselin Jhohana Garro Pastor, Ariana Yamile Oquiche Huarcaya, Inés Tarazona Marañón, Susana Ulloa Arellano
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Circular manufacturing and sustainability are strategic pillars for resource optimization environmental impact in the industry. To achieve them, it is necessary to identify and eliminate Lean waste. This article explores the identification and prioritization of lean waste in relation to circular manufacturing and sustainability. A comprehensive literature review, established how waste elimination can significantly contribute to more efficient and sustainable production. To address the challenges of prioritizing these wastes, the Fuzzy Analytic Hierarchy Process (Fuzzy AHP) methodology is used. The results show how the most critical waste categories impact both circular manufacturing and sustainability, providing key tools to improve operational efficiency and reduce environmental impact in the manufacturing industry.

title: Exploring the Development of Microgrids Using Residential Rooftop Photovoltaic Systems as an Alternative to the Existing Grid in Puerto Rico
authors: Geralis Del Valle-Nieves, Abdiel V. Villegas-Rodriguez, Armando J Bozzo-Vazquez, Aleishka N Rodriguez-Buxo, Miguel A Goenaga-Jimenez, Hermes Calderon
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: This article explores the creation of microgrids using photovoltaic systems installed on residential rooftops in Puerto Rico, comparing their performance and benefits with those of the existing electrical grid. Using the island's abundant solar energy potential, residential rooftops were analyzed using Google Earth and PVWatts software to identify feasible photovoltaic installations. The findings reveal that rooftop systems can generate 2 to 3 times more energy than residential consumption, allowing excess energy to be shared with the central grid or neighboring users. To design the microgrids, various software tools, including the Microgrid Design Toolkit (MDT), were utilized to achieve a balance between technical performance and economic feasibility. This study highlights how these microgrids could enhance grid resilience, reduce dependence on fossil fuels, and lower greenhouse gas emissions. Future work will further quantify the economic and environmental benefits of implementing these systems, supporting Puerto Rico's transition to a sustainable energy model.

title: Evaluating Interpretability Using Logical Relations: Do Saliency Maps Encode Relevant Information?
authors: Leonid Schwenke, Martin Atzmueller
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: With their increase in performance, neural network architectures also become more complex, necessitating explainability. Therefore, many new and improved methods are currently emerging, which often generate so-called saliency maps in order to improve interpretability. Those methods are often evaluated by visual expectations, yet this typically leads towards a confirmation bias. Due to a lack of a general metric for explanation quality, non-accessible ground truth data about the model's reasoning and the large amount of involved assumptions, multiple works claim to find flaws in those methods. However, this often leads to unfair comparison metrics. Additionally, the complexity of most datasets (mostly images or text) is often so high, that approximating all possible explanations is not feasible. For those reasons, this paper introduces a test for saliency map evaluation: proposing controlled experiments based on all possible model reasonings over multiple simple logical datasets. Using the contained logical relationships, we aim to understand how different saliency methods handle information in different class discriminative scenarios (e.g., via complementary and redundant information). By introducing multiple new metrics, we analyse propositional logical patterns towards a non-informative attribution score baseline to find deviations of typical expectations. Our results show that saliency methods can encode classification relevant information into the ordering of saliency scores, resulting in unreliable interpretations.

title: A security framework: Sensitive data from wearable devices in Health Care
authors: Sheetal V A, Jyothi S Nayak
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Wearable devices have become an integral part of our lives, and these devices collect a lot of sensitive personal data and transmit that data for analysis. Analysis of data related to a person’s vitals is crucial as it may give insights into the well-being of a person. However, processed data required for analysis in a computing system like edge/cloud requires a connection to the internet and data communicated over the channel; the data that gets communicated between these devices, as a result of the cloud, raises significant security, privacy, and compliance concerns. To address all the issues presented above, this paper proposes a robust framework that, when implemented, will significantly enhance data transfer security between wearable devices and the cloud and provide data security through encryption techniques and authentication mechanisms at every stage. To enhance protection against possible threats from harmful attacks and unauthorized access, the framework incorporates multiple security layers, featuring compliance, regulations for secure data storage, and fully verified encryption from end to end. Amid rising cybersecurity threats, the promising implications of this framework provide optimism and a beacon of hope.

title: Cloud-Based Digital Twins in Real-time Manufacturing Process Optimization
authors: Anshu Tiwari, Pranav Gupta, Avinash Tripathi, Deepak Kumar Shukla, Sandeep Kanaujia, Sandeep Gupta
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Modernising production processes with cloud-based digital twins allows real-time optimisation & smart operations. Digital twins offer continuous surveillance, predictive maintenance, & data-driven choices by digitally replicating physical resources through cloud computing, Iot, & sophisticated analytics. This study examines how cloud-based digital twins affect energy usage, failure rates, downtime, and processing times in manufacturing. Digital twins might improve efficiency, cost, and product quality in every factor, as demonstrated by comparing them against traditional methods. A comprehensive examination of modern (SOTA) digital twin mechanisms highlights the present technological developments powering this new era. The outcomes indicate that cloud-based digital twins enable smart manufacturing and create flexible, robust, as well as future-ready production systems.

title: Sustainable Industry 5.0 and Digital Transformation: Analytical Insights on Challenges, AI-Driven Strategies, Frameworks, and Future Directions
authors: Ramu Yadavalli, Anika Sumeet
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Digital transformation has advanced beyond the automation-centric principles of Industry 4.0 to embrace the human-centric, AI-driven vision of Industry 5.0, which emphasizes adaptability, sustainability, and intelligent collaboration. This study conducts an in-depth literature review of 20 key research articles, synthesizing the current trends, methodologies, and challenges shaping the evolution of Industry 5.0. A comparative analysis is performed between traditional and AI-enhanced digital transformation approaches, highlighting innovations in AI-based decision-making, edge computing, IoT integration, and data interoperability. To address persistent challenges, a comprehensive framework is proposed for a sustainable Industry 5.0 ecosystem that leverages AI, energy-efficient infrastructure, and scalable digital technologies. The study identifies emerging themes such as ethical AI governance, real-time analytics, and the transition toward resilient, decentralized infrastructures. A significant contribution is the structured integration of AI-driven automation, sustainable digital frameworks, and Industry 5.0 readiness. The findings offer a strategic direction for future research, supporting innovation, policy alignment, and industrial adoption of next-generation digital transformation models.

title: Modeling and Simulation of Mechanical Failures in Three-Phase Induction Motors Using Support Vector Machines
authors: Cielo Espinoza, Javier Aranda, Renzo Albatrino
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: The early detection of mechanical faults in three-phase induction motors is essential for enhancing operational reliability and reducing maintenance costs. This study presents a simulation-based methodology for fault diagnosis using supervised machine learning, specifically Support Vector Machines (SVMs). A 3 HP, 220 V, 60 Hz induction motor was modeled in Simulink, including detailed electrical and mechanical dynamics. Two types of mechanical failures—rotor imbalance and bearing defects—were simulated through controlled perturbations in torque and stiffness. From the resulting vibration and temperature signals, a total of 15 time, frequency, and thermal domain features were extracted in segmented windows. The classification model was trained on a synthetic dataset comprising 300 labeled samples representing three motor conditions: healthy, imbalance, and bearing failure. Using a radial basis function (RBF) kernel, the SVM classifier was optimized via cross-validation and Bayesian search. The model achieved an overall accuracy of 96.7% on the test set, with an area under the ROC curve (AUC) of 1.00 for all classes. The results demonstrate high diagnostic performance, even with a limited and entirely simulated dataset. This work validates the feasibility of using SVMs for accurate fault classification in induction motors based solely on vibration and temperature features. Although tested in a simulated environment, the method shows promising potential for future real-time implementation in predictive maintenance systems. Future work will focus on experimental validation and integration of additional signal types, such as motor current, to improve robustness and extend applicability to real industrial scenarios.

title: Machine Learning Approaches for the classification of infected Soyabean Leaves
authors: Veena K, Harshitha N, Sunil Kumar G, Pushpa C N, Thriveni J
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The productivity and quality of soyabean crops are greatly impacted by insect infestations, such as Diabrotica speciosa and caterpillars. For early and precise categorization, automated solutions are required because traditional detection techniques are time consuming and prone to mistakes. This paper proposes an automated system for classifying soyabean leaves as either healthy or infested utilizing GoogleNet, Random Forest, KNN, and SVM. According to the test results, GoogleNet outperformed Random Forest(97%), KNN(96%) and SVM(90%), achieving the highest accuracy of 98%. This shows how much deep learning models have improved in accurately detecting pests. By automating early infestation detection, decreasing reliance on manual inspection, and improving pest control tactics, the suggested approach improves precision agriculture. By enhancing crop health monitoring and reducing financial losses, the findings support sustainable farming.

title: Hybrid Model for Alzheimer Disease Prediction from Electronic Health Records of patients
authors: P. Jeba Christybai, R. PriyaAnand
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The chronic progressive neurodegenerative disorder Alzheimer's disease (AD) renders various challenges to diagnose and provide treatments early on. Standard diagnostic methods are based on cognitive assessment, imaging, and clinical examination, each of which are costly and time-consuming. In this research, a new method is introduced for utilizing Electronic Health Records (EHR) in the early diagnosis of AD. For the identification of relevant biomarkers in unstructured as well as structured EHRs like patient history, demographics, administered medication, and cognitive tests, the proposed method integrates ML with feature selection methods. The study utilizes a hybrid approach that integrates Transformer-based natural language processing for structured data and ensemble learning for processing text-based information. Experimental results on a large-scale EHR dataset illustrate that our model is superior to conventional ML methods in terms of predictive accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity. The proposed system provides a scalable and interpretable solution for physicians for the early detection to facilitate timely interventions.

title: Segmentation and Classification Techniques: A Comparative Analysis Based on Performance Properties
authors: Karan Chander S R, Dineshprasath GA, R Muruganandham
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The increasing use of intelligent systems in healthcare, remote sensing, and autonomous technologies demands high-precision image segmentation and classification tools. This study offers a comparative analysis of established methods, focusing on accuracy, computational efficiency, and adaptability to diverse data. While traditional models like SVMs and Decision Trees offer interpretability, they are often outperformed by advanced techniques. Deep learning models such as U-Net and 3D U-Net excel in segmentation, especially in medical imaging, while CNNs lead in classification by effectively capturing spatial hierarchies. The results highlight U-Net-based segmentation and CNN-based classification—particularly with multi-modal data—as the most effective solutions, guiding method selection based on task requirements and resource constraints.

title: Long Short Term Memory Model based Graph Convolution Network towards Deep Scale Fusion in Multimodal Emotion Recognition
authors: V. Balamurugan, K. Sivasankari
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Emotion is an important state of the human body with respect to neurological and physiological changes to human thought, feelings and behaviors. Especially human emotion is determined easily through conversations and behaviors. Thus recognizing human emotion in the conversation becomes significant to multiple key applications in healthcare, education and entertainment. Particularly recognizing human emotions on the video contents is gaining more attention in education and entertainment domain in large extent. Recognizing human emotions of the video content are performed with respect to multiple modalities in form of speech, gesture and facial expressions. Traditionally many researches has performed using natural language processing model and computer vision approaches through deep learning and machine learning for relationship modeling of the multimodal emotions with high scalability and reliability. Despite of several advantages, those architectures produces multiple challenges in feature aggregation of the multimodal features and feature alignment according to the emotion classes. In order to manage those challenges, new multimodal emotion recognition architecture is designed using graph convolution network and long short term memory network to aggregate multimodal feature and recognize the aggregated features emotion state. Initially pretrained model is used to extract the audio and video features of the cross model sequential data effectively. Graph Convolution Network is highly efficient in processing sequential data effectively with less parameter. Graph Convolution Network processes the visual features and audio features of multimodal dataset in form of graph structured data as node and edge. Node represents audio features and visual features and edge represents relationship between features. Transformed Graph data is processed in graph convolution layer on utilizing filter to learn features of the each sequence with its neighbor sequence to aggregate the similar features to be represented as feature embedding. Feature embedding of visual features and audio features in form candidate activation vector in long short term memory network. Fully connected layer of the model uses activation function to aggregate the visual and audio features as fusion mechanism with feature normalization. Finally softmax function of the fully connected layer using support vector machine to recognize emotion and classifies the particular emotions to available emotion class label. Extensive experiment and performance analysis of the current graph convolution network with long short term model is performed using benchmark dataset referred as CMU-Multimodal Opinion Sentiment and Emotion Intensity (CMU-MOSEI) dataset. On performance analysis, current model attains 98.7% accuracy which is found to be higher than conventional approaches. Finally proposed architecture is highly effective in identifying speaker emotions and further it improves stability of the emotion analysis on fusing richer feature information.

title: Computer Assisted Diagnosis: does it make sense for Lungs Tumor Detection? A Qualitative study with Pulmonologists.
authors: Robin Ghyselinck, Thibaut Septon, Nicolas Geuens, Margaux Mannaerts, Julie Vijghen, Samy Lachkar, Benoit Frenay, Bruno Dumas
publish: Proceedings of the 36th Conference on l'Interaction Humain-Machine
abstract: This study presents the evaluation by 10 pulmonologists of a diagnostic support system for lung cancer detection through optical endoscopy based on deep learning techniques. The evaluation relies on semi-structured interviews and System Usability Scale (SUS) tests to analyze the utility, reliability, and acceptability of this device during patient procedures. The results reveal a good SUS score, which is better than the vast majority of evaluated systems (88th percentile). Furthermore, the assessment highlights the absence of cognitive biases commonly associated with medical artificial intelligence (AI) systems. Our contribution is structured around three axes: the validation of an assistance system by clinical experts, the evaluation of potential biases during the use of AI tools in interventional pulmonology, and concrete recommendations for the design of medical diagnostic support interfaces. These findings emphasize the potential of assistance systems to improve early detection of lung cancer while preserving the decision-making autonomy of practitioners.

title: Consolidation of the Superconducting Circuits Energy Extraction Systems at the Large Hadron Collider
authors: M. Pojer, J.-E. Aas, D. Carrillo, G.-J. Coelingh, A. Donato, S. Georgakakis, M. Grigorov, B. Panev, S. Pemberton, V. Pirc
abstract: At the beginning of the next long shutdown, foreseen mid 2026, the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) will have been in operation for almost 20 years. After this period, the operation of the present Energy Extraction (EE) systems, that are part of the protection of the superconducting circuits of the LHC, will present significant challenges. As many system components will have exceeded their expected lifetimes, the risks of failure, system degradation, and obsolescence increase, ultimately compromising operational performance and safety. Although preventive maintenance is regularly performed on the EE facilities, an extensive consolidation program of these facilities has started, to improve their dependability and assure their performance till the end of operation of the LHC. This paper illustrates the two projects of consolidation of the 600 A and 13 kA EE systems, which aim to modernize and optimize these systems, ensuring that they continue to provide reliable protection while reducing maintenance costs and integrating the latest advances in materials, control technologies, and diagnostics, together with enhanced safety.

title: Surgical Workflow Prediction Via Visual Information in Laparoscopic and Robot-Assisted Surgery
authors: Yilin Li, Zijian Zhao, Renbo Li, Feng Li, Yizhuo Yuan
abstract: Surgical workflow prediction is critical for enhancing safety and providing real-time guidance in Computer-Assisted Surgery (CAS), particularly in laparoscopic and Robot-Assisted Surgery (RAS). We propose a novel visual information-based method for predicting surgical workflows at fine temporal scales. Our model adopts a two-stage training strategy. First, a ResNet50 backbone is trained to extract robust spatial features from individual surgical frames. Then, a predictive network is trained on sequential features. This network integrates a novel Temporal Feature Recorder (TFR) module, which aggregates both local and global temporal information from observed frame sequences, together with a Cross-Attention mechanism that fuses these temporal features with spatial information. A Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN) subsequently leverages this aggregated spatiotemporal representation to predict future feature states and corresponding workflow classifications. We evaluate our method on the JIGSAWS (activity level) and Cholec80 (phase level) datasets. It achieves superior classification accuracy (60.37%), significantly outperforming baselines on JIGSAWS, and delivers competitive accuracy (85.73%) with the lowest prediction error (MAE: 0.3672, MSE: 0.2148) on Cholec80 compared to existing baselines.

title: Desing and Development of a Mixed Si-GaN Open-End Winding Inverter for Electric Vehicles
authors: Salvatore Foti, Gioele Baia, Danilo Campagna, Haseeb Hassan Khan, Antonio Testa, Salvatore De Caro
abstract: This paper presents the design and development of a hybrid multilevel inverter for electric vehicle applications employing an open-end winding motor configuration. This architecture allows for the use of commercially available 650 V GaN devices in Electric Vehicles with high-voltage (800–1000 V) batteries. It combines a three-level T-type converter with Si-IGBTs, which processes the full battery voltage at a low switching frequency, with an auxiliary two-level GaN inverter operating at a lower voltage (below 350 V) and at 50 kHz to play the role of an active filter. This results in a six-level output voltage waveform, leading to approximately 50% lower voltage total harmonic distortion than conventional solutions. Experimental validation confirms that the proposed topology achieves high efficiency and improved voltage and current waveforms. It also reduces common-mode voltage while decreasing the number of power devices and the overall system volume and cost relative to conventional fully GaN-based multilevel converters. Additionally, since operating GaN devices at high switching frequencies (above 50-100 kHz) in vehicular applications is counterproductive, as it increases switching losses without significantly improving the quality of voltage and current waveforms, a relatively low switching frequency is adopted for GaN devices to exploit their full potential in improving efficiency.

title: Differentially-Fed Dual-Polarized Microwave and Millimeter-wave Shared-Aperture Antennas with Single-layer Substrate
authors: Hui Tang, Rong Li, Kai-Qi Wei, Dan-Le Ma, Rui-Ping Liang, Ding-Wen Shen, Li Jiang, Xue-Feng Zhang, Ling-Ling Yang, Jian-Xin Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Dual-polarized microwave and millimeter-wave shared-aperture antennas with differential feedings based on a single-layer substrate are proposed. In the microwave band, the orthogonal degenerated modes of a square patch are differentially excited to generate a dual-polarized radiation. The polarization isolation is realized by diagonal splits and short-circuit pins, and the latter could also simply transform the dual-band operation into a wideband one. In both cases, high gain and high polarization isolation performance are attained for the differentially-fed dual-polarized microwave patch antennas. The characteristics of the electric field distribution of the patch working modes show some weak field areas which can be used for more functions without influence on the microwave part. In the millimeter-wave band, a cross-shaped substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) cavity is constructed, and orthogonal slot arrays are etched on the SIW structure, which are fed by differential feedings to achieve a dual-polarized wideband radiation. The deformation of the SIW cavity and the slots increases the polarization isolation and improves the impedance matching, respectively. The millimeter-wave part is accordingly embedded into the region where the electric field of the patch is weak, forming two different aperture-shared antennas. The operations in different bands are almost independent of each other. The isolation between antennas is higher than 45 dB, due to the embedding position selection and the inherent shielding of the SIW structure. Finally, prototypes of the proposed differentially-fed dual-polarized micro- and millimeter-wave shared-aperture antennas based on single-layer substrate are designed and implemented for validation.

title: A Radical Heavy-Ball Method for Gradient Acceleration in Communication-Efficient Mobile Federated Learning
authors: Boyuan Li, Zijian Li, Yafei Li, Mingliang Xu, Shengbo Chen, Cong Shen, Tony Q.S. Quek
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is widely used in mobile computing as a communication-efficient distributed machine learning (ML) paradigm; however, it faces challenges such as model convergence to local optima or slow convergence due to the heterogeneity of client data. To mitigate data heterogeneity, the Nesterov Accelerated Gradient (NAG) method demonstrates its effectiveness by predictively updating the gradient to improve system performance. However, the performance of NAG depends heavily on the choice of decay coefficients; larger coefficients have greater acceleration but may lead to an unstable convergence process due to their unreasonable prediction of the descent gradient. To solve the above problems, this paper proposes the first radical heavy ball (RHB) method that combines momentum and NAG. In Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD), momentum stabilizes the gradient descent process by integrating the historical gradients to update the parameters, and the RHB strategy decouples a single decay coefficient into an NAG component and a momentum component. The RHB introduces a gradient recall after each gradient acceleration by the NAG to strengthen the NAG's perception of the historical gradients, thus stabilizing the gradient descent process. By weighing the historical gradients and the predicted gradient, RHB effectively mitigates the instability of NAG convergence and demonstrates better performance. As a result, the algorithm further mitigates the impact of customer data heterogeneity in FL and can effectively deliver global update information to participants without additional communication costs. We conduct comprehensive experiments in a binary function, single node, and federated model environment to analyze the convergence properties in non-convex loss functions. RHB exhibits better performance and less computational overhead than many existing algorithms.

title: A Simple and Cost-Effective Method for Condition Monitoring of Inverter DC-Link Film Capacitors based on Capacitance Variation
authors: Seyed Hossein Aleyasin, Fausto Stella, Radu Bojoi, Enrico Vico, Chaohui Liu
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Industry Applications
abstract: DC-link capacitors are among the most critical components in traction inverters, with a high likelihood of failure. Effective condition monitoring (CM) of these capacitors is crucial for improving converter reliability and preventing catastrophic failures. This paper presents a cost-effective and reliable methodology for evaluating the health state of film capacitors used as DC-link in traction inverters. The proposed approach uses a controlled discharge test to track capacitance variations over time, which can be used as an indirect indicator of the capacitor's health state. Key advantages of this technique include the minimal additional component requirements for cost efficiency, strong noise immunity, and high precision. Furthermore, the proposed aging detection test can be fully automated without requiring the removal of the capacitor or modifications to the converter's power stage. Experimental results are provided to validate the effectiveness of the proposed solution.

title: Indoor Channel Characterization and Performance Analysis for RIS-assisted Communication Systems with Multi-Codebook
authors: Peng Zheng, Dan Fei, Haoran Chen, Jiayi Zhang, Yanyan Huang, He Hu, Yiyan Ma, Bo Ai
abstract: As a key technology of future communication systems, reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) can intelligently control wireless signal reflections, thereby optimizing propagation channels and enhancing communication performance. However, the indoor channel characteristics and communication performance of RISs in real-world deployment environments remain insufficiently studied. In this paper, we develop a RIS-based measurement platform for simultaneous channel measurement and link-level performance analysis, followed by verification and validation in a laboratory environment. Utilizing this platform, we conduct wideband channel measurement and performance analysis work in indoor scenarios at 2.6 GHz band. Multiple RIS phase shift codebooks are employed, including the 1-bit discrete Fourier transform (DFT) codebook, the Ring-type codebook, and the conditional sample mean (CSM) codebook. Based on these measurements, two empirical path loss (PL) models, namely the floating-intercept (FI) model and the close-in (CI) model, are fitted to the measured data. Furthermore, we comprehensively analyze and compare the channel characteristics of RIS-assisted communications, including shadow fading (SF), multipath components (MPCs) statistics, the Rician K-factor (KF), and root mean square (RMS) delay spread. Finally, we evaluate and compare the wireless coverage and link-level performance of various RIS reflection schemes. The findings on propagation characteristics and communication performance provide essential insights that can support the future application and deployment of RIS-assisted communication systems.

title: Design of High-Selectivity Bandpass Filter Using 3-D Coupling and 2-D Lump Resonators Based on TGV Technology for RF Front-End Application
authors: Qi Zhang, Yazi Cao, Shichang Chen, Gaofeng Wang
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: In this letter, a novel design approach is proposed for on-chip bandpass filter (BPF) design with high-selectivity performance and high out-of-band rejection based on through glass via (TGV) technology. The proposed approach uses a combination of 3-D coupling and 2-D lump resonators, which can generate multiple transmission zeros (TZs) and transmission poles (TPs). An equivalent circuit model based on the odd–even mode is used for theoretical analysis. To prove the concept, the designed BPF with a chip size of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.0\times 2.0\times 0.3$</tex-math> </inline-formula> mm is fabricated using a commercial 230-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>m TGV technology. The measured center frequency of the fabricated BPF is located at 2.85 GHz with an operating bandwidth of 100 MHz [3-dB fractional bandwidth (FBW) is 8.4%], and it achieved an insertion loss lower than 2.3 dB and a return loss better than 12 dB. In addition, more than 20-dB rejection is achieved up to 12.2 GHz. Compared with the previous BPF based on TGV technology, the proposed one shows a comparable loss and higher selectivity performance.
