title: Dynamic Target Detection by Metasurface with Multiple DC-based Sensing Channels
authors: Shi Yu Wang, Xuan Hao Tian, Yong Han Liu, Yun Bo Li
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: A novel electromagnetic (EM) detection for dynamic targets is proposed by applying metasurface with multiple Direct Current (DC)-based sensing channels in time-domain without complex Radio Frequency (RF) manipulation of receiving aperture. The unit cell for EM receiving is composed of the patch antenna and the rectifier circuit converting input RF signals to DC voltages in real time. Only half of unit cells in metasurface are utilized for receiving echo from objects under the distribution of chessboard pattern with considering both sensing results and cost. The artificial intelligent (AI) technology based on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) is applied to process the collected signals from multiple time-domain DC-based channels, and human gait as typical dynamic target from many models has been successfully classified and identified in our proof-of-concept experiment.

title: Grape Leaf Disease Detection Using Deep Learning Algorithms
authors: Sampath A K, Vibha D Rao, Meghana M
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Grape farming is an essential part of agriculture, but it is susceptible to productivity loss due to multiple leaf diseases which can damage both yield quality and quantity. The conventional techniques employed in the detection of diseases include visual assessments, which is a very slow and expert-dependent process, hence not very effective. This research aims to develop an automated diseased grape vine leaf identification system using deep learning based Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and a hybrid CNN-RNN architecture. This system helps in early disease detection through sophisticated image processing, which reduces losses and improves agricultural productivity. The research involves data gathering, model training, and testing the model against established. The best-performing model is a web-based application to assist farmers in real-time disease detection. Results show that combining CNNs with RNNs improves classification accuracy, reinforcing AI's role in transforming precision agriculture.

title: Digital Twin–Enabled IoT Architecture for Early Fault Detection and Integrated Forklift Monitoring Using an ESP32 Platform
authors: H. R. Bravo Jacha, E. H. Aroni Acuña, A. K. Nieves Acosta, J. L. Becerra Felipe, J. R. Ronceros Rivas, J. A. Carrizales Navarro
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This study proposes an intelligent forklift monitoring system based on the implementation of a low-cost Digital Twin using an ESP32 microcontroller and critical variable sensors. The main objective is to detect potential failures early and provide real-time operational data to improve fleet management in heavy equipment rental companies. The developed architecture records data on fuel level, GPS location, traveled distance (via wheel revolutions), engine temperature, exhaust temperature, and levels of pollutant gas emissions (CO and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>). These data are transmitted to a web interface for remote visualization and analysis. The methodology integrates multisensor data acquisition, local processing via ESP32, and digital modeling of forklift behavior under real operating conditions. A configurable alert system is included and integration with machine learning algorithms is proposed for failure prediction. As a result, an effective synchronization was achieved between the physical state of the forklift and its digital representation, allowing continuous monitoring from any location. The system was shown to be functional, scalable and applicable to operating fleets, thereby enabling the development of accessible predictive maintenance solutions in demanding logistics contexts.

title: Enhanced privacy in Real time Data offloading using Federated Hybrid MLP and LSTM approach for Optimized solutions
authors: Jayaprakash Hampi, Vinutha C B
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Using a privacy-preserving federated hybrid architecture that combines Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Multilayer Perceptron networks (MLP), the research suggests a novel method. Our approach tackles the challenges of dynamic offloading choices in changing network conditions by combining the advantages of hybrid neural network designs and federated learning. The hybrid MLP-LSTM architecture enables effective learning from sequential and non-sequential data, enhancing the model's adaptability to diverse network scenarios. The proposed study integrate privacy-preserving mechanisms, including differential privacy techniques and secure aggregation protocols, to further fortify user privacy during model training and inference. The proposed method is implemented in Python software and has an Offloading accuracy of 99.5 percent which is higher than other existing methods like FCNN, CNN, KNN and Decision Tree. The research contributes to advancing the field of network optimization by providing a secure and efficient solution for real-time data offloading while prioritizing user privacy and data ownership.

title: Improving Metal Plate Utilization through IoT-Based Poka Yoke, AHP, and Ergonomic Design in an Electrical Transformer Company
authors: Cristian Cosme-Rodriguez, Jose Macedo-Adrianzen, Pablo Cesar Gutierrez-Falcon
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Metal casing manufacturing in the electrical transformer industry faces significant challenges related to material waste and ergonomic issues that impact both production and worker health. This study aims to improve sheet metal utilization by integrating Poka Yoke with loT-based systems, ergonomic workplace design, and the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) for supplier selection. The results show substantial improvements in key indicators. Metal waste was reduced from 9.78% to 5.12%, exceeding the company's target of 6.51 %. Errors in the cutting process decreased from 2.80% to 0.47%, equivalent to an improvement of 83.21 %. Furthermore, the AHP method optimized supplier selection, reducing the percentage of factory-defective sheets from 4.10% to 2.63%. Regarding ergonomic design, ergonomic risk at the assembly station was reduced by 23.26%, going from a medium to a low level. These findings not only close the technical gap identified in the company, but also offer a replicable solution in other industries, improving the sector's competitiveness and safety.

title: Context-Driven Natural Language Understanding for Smarter Chatbot Responses
authors: Sunjhla Handa, Shanmugaraja Krishnasamy Venugopal, Madhusudana Kamballi, Devanand Ramachandran, Amit Ojha, Ajay Shriram Kushwaha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The quality of chatbot responses in multi-turn conversations is improved by employing a context-driven natural language understanding (NLU) approach in this study. The system successfully records semantic relationships and speaker dynamics across conversation history by combining transformer-based models like BERT, GPT-2, T5 along with BART with hierarchical context encoders. Employing PyTorch along with HuggingFace on the high-performance configuration using NVIDIA A100 GPUs, the design is tuned for speed, relevance, and consistency. Hierarchical BERT+GPT-2 model achieves outstanding outcomes for BLEU (26.3), METEOR (22.1), BERTScore (0.889) along with F1 (0.81), coupled with strong user engagement, according to evaluation in datasets like MultiWOZ and PersonaChat. The significant performance-computational cost trade-off is shown in the study, which delves deeper into the effects of context embedding techniques, inference latency as well as and training efficiency. The significance of deep contextual modelling for developing conversational software with intelligence and human-like characteristics is highlighted by these results, which also provide a basis for future advancements with scalable along with adaptive dialogue systems.

title: Leveraging Continuous Integration and Deployment to Operationalize a Fine-Tuned LLaMA Healthcare Chatbot
authors: Priyanka More, Nishica Kothawade, Anushka More
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The study demonstrates the application of Llama 3.1 paradigm and Groq API to build a full CI/CD pipeline that deploys Flask-based applications. A CI/CD orchestration function belongs to Jenkins, while Docker performs containerization and DockerHub registers images and Kubernetes deploys applications, and GitHub manages source code. The fully automated solution allows minimal human involvement, which enables complete automation of machine learning application testing and development, and deployment thus shortening the time to release and reducing errors. This implementation demonstrates the effectiveness of contemporary DevOps practices when delivering big language models. The research examines LLM-based service containerization challenges alongside the advantages of AI application automated deployment before presenting planned enhancements in monitoring frameworks, together with multi-environment deployment methods.

title: Prediction of DNA Methylation Sites
authors: Suresh A, Samruddhi Bhandare, Shreyas Talukdar, Salkwchang Kalai
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The epigenetic modification DNA methylation is critical for the regulation of gene expression and genome stability. To understand gene regulation and its impact on disease and health, accurate prediction of methylation sites is crucial. Traditional methods like Whole Genome Bisulfite Sequencing are reliable but costly and time consuming, necessitating efficient computational approaches. This study employs advanced feature encoding techniques, including symmetric encoding and three-mer encoding, to transform DNA sequences into multidimensional representations. Deep-learning models such as MEDCNN and DEEPGO process these encodings, leveraging their strengths in sequence analysis. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of PyTorch implementations over TensorFlow counterparts, with DEEPGO achieving a better test accuracy. By integrating novel encoding techniques with deep learning, this work provides a scalable and accurate approach to computational epigenetics, offering a viable alternative to traditional laboratory methods.

title: Vocational Prediction Method for High School Students Based on Machine Learning
authors: Juan Carlos Saravia Inga, Victor Raul Herrera Castillo, Rubén Oscar Cerda García
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This article proposes a vocational prediction method for high school students based on Machine Learning (ML) techniques, specifically using Graph Neural Networks (GNN). Choosing a professional career is a crucial decision for students, but it is often influenced by subjective factors such as family pressure and friends' opinions, which can lead to a disconnect between the career choice and personal aspirations. This disconnect contributes to high dropout rates in higher education. The proposed model integrates psychometric profiles (RIASEC), academic performance, and socioeconomic data to recommend personalized career paths. By using GNNs, the model captures complex relationships between these factors, providing students with career suggestions tailored to their true interests and abilities. The system was evaluated using several GNN models, including GraphSAGE, GCN, and GAT, with GraphSAGE showing the highest accuracy in predictions. This approach aims to reduce dropout rates and help students make more informed vocational decisions aligned with their academic and professional future.

title: 3D MRI-Based Multiclass Brain Tumor Detection and Classification using YOLOv8
authors: Shahad Palathingal, Abhitha Lakshmi Povakula, Hema Shankar Nuthanki, Kumar Sadugula, Garladinne Hemanth Kumar, Ameya Sree Kasa
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Medical professionals need precise brain tumor identification to develop better treatment approaches which leads to extended survival durations for their patients. This research develops an advanced method for brain tumor multi-classification by fusing YOLOv8 object detection with 3D-MRI data. The approach enables effective tumor identification and type classification through three-dimensional analysis. Data preprocessing includes noise reduction and intensity normalization before transformation. YOLOv8 training focuses on different tumor patterns with a specialized loss function that reduces classification errors while maintaining system stability. Experimental tests demonstrate superior speed and accuracy compared to conventional machine learning and deep learning methods. The model excels at distinguishing non-hazardous tumors from those requiring chemotherapy intervention. The system generates automated diagnostic reports that assist clinicians in treatment planning and patient management decisions. YOLOv8 integration into CT scanners enhances medical staff detection capabilities by streamlining processing of large datasets. The application of artificial intelligence in precision medicine reached a significant advancement based on research discoveries that benefit exclusively medical imaging technology.

title: Computational Validation of the Fluid-Dynamic Behavior of the Von Kármán Vortex-Induced Vibration Effect in a Bladeless Wind Turbine
authors: Julian Urrutia Natera, Jonathan Fábregas Villegas, Carlos Díaz Sáenz, Argemiro Palencia Díaz
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Renewable energies, especially wind energy, have become relevant as an alternative source of energy generation. For this reason, new designs of turbines have emerged that take advantage of the kinetic energy of the wind, such as bladeless wind turbines, which work from the oscillatory movement due to the effect of vibrations induced by Von Kármán vortices. The aim of this research is to study the fluid dynamic behavior of these turbines through computational simulation, and how the effect of induced vibrations intervenes in their operation. Initially, a three-dimensional model of the turbine is designed, for this geometric characteristics, suitable materials and mathematical models that characterize their behavior are identified. Finally, the simulation of the fluid structure interaction is performed in the Ansys software. A study domain is established to validate real operating conditions. Through this simulation, the main result was obtained velocity, pressure and graph fields that relate the theoretical concepts and mathematical models behind the operation of this turbine, coinciding with the physical phenomenon experienced as validation.

title: Advanced Lung Cancer Diagnosis Using Optimized Deep Learning Models
authors: Kalpana. V, Vijaya Kishore. V, Ravindra Murthy. C, Narendra. R, Sruthi. M. V
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The early detection and diagnosis of lung cancer have significantly contributed to the improvement of patient outcomes. These contributions are in the form of early detection and diagnosis. A comparison of deep learning models to diagnose lung cancer is performed by using a dataset consisting of CT scan lung images. Popular Deep learning network architectures included in our analysis are CNN, DNN, Mobile Net V2, and Xception. The CT scan images underwent meticulous pre-processing to ensure the models effectiveness in capturing relevant features. Each deep learning architecture was individually implemented, taking into account unique hyperparameters and architecture specifications. The models were trained and evaluated on the dataset, and performance metrics such accuracy, precision, sensitivity, specificity and area under ROC curve was employed for a comprehensive comparative analysis. In order to make significant contributions to the development of strong clinical decision support systems, the findings of this study offer significantly important insights into the process of selecting the most effective deep learning techniques for the early identification of lung cancer.

title: AI-Driven Urban Traffic Optimization for Smart Cities
authors: Ganesh Kumar Ayyalusamy, Srikanth Srinivas, Sathish Rao Sridhar Rao, Kishore Ande, Anzar Ahmad, Roosha Shamoon
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Traditional rule-based traffic management systems are becoming increasingly ineffective at controlling real-time congestion and assuring smooth traffic flow as urban populations increase and mobility needs increase. A thorough AI-based traffic optimization system for smart cities is presented in this research. It incorporates intelligent decision-making, predictive modeling, and real-time data collection into a continuous feedback system. Advanced machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) methods, such as LSTM, GNN as well as Transformer models, are used to preprocess and analyze traffic data that comes from a variety of sources, such as inductive loop sensors, traffic cameras, connected vehicles, as well as mobile navigation platforms. For optimization algorithms, mainly reinforcement learning (RL) as well as Deep Q-Networks (DQN), to control traffic lights automatically in real time, they use predicted traffic conditions as input.Key performance measures such as vehicle delay, queue duration, consumption of fuel, carbon dioxide emissions, and system efficiency are used to compare the proposed system's efficacy to existing traffic management systems. The findings demonstrate significant improvements, including increases in efficiency of 33.33%, fuel consumption of 37.14%, CO2 emissions of 28%, delay reductions of 33.78%, and queue length reductions of 53.33%.

title: AI-Based Automated Student Management Platform for Enhancing Academic Performance of Students
authors: Abhishek Sharma, Abhishek Rathore, Seema Bushra, Chinnaiyan R, Ragavendra T S, Vimal Kumar Khanna
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and development of an AI-based automated student management platform aimed at enhancing the academic outcomes of students. The core of the model is, it’s an AI-powered assistant, which uses natural language processing (NLP) through Dialogflow or Rasa to enable intuitive, conversational user interactions. This assistant allows students, faculty, and staff to access real-time information and perform tasks effortlessly, such as querying attendance records or finding library. Utilizing the MERN stack (MongoDB, Express.js, React.js, Node.js), it provides a robust and scalable solution to handle critical campus functions such as attendance tracking, fee management, notes repository, and library services. The model incorporates several core modules that address essential campus management functionalities. These features are designed to enhance efficiency, improve accessibility, and provide real-time interaction for students, faculty, and administrators. Below, each key feature is elaborated upon with detailed explanations and a system-wide diagram for better understanding

title: Improving the Performance of Convolutional Neural Networks for Image Classification
authors: Laxmi Vanam, Savya Sachi, Hina Gandhi, Sanjeev Kumar Shah, Madhusudana Kamballi, Punit Goel
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Image classification is a crucial part of computer vision that has applications in security, autonomous systems and healthcare. Enhanced classification accuracy has been achieved by Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) by autonomous learning of hierarchical feature representations in images. The study's primary objective is to advance and improve the architecture of convolutional neural networks in order to achieve higher level accuracy in image classification. Multiple vital measures are used including augmenting the data, normalization in batches, adaptive learning rate scheduling and dropout to avoid overfitting and enhance the method's generalizability. In classification studies carried out on typical datasets like CIFAR-10 and MNIST, the results show that the method outperforms conventional neural network algorithms. In order to attain better accuracy, the research stresses the necessity for deeper approaches and more sophisticated training process. The suggested method offers a scalable and reliable answer to many practical image classification problems making a significant contribution to deep learning and computer vision

title: Optimized Wireless Sensor Network: Path Planning, Clustering, and Obstacle Avoidance with Failure Analysis
authors: Sridevi S, Mohana S D, Bablu Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: It is well known that using the sink’s mobility to increase the network lifetime in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) is a successful tactic. However, barriers make it difficult to ensure effective data collecting and routing in real-world settings. An energy-efficient routing technique for mobile sinks in WSNs functioning in environments with neighboring barriers is presented in this work. The suggested technique makes use of a cluster-based methodology, in which cluster heads collect information from each member of the cluster and send it to the mobile sink. Before returning to the starting point, the mobile sink collects data from cluster heads within a single hop using a periodic data-gathering route. Routing in such contexts is difficult for standard algorithms to optimize due to the complexity provided by impediments. We address this by proposing an effective scheduling approach based on spanning graphs that allows the mobile sink to find the shortest path that avoids obstacles. The mobile sink is led via the best path while avoiding obstacles using a heuristic tour-planning algorithm. The simulation results show that our method is successful in enhancing network performance and energy efficiency.

title: Virtual Reality in Education: Exploring Opportunities, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: Rahul Benhar Mattukoyya, Manoj Panguluri, V. M. Manikandan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Virtual reality introduces an innovative learning methodology in the field of education.Virtual Reality is transforming the standard of education by offering new learning techniques that increase a student’s interest and learning of abstract concepts. Reviewing the broad applications of this technology across various sectors including higher education, vocational training health care, engineering, or business disciplines is the study’s objective. The immersive nature of VR enables students to interact with content in ways that traditional pedagogical methods cannot achieve, which in turn promotes active learning and collaboration. Underpinning the effective use of VR are key learning theories such as constructivism and experiential learning, promoting deeper cognitive engagement and retention of knowledge. However, the main challenges include high implementation costs, technical barriers, and the need for robust pedagogical frameworks. This paper synthesizes existing findings to highlight the benefits as well as the limitations of VR in education and consequently suggests pathways for future research and development. By addressing these challenges, educators can utilize the VR technology to produce even more engaging and personalized learning experiences that meet the requirements of a digital age. Meanwhile, the share of traditional education is still significant, but its combination with VR technology promises impressive student engagement, better retention of knowledge, and further development of useful skills.

title: FoodConnect: A CPS based Smart City Food Management Application
authors: Anand Prakash, Galiveeti Poornima
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The primary objective of the "FOODCONNECT " Application is to bridge the gap between surplus food in restaurants and individuals in need. The app will facilitate the donation of excess food to poor people, ensuring that no food goes to waste and helping to alleviate hunger in the community. "FOODCONNECT" is an innovative Android application designed to help locate free food for the needy and provide a platform for restaurants and individuals to donate excess food. The app will serve as a real-time solution to hunger by connecting donors with recipients, thereby promoting food security and reducing food wastage.

title: Student-Perceived Cognitive Load of LLM-Generated Programming Exercises
authors: Muhammad Fawad Akbar Khan, Ludia Eka Feri, Ha Nguyen, Hamid Karimi
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Large language models are increasingly used to generate programming practice, yet their cognitive demands for CS1 learners remain underexplored. We investigate student-perceived cognitive load on GPT-generated Python exercises using a custom intelligent tutoring system that captures fine-grained keystrokes and offers in-exercise AI feedback. Nineteen undergraduates completed nine exercises spanning loops, recursion, and classes and objects, yielding 171 submissions and 83,377 keystrokes. We triangulate self-reports with keystroke dynamics, code quality metrics, and knowledge component (KC) mastery. Perceived load largely tracked labeled difficulty and was inversely related to satisfaction. Keystroke features were the strongest correlates of load, with more typing bursts and longer inter-keystroke latencies accompanying higher demand; among code metrics, the SLoC-LLoC differential showed the highest association with demand, aligning higher structural complexity with greater mental effort. Lower mastery of core knowledge components—especially loops plus string and list operations—coincided with higher load. Students rated instant AI feedback helpful for debugging and best practices, though at times redundant or inconsistent with instructions. To estimate load automatically, we trained models on observed traces. An Extra Trees regressor predicted the primary load measure Demanding with RMSE 0.81, and a three-level classifier achieved 86 % accuracy with weighted F1 0.85 on held-out students. These results suggest actionable design levers for LLM-based tutors: calibrate task complexity, scaffold high-strain concepts, and deliver concise, context-aligned feedback while using keystroke- and code-based signals for real-time load monitoring. The code and data are available: https://github.com/DSAatUSU/LLMCognitiveLoadProgramming.

title: A Self-Synchronizing Cyber Deception Framework via Infrastructure as Code Reflection
authors: Junyeong Park, Sayeon Kim, Woohyun Jang, Yeon-Jae Kim, Shinwoo Shim, Olmi Lee, Ki-Woong Park
publish: 2025 IEEE 30th Pacific Rim International Symposium on Dependable Computing (PRDC)
abstract: As cyberattacks become more sophisticated, the us e of honeypots has emerged as an alternative to proactively collec t attackers' exploit strategies. However, conventional honeypots o ften lack realism and require much human effort to deploy and m aintain in modern IT infrastructures. This excessive cost in resou rces creates a major obstacle to their widespread use. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a self-synchronizing cyber d eception framework that upholds the declarative approach of I nfrastructure as Code (IaC), maintaining idempotency and consis tency while automatically generating a deceptive environment. O ur framework treats the target system's laC files as a blueprint to automatically generate and deploy a high-fidelity, “digital twin” deception environment. Our framework uses an automated pip eli ne to analyze the laC file, apply the predefined transformation ru les, and dynamically build new container images - replicating stru ctural elements while replacing the core application logic with a h oneypot. After deployment, the framework keeps the deceptive en vironment synchronized with the original system by automaticall y re-deploying the pipeline in response to any changes in the sour ce laC file, increasing fidelity and reducing management costs. T he implementation of this prototype successfully shows a reductio n in the manual effort required for deploying and maintaining de ception environments, presenting a scalable and sustainable fram ework for active defense. This provides a strong foundation for b uilding the next-generation defense mechanisms that can adapt to both evolving cyberattacks and changing infrastructure.

title: Interactive Visualization of Sudoku Constraint Satisfaction Using R Programming and Prospective Power BI Integration
authors: Rajan. T, Pravinth Raja, Saheen. H, Jai Kumar B
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Sudoku puzzles form perfect constraint satisfaction problems (CSPs), with a goal of populating a 9x9 grid with 1 through 9, with compliance with specific constraints for rows, columns, and 3x3 blocks. Computational techniques such as constraint propagation and backtracking have become widespread for resolving Sudoku, but with no visualization tools for visualization of resolving, constraint dynamics and algorithmic approaches cannot be analyzed in detail. In this work, an enriched framework with computational resolving through R and visualization through visualization tool ggplot2 is proposed for demonstration of resolving process. Step-by-step constraint satisfaction and backtracks in visualization ease complex processes in CSPs for analysis in detail. Besides, in this work, a future work opportunity in creating an interactive visualization through Power BI is mentioned, with a potential for transforming static visualization into a dynamic, accessible dash board for a user. With computational approaches and powerful visualization tools, this work takes a significant contribution in enriching methodologies for CSPs, with strong implications in terms of analysis and education.

title: AI-Powered Resource Management to Improve Cloud Scalability
authors: Aravind Barla, Lakshmi Priyanka, Pratyosh Desaraju, Venkata Phanindra Kumar Janapareddy, Shiv Dayal Pandey, Rajiv Kumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The incorporating of different algorithms for machine learning (ML) into resource management is a potential way of rendering the cloud more scalable, and this study intends to investigate the elements that contribute to this development. Most traditional resource management systems may not be sufficient to handle the growing complexity of cloud resource control and management due to increased base requirements. Employing metrics like operational cost, resource utilization, and overall system efficiency, this study compares five cutting-edge ML methods: Neural Architecture Search, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Gradient Boosting Machines (GBM), Autoencoders, and Reinforcement Learning (RL). The objective is to determine the most effective method for running the organization. The results show that LSTM networks may improve demand estimation accuracy by 13% and total resource usage efficiency by 23%, while RL-based techniques can reduce the operational cost and minimize the provisioning delay for about 20% and 30%, respectively. When GBM models are used in predictions, there is a 31% decrease in predicting inaccuracy, a twenty percent reduction in expenses, and a 25% improvement in services. The models identify anomalies and 98% accuracy using autoencoders, which results in a 16% increase in allocation efficiency. A 25% boost in computing speed and an 19% increase in accuracy are produced by the Neural Architecture Search (NAS)-optimized models. These theorized results demonstrate that AI-based strategies may improve cloud scalability as well as offer practical suggestions to the management of resources at the cloud environment.

title: HyperNeRFGAN: Camera-Free 3D Scene Generation via Hypernetwork-Driven Neural Radiance Fields
authors: Adam Kania, Artur Kasymov, Jakub Kościukiewicz, Artur Górak, Marcin Mazur, Maciej Zieba, Przemysław Spurek
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Training 3D generative models often faces bottle-necks due to dependencies on precise camera pose estimation, particularly when using Neural Radiance Fields (N eRFs) for photorealistic novel-view synthesis. We introduce HyperNeR-FGAN, a generative framework that eliminates camera pose requirements by integrating a hypernetwork with a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN). This architecture maps Gaussian noise directly to the weights of a NeRF model, bypassing viewing direction inputs during training. Our experiments demonstrate that HyperNeRFGAN achieves state-of-the-art performance on datasets where camera position estimation is impractical - notably in medical imaging scenarios with limited or ambiguous viewpoint metadata. Despite its architectural simplicity compared to existing methods, the model produces high-fidelity 3D reconstructions across diverse modalities, including MRI and X-ray-derived 2D scans. The framework's efficiency and robustness suggest broad applicability in domains requiring 3D generation from unstructured or poorly annotated 2D data. Key revisions emphasize the camera-pose independence, clinical relevance, and architectural efficiency while maintaining technical nrecision.

title: Teaching Continuous Action Space Reinforcement Learning with a Mobile Robot
authors: Thiago Martins, Larissa Driemeier
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: This paper presents a teaching framework that integrates continuous action space reinforcement learning with a mobile robotics platform. Reinforcement learning (RL) enables agents to learn optimal decision-making policies through interaction with their environment, making it a natural fit for robotics applications. The study examines the challenges and solutions for applying RL algorithms, specifically SARSA and Actor-Critic methods, to continuous state and action spaces. These methods are implemented and compared on a differential-drive robot tasked with maintaining a specific orientation and position. A virtual model is utilized to facilitate safe and efficient learning before deploying the algorithms to a physical robot. This study provides practical insights into teaching reinforcement learning concepts and leveraging them for robotics applications.

title: Towards an Explainable-AI Enhanced Predictive Analytics System for Collaborative Learning in Smart Educational Environments
authors: Rawia Bdiwi
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: This study emphasizes recent advances in learning analytics and explainable AI to provide meaningful insights for data-driven interventions. We explore how ICT-based Smart Learning Environments (SLE) can enhance decision-making through predictive models with the aim of supporting learners at risk of underperformance. Our approach introduces an analytical framework that uses raw interaction data extracted from Learning Management Systems (LMS), focusing on both cognitive and social dimensions of the collaborative learning process. The system incorporates interactive dashboards and dynamic visualizations that inform tutors about group dynamics and individual engagement, allowina for early detection of learning difficulties. The first experimental results underline the effectiveness of tracking behavioral patterns and generating multi-dimensional learning indicators, which serve to improve instructional support and reflective learner feedback. This contribution emphasizes the role of predictive analytics and interpretability in the facilitation of adaptive and scalable learning interventions within SLE. This predictive model is enhanced by the integration of SHAP values of explainable AI techniques to describe the most influential learning behaviors that conduct the model's decisions. In this case, the tutors receive early risk alerts and understand each prediction.

title: Comparative Analysis of Controllers for Autonomous Vehicle Steering
authors: Bruno Campos Trovatti, Giovani Bruno Cicone, Lucas Barbosa Marcos
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Technological advances in recent years have allowed major developments in the field of autonomous vehicles. This technology has proven to be increasingly reliable and efficient in reducing accidents and optimizing transportation resources. However, it is a rapidly developing area, and comparative studies are still needed to clarify the advantages and disadvantages of each type of controller in different use cases. This article addresses the development of steering control for autonomous vehicles by comparing the classic PID control technique and the modern control techniques using a Robust Linear Quadratic Regulator. The objective is to assess the advantages and disad-vantages of each of these controllers when applied to automotive models in a numerical simulation environment. PID, nominal LQR, and robust LQR controllers were designed and applied to autonomously drive the car along a reference path. The simulated results show the highest efficiency in the nominal LQR controller when there are no car parameter variations, the PID controller shows performance degradation with mass variations, while the Robust LQR controller maintains its performance. Therefore, applications that are subject to high parametric uncertainties are better served by the robust LQR controller.

title: GALAXY: Generalized Attention-Based LSTM Architecture with External Query for Intrusion Detection in UAV Communication
authors: Jae Yeon Lee, Huy Kang Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE 30th Pacific Rim International Symposium on Dependable Computing (PRDC)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) rely on wireless communication with a Ground Control Station (GCS) for flight control, primarily using the Micro Air Vehicle Link (MAVLink) protocol. However, MAVLink lacks essential security mecha-nisms, making UAVs vulnerable to attacks. We introduce a stealthy relay-based Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) attack called Shadow-GCS, in which an unauthorized node relays MAVLink messages to maintain normal communication while injecting commands. The Shadow-GCS attack enables an adversary to monitor and control UAV s without triggering alerts at the GCS. To assess the attack's detectability, we collected a dataset from four realistic UAV-GCS scenarios. We then evaluated two existing MAVLink intrusion detection systems (IDSs), revealing their limitations in identifying attacks that do not significantly alter normal communication flow. To overcome these limitations and develop a more generalized intrusion detection capability, we propose GALAXY, an attention-based LSTM model with a single LSTM layer, where the attention weights are jointly derived from the hidden state and local statistical features. Experimental results show that GALAXY achieves detection performance comparable to a stacked LSTM baseline while offering improved interpretability.

title: IOT Based Women Security System for Real Time Threat Detection and Emergency Alerts
authors: V. Kalpana, P. Lokeshwari, S. Vinitha, P. Ganga, N. Vani
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The IoT-based Women Security System is a real-time threat detection and emergency alert solution designed to enhance the safety and well-being of women in various environments. The system utilizes a portable device integrated with Arduino, LCD display, Buzzer, GPS, IR sensors, and Camera module to continuously monitor physical conditions and detect potential threats, such as sudden falls, aggressive movements, or distress sounds. In the event of an emergency, the system automatically sends alerts to emergency contacts and local authorities, including real-time location information. By leveraging GPS technology and IoT enabled infrastructure, the system ensures rapid intervention, seamless communication, and data privacy. This solution aims to provide a reliable and discrete security tool for women, ensuring that help is always just a click away. The system’s scalability and integration with smart city frameworks further enhance its effectiveness, offering an all-encompassing safety network.

title: Nonnegative Matrix Factorization and the Principle of the Common Cause
authors: Edvard Khalafyan, Armen Allahverdyan, Arshak Hovhannisyan
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Nonnegative matrix factorization (NMF) is a known unsupervised data-reduction method. The principle of the common cause (PCC) is a basic methodological approach in probabilistic causality, which seeks an independent mixture model for the joint probability of two dependent random variables. It turns out that these two concepts are closely related. This relationship is explored reciprocally for several datasets of gray-scale images, which are conveniently mapped into probability models. On one hand, PCC provides a predictability tool that leads to a robust estimation of the effective rank of NMF. Unlike other estimates (e.g., those based on the Bayesian Information Criteria), our estimate of the rank is stable against weak noise. We show that NMF implemented around this rank produces features (basis images) that are also stable against noise and against seeds of local optimization, thereby effectively resolving the NMF nonidentifiability problem. On the other hand, NMF provides an interesting possibility of implementing PCC in an approximate way, where larger and positively correlated joint probabilities tend to be explained better via the independent mixture model. We work out a clustering method, where data points with the same common cause are grouped into the same cluster. We also show how NMF can be employed for data denoising.

title: Towards Unified Multimodal Financial Forecasting: Integrating Sentiment Embeddings and Market Indicators via Cross-Modal Attention
authors: Sarthak Khanna, Armin Berger, David Berghaus, Tobias Deusser, Lorenz Sparrenberg, Rafet Sifa
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: We propose STONK (Stock Optimization using News Knowledge), a multimodal framework integrating numerical market indicators with sentiment-enriched news embeddings to improve daily stock-movement prediction. By combining numerical & textual embeddings via feature concatenation and cross-modal attention, our unified pipeline addresses limitations of isolated analyses. Backtesting shows STONK outperforms numeric-only baselines. A comprehensive evaluation of fusion strategies and model configurations offers evidence-based guidance for scalable multimodal financial forecasting. title: Identification of Uterine Fibroids using Deep Learning Models
authors: Baby Vijilin, Anitha V. S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The quality of women life can significantly impact due to uterine fibroids causing symptoms such as heavy pelvic pain and menstrual bleeding, infertility and complications during pregnancy. This may hinder daily routines of a women affecting her personal and professional life. Timely intervention during disease stage improves understanding of disease progression and facilitates the development of targeted therapies. Hence early identification of uterine fibroids is crucial in daily life of a women. Deep learning enhances uterine fibroid identification by enabling accurate, automated detection and classification from medical imaging, improving diagnostic efficiency and precision. There are different deep learning models to identify the uterine fibroids. Ultra sound images are utilized in this study. A comparative study of 10 different state-of-the-art deep learning models like ResNet50, ResNet50V2, DenseNet121, InceptionV3, Xception, EfficientNetB0, MobileNet, VGG16, EfficientNetB0 and InceptionV3 are performed with Dual Path CNN (DPCNN) this research. The accuracy of the DPCNN is found 97%. The accuracy obtained by all other models showed similar values which is less than DPCNN. Performance measures used in this paper are accuracy, precision, confusion matrix and F1 score values. While comparing these performance values of DPCNN, found that the values are better than other models. Future research can be explored by integrating a refined customized model of DPCNN to improve the existing performance measures for the identification of uterine fibroid.

title: Design and Analysis of Triple- Band Copper- Based Metamaterial Absorber for GHz Applications
authors: K N Kartheek, C Kalyani, G Jahnavi, S. Rajasekaran, G. Subbarao
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: This research presents a simple triple-band metamaterial absorber designed for gigahertz applications. The proposed structure consists of a unidirectional, single-layer unit cell that functions as a triple-band microwave absorber. The top surface of the absorber features a copper-based geometric pattern on a FR-4 lossy substrate, whereas copper completely covers the bottom surface. As per the simulation outcomes, the absorber exhibits peak absorption values of 92%, 96%, and 98% corresponding to frequencies of 3.02 GHz, 5.11 GHz and 8.37 GHz. Incoming electromagnetic waves are efficiently captured by the absorber under dual-mode (TE/TM). Strong absorption in the triple-band range is accomplished by means of an optimal structural configuration. In the 1–10 GHz frequency range, under dual-mode (TE/TM), the reflected signal remains under -14 dB. The efficiency of the design frequency-sensitive surface is validated through both simulation and experimental observations.

title: Artificial Intelligence Applied to Epilepsy: A Bibliometric Analysis of Machine Learning Techniques for Early Seizure Detection
authors: Edison Meneses Torres, Mónica Karel Huerta, Erwin J. Sacoto-Cabrera, Santiago Acurio Maldonado, Esteban Ordoñez
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Epilepsy, one of the most common neurological disorders worldwide, significantly affects the quality of life of millions of people due to its unpredictable seizure episodes. Early detection of seizures becomes a critical area to improve the diagnosis, treatment, and monitoring of the disease. This study conducts a systematic review and a detailed bibliometric analysis of recent research focused on the use of advanced machine learning (ML) techniques for the early detection of epileptic seizures. This study analyzes relevant scientific literature, obtained through an exhaustive search in the Scopus database, covering the period 2020-2024. The PRISMA methodology was applied to ensure transparency and rigor at each phase of the process. The results show a significant increase in scientific production on this topic, highlighting the predominant use of hybrid techniques that combine convolutional neural networks (CNNs), support vector machines (SVMs), and geometric deep learning methods, demonstrating high effectiveness in real clinical settings. In addition, a growing trend was identified toward the use of wearable devices and multimodal analysis, offering innovative and highly accurate solutions for real-time early alerts. The research also revealed persistent challenges in effective clinical implementation, such as interindividual variability, limited availability of labeled data, and the need for robust validation under real-world conditions.

title: The Impact of Social Media on Mental Health
authors: Pallavi Jaggi, Rakatu Vijaya Lakshmi, Saheb Debnath, Samrat Kumar Mukherjee, S. Benita
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: In this research, the intricate relationship between mental health and social media is examined. Although social media offers many benefits, such as enhancing knowledge accessibility and fostering meaningful connections, its growing use also presents considerable risks to mental health. This abstract includes details on heightened anxiety, sadness, and diminished self-esteem. Social comparison, online abuse, and FOMO are frequently linked to these illnesses. Numerous concepts have been put forward to deal with these adverse consequences. Mental health counselling (CBT), educating people the way to use media properly and organised social interactions in the real world are all part of the mixed-methods approach. System dynamics simulations and weekly psychology tests are also used to support the approach. Over six weeks, participants in the study had considerable improvements in all outcome measures compared to the control group, including anxiety (which decreased by 30.6%), depression (which decreased by 33.3%), and self-esteem (which increased by 25.4%). The uniqueness and efficacy of this method in connecting theoretical suggestions with practical, scalable solutions are validated by a comparative SOTA study. To promote healthy digital behaviour and improve psychological well-being within the ever-more-connected society, this study offers a verified, data-driven plan of action.

title: Photovoltaic System Design: Nonlinear Modelling, MPPT Control, and LCL Filtering for Grid Integration
authors: Abdebel Flores Guerrero, Edilberto Vásquez Diaz, Alejandro Herencia Sullon, Justo Oquelis Cabredo, Daniel Marcelo Aldana, Raúl La Madrid Olivares
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: This research presents a comprehensive modelling and analysis of the key components and control strategies within a photovoltaic system. The study begins with the mathematical modelling of solar cells and panels, characterizing their nonlinear behavior to evaluate energy conversion efficiency. Subsequently, DC-DC boost converters are analyzed, focusing on the implementation of Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) algorithms, specifically the Perturb and Observe method, combined with PI controllers to maximize power extraction. A three-level Neutral Point Clamped (NPC) inverter is then modelled and controlled using Space Vector Pulse Width Modulation (SVPWM), ensuring efficient voltage regulation. To mitigate total harmonic distortion, an LCL filter is designed to deliver high-quality sinusoidal signals suitable for grid integration The system is simulated under dynamic irradiance and temperature conditions, demonstrating robust performance, efficient power delivery, and adaptability to real-world scenarios. This work highlights the importance of integrated control strategies and system design to improve efficiency between 98 % and 98.7 % of the inverter with its control system, as well as the reliability of photovoltaic systems for sustainable energy applications.

title: Effect of Socioeconomic Level on Internet Home Complaints, Inquiries, and Payments
authors: Fernando Uyaguari, Erwin J. Sacoto-Cabrera, Alvaro Uyaguari, Vanessa Bermeo
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: In the context of Internet Service Provider (ISP) services, customers seek corrective action, explanations, repair, and apologies when making a complaint. There are indications about the influence of socioeconomic level on the behavior of Internet customers. This study measures the effect of the socioeconomic level on complaints, inquiries, and payments. For the analysis we used <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 5, 8 4 2}$</tex> complaints and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 2 1}$</tex> inquiries made by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1, 9 9 8}$</tex> customers of home Internet service are used. Nonparametric tests were used for hypothesis testing. The results indicate that the socioeconomic level influences the number of complaints, with the high level generating more complaints than the low and medium levels. Regarding inquiries, the socioeconomic level does influence the number of inquiries, with low socioeconomic levels doubling the number of inquiries compared to high levels. The socioeconomic level doesn't influence the number of annual payments or the value paid annually.

title: CACTUS: Cross-Aligned Counterfactual Explanation for Time Series Classification
authors: Pouya Hosseinzadeh, Peiyu Li, Omar Bahri, Soukaina Filali Boubrahimi, Shah Muhammad Hamdi
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Counterfactual explanations are essential for inter-preting predictions made by time series classifiers, yet existing methods often disrupt inherent temporal dependencies, resulting in unrealistic explanations. We propose CACTUS (Cross-Aligned Counterfactuals for Time Series Classification), a novel model-agnostic framework designed to generate interpretable explanations for black-box models. CACTUS leverages Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) Barycenter Averaging and introduces a cross-correlation loss to enforce temporal consistency and alignment. We introduce two variants of CACTUS: one that emphasizes minimal perturbations while maintaining classification validity, and another that ensures gradual, realistic modifications in the time series. Comprehensive experiments on diverse benchmark datasets demonstrate that CACTUS outperforms state-of-the-art optimization-based methods by generating more reliable and interpretable counterfactual explanations, establishing it as a robust tool for post-hoc time series models analysis and explanations.

title: Detection of Defects in Industrial Pipelines Based on Computer Vision: a Comparative Study
authors: De Lama Jimenez Angelo, Carbaial Balarezo Renzo, Inga Espinoza Carlos
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This work addresses the detection of internal faults in industrial pipelines, specifically cracks, dents, and scratches. Two deep learning models, YOLOv8 and U-Net, were trained and evaluated for this purpose. The dataset consisted of real-world images capturing various types of pipeline damage. The performance comparison focused on detection accuracy, classification capability, inference speed, and computational efficiency within the context of industrial inspection. Experimental results indicate that YOLOv8 achieved an inference speed of 13–14 frames per second, with an overall precision of 82.5 % and an Intersection over Union (IoU) of 75.9% for the scratch class. In contrast, U - N et reached a precision of 91.3 %, a Dice coefficient of up to 88.9%, and an inference speed of 1–2 frames per second.

title: CLGuard: A Context-Aware Suppression Framework for Resilient Driving Control
authors: Yeongju Seong, Hyuk Lim, Seunghyun Yoon
publish: 2025 IEEE 30th Pacific Rim International Symposium on Dependable Computing (PRDC)
abstract: Autonomous vehicles are vulnerable to diverse faults-including CAN injection, controller errors, and AI mis-judgments-that can trigger unsafe actions such as sudden acceleration or erratic steering. We propose CLGuard, a context-aware suppression framework that semantically validates control commands using a pre-trained vision-language model (VLM) and a temporal context buffer. At its core, CLGuard uses a contrasting language goal (CLG) formulation to measure the semantic alignment between a vehicle's action and the driving scene. When a control command is found to be inconsistent with the expected behavior in context, CLGuard suppresses it in real time. Unlike signal-level detectors, CLGuard is faultagnostic and operates as a non-intrusive wrapper. Experiments in CARLA show that CLGuard improves safety and robustness across diverse control fault scenarios.

title: An Explainable Multi-Modal Deep Learning Framework for Early Detection and Classification of Pancreatic Cancer Abstract using PancreoFusion-Net
authors: Meena Kumari K S, E. Maheswari, S. Suganyadevi, R. Gladis Thanka Roobi, A. Seethalakshmy, M. Renuka Devi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Pancreatic cancer remains one of the deadliest malignancies due to late diagnosis and limited treatment options. To address this, we propose PancreoFusion-Net, an explainable multi-modal deep learning framework that integrates CT images, clinical biomarkers, and genomic data for early detection and classification. By leveraging cross-modal interactions and incorporating explainability tools like Grad-CAM and SHAP, our model achieves superior performance— 93.6% accuracy and 0.96 AUC—on benchmark datasets. PancreoFusion-Net not only enhances diagnostic accuracy but also ensures transparency, paving the way for reliable, AI-assisted clinical decision-making.

title: Implementation of an Automated Aquaponic System for the Treatment of Aquaculture Wastewater in Arequipa, Peru
authors: Ronny Ivan Gonzales Medina, Eduardo José Zuñiga Goyzueta, Rosa María Morán-Silva, Juan Carlos Cuadros Machuca, Luz Eleana Gonzales Medina, Jorge Manuel Polanco Arguelles
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Automated aquaponic systems are an efficient solution for the treatment of wastewater from aquaculture, by integrating aquaculture and agriculture, minimizing environmental impact and maximizing water use efficiency. This study implemented an automated aquaponic system in Arequipa, Peru, designed with low-cost and open-source technology. The system successfully produced rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss Walbaum, 1792) and three varieties of lettuce (Lactuca sativa L.) while treating wastewater. Water quality parameters (pH, dissolved oxygen, temperature, nitrogen compounds) were systematically monitored. The results demonstrated compliance with Peruvian environmental standards (DS 004-2017-MINAM) and suitability for agricultural reuse. The efficient design reduced operating costs and optimized water resources, generating organic biofertilizers as valuable by-products. This research validates aquaponics as a viable model for sustainable food production and wastewater treatment in water-scarce regions.

title: Influence-aware Label Propagation Algorithm for Robust Community Detection
authors: Sneha Prasad, Dhruv Sharma, Medhavi Chaudhry, Preeti Kaur
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Social network analysis is crucial and often relies on community detection to uncover meaningful patterns. The Label Propagation Algorithm (LPA) is a popular approach known for its efficiency and ease of implementation. However, LPA suffers from instability caused by random order updates and tie-breaking in label assignment. To address these limitations, we present the ILPA (Influence-aware Label Propagation Algorithm), which enhances label assignment using node influence, incorporating degree and neighbor centralities, along with structural similarity based on common neighbors. ILPA eliminates randomness and thereby ensures more accurate and stable community detection. Evaluation on real-world social networks demonstrate that ILPA yields better results than LPA and its variants in most cases based on modularity and NMI while maintaining near-linear time complexity.

title: Analysis of the Challenges and Opportunities for Gambote Peasant Women in the Implementation of Renewable Energies
authors: J.L. Villa, C. Osorio-Del-Valle, O. Acevedo, Y. Cassiani-Arroyo, M.J. Camargo-Martínez
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The township of Gambote, located in the municipality of Arjona, Bolívar, faces structural challenges in access to sustainable technologies and renewable energies. This study analyzes the findings of the focus group carried out with peasant women from Gambote, using the PESTEL methodology to evaluate political, economic, social, technological, environmental and legal factors that impact their reality. The results reveal barriers in the inclusion of renewable energy projects, inequality in access to land and technology, and economic constraints to agricultural modernization. Strategies for the implementation of renewable energies adapted to the specific conditions of the community are proposed.

title: A Global Dataset-Specific Any-Order Minimal Expectation Baseline for Saliency Scores
authors: Leonid Schwenke, Martin Atzmueller
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: A prominent type of explanation for neural networks are saliency/attribution-based approaches, which highlight the most relevant inputs. Here, recent works suggest sub-optimality of those methods and emphasize the challenge of evaluation. In this paper, we present a new dataset-relative baseline to assess the minimal expectations on saliency scores, leading towards a new any-order interpretation evaluation framework. Using the Global Coherence Representation (GCR), we propose the SimpleGCR as an implementation of this framework acting as a stable minimal performance baseline. It thus enables a reference point for comparing different explainability metrics. We evaluate our proposed approach by applying a set of current saliency methods on the univariate UCR UEA time series datasets, and demonstrate the sub-optimality of those methods in this context.

title: Development of a Prototype IoT-Integrated Hydroponic Green Forage System for Sustainable Agriculture
authors: Maria D. L. A. Barraza Ramos, Jose L. Colomo Rodelo, Humberto J. López Torres, Cristian Y. Olivares
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: This work presents the design and implementation of an IoT-enabled hydroponic green forage system. The prototype integrates a LoRaWAN-based communication network to monitor and control key growth parameters, promoting a sustainable agricultural approach. The system operates in three main stages. First, a Heltec Wireless Stick, an ESP32-based MCU, processes sensor data and adjusts environmental conditions to maintain optimal growth parameters. Second, data is transmitted via LoRaWAN through The Things Network (TTN) and relayed to a server via downlink communication. Finally, in the third stage, the data is processed for visualization. Information from TTN is transmitted via MQTT to Node-RED, where it is filtered and organized for real-time monitoring on an interactive dashboard. This architecture ensures efficient data transmission, remote monitoring, and precise environmental control for hydroponic forage production.

title: MUSE-SLAM: Multi-Sensor Underwater State Estimation SLAM
authors: Larissa e S. Gomes, Paulo L. J. Drews
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: This paper presents MUSE-SLAM, a robust multi-sensor fusion framework designed for state estimation of Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) operating in GPS-denied and visually degraded environments, such as underwater. The system is based on an Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) and four complementary sensors to overcome the drift commonly associated with traditional dead-reckoning methods. The sensors are: an Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) for high-frequency motion tracking, a Doppler Velocity Log (DVL) for velocity relative to the seafloor, a pressure sensor for absolute depth measurement, and a mechanically scanned imaging sonar (MSIS) used to detect environmental landmarks. An important aspect of MUSE-SLAM is its asynchronous sensor integration strategy, which processes timestamped measurements in chronological order, allowing for varying sensor update rates and accommodating communication delays. The approach is validated using a real-world dataset. Experimental results highlight the clear benefits of the multi-sensor setup: when comparing different sensor combinations, the full configuration (using all four sensors) showed significantly improved performance.

title: Mixed-Reality System for Neurodegenerative Disorders: Design, Implementation, and User Evaluation
authors: Daria Hemmerling, Paweł Jemioło, Mateusz Danioł, Marek Wodziński, Miłosz Dudek, Marta Kaczmarska, Kinga Jasiewicz, Magdalena Igras-Cybulska, Jakub Kamiński, Magdalena Wojcik-Pędziwiatr
abstract: This study introduces an innovative multimodal system designed to support the assessment of Parkinson’s disease, atypical Parkinsonian syndromes, and Huntington’s disease by integrating mixed-reality (MR) technology, specifically using augmented reality goggles. The system captures symptoms related to neurodegenerative disorders through detailed sensor data, including hand movements, gait, and gaze patterns. Central to our methodology is an interactive, game-like experience lasting 30 min, comprising 17 tasks that evaluate motor skills, speech, memory, cognitive functions, gait, and gaze. These tasks were developed in collaboration with neurologists and draw upon established clinical paradigms. This engaging experience, combined with traditional clinical tests, provides a comprehensive assessment of both physical and cognitive capabilities. Rather than aiming to provide a diagnostic decision, this study focuses on evaluating the feasibility and usability of the system in a clinical setting. By automating diagnostic tasks and utilizing MR technology, our approach enhances patient comfort and offers a more immersive and efficient assessment process. The system was evaluated with 15 neurodegenerative patients and 32 healthy subjects, demonstrating high scores in both immersion and usability across both groups. This work represents a first step toward integrating MR into clinical workflows for neurodegenerative disease assessment.

title: Exploring Gradient-Guided Masked Language Model to Detect Textual Adversarial Attacks_supp1-3635788.pdf
authors: Leo Yu Zhang
abstract: Textual adversarial examples pose serious threats to the reliability of natural language processing systems. Recent studies suggest that adversarial examples tend to deviate from the underlying manifold of normal texts, whereas pre-trained masked language models can approximate the manifold of normal data. These findings inspire the exploration of masked language models for detecting textual adversarial attacks. We first introduce Masked Language Model-based Detection (MLMD), leveraging the mask and unmask operations of the masked language modeling (MLM) objective to induce the difference in manifold changes between normal and adversarial texts. Although MLMD achieves competitive detection performance, its exhaustive one-by-one masking strategy introduces significant computational overhead. Our posterior analysis reveals that a significant number of non-keywords in the input are not important for detection but consume resources. Building on this, we introduce Gradient-guided MLMD (GradMLMD), which leverages gradient information to identify and skip non-keywords during detection, significantly reducing resource consumption without compromising detection performance. Extensive experiments show that GradMLMD maintains comparable or better performance than MLMD and outperforms existing detectors. Among defenses based on the off-manifold conjecture, GradMLMD presents a novel method for capturing manifold changes and provides a practical solution for real-world application challenges.

title: State-Action Control Barrier Functions: Imposing Safety on Learning-Based Control With Low Online Computational Costs
authors: Kanghui He, Shengling Shi, Ton van den Boom, Bart De Schutter
abstract: Learning-based control with safety guarantees usually requires real-time safety certification and modifications of possibly unsafe learning-based policies. The control barrier function (CBF) method uses a safety filter (SF) containing a constrained optimization problem to produce safe policies. However, finding a valid CBF for a general nonlinear system requires a complex function parameterization, which in general makes the policy optimization problem difficult to solve in real time. For nonlinear systems with nonlinear state constraints, this paper proposes the novel concept of state-action CBFs (SACBFs), which do not only characterize the safety at each state but also evaluate the control inputs taken at each state. SACBFs, in contrast to CBFs, enable a flexible parameterization, resulting in a SF that involves a convex quadratic optimization problem, which significantly alleviates the online computational burden. We propose a learning-based approach to synthesize SACBFs. The effect of learning errors on the effectiveness of SACBFs is addressed by constraint tightening and introducing a new concept called contractive-set CBFs. This ensures formal safety guarantees for the learned CBFs and control policies. Simulation results on an inverted pendulum with elastic walls validate the proposed CBFs in terms of constraint satisfaction and CPU time.

title: Multi-constraint Evolutionary Algorithm Based on Decomposition for the Synthesis of Concentric Ring Sparse Array
authors: Zeyang Jin, Ronghong Jin, Tingting Fan, Junping Geng, Yuxuan Zhao, Xue-Xia Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: For the local convergence phenomenon in the multiobjective evolutionary algorithm based on decomposition (MOEA/D) when applied to multiconstraint sparse array optimization, a multiconstraint evolutionary algorithm based on decomposition (MCEA/D) is proposed in this communication. Unlike MOEA/D, which constructs subproblems through weighted aggregation of multiple objectives, MCEA/D converts objective functions into constraints while retaining a single objective function, generating subproblems via constraint value space decomposition. Consequently, MCEA/D performs optimization within different constraint subspaces, with each subproblem operating in its own search space. This novel approach effectively mitigates the diversity loss and premature convergence issues of MOEA/D caused by the shared search space among subproblems. The results of uniformly excited concentric ring sparse array optimization demonstrate that MCEA/D can successfully identify feasible Pareto fronts, outperforming MOEA/D algorithm in this capability. Electromagnetic simulations validate the results.

title: BDC-Occ: Binarized Deep Convolution Unit For Binarized Occupancy Network
authors: Zongkai Zhang, Peng Ling, Zidong Xu, Wenming Yang, Qingmin Liao, Jing-Hao Xue
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Existing 3D occupancy networks demand significant hardware resources, hindering the deployment of resource-limited devices. Binarized Neural Networks (BNNs) offer a potential solution by substantially reducing computational and memory requirements. However, their performance decrease notably compared to full-precision networks. In addition, it is challenging to enhance the performance of the binarized model by increasing the number of binarized convolutional layers, which limits its practicability for 3D occupancy prediction. In this paper, we reconsider the components in binarized convolutional layers, and structures, for 3D occupancy prediction task. Two original insights into binarized convolution are presented, substantiated with theoretical proofs: (a) 1×1 binarized convolution introduces minimal binarization errors as the network deepens, and (b) binarized convolution is inferior to full-precision convolution in capturing cross-channel feature importance. Building on the above insights, we propose a novel binarized deep convolution (BDC) unit that significantly enhances performance, even when the number of binarized convolutional layers increases to meet the requirements of 3D occupancy networks. Specifically, in the BDC unit, additional binarized convolutional kernels are constrained to 1×1 to minimize the effects of binarization errors. Further, we propose a per-channel refinement branch to reweight the output via first-order approximation. Then, we partition the 3D occupancy networks into four distinct convolutional modules, employing BDC units to explore the effects of binarizing each of these modules. The proposed BDC unit minimizes binarization errors and improves perceptual capability, meeting the stringent requirements for accuracy and computational efficiency in 3D occupancy prediction. Extensive quantitative and qualitative experiments demonstrate that the proposed BDC unit achieves state-of-the-art performance in 3D occupancy prediction and 3D object detection tasks, while significantly reducing parameters and computational costs. This highlights the potential of the BDC unit as an efficient fundamental component in binarized 3D occupancy networks. Code for our paper will be released on “https://github.com/zzk785089755/BDC”.

title: Leveraging Swin Transformer for enhanced diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease using multi-shell diffusion MRI
authors: Quentin Dessain, Nicolas Delinte, Bernard Hanseeuw, Laurence Dricot, Benoit Macq
abstract: Objective: This study aims to support early diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease and detection of amyloid accumulation by leveraging the microstructural information available in multi-shell diffusion MRI (dMRI) data, using a vision transformer-based deep learning framework. Methods: We present a classification pipeline that employs the Swin Transformer, a hierarchical vision transformer model, on multi-shell dMRI data for the classification of Alzheimer's disease and amyloid presence. Key metrics from DTI and NODDI were extracted and projected onto 2D planes to enable transfer learning with ImageNet-pretrained models. To efficiently adapt the transformer to limited labeled neuroimaging data, we integrated Low-Rank Adaptation. We assessed the framework on diagnostic group prediction (cognitively normal, mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer's disease dementia) and amyloid status classification. Results: The framework achieved competitive classification results within the scope of multi-shell dMRI-based features, with the best balanced accuracy of 95.2% for distinguishing cognitively normal individuals from those with Alzheimer's disease dementia using NODDI metrics. For amyloid detection, it reached 77.2% balanced accuracy in distinguishing amyloid-positive mild cognitive impairment/Alzheimer's disease dementia subjects from amyloid-negative cognitively normal subjects, and 67.9% for identifying amyloidpositive individuals among cognitively normal subjects. Grad-CAM-based explainability analysis identified clinically relevant brain regions, including the parahippocampal gyrus and hippocampus, as key contributors to model predictions. Conclusion/Significance: This study demonstrates the promise of diffusion MRI and transformer-based architectures for early detection of Alzheimer's disease and amyloid pathology, supporting biomarker-driven diagnostics in data-limited biomedical settings.
