title: Fully Soft Switched Step-up Bridgeless SEPIC PFC Converter With Simple Auxiliary Circuit
authors: Atefe Shameli, Hosein Farzanehfard, S. Ali Khajehoddin
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: This paper proposes a novel step-up Bridgeless (BL) SEPIC Power Factor Correction (PFC) converter which operates under Discontinuous Conduction Mode (DCM) which simplifies the control circuit and provides inherent PFC. Also, the main converter utilizes a single switch without elevating the switching rate. The simple auxiliary circuit provides soft switching condition for the main switch as well as an improvement in the overall gain. Zero-Voltage Switching (ZVS) and Zero-Current Switching (ZCS) turn-on and off are achieved for the main switch and the auxiliary switch, respectively. All diodes turn off under ZCS. Consequently, conduction and switching losses, along with the reverse recovery problem, are significantly reduced that enables an increased switching frequency of 100kHz along with an enhancement in the overall efficiency. A 500W, 400V experimental prototype is implemented and the reported full load theoretical and practical efficiencies are 96.81% and 96.5%, respectively. Moreover, a full load THD of 3.8% is achieved.

title: Deep Learning–Integrated Agarose-Coated Micro-loop Fiber Resonator for Relative Humidity Measurement
authors: Huda Adnan Zain, Khurram Karim Qureshi
abstract: This work presents a fiber-optic sensor for relative humidity measurement, integrated with a deep learning model to address performance limitations of conventional fiber sensors. The proposed micro-loop resonator was coated with 0.5% agarose, exhibiting a sensitivity of 0.2037 dB/%RH within the 35–85%RH range. The sensor’s time stability and temperature dependence were also examined, showing a maximum power fluctuation of 0.0993 dB. Spectral responses from the coated micro-loop were recorded and converted into Parula heatmaps, then gray-scaled, resized, and compressed to generate a dataset of approximately 5,000 samples for training and testing a convolutional neural network (CNN). The integrated CNN model achieved an accuracy of 98%, demonstrating the feasibility of combining optical sensing and deep learning for enhanced humidity measurement.

title: RATR: Optimized Trajectory Release With Temporal Local Differential Privacy
authors: Shiyu Zhang, Qingqing Ye, Junxu Liu, Kai Huang, Yulian Mao, Xinyue Sun, Wei Dong, Haibo Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Time series data has a wide range of real-life applications, including financial forecasting, health monitoring, and social media analysis. However, this data often contains substantial individual privacy, and directly releasing them may lead to privacy infringement. Although existing research has proposed methods based on centralized differential privacy or local differential privacy to protect the privacy of time series data by injecting noise into the data, these methods may not be feasible in value-critical applications. Our previous work has introduced the TLDP model, which perturbs temporal data to ensure privacy guarantee while retaining original values. However, challenges persist when applying these methods to data exhibiting spatiotemporal correlations, such as trajectories. This paper proposes a novel trajectory release framework, Region-Aware Trajectory Re-sorting (RATR), which builds upon the temporal perturbation mechanism of TLDP by further introducing region-aware reachable constraints based on real road networks. In this way, it ensures privacy while significantly improving the spatial data utility. We construct region-aware reachable constraints and design a re-sorting algorithm to optimize the perturbed trajectories. Extensive experiments conducted on three real-world datasets demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of data utility while maintaining a lower overall cost.

title: Optimal Model-Free Tracking Control Based on Direct Adaptive Fuzzy Controller for a Mini-Drone
authors: Hossam Eddine Glida, Abdelghani Chelihi, Chouki Sentouh, Jagat Jyoti Rath
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This paper presents a direct robust adaptive fuzzy controller designed for a mini drone. The controller is developed to address the challenge of controlling the six-coupled nonlinear subsystems of the mini-drone with unknown dynamics for position and attitude control. The proposed control approach combines a fuzzy adaptive controller and the Bat Algorithm (BA) based optimization technique to elaborate decentralized control structure. The control inputs of the drone are generated through a Mamdani-type fuzzy adaptive controller, based exclusively on the system's tracking errors. This design choice effectively circumvents the singularity issues commonly encountered in indirect adaptive control schemes, while avoiding the need for robust state observers. To address external disturbances and model uncertainties, a robust compensatory term is incorporated into the fuzzy controller. The Bat Algorithm (BA) is employed to optimize the adaptation parameters of the controller to achieve the best performance in trajectory tracking. This approach resolves the trial-and-error issue in parameter selection which gives a systematic and optimal tuning of the control parameters. The stability of the closed-loop system is rigorously established via Lyapunov theory. The effectiveness of the proposed controller is demonstrated through various simulation cases on a virtual platform of Parrot Mini-Drone, as well as experimental validation for hovering. The results show that the proposed controller can handle unknown dynamics, uncertainties, and external disturbances while achieving accurate position and attitude control.

title: Dual-Level Imbalance Mitigation for Single-FoV Colorectal Histopathology Image Classification
authors: Lingling Yuan, Yang Chen, Md Rahaman, Hongzan Sun, Haoyuan Chen, Marcin Grzegorzek, Chen Li, Xiaoyan Li
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Single-field-of-view (FoV) histopathological image classification is vital for colorectal cancer (CRC) diagnosis in mid- to low-tier hospitals lacking whole-slide imaging (WSI) scanners and storage, yet suffers from severe class imbalance and degraded performance. To address this, we propose a dual-level imbalance mitigation (DIM) framework integrating data-level and algorithm-level approaches. Specifically: (1) A global context generative adversarial network (GCGAN) generates realistic minority-class images for augmentation to balance the dataset. (2) A frequency-aware adaptive focal loss (FAFL) applies a frequency-aware offset and adaptive modulation to better separate overlapping classes. (3) A lightweight receptive field-based convolutional neural network (LRF-CNN) is trained under DIM to leverage both augmentation and loss modulation for improved classification. Extensive experiments on the single-FoV colorectal histopathology dataset demonstrate that DIM-equipped LRF-CNN outperforms five state-of-the-art models (SOTA) across multiple metrics. Furthermore, each DIM component enhances performance when applied individually to those SOTA models, and additional validation on six single-FoV histopathological datasets confirms the generalizability and effectiveness of the proposed DIM framework. Our code is available at https://github.com/Lingling-Yuan/DIM.

title: Psychological Stress Inference for Professional Women via Multimodal Deep Representations
authors: Ma Jiahui
abstract: Modeling latent psychological stress in socio-cognitive and occupational environments is critical for intelligent human-centric computing, particularly under conditions of role conflict, hierarchical pressure, and cognitive overload. Existing inference methods, which often rely on self-reports or shallow behavioral cues, are insufficient for capturing the multifactorial and temporally dynamic nature of internal stress. A novel computational framework is introduced, integrating a graph-based multimodal embedding network with an adaptive strategy engine to reflect the interactional semantics of stress propagation. The framework includes StressGraph, a cognitive-interactional graph dynamics network that models time-evolving stress states via graph convolution and recurrent operations, and NeuroReaSON, a neurocognitive realignment module that transforms latent embeddings into individualized mitigation strategies through predictive realignment and simulation. Experimental results demonstrate improved predictive accuracy and long-horizon strategic coherence over existing approaches, supporting scalable and interpretable modeling of complex internal states in uncertain and dynamic environments.

title: An Enhanced GNN Encoder-based Approach to the Vehicle Routing Problem with Task Priority and Limited Resources
authors: Kwangcheol Shin, Uyanga Otgonbayar, Youngmi Kim
abstract: This study proposes a novel approach to the Vehicle Routing Problem with Task Priority and Limited Resources (VRPTPLR) by leveraging a Graph Neural Network (GNN) encoder. Unlike conventional methods that rely on Point Neural Network (PNN) encoders, our model explicitly exploits the inherent graph structure of the problem, enabling a more comprehensive representation of node and edge relationships. Specifically, we transformed a VRPTPLR dataset into a graph prior to training, assigned and normalized the edge weights, and then used the resulting graph as input to the GNN encoder. This preprocessing enriches the input representation, allowing the model to extract more informative features and thereby identify improved routing solutions. The GNN encoder was implemented with a Neural Network Convolution (NNConv) layer to effectively capture the complex interdependencies between customer nodes and vehicles. We evaluated the proposed approach against the PNN-based baseline across the three datasets. Experimental results show that the GNN-based model achieves faster convergence and yields benefit improvements ranging from 0.24% to 0.49%.

title: Universal Source Separation with Weakly Labelled Data for Computational Auditory Scene Analysis
authors: Qiuqiang Kong, Ke Chen, Haohe Liu, Xingjian Du, Taylor Berg-Kirkpatrick, Shlomo Dubnov, Mark D. Plumbley
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Computational Auditory Scene Analysis (CASA) aims to detect what sounds appear and when they occur in an audio recording, as well as to separate the audio into waveforms corresponding to the identified sound classes. The CASA problem presents several challenges. First, previous source separation sys tems require training on clean data, which is often scarce. Second, existing conditional source separation systems are designed to separate only a limited number of sound classes and cannot scale to separate hundreds of classes. Third, prior works require users to specify the sounds to be separated and cannot automatically detect which sound classes to separate. Fourth, there is a limited research on building hierarchical source separation systems. The contributions of this work are as follows. First, we propose training universal source separation (USS) systems on large scale weakly labeled and unlabelled datasets, rather than relying solely on clean data. Second, we develop a large-scale USS system capable of separating up to 527 sound classes, with the potential to scale to unlimited number of classes. Third, we introduce a method to automatically detect and separate sound classes without user specification. Fourth, we present a hierarchical USS system that can separate sound classes at various hierarchical levels. We train the USS systems on AudioSet and evaluate their performance on speech, audio, and music datasets, demonstrating the effectiveness of our approach. The source code is publicly available at https://github.com/qiuqiangkong/uss.

title: A Portable and Non-Invasive Device for Classifying and Detecting Swallowing and Respiratory Behaviors Using Deep Learning
authors: Mohammad Anwar Khan, Chin-Man Wang, Wann-Yun Shieh, Xian-Long Hou
abstract: Aging often leads to dysfunction of the swallowing and respiratory systems due to physiological changes, chronic diseases, or neurological degeneration, with dysphagia and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) being prevalent outcomes. These conditions, which have shared risk factors such as muscle weakening and neurological impairments, can considerably affect health, particularly in older adults, leading to malnutrition, respiratory infections, cardiovascular strain, and reduced quality of life. Thus, regular assessment and the early detection of swallowing and respiratory disorders are critical for preventing life-threatening complications. Traditional diagnostic methods, such as videofluoroscopic swallow study and polysomnography, are effective but impractical for home use because of their invasiveness, high costs, and reliance on specialized equipment. Therefore, this study developed a portable noninvasive system equipped with a force-sensitive resistor, laryngeal microphone, and nasal airflow cannula attached to an airflow transducer to monitor behaviors that require coordinated respiratory and neurological control, namely swallowing, speech, coughing, and snoring. The system collects synchronized multi-sensor data at 30 Hz and converts these signal into static waveform images for classification. To enhance behavior classification performance, a YOLOv5s 4-model ensemble was developed, where each YOLOv5s model is specialized to detect one specific behavior. The proposed system achieved an overall classification accuracy of 97.4% and a mean average precision of 97.3% across 3920 labeled images. Comparative evaluations were performed against three alternative models: the YOLOv5s single model, YOLOv8n, and a 1D CNN model using raw time-series data. The YOLOv5s 4-model ensemble outperformed these baseline methods, achieving superior detection performance while maintaining robustness across behavior classes. This system may offers a cost-effective solution for early detection and continuous monitoring of dysphagia, OSA, and related respiratory conditions in home or clinical environments, potentially providing an accessible alternative to conventional diagnostic approaches.

title: Virtual or Live? Choosing the Optimal Live-streaming Mode in a Dual-channel Supply Chain
authors: Ying Wei, Shan Lyu, Ruisi Yang
abstract: With the emergence of virtual AI streamers, choosing between a virtual streamer and a live streamer is a crucial decision for the brand manufacturer when launching a live-streaming business. This paper examines a dual-channel supply chain model consisting of a brand manufacturer, a store retailer, and either an artificial intelligence (AI) streamer or a key opinion leader (KOL) streamer. KOL streamers possess significant advantages over AI streamers due to their ability to interact effectively with consumers and their large fan bases. However, participating in pre-arranged KOL live-streaming events can incur a hassle cost for consumers, which is not required for AI streamers. Additionally, when collaborating with a KOL, the brand manufacturer must pay a fixed payment and a commission rate on revenues generated from live-streaming e-commerce, which can be ignored for AI streamers. Our research indicates that the costs associating with KOLs are a key factor in mode selection. We identify cost thresholds under which the brand manufacturer may prefer the KOL live-streaming mode over the AI mode. We also find that the hassle cost is a double-edged sword for the brand manufacturer. When the hassle cost is high, the KOL mode may still be preferred over AI mode. We then derive the retailer's mode preference and identify the conditions for achieving a common preference for the brand manufacturer and the retailer in both live-streaming scenarios. Finally, we conduct three extensions: considering product returns, exploring an alternative in-house live-streaming mode to the KOL mode, and examining the implications of an existing online channel. Results show that the findings of the main model remain robust.

title: AG-Pose: Anatomy-Guided Human Pose Estimation with Sparse IMUs_supp1-3635799.docx
authors: Xiaoyu Cui
abstract: This paper proposes a high-precision human pose estimation method using sparse IMU sensors, featuring two novel components. Firstly, an anatomy-guided sensor association model is proposed. Based on the inherent anatomical relationships within the human body, the human body is divided into five main parts, with joints in each part being associated with specific IMUs. By means of this model, the limited data from sparse IMUs can be effectively utilized to enhance the accuracy of pose estimation. Secondly, a hybrid deep learning architecture is presented. It consists of five parallel branches corresponding to the five parts of the human body. The architecture combining Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KAN) is utilized to reconstruct the pose of the corresponding anatomical part. The method addresses motion ambiguity caused by action distribution limitations in traditional inertial pose estimation. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance over state-of-the-art models across four public datasets.

title: Adaptive Change-Point Detection in S-RISnet-Assisted Wireless Networks
authors: Sida Dai, Bile Peng, Ehsan Tohidi, Setareh Maghsudi, Eduard A. Jorswieck, Slawomir Stanczak
abstract: The reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) is a promising technology for next-generation wireless communication systems, owing to its ability to intelligently manipulate wireless channels by adjusting the phase of impinging signals. Despite its potential, the practical deployment of RIS faces significant challenges, primarily due to the requirement of accurate reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) configuration, leading to substantial channel estimation overhead and increased hardware complexity. While the use of statistical channel state information (CSI) mitigates this issue to some extent, the dynamic nature of wireless channels, driven by user mobility, environmental changes, and other factors, continues to restrict system performance. In this work, we propose a joint optimization framework to address these challenges. Our approach combines a neural network-based reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) configuration method called statistical-RISnet (S-RISnet), which uses partial historical channel samples to predict optimal phase shifts, with a robust change-detection mechanism for the covariance matrix. The detector monitors variations in the angle of arrival (AoA) and user equipment (UE) distance, updating the channel covariance matrix only when significant performance degradation is predicted. Simulation results demonstrate that our proposed method significantly reduces estimation and computation overhead while maintaining performance near the theoretical optimum. This framework offers a scalable and efficient solution for real-world reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted networks, enabling feasible and high-performance deployment.

title: How Do Data Journalists Design Maps to Tell Stories?_supp1-3633911.pdf
authors: Arlindo Gomes
abstract: Maps are essential to news media as they provide a familiar way to convey spatial context and present engaging narratives. However, the design of journalistic maps may be challenging, as editorial teams need to balance multiple aspects, such as aesthetics, the audience's expected data literacy, tight publication deadlines, and the team's technical skills. Data journalists often come from multiple areas and lack a cartography, data visualization, and data science background, limiting their competence in creating maps. While previous studies have examined spatial visualizations in data stories, this research seeks to gain a deeper understanding of the map design process employed by news outlets. To achieve this, we strive to answer two specific research questions: what is the design space of journalistic maps? and how do editorial teams produce journalistic map articles? To answer the first one, we collected and analyzed a large corpus of 462 journalistic maps used in news articles from five major news outlets published over three months. As a result, we created a design space comprised of eight dimensions that involved both properties describing the articles' aspects and the visual/interactive features of maps. We approach the second research question via semi-structured interviews with four data journalists who create data-driven articles daily. Through these interviews, we identified the most common design rationales made by editorial teams and potential gaps in current practices. We also collected the practitioners' feedback on our design space to externally validate it. With these results, we aim to provide researchers and journalists with empirical data to design and study journalistic maps.

title: Design and Modeling of a Gliding Robotic Penguin Capable of Multimodal Locomotion
authors: Yelin Luo, Zhengxing Wu, Jian Wang, Laien Luo, Junzhi Yu, Min Tan
abstract: Penguins exhibit remarkable swimming capabilities with high speeds and efficient gliding for extended durations, thus providing an exemplary biological model for biomimetic underwater vehicles. In this article, inspired by the flapping–gliding locomotion mechanism observed in aquatic organisms, we create a novel robotic penguin capable of multimodal locomotion that combines biomimetic flapping and efficient gliding motions. Initially, a pair of three-degree-of-freedom (3-DOF) wings and a 1-DOF vertical tail is constructed to generate forward thrust and steering torque for biomimetic flapping motion. Meanwhile, a buoyancy adjustment system and a slider system are designed for gliding motion. Thereafter, a full-state dynamic model, including both flapping and gliding motions, is established by employing the Newton–Euler method. Particularly, the hydrodynamic coefficients are precisely calibrated through system identification utilizing experimental data. Finally, extensive simulations and experiments are conducted, encompassing forward swimming and turning maneuvers in both flapping and gliding modes. The results obtained validate the superior flapping and gliding performance of the designed system as well as the effectiveness of the dynamic model, providing new insights for next-generation underwater vehicles with enhanced maneuverability in dynamic and complex aquatic environments.
