title: Real-Time Impact Assessment of Sensor Measurement Falsification on Smart Grid Operations
authors: Brundavanam Seshasai, Subhojit Ghosh, Ebha Koley, Prasanta Kumar Jena
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The penetration of information and communication technologies (ICT) and the Internet of Things (IoT) in the smart grid (SG) power network paradigm has widened the landscape of cyber threats aiming at disrupting the grid operations. The wider exposure of the communication infrastructure increases the vulnerability of smart grids towards cyber intrusions. The most common impactful intrusions (commonly referred to as false data injection attack (FDIA)) involve falsification of sensor measurement while it is being transmitted to the control centre. Among FDIAs, the load redistribution(LR) attack causes the maximum disruption on the grid operations without being detected at the control centre. During the LR attack, the intruder attempts to virtually manipulate the sensor information at different locations. Analyzing the cyber vulnerability of power networks demands identifying possible LR attack scenarios that disrupt the grid operations to the maximum extent. In this regard, the present work proposes monitoring metrics, Cyber Resiliency Index (CRI), Cyber Severity Index (CSI) and Cyber Market Index (CMI) to quantify the impact of measurement falsification through LR attack scheme, executed with minimum budget and resources. The attack design task has been framed as a multi-objective optimization based on the trade-off between the objectives of maximum disruption and minimum attack cost. A set of solutions (Pareto-front), each pertaining to a bus location for LR attack, is derived post-convergence of the optimization problem. The proposed metrics have been validated for different attack scenarios in a real-time environment.

title: QoriTalk: An Adapted Neural Text-to-Speech System Tailored for Peruvian Spanish
authors: Josué Abel Florián Párraga, Pablo Alejandro Fonseca Arroyo
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Most existing Text-to-Speech Systems (TTS) targeting the Spanish language are based on neutral Latin American or Iberian data, often overlooking the importance and variety of accents across the Spanish-speaking countries. This work presents QoriTalk as an initial system-level implementation of a voice synthesizer tailored to generate natural-sounding and culturally resonant speech with unique Peruvian accents and prosody. Built upon the Spanish-adapted version of FS-TTS—an open-source, MIT-licensed model—QoriTalk was trained with publicly available datasets containing several hours of high-quality recordings from native Peruvian speakers. While no formal perceptual evaluation has yet been conducted, this preliminary contribution demonstrates a promising path toward accessible, culturally adapted TTS systems for applications in education, assistive tools and healthcare interfaces.

title: A Multifunctional UAV System for Precision Agriculture and Environmental Monitoring
authors: Yashas D, Kaviya Shri P, M Shivani Kashyap, Sahana Ravi, Sumehra Banu S, Yazhini T S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Today, precision agriculture as a modern approach to farming has been aided by advanced technology for optimizing crop management and resource utilization. A multifunctional UAV system for real-time environmental monitoring in agriculture landscapes is presented here. This drone has a Pixhawk flight controller and a variety of environmental sensors from which air quality using the MQ-135, soil moisture, temperature using DHT22, water pollution, and LIDAR-based distance sensors (VL53L0X) would be applied. Moreover, it has an SD card-associated black box for safe data storage, allows solar charging so it can have a much longer mission time, and permits autonomous water landing when necessary for better survivability in emergency situations. The UAV can provide accurate environmental data which could help farmers or environmental agencies in decision making with regards to irrigation, fertilization, or pollution control. The efficiency of capturing accurate sensors data is verified through test results that also show the solar charging-enabled extended mission endurance and miss emergency landings without damage to critical components. The cashless data integrity is ensured with the black box mechanism. The system is also far superior to conventional systems based on ground monitoring in terms of scalability, flexibility, and reduced cost. In the future, research initiatives will focus on developing machine learning algorithms that enable improved navigation and decision-making in a more autonomous fashion, with the real-time capability for dynamic field management. This UAV-based precision agriculture platform thus assures sustainable agriculture by reducing wastages, improving productivity, and preventing environmental degradation.

title: A Strategic Model for Evaluating and Selecting Suppliers Based on Sustainability for a Mining Company
authors: Aldenir Jara, Luis Hinostroza, Inés Tarazona Marañón, Andres Sotil
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: The mining industry is a key business due to its constant output, and timely supply is critical to its operation. Recurring issues with delivery delays and receiving improper supplies have a significant impact on sustainability. This article covers the characteristics that allow for effective supplier relationship management, emphasizing the role of sustainability in this assessment. It also provides a strategic model for developing plans and enhancing a mining company's supplier selection and evaluation processes, known as SSM. Based on a survey of the literature, this study identified a strong and reliable supplier classification model that will allow for supplier selection and evaluation. This is achieved by combining KPM and SRM techniques and implementing the F -AHP and F-TOPSIS procedures, which are based on the best management criteria and the impact of the supplies they provide. The data indicates which supplier is best suited to developing a plan for the six types of supplies from the three maj or families studied. Similarly, eight suppliers are deemed in need of replacement, and the decision to discontinue relationships with some of them is made. Furthermore, it was discovered that the Lubricants II product lacked suitable suppliers, presenting an opportunity to establish new ties with other providers.

title: Integrating XAI with Quantum Machine Learning Models for Interpretable Breast Cancer Classification
authors: V. Bhuvaneshwari, P. Shanmugavadivu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: It is estimated that millions of people from different parts of the world are suffering from breast cancer. As of 2022, it has one of the highest mortality rates. It symptomatized by the abnormal growth of breast tissue cells aggregating into malignant tumors. Because of this, the current study investigates quantum-enhanced machine learning models in hope of curing the disease in its earlier stages. In this case, breast cancer tumors are deemed benign or malignant using three different datasets—Wisconsin Diagnostic Breast Cancer (WDBC), Mammographic Mass (MM) and Breast Cancer Wisconsin (Original), all of which are publicly accessible on the UCI Machine Learning Repository. These datasets differ greatly in terms of size and the number of features that make it suitable for performance analysis of breast cancer classification. On the Breast Cancer Wisconsin (Original) and WDBC datasets, Quantum Random Forest (QRF) has gained the maximum accuracy of 97% and 96%, respectively, suggesting superiority in high-dimensional feature sets. Moreover, Quantum Support Vector Machine (QSVM) showed promising results with 81% accuracy on the MM dataset. The latter result was achieved with the use of Explainable AI (XAI) approach with Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME), which ensured interpretability and transparency of the quantum machine learning models. For each explanation LIME provided, there were important decision-altering features, like tumor size, lymph node involvement, degeneracy of malignancy and irradiation status, which were the primary determinants of the model’s choice. Such interpretability enhances trust in AI systems for medical diagnostics, as well as validating the outputs. Integrating quantum machine learning models with XAI techniques offers robust and interpretable frameworks for breast cancer classification, resulting in improved accuracy.

title: Autonomous Vehicle Localization with Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Henrique Barros Oliveira, Felipe Gomes de Melo D'Elia, Larissa Driemeier
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Accurately estimating a vehicle's position is a key challenge in autonomous navigation, requiring real-time performance and robustness to sensor noise, outages, and unmodeled dynamics. Recent advances in deep reinforcement learning (DRL) have shown promise as a data-driven, model-free alternative for various robotics and autonomous driving tasks. This work proposes an end-to-end DRL-based pipeline for vehicle localization using only proprioceptive sensor data, including IMU, speed, and steering angle, combined with estimates from an Extended Kalman Filter. The proposed system is built around a containerized architecture that enables simplified deployment from training in the CARLA simulator to real-time execution on embedded hardware. The approach is validated both in simulation and on a 1: 10 scale physical vehicle, demonstrating stable training convergence and real-time inference capabilities on resource-constrained platforms. While the model's accuracy is not yet sufficient for closed-loop operation, the results confirm the viability of the architecture and the training approach as a foundation for further development.

title: TZmediator: Secure Cooperative Execution of Cloud Applications Using POSIX APIs on Arm TrustZone
authors: Taiyo Sato, Kenichi Kourai
publish: 2025 IEEE 30th Pacific Rim International Symposium on Dependable Computing (PRDC)
abstract: Edge computing enables clouds to execute their applications closer to end-users. Even on untrusted edge devices, Arm TrustZone can securely run cloud applications in the secure world as trusted applications (TAs). Since the secure world has too high privileges, vulnerabilities in cloud applications could lead to the compromise of the entire system. To minimize the attack surface, it is desirable to run security-insensitive tasks in the normal world as unprivileged client applications (CAs). However, cooperation between CAs and TAs requires the use of the APIs specialized for TrustZone, which prevents flexible interactions. This paper proposes TZmediator to enable cooperative execution using standard POSIX APIs for a cloud application partitioned into two worlds. For inter-world seamless communications, TZmediator creates a shadow process in the normal world for each TA and delegates the invocation of POSIX APIs by a TA to the shadow process. Currently, it supports the message passing APIs, the shared memory API, and the signal API. If users require stronger isolation, TZmediator can execute security -sensitive tasks in TAs using WebAssembly. We have implemented TZmediator on OP- TEE and examined communication performance between CAs and TAs.

title: AI-Driven Adaptive Power Management for Sustainable 6G Wireless Networks
authors: K. Chandrasekhar, G. Prabakaran, P. Dileep Kumar Reddy
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The increasing demand for ultra-reliable, high-speed, and energy-efficient communication in next-generation wireless networks necessitates the development of advanced power management strategies. This research proposes an AI-enhanced cross-layer predictive power management framework for sustainable 6G networks, integrating artificial intelligence (AI), cross-layer optimization, predictive analytics, and wireless power transfer (WPT). The framework dynamically adjusts power allocation, scheduling, and beamforming using deep reinforcement learning (DRL) and lightweight machine learning (ML) models to optimize energy efficiency across different network layers.By leveraging multi-dimensional cross-layer optimization, the proposed approach enables adaptive power control across PHY, MAC, and network layers, enhancing energy efficiency in multi-cell, multi-carrier environments. Additionally, predictive power management techniques are incorporated to anticipate traffic demands and optimize sleep scheduling for mobile LTE and 6G devices, reducing unnecessary power consumption. The integration of wireless power transfer (WPT) and hybrid power-splitting receivers further ensures continuous energy harvesting for IoT and edge computing applications.Preliminary analysis suggests that the proposed framework can achieve up to 30% improvement in energy efficiency compared to traditional static and reactive power allocation strategies. This research will contribute to the development of scalable, sustainable, and intelligent energy management solutions for 6G networks, enabling the realization of green communications, smart cities, and ultralow-power IoT systems.

title: A Container-Based Approach for Proactive Asset Administration Shell Digital Twins
authors: Carsten Ellwein, Jingxi Zhang, Andreas Wortmann, Antony Ayman Alfy Meckhael
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems (MODELS)
abstract: In manufacturing, digital twins, realized as Asset Administration Shells (AAS), have emerged as a prevalent practice. These digital replicas, often utilized as structured repositories of asset-related data, facilitate interoperability across diverse systems. However, extant approaches treat the AAS as a static information model, lacking support for dynamic service integration and system adaptation. The existing body of literature has not yet thoroughly explored the potential for integrating executable behavior, particularly in the form of containerized services, into or from the AAS. This integration could serve to enable proactive functionality. In this paper, we propose a submodel-based architecture that introduces a structured service notion to the AAS, enabling services to dynamically interact with and adapt AAS instances at runtime. This concept is implemented through the extension of a submodel with behavioral definitions, resulting in a modular event-driven architecture capable of deploying containerized services based on embedded trigger conditions. The approach is illustrated through a case study on a 3-axis milling machine. Our contribution enables the AAS to serve not only as a passive digital representation but also as an active interface for executing added-value services.

title: Juca, An Embedded Mobile Robotics Board for Education
authors: Matheus Leitzke Pinto, Renan Augusto Starke, Adriano Vitor
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: Mobile robotics has become an essential tool in educational environments due to its dynamic and practical nature, which allows students to experiment with real-world applications. This paper introduces “Juca”, an embedded mobile robotics board designed specifically for education. Juca combines affordability, expandability, and robust functionality, making it suitable for classroom and competition environments. Key features include modular hardware akin to Arduino shields, support for differential drive robots, and seamless integration with educational programming platforms. Experimental results demonstrate its effectiveness in fostering hands-on learning and engagement.

title: Breakerspace Coffee: A Proof of Concept for Expanding Informal STEM Education and Citizen Science in Ecuador
authors: Vanessa Bastidas, Jorge Ayamara, Hernan Lara-Padilla
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Informal STEM education has the power to spark curiosity and engagement beyond formal classrooms, reaching diverse audiences in everyday settings. Citizen science initiatives and maker culture exemplify how hands-on, community-driven projects can make STEM accessible and relevant. Breakerspace Coffee is presented as a proof of concept that fuses informal STEM learning with citizen science principles. This pilot program-centered around coffee-allowed participants to explore engineering and science concepts through brewing experiments, materials analysis, and quality control tests in a casual environment. Key takeaways from this experiment suggest that such informal, interest-driven learning experiences can improve scientific literacy and enthusiasm. The implications point toward expanding these models into broader community engagement efforts.

title: Best Practices for Constructing Knowledge Graphs in Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) Systems
authors: Yeresime Suresh, Hayath T. M, S Shenaz Begum
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems enhance generative AI models by integrating external knowledge, improving factual accuracy, and reducing hallucinations. This paper presents a structured workflow for constructing knowledge graphs in RAG systems, covering document parsing, metadata extraction, data chunking, embedding generation, and vector database selection. By comparing chunking strategies, evaluate embedding models, and explore advanced metadata enrichment techniques to optimize retrieval accuracy. Experimental results provide best practices for improving RAG-based retrieval, with future work focusing on hybrid retrieval models and adaptive chunking strategies.

title: Design Hybrid Solar-Battery Methodology for Remote Communities
authors: Ricardo Manuel Arias Velásquez, Jennifer Vanessa Mejía Lara
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This paper developed the methodology for design, simulation, and techno-economic evaluation of a hybrid renewable energy system, with a case study of a remote community in south America, aimed at reducing reliance on diesel generation. The proposed system integrates photovoltaic solar power and a lithium-ion battery energy storage system to enhance energy reliability, reduce fuel consumption, and improve cost efficiency. A comprehensive methodology was applied to assess load profiles, solar resource potential, technical constraints, and environmental regulations. Geographic Information Systems and Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis were used to identify optimal sites. Simulation results showed that the hybrid configuration reduced annual diesel consumption by 91.3%, from 570,730 liters to 49,650 liters, while supplying over 716 MWh/year from solar PV. The Net Present Cost (NPC) decreased to $2.73 million, the Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE) was reduced to $0.0961/kWh, and the system achieved an Internal Rate of Return (IRR) of 7.91% with a 9.05-year payback period. The BESS operated at 89.5% round-trip efficiency and enabled daily energy shifting and peak shaving. These results confirm that hybrid PV-BESS systems offer a viable, cost-effective solution for decarbonizing off-grid communities while enhancing operational flexibility and energy security.

title: PSM: Proactive Spill Mitigation in PySpark
authors: Amin Karami
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Apache Spark's performance is critically dependent on efficient in-memory computation; however, insufficient executor memory frequently results in costly disk spills, severely degrading performance. Traditional spill mitigation techniques, including static configuration tuning, reactive Adaptive Query Execution (AQE), and internal spill handling mechanisms, exhibit limitations in addressing the dynamic and fine-grained nature of memory pressure in complex and large-scale workloads. This paper introduces Proactive Spill Mitigation (PSM), a novel methodology designed to anticipate and mitigate memory spills in PySpark applications before they occur. PSM leverages real-time task and executor metrics, accessible via the Spark Listener API, as input to a machine learning model trained to predict the likelihood and potential severity of impending spills. Upon detecting a high spill risk, a control mechanism triggers preemptive actions, such as checkpointing intermediate results or dynamically adjusting partition counts, to alleviate memory pressure. Experimental evaluation using the TPC-DS and HiBench Sort benchmarks demonstrates that PSM significantly reduces both execution time and the volume of data spilled to disk across various cluster sizes, outperforming default Spark configurations, statically tuned setups, and configurations with AQE enabled. This work establishes the efficacy of predictive control for enhancing Spark's memory management and improving application performance in dynamic environments.

title: Aqua-Mind Intelligent Rural Water Distribution System Using Iot
authors: Sahaya Fathima Suja V, Tamilselvi B, Nivetha M, Nithishkumar A, Yasotha T, Nethaji Naveen Prasath S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: There are two key problems that need to be addressed immediately in rural areas, and these are the lack of water and the insufficient distribution of water. It is possible that conventional water management systems do not have real-time monitoring, which might result in leaks, increased waste, and insufficient supply. This is a potential risk. The purpose of this article is to present a description of a smart water management system that is powered by the Internet of Things (IoT) and has the objective of optimizing the distribution and use of water in rural regions. The use of data analytics, cloud computing, and wireless sensors allows for the measurement of water levels, the identification of leaks, and the management of an acceptable supply. All of these tasks may be completed simultaneously. The Internet of Things gives consumers and authorities the capacity to make well-informed decisions, which simultaneously reduces the amount of water that is wasted and improves sustainability while doing so.

title: A Systematic Review on Teacher Training in Educational Robotics: Global and Brazilian Perspectives
authors: Lídia Gabrielly Dutra de Meneses Santos, Carla da Costa Fernandes Curvelo, Luiz Marcos Garcia Gonçalves
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: This paper presents a systematic literature review on teacher training in educational robotics, with a twofold objective: to map the global research landscape and to provide a focused analysis of the Brazilian context. The review was guided by spe-cific research questions and conducted using the Scopus and Web of Science databases for the global perspective, complemented by the Brazilian Digital Library of Theses and Dissertations (BDTD) for the local analysis. Our findings highlight Brazil's significant international contribution, ranking second in the number of publications in both Scopus (6 out of 28) and Web of Science (4 out of 15). At the national level, our analysis identified 11 recent theses and dissertations completed between 2020 and the present. These results indicate that robust methodologies for teacher training in Educational Robotics are not only being actively researched but also effectively implemented throughout Brazil.

title: Optimization of Pneumatic Finger Actuator Design for Soft Robotic Applications in Hand Therapy
authors: Milagros J. Noriega, Victoria E. Abarca, Dante A. Elias
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: The human hand plays a fundamental role in daily activities and the development of fine motor skills, particularly during childhood; however, traumatic injuries or neurological disorders affecting hand joints can severely impair functionality and compromise the long-term quality of life in pediatric populations. Robotic gloves equipped with pneumatic actuators have emerged as promising tools to support rehabilitation in these cases, offering precise and adaptive assistance to restore movement. Despite their potential, current devices exhibit notable limitations, particularly in terms of durability and uniformity of pressure distribution in the actuators, which often result in premature material failure and reduced therapeutic effectiveness. This study aimed to optimize the design of pneumatic finger actuators for pediatric rehabilitation by evaluating how actuator geometry influences fatigue life and pressure performance. Using room temperature vulcanizing (RTV) Type 6 silicone for its favorable mechanical properties, three actuator designs were fabricated with polylactic acid (PLA) molds produced through 3D printing and subjected to fatigue, pressure, and deformation tests. The results showed that geometry had a substantial impact on performance: Design 1 withstood 3393 cycles at 62 kPa, whereas Design 2 failed after 1293 cycles at 51 kPa. Fatigue analysis confirmed that internal reinforcements and the distribution of stress concentration zones play a critical role in enhancing long-term durability.

title: Predictive Analysis of Deforestation in India: Identifying Hotspots and Policy Implication
authors: Abdul Subhan Omeez, Shobha Rathod, Falisha Umaiza, Viraj Nandalikar, Shreya J, V Leelambika
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Rapid urbanization, agriculture, and industrialization are putting increasing strain on India's forests, creating serious environmental problems. This study uses machine learning and time-series models including LightGBM (Light Gradient Boosting Machine), LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) and ARIMA (AutoRegressive Integrated Moving Average) to examine how the forest cover is changing across Indian states and forecast future trends. We project changes in forest cover between 2024 and 2030 using government records and historical data from Global Forest Watch According to our models, some states—including Mizoram, Assam, Manipur, Meghalaya, and Nagaland—are more vulnerable to deforestation in the years to come. Failure to take preventive action could have major ecological and socioeconomic repercussions for these locations. This study foresees forest decline and offers strategic recommendations for prompt intervention by fusing predictive modeling and prescriptive analytics. It provides useful information to support evidence-based policy planning and sustainable forest management in India.

title: Neural Network Approach for ASL Translation to Indian Languages with Integrated Speech Synthesis
authors: Varnitha Venkatesh, Shreyaa S M Kudremane, Pallavi R.
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: This work introduces an American Sign Language (ASL) hand gesture detection system in real-time for communication between the deaf-dumb community and other individuals by converting sign language to both text and speech. Current approaches utilize computer vision software such as MediaPipe and OpenCV to detect hand landmarks and movements. To bypass their limitations, we present a new CNN architecture that learns to automatically extract discriminative spatial-temporal features from raw video streams without the need for feature engineering. In contrast to LSTM networks, which are more commonly applied to sequential data, CNNs can take advantage of both spatial and temporal information efficiently and are thus well-suited to process dynamic hand motion. This architecture also facilitates quicker processing and real-time operation, which is essential for real-world applications. Moreover, by incorporating text-to-speech (TTS) translation, the system promotes accessibility by transforming identified gestures into spoken words, further reducing communication gaps. With the help of superior CNN-based models and multilingual language translators, the system proposes to serve India's multi-linguistic communities. The data is separated into 70% for training and 30% for testing, with an accuracy rate of 95% which is higher than the conventional method. This system has broad applications across public services, healthcare, and education, providing an assistive technology tool for better communication and the promotion of a more inclusive community.

title: Enhancing Crop Growth Monitoring through Satellite Imagery Analysis: A Precision Agriculture Approach
authors: Shehu Mohammed, Harmeet Singh, Arun Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Satellite imagery analysis for monitoring crop growth has been one of the most critical innovations in precision agriculture, making this sort of tool one of the strongest approaches farmers and agronomists can use to increase productivity and sustainability. This paper reports on the potential of high-resolution multispectral and hyperspectral satellite imagery for monitoring crop health throughout the growing season, including above-ground accumulated biomass, chlorophyll content, and stress. The use of satellite imaging and its analysis using advanced algorithms coupled with machine learning technologies allows for the real-time evaluation of anomalies in growth, which ensures timely interventions and hence better management of resources to counter any possible yield loss in a relatively shorter timeframe. What is more, this technology can contribute to precision irrigation and the accurate control of both water and nutrients (fertilizers and pesticides) at the same time, it helps in reducing environmental degradation as well as in sustainable production. Case examples are provided for a range of agricultural contexts to illustrate how the use of satellite imagery can inform decisions, as well as crop management strategies. The paper reviews the current status of neural network applications, demonstrating incredible progress, but also identifies some drawbacks and slowly assesses its future potential by improving resolution, lowering costs, and data integration from multiple sources. Altogether, the results highlight the revolutionary nature of satellite imagery to usher in a new state-of-the-art era of data-driven agriculture monitoring and management.

title: Design of A Large-Scale, Rectangular-Shaped Superferric Dipole Magnet for High Rigidity Spectrometer at Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB)
authors: Danlu Zhang, Yoonhyuck Choi, Xiaoji Du, Junseong Kim, Hengkang Zheng, John Wenstrom, Mohit Patil, Jeff Hulbert, Bryan Tousignant, Hai Nguyen, Yamen Al-Mahmoud, Blake Gower, Raul Quispe-Abad, Courtney Smith, Samuel Miller, Christopher Baker, Cody Knowles, Nusair Hasan, Jonathon Howard, Rao Ganni, Ting Xu, Shumpei Noji, Remco G. T. Zegers
abstract: A large-scale, rectangular, iron-dominated superconducting dipole magnet, DS1, has been designed for the High Rigidity Spectrometer (HRS) at Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB), Michigan State University (MSU). As part of the 8 Tm spectrometer system, DS1 is designed to produce a 2.32 T mid-plane field at an operating current of 406 A. It is energized by six superconducting coil sub-divisions wound with large wire-in-channel (WIC) NbTi conductor and cooled with liquid helium. A room-temperature iron yoke shapes the dipole field, with ferromagnetic field clamps added to reduce fringe fields near detectors and sensitive electronics. A novel quench protection circuit incorporating cold diodes has been developed to prevent unbalanced forces on support links during asymmetric quench events and to limit current through the high-temperature superconductor (HTS) leads. The coil helium vessel has been optimized to withstand large Lorentz forces, with stress and displacement analyses confirming mechanical integrity at cryogenic temperatures. The thermal shield, constructed from alternating copper and stainless steel panels, has been designed to maintain mechanical integrity and suppress eddy currents during quench events.

title: PRISM-FL – A Privacy-Aware Decision Support System for Enhanced Medical Diagnostics Based on Federated Learning
authors: Barbara Pękala, Przemysław Grzegorzewski, Jarosław Szkoła, Dawid Kosior
abstract: This study tackles the challenge of building effective diagnostic models while preserving patient data privacy, a critical issue in medical applications like breast cancer diagnosis. Individual healthcare institutions often lack sufficient or high-quality data to train reliable machine learning models, and privacy regulations prevent data sharing. To address this, we use federated learning, a technique that allows multiple organizations to collaboratively train a model without sharing local data. Our focus is on horizontal federated learning, where each participant trains a local model on its own data. These models are updated locally, then aggregated periodically to improve the global model’s performance. Aggregation typically relies on weighted averaging, with different strategies for assigning weights. We enhance this process by incorporating uncertainty-aware aggregation using the Choquet integral, a method for information fusion. And also by integrating uncertainty measures such as entropy, we aim to improve both model performance and robustness. We also investigate how local model parameters are affected by their performance and by uncertainties present in the data.

title: Identifying Acute Thoracolumbar Vertebral Compression Fractures From Low-Quality Small-Sample X-Ray Images: A Transfer Learning-Based Approach
authors: Yilin Wang, Weijun Li, Siyu Chen, Yang Yang, Aidi Fan, Chenhao Lei, Yuhui Kou, Na Han, Feng Xue, Peixun Zhang, Dianying Zhang, Xiwen Bai, Maohan Liang, Jian Xiong
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Timely and accurate diagnosis of acute thoracolumbar vertebral compression fractures in X-ray images is critical for initiating prompt and effective treatment, preventing potential neurological damage and long-term disability. Recent advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) have significantly improved medical imaging analysis, providing sophisticated tools to assist clinicians in diagnosing acute thoracolumbar vertebral compression fractures. Nonetheless, detecting these fractures through imaging remains challenging due to the complex overlapping of bony structures in the thoracolumbar region, variability in fracture patterns, and often subtle nature of these injuries. Additionally, the limited availability and sometimes poor quality of medical images further complicate accurate AI-based detection. Addressing these challenges, this study introduces a transfer learning model optimized for recognizing acute thoracolumbar vertebral compression fractures from a small set of low-quality X-ray images. The model starts with a feature extraction model that analyzes multiple texture features of X-ray images. It then employs a Vision Transformer Detector (ViTDet) combined with a faster region-based convolutional neural network (Faster R-CNN) to recognize fractures efficiently. To enhance its performance on small datasets, the model employs a transfer learning approach for training. Extensive experiments with a large dataset of real-world images have shown that this model can effectively recognize acute thoracolumbar vertebral compression fractures from low-quality images, outperforming professionals with specialized knowledge in some cases.

title: Phase-Shifter-Free Reconfigurable Array Architecture Using Pattern Rotation—Part I: Theory and Validation
authors: Bingyi Qian, Shuxin Zheng, Jianchuan Wei, Bo Wang, Xiaoming Chen, Ahmed A. Kishk
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A unified reconfigurable array architecture is proposed, supporting two-phase modulation mechanisms: element rotation and initial phase modulation. Both approaches enable subarray-level beam steering without needing phase shifters or complex feeding networks, facilitating large-scale array beam scanning with fewer radio frequency channels. An innovative beamforming method is introduced in Part I, leveraging element rotation within an N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub>-element (6-element) linear subarray. Vertical partition scanning within ±θ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</sub> (±10°) is achieved by presetting the tilt angles of the elements in the N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub>-element subarray (6-element). A longer linear array of N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">y</sub>-elements formed by M<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub>-subarrays is formed (N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">y</sub>=M<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub>×N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub>). A high-profile N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</sub>×N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">y</sub> array (8×24) of Yagi elements achieves two-dimensional beam scanning at 4.5 GHz with a grating lobe suppression algorithm. To generalize this approach, a theoretical framework is established that incorporates concepts such as phase smoothing region, deflection phase, intrinsic phase, and initial phase modulation, ultimately extending the rotation-based method into a universal initial phase control scheme. Simulation and measurement results confirm that replacing conventional small-ratio power dividers with 1-to-N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</sub> equal-dividers preserves low sidelobe levels in vertical scanning, maintains original horizontal scanning performance, and achieves channel capacity parity with full-channel systems. Part II will further validate the approach by designing and implementing a dual-polarized base station antenna element with electronically tunable initial phase control.

title: High-Gain and Wideband 3D Pattern Reconfigurable Antenna using Tunable Parasitic Strips
authors: Ahmed N. D. Tetteh, Patrick Danuor, Young-Bae Jung
abstract: This article presents a wideband and high-gain pattern reconfigurable antenna for dynamic IoT communication networks in smart indoor environments of 5G FR1 n78 band (3.3 to 3.8 GHz). The proposed antenna enables adaptive beam steering and coverage optimization for diverse IoT device deployments in smart buildings and intelligent indoor spaces. The antenna comprises a direct-fed square patch and a reconfigurable parasitic layer that dynamically adjusts to varying IoT traffic patterns and device locations. The parasitic layer consists of a parasitic patch and four pairs of bracket-shaped strips to facilitate intelligent beam steering toward different IoT clusters with minimal steering variability across a wide operating bandwidth. To achieve context-aware beam pattern reconfigurability, each bracket-shaped strip pair is incorporated with a PIN diode to alter the surface current distribution, enabling real-time adaptation to IoT network topology changes. The proposed antenna supports eight directional IoT communication zones as well as broad and narrow 3-dB beamwidth reconfigurability to optimize coverage for heterogeneous IoT device densities. A prototype demonstrates an impedance bandwidth of 21.58% with |S<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</sub>| < –10dB from 3.1 to 3.85 GHz, and a measured realized gain of 8.8 dBi, making it suitable for energy-efficient IoT communications and smart environment applications.

title: Game-Theoretic Reinforcement Learning-Based Behavior-Aware Merging in Mixed Traffic
authors: Dan Wang, Gangyan Xu, Changsheng Qu, Zhizhou Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: With the increasing integration of Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) into traffic systems, the interaction between different types of vehicles presents a significant challenge for cooperative decision-making, particularly in mixed traffic environments where AVs coexist with Human-driven Vehicles (HVs). Among various scenarios, highway on-ramp merging is a critical and complex one where effective interaction is essential for ensuring traffic safety and efficiency, and decisions of AVs and HVs should be made efficiently. In this paper, we propose a Game-Theoretic Reinforcement Learning (GTRL)-based vehicle behavior interaction framework designed for various merging scenarios in mixed traffic environments. This framework includes Stackelberg leader-follower interactions between AVs and HVs, as well as Nash cooperative interactions between vehicles of the same type, such as AV-AV or HV-HV. We formulate the problem as a Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP) and employ the Bi-level Reinforcement Learning (Bi-RL) method and Safe Multi-Agent Deep Q-Network (MADQN) method to address two distinct types of interaction problems. A gym-based simulation environment is developed to evaluate four interaction scenarios between vehicles in mixed traffic. Comprehensive experimental results demonstrate the potential of the GTRL-based behavior interaction framework to adapt to the dynamic and uncertain nature of vehicle interactions.

title: Robust Six-DOF Localization of Two Close-Proximity Magnets via Smart Initialization for Biopsy-Capable Capsules
authors: Zahra Tolouei, Hossein Nejat Pishkenari, Masoud Yousefi, Hamidreza Razavi
abstract: Endoscopic capsules have emerged as a promising technique for minimally invasive procedures, offering reduced patient discomfort and eliminating the need for external connections. However, integrating a biopsy mechanism into these capsules requires multiple internal magnets, which complicates magnetic localization. This paper addresses the six-degree-of-freedom magnetic localization of a biopsy-capable endoscopic capsule containing two magnets with opposite dipoles and conventional forceps. While using two magnets may offer benefits, it introduces significant technical hurdles in magnetic field interpretation and algorithmic robustness. The magnetic localization is performed using the Levenberg-Marquardt optimization algorithm. However, since Levenberg-Marquardt is sensitive to the initial guess, we propose a novel method using an equivalent magnetic dipole model and analytical equations to determine an appropriate initial guess. Additionally, due to the capsule’s magnetic configuration, the magnetic field strength decreases rapidly as distance from the magnetometers increases. So, to achieve accurate localization across all samples with different orientations in the workspace, we employ two perpendicular magnetometer arrays. Experimental results demonstrate an average position error of 3.2 ± 1.2 mm and an orientation error of 4.7 ± 2.8° for a capsule containing two magnets with volumes of 280.39 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> and 84.823 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, respectively. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method provides strategic initial values that effectively prevent both local convergence and divergence.

title: Visual Measurement and Uncertainty Prediction of Insulator Thickness in Insulated Rail Joints
authors: Ryohei Kasai, Takayuki Okatani
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Railway tracks are critical to social infrastructure, and their maintenance is essential for operational safety. Glued Insulated Rail Joints (GIRJs) are vital for railway signal control, where the insulator’s thickness helps prevent signal failures. This paper addresses detecting anomalies in GIRJ insulator thickness using images captured by devices on operational trains. Due to various factors, the insulator is not always clearly visible, and standard computer vision methods often struggle. In severe cases, judgments cannot be made from the image alone, requiring the system to return “unable to determine.” If these cases are rare, they can be manually inspected, still lowering overall inspection costs. We tackle this by framing the task as a one-dimensional regression problem, using convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to predict the boundary between the insulator and rail, while also estimating prediction uncertainty. Experiments with real-world data show that the model is accurate enough for practical use, even with challenging images. Additionally, we propose a robust method for detecting GIRJs in long-range railway images. This system is now operational in railway inspections.

title: Algorithmically-Assisted Schematic Transit Map Design: a System and Algorithmic Core for Fast Layout Iteration_supp1-3633910.mp4
authors: Thomas C. van Dijk
abstract: London's famous "tube map" is an iconic piece of design and perhaps represents the schematic visualization style most well-known to the general public: its octolinearity has become the de facto standard for transit maps around the world. Making a good schematic transit map is challenging and labour-intensive, and has attracted the attention of the optimization community. Much of the literature has focused on mathematically defining an optimal drawing and algorithms to compute one. However, achieving these "optimal" layouts is computationally challenging, often requiring multiple minutes of runtime. Crucially, what it means for a map to be good is actually highly dependent on factors that evade a general formal definition, like unique landmarks within the network, the context in which a map will be displayed, and the preference of the designer and client. Rather than attempting to make an algorithm that produces a single high-quality and ready-to-use metro map at great cost, we propose it is more fruitful to support rapid layout iteration by a human designer, providing a workflow that enables efficient exploration of a wider range of designs than could be done by hand, and iterating on these designs. To this end we identify steps in the design process of schematic maps that are tedious to do by hand but are algorithmically feasible, and present a framework around a simple linear program that computes network layouts almost instantaneously given a fixed direction for every connection. These connection directions are decided by a designer in a graphical user interface with several interaction methods and a number of quality-of-life features demonstrating the flexibility of the framework; the implementation is available as open source.
