title: Data-Driven Secondary Frequency Restoration and SoC Balancing Control of ESSs with Multiple Faults Under Event-Triggered Communication
authors: Zhenjian Xie, Yi Tang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: This paper focuses on the secondary frequency restoration and state-of-charge (SoC) balancing control problem for energy storage systems (ESSs) with multiple faults under event-triggered communications. Specifically, a data-driven estimator is first designed by using the temporal convolutional network (TCN) to estimate the communication faults. Then, a k-step fault estimator is introduced to estimate the unknown actuator faults such that the estimation error converges to zero as the number of estimation steps increases to infinity. Based on these estimators, an event-triggered distributed secondary fault-tolerant controller is designed by introducing a dynamic event-triggered mechanism for each ESS. Different from existing secondary control results on ESSs, the developed strategy can achieve both frequency restoration and SoC balancing with restricted communication under multiple faults. It is shown that both frequency restoration and the SoC balancing objectives can be achieved under the developed method. Finally, a real-time experiment is introduced to show the effectiveness of the developed method.

title: Experimental Analysis of CFRP and GFRP Composites Using Guided Ultrasonic Waves: Development of Frequency Maps
authors: Saúl Hernández-Moreno, Víctor A. Ramírez-Elías, E. Rojas-Mancera, C.E. Peñuela-Cruz, Francesc Pozo, Antonio Balvantín-García
abstract: The in situ and non-destructive inspection of composite materials, particularly carbon fiber-reinforced polymers (CFRP) and glass fiber-reinforced polymers (GFRP), is essential in lightweight structural applications where early damage detection is critical for ensuring structural reliability. Guided ultrasonic waves (GUWs) offer a promising non-destructive evaluation (NDE) technique due to their ability to propagate throughout long distances while being sensitive to material defects. This work presents the characterization of experimental GUW propagation features in CFRP and GFRP laminates, providing a comparative assessment of wave behavior in these materials. Experiments were conducted using piezoelectric transducers to generate and receive guided ultrasonic waves under varying excitation frequencies, plate thickness, and transducer arrangement. Key parameters, such as phase and group velocities, and attenuation, were analyzed to identify the impact of fiber type, layup orientation, and internal structural differences on wave propagation. The results indicate that CFRP exhibits lower attenuation and more substantial mode dispersion than GFRP, attributed to its higher stiffness and anisotropy. As a result, CFRP shows better wave transmission with lower attenuation, allowing long-range ultrasonic inspection. This study also provides valuable insights for developing ultrasonic inspection methodologies based on different fiber orientations and multiple laminated composite materials (CFRP and GFRP).

title: Fatigue properties of cold-rolled Cu-Zr alloy sheets
authors: R. Niu, K. Han, V. J. Toplosky, J. Toth
abstract: We performed tension-tension fatigue tests in stress control mode on cold-rolled Cu-Zr alloy sheets with various levels of tensile strength (TS). We then compared the fatigue properties of these sheets to those of cold-rolled Cu sheets. Fatigue life increased as TS increased. We separated our Cu-Zr sheets according to their mechanical strength levels, designating those with their TS ∼490 MPa as “H”, those with TS around 448±5 MPa as “M”, and those with TS < 440 MPa as “L”. The “H” sheets exhibited the longest life, followed by the “M” sheets, and the “L” sheets, all outperforming Cu. At 390 MPa. “H” Cu-Zr's fatigue life was ∼3 times that of Cu. Both the Cu-Zr and the Cu showed cyclic hardening. The presence of Zirconium improved fatigue life by stabilizing microstructure and retarding the formation of cracks during fatigue cycling, thus positioning Cu-Zr alloys as much stronger candidates than Cu for resistive magnet conductors.

title: Takagi–Sugeno&ndash;Kang Fuzzy Systems With Iterated Projection Optimization for Classification Problems_supp1-3635407.pdf
authors: Jian Wang
abstract: Takagi–Sugeno–Kang (TSK) fuzzy systems are valued for their interpretability and flexibility, yet scaling them to high-dimensional data remains challenging. On the antecedent side, computing firing strengths with the product T-norm often results in ineffective activations, undermining rule utilization. On the consequent side, classical least-squares and gradient-based training may generalize poorly without additional regularization. Thus, an efficient and effective training algorithm is required to strike a balance between generalization and precision. To overcome these challenges, we propose a high-dimensional adaptive uniform membership function (HDAUMF) that adapts the width parameter using a theoretically motivated lower bound on the Gaussian width. By incorporating an activation radius to regulate the activation distribution, HDAUMF improves the effectiveness of rule activation. Building on this, a variant of the Kaczmarz method is extended to learn consequent weights of multioutput TSK models, which is further enhanced by a dual residual strategy to accelerate convergence. To mitigate the computational burden of matrix operations, a partitioned update scheme is designed, giving rise to the dual residual iterated projection (DRIP) algorithm. Theoretical analysis shows that convergence under the dual residual strategy yields the minimum-norm least-squares solution, thereby supporting robust generalization. Combining these advancements, a novel iterated projection TSK fuzzy system (IPTSK) is developed. Numerical experiments validate that the proposed methods achieve competitive performance in tackling high-dimensional problems.

title: TimeCraft: Bridging Communities through an AI-Driven Time Banking Platform for Smarter Skill Exchange and Service Sharing
authors: Nikhil N, Sheba Selvam, Smrithi R, Pranava M K
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: TimeCraft is a timebanking platform powered by artificial intelligence (AI) that uses cutting-edge machine learning algorithms to revolutionize community-based skill and service exchange. To provide precise and customized task matching, TimeCraft primarily uses a hybrid recommender system that combines TF-IDF-based content filtering and nearest neighbor-based collaborative filtering. These algorithms optimize the matchmaking process, guaranteeing fair and effective exchanges, by analyzing user profiles, transaction history, and contextual preferences. By capturing intricate, non-linear relationships between users and services, the Memory-Based Collaborative Filtering (MBCF) model, which is further integrated into the platform, improves recommendation accuracy. With real-time user feedback, TimeCraft’s continuous learning pipeline updates the models, enabling the system to dynamically adjust to changing user behaviors and community demands.

title: Survival Analysis for the Evolution of Lifespan of Electrical and Electronic Equipment: A Case Study of Television Equipment in Peru
authors: Pedro Chumpitaz-Flores, Marco Gusukuma
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: This research presents a framework for analyzing the life cycle evolution of first use of electronic and electrical devices for the assessment and management of Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment (WEEE), with a focus on television equipment in Peru as a case study. This analysis is based on data from official entities such as National Institute of Statistics and Informatics (Instituto Nacional de Estadística e Informática or INEI), providing a basis for research. The study begins with the application of non-parametric methods, such as the Kaplan-Meier method, to estimate the lifespan of televisions, followed by an analysis using parametric models that suit the nature of the data, implementing statistical validation techniques to ensure the reliability of the obtained results. The proposed framework highlights retention and management patterns of the electrical devices in the examined context and offers a structure for similar studies in different contexts or regions. By focusing on official data sources, the study proposes a methodology, paving the way for policy formulation for the management of waste from electrical and electronic equipment.

title: Offshore Asset Inspection Redefined: Expert- Validated Deep Learning for Critical Defects
authors: Urmila Gurung, M S Mekala, Carlos Francisco Moreno-Garcia, Nikolaus Zolnhofer, Barry Marshall, Elyan Eyad
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: The offshore energy industry faces challenges in maintaining ageing infrastructure, with over half of North Sea platforms past their 25-year design life. This creates a need for scalable inspection methods beyond traditional manual reviews. We present a collaborative Human-AI framework that assists in detecting structural defects whilst preserving expert oversight under challenging marine conditions. Our two-stage system first employs a lightweight classifier to filter video frames by risk level. High-risk frames are then analysed by a modified Pyramid Attention Network that performs precise defect localisation. Experts validate the results at both stages, ensuring the system's continuous improvement. To better identify rare but critical flaws, we design Enhanced Tversky, a composite loss function to mitigate severe class imbalance by explicitly prioritising rare yet safety-critical defects like cracks. Evaluation on 5,525 classified frames and 1,013 segmented images demonstrates F2 score of 87.59% and a mean IoU of 78.73%, with crack detection reaching a crucial 89.62% F2 score. The framework reduces expert review time by 3.88 x whilst maintaining safety standards, offering a practical approach to scaling offshore inspection capabilities through Human-AI collaboration.

title: Monocular Visual Odometry with YOLO-Based Dynamic Object Filtering
authors: Márcio G. L. Filho, André O. Françani, Marcos R. O. A. Maximo
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: This work addresses the challenge of dynamic elements in monocular visual odometry, which traditionally relies on keypoint matching under the assumption of a fully static scene. In real-world environments, however, moving objects violate this assumption and can degrade pose estimation accuracy. To miti-gate this, we propose enhancing a classical feature-based visual odometry pipeline by using the YOLO (You Only Look Once) neural network to detect potentially dynamic objects and remove keypoints located within their bounding boxes. We compare this approach to a baseline method that uses only geometric keypoint matching, using sequences from the KITTI dataset for evaluation. Quantitative evaluation shows an improvement in the accuracy of the estimated trajectory when keypoints on dynamic objects are excluded from the odometry process.

title: State of the Trekking Autonomous Robots Competition
authors: Felipe G de M D'Elia, Bruna Vitória R Pinheiro, Larissa Driemeier
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the 2025 RoboCore Experience's Trekking competition, one of Latin America's largest autonomous robotics challenges. Modeled after RoboMagellan, the Trekking category tasks ground robots with autonomously navigating a known environment, reaching predefined landmarks in sequence in the shortest possible time. We provide a benchmark of hardware and software approaches employed by participating teams, covering mechanical design, perception, planning, and control algorithms. Our survey reveals key trends, the dominance of Ackermann steering and differential drive systems, the widespread use of inertial navigation, and the growing adoption of ROS 2. Additionally, we examine team composition, highlighting the competition's relevance across high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels. The findings suggest that while simpler approaches remain competitive, advanced techniques such as sensor fusion and machine learning are gaining influence. We conclude with recommendations for future editions, emphasizing knowledge sharing, dynamic challenges, and ongoing benchmarking to reduce entry barriers and accelerate innovation in autonomous robotics.

title: Ai-Driven Workplace Transformation: Enhancing Performance and Job Satisfaction
authors: Jessica Lopez-Garcia, Esperanza Manrique Rojas, Duniesky Feito Madrigal
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: This study investigates the effects of Artificial Intelligence (AI) on workforce performance using OCDE data and multivariate regression analysis to explore how AI use, worker demographics, and training shape productivity. Descriptive and inferential statistics highlight AI's impact on job security and working conditions. The goal is to guide best practices for AI in the workplace, aligning performance enhancements with ethical considerations.

title: Equipment Health Status Assessment Based on Improved Evidence Theory
authors: Wenwu Zhou, Lei Lei, Wenjian Xiao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Equipment and Industrial Design (IEID)
abstract: To improve the accuracy and reliability of equipment health status assessment and address the failure issues of traditional evidence theory, this paper proposes an evaluation method based on improved evidence theory. Firstly, the basic principles of evidence theory were elucidated. Secondly, an improved method based on similarity coefficient is introduced to address the issue of evidence conflicts. By calculating the similarity between evidence bodies to measure their mutual support, the original basic probability allocation function is modified accordingly, effectively reducing the adverse impact of conflicting evidence on the synthesis results. Subsequently, the effectiveness of the proposed method was verified through simulation testing. Finally, by combining specific examples for application verification, the results show that the improved model can scientifically and accurately integrate multi-source uncertainty information, achieve reasonable evaluation of equipment health status, and is superior to traditional methods, providing reference for equipment health management.

title: Leveraging Generative AI Trained on Enterprise Data for Business Value in Large Enterprises
authors: Nikhil Vishnu Vadlamudi, Sriram Panyam, Praveen Gujar
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) is redefining how large enterprises harness data for strategic advantage. This paper explores the impact of GenAI models trained on proprietary enterprise data, detailing methodologies, applications, and challenges. We discuss how fine-tuned GenAI systems enhance decision support, knowledge management, automation, customer service, and forecasting in a corporate context. Key contributions include a framework for implementing GenAI with robust data governance and compliance, and real-world case studies demonstrating business value. Findings indicate that enterprise-trained GenAI can significantly improve productivity and decision-making quality while maintaining security and regulatory compliance. We also address risks such as data privacy, bias, and model drift, and propose best-practice guidelines for responsible adoption. By examining current literature and industry examples, this paper provides business leaders and practitioners with a strategic roadmap to unlock value from GenAI in large organizations. The insights highlight that, with careful implementation and ethical safeguards, GenAI trained on enterprise data can become a transformative catalyst for innovation and efficiency in large enterprises.

title: STEAM Research for Innovation and Competency Development: A Systematic Review
authors: Consuelo Cano-Gallardo, Carlos Guillermo Hernández-Cenzano
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics) education is increasingly recognized as a strategic approach to fostering innovation and competency development in higher education. This study presents a systematic literature review of STEAM research and its implications for promoting innovation through art-science collaboration. A total of 172 articles were initially identified through database searches, of which 34 met the inclusion criteria for final analysis. The review included publications from IEEE Xplore, SCOPUS, Web of Science, and Springer, covering the period from 2014 to 2024. The selected studies highlight diverse case studies and applied research initiatives involving interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary teams. Results reveal a global increase in STEAM-related academic output, although research remains limited in Latin America. This gap underscores the importance of promoting regional studies and institutional support in Latin America to strengthen STEAM research ecosystems. Key competencies linked to innovation identified in the reviewed studies include critical thinking, creativity, collaboration, and problem-solving. This review contributes to understanding the role of STEAM in advancing educational innovation and knowledge transfer through integrated, collaborative practices.

title: Going from the Past back to the Future: Incrementally Reconstructing a Metamodel History
authors: Marcel Homolka, Luciano Marchezan, Wesley K. G. Assunção, Alexander Egyed
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems (MODELS)
abstract: One of the most important artifacts of Model-Driven Engineering (MDE) are metamodels. Like other software artifacts, they are expected to evolve. Consequently, their models thus become invalid and need to be fixed. The usual strategy is to adapt those models based on changes made to the metamodel, i.e., co-evolution. Co-evolution, however, depends on correctly recorded changes since even small deviations can impact the models that will be evolved. One problem is that those changes are usually not preserved or complete. The reason is that the most common way to record the history of metamodels is by using text-based version control systems, i.e., Git. This, however, hinders the detection of the concrete changes made to the metamodel, which are used for co-evolution. This aspect leads to problems in maintaining and evolving metamodels and their models in practice. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that allows engineers to reconstruct the history of metamodels with the help of ChangeTrees. These ChangeTrees recommend possible sequences of changes between two metamodel versions, i.e., evolved metamodels. We conducted an empirical study that detected changes to eight different metamodels across varying domains. The results show that our approach can correctly reconstruct the metamodel's history by detecting all possible changes between the two versions. Furthermore, performance results show that, in the worst case, our approach required 15.65 seconds to detect and generate a ChangeTree of a metamodel with more than 351 changes applied to it (between two versions), leading to 11,268 branching change paths (alternative sequences of changes).

title: Reproducibility and Case Sensitivity of LLMs for Anonymizing Depressed Tweets
authors: Sameen Mansha, Hamza Mahmood, Anne Håkansson, Faisal Kamiran, Vladimir Vlassov
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: A careful analysis of the Large Language Model (LLM) results, generated through anonymized representations of the original dataset, is crucial to precisely evaluate the data-sharing procedure's limitations and facilitate valuable collaborations among Internet-based cognitive behavioral therapy (ICBT) companies and third parties. This paper presents an experimental study of fine-tuning 27 LMs for a multiclass classification task to identify depression severity using 40,191 tweets labeled by human annotators. We fine-tune 14 Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT), 6 Robustly Optimized BERT Pretraining Approaches (RoBerta), 3 Generative Pretraining (GPT), and 4 Text-to-Text Transfer Transformer (T5) based LMs to classify confidential and anonymized tweets. We report that T5, through conditional generation, outperforms widely adopted BERT, RoBerta, and GPT types for classifying confidential and anonymized tweets. Anonymizing personal information safeguards user privacy and often increases LM performance. Case sensitivity can potentially improve or harm the performance of domain-specific LMs for original and anonymized text.

title: Towards LLM-Guided Healthcare Dataset Harmonization
authors: Christos Smailis, Carlos Ordonez, Ioannis A. Kakadiaris
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Electronic health record (EHR) datasets come in various schemas and can contain a range of data types, measurement units, and variables that share duplicate semantic content. The process of bringing such datasets into a common schema with consistent values, so that it is possible to perform queries uniformly, is known as harmonization. However, performing this process manually can be both time-consuming and prone to errors. In this work, we present a web-based platform that semi-automates the harmonization and linking of EHR datasets through a human-in-the-loop framework, guiding users with the use of large language models (LLMs). Our solution is a two-stage harmonization pipeline that keeps schema metadata processing online while handling patient-level data locally, to align with HIPAA data privacy principles. In the first stage, users harmonize and link only non-identifiable schema information. In the second stage, sensitive value-level harmonization occurs entirely on the user's system, so no private and protected health information ever leaves their environment. Throughout both stages, we expect that LLM-powered suggestions could potentially speed up the harmonization and linking processes.

title: Feature-Reduced Machine Learning Models for Water Potability Prediction
authors: K. Roselin Mary Clare, S. Anitha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Water is crucial resource for life, and evaluating its quality is essential to ensure it is safe for consumption. Recently, water quality is declining due to human activities often referred to as the "universal solvent," water can dissolve more substances than any other liquid, making it highly susceptible to contamination. With advancements in machine learning (ML), A number of quality factors may be used to streamline process of predicting whether water is drinkable. Our study examines uses of several ML modules with hyper tune parameters, including Quadratic Discriminant Analysis, Random Forests, XGBoost, (QDA), a hybrid model that uses stacking with Random Forest as the base model, XGBoost as the meta-model, and a soft voting model that combines Random Forest and XGBoost. Work uses SMOTE (Synthetic Minority Over-Sampling Technique), which improves model training and accuracy in classification by creating synthetic samples for minority class, to tackle problem of class imbalance. Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) improves a model's efficiency and interpretability by maximizing class separation and reducing dimensionality. Feature ranking was done by analyzing LDA weights, and models were trained with varying numbers of top-ranked features to reduce training time. Results were compared to those from models using all features. This study utilized a dataset adapted from Kaggle to develop an efficient and accurate system for real-time water quality monitoring. Outcomes portray as machine learning (ML) models could efficiently forecast water potability, serving as an invaluable tool for resource management and ensuring public health in areas with limited access to conventional water testing infrastructure.

title: From Prediction to Action: Counterfactual Explanations and Ensemble Learning for Explainable Maternal Health Risk Modelling
authors: Merlin Monson, Sabarmathi G
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Maternal health is critical to women’s well-being, particularly during pregnancy, delivery, and postpartum. Early prediction and prevention of health risks are essential for reducing complications and improving outcomes. This research introduces a stacking ensemble model for maternal health risk prediction, combining the strengths of Random Forest, XGBoost, and Gradient Boosting with XGBoost as the meta-model. The ensemble approach enhances accuracy and reliability, achieving a classification accuracy of 91.13%, with precision, recall, and f1-scores exceeding 85% across all risk categories.Beyond accurate prediction, this study emphasizes model interpretability through Diverse Counterfactual Explanations (DiCE), an Explainable AI (XAI) method that provides actionable insights for risk reduction. Counterfactual analysis identifies the minimal changes needed in the patient features to shift a high- or medium-risk classification to low-risk, offering clinically relevant recommendations. These counterfactuals are generated to ensure feasibility, preserving physiological plausibility and practical applicability for healthcare professionals. This work bridges the gap between black-box machine learning models and actionable decision-making by integrating predictive power with explainability, supporting more transparent and patient-centric maternal health interventions.

title: Comparative Analysis of Neural Network Architectures for Telemetry-Driven Malware Behavior Classification
authors: Michael Schladt, John Gallagher
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Malware remains a persistent and evolving cyber-security threat. Conventional detection methodologies rooted in static binary analysis or dynamic tracing of API calls suffer from critical limitations. The former is readily circumvented through code obfuscation, while the latter demands substantial computational resources and is often infeasible at enterprise scale. This work investigates an alternative approach to malware classification that forgoes both direct binary analysis and fine-grained instrumentation, instead utilizing high-level system telemetry such as process, file, registry, and network events. Such telemetry is routinely generated by Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) systems and retained in centralized security logging platforms (e.g., SIEMs), rendering this method applicable to enterprise environments. Treating sequences of telemetry events as text-like data, we apply Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques to model behavioral patterns and evaluate four neural architectures: Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and a Transformer-based model on the task of malware family classification. Our results show that telemetry-only data enables accurate classification, with the Transformer model achieving peak performance ( 95–96% accuracy) and the remaining models following closely. This study contributes (1) empirical evidence that high-level behavioral telemetry is sufficient for malware classification on real-world samples, (2) a novel application of NLP-based sequence modeling to malware behavior data, and (3) a comparative analysis of modern neural architectures, highlighting trade-offs in accuracy, efficiency, and deployability. The findings underscore the potential of leveraging existing enterprise telemetry for scalable, real-time malware detection. Code for this project is available at: https://github.com/schladt/GIMC/.

title: Computer Vision based System for Speed Controlling of Vehicles using Signboard Detection
authors: Vartika Sharma, Ankith V, Bhuvan C P
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: This paper aims to develop an intelligent system for automatic traffic speed sign board detection using YOLO (You Only Look Once) object detection algorithm. The system captures real-time video feed from a webcam mounted on a laptop, detects the traffic speed signs, and the detected speed sign limits the model car. The model car, built using Arduino, an 8.4V Li-Ion battery, a 1000 RPM BO motor, and an L298N motor driver, automatically adjusts the speed based on the detected speed sign that has been displayed. The proposed work demonstrates the integration of image processing and embedded systems for real-time traffic sign recognition and speed controlling.

title: Analysis of silkworm gene expression data based on Various Machine-learning and Deep-learning Approaches for the Gender Identification
authors: Kumari K, J. Thomas
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: This study focuses on using deep learning and machine learning methods to classify the gender of silkworms (Bombyx mori) based on gene expression data. Accurate gender classification is crucial for improving silkworm breeding, enhancing silk production, and advancing genetic research. Traditional methods are often slow and error-prone, prompting the need for more efficient solutions. The research evaluated popular algorithms such as K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Random Forests (RF), Support Vector Machines (SVM), and deep learning techniques like Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs).Among these, SVM demonstrated the highest accuracy, outperforming other techniques by 85%. This highlights SVM's potential as a reliable tool for silkworm gender classification, contributing to advancements in the field.

title: An Event Study Framework for Analyzing Bidirectional Causality Between House Prices and Premium Café Entry
authors: Sachin Date
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: The relationship between cafes and house prices is an emerging field of study in urban data analytics. Recent research suggests that homes near cafes, especially premium cafes, start out dearer and appreciate faster than the broader U.S. housing market. However, significant endogeneity due to omitted variables and the possibility of bidirectional causality has made interpretation problematic. This uncertainty is compounded by limited methodical transparency, inadequate falsification criteria, and absence of rigorous analysis of bidirectional causation in the published work on this topic. Our study aims to fill these gaps. We present an analytical framework based on a Two-Way Fixed Effects (TWFE) event-study regression model (i.e., a generalized difference-in-differences design for staggered entry) combined with matching and covariate adjustment, to simultaneously study forward and reverse causality between house prices and premium café entry. Using Starbucks as a case study, we performed robust empirical analysis of the association between Starbucks' entry, and pre- and post-entry house price growth in over 500 U.S. neighborhoods across 45 states from 2012 to 2022. We controlled for nationwide price trends and shocks, neighborhood affluence, and short- and long-term price momentum. Our study included a placebo arm populated with “fake” Starbucks stores opened in random years to test whether pre- or post-entry price growth was driven solely by non-Starbucks related covariates. We found that while neighborhood characteristics and historical price momentum dominated, significant bidirectional effects consistent with causal influence between Starbucks' entry and house prices were also observed under stated assumptions. Placebo results falsified the hypothesis that the observed bidirectional effects were driven purely by non-Starbucks covariates. Our findings contribute real-world insights on urban amenity-price dynamics and offer a generalizable template for such empirical studies with strong policy and market relevance.

title: Real-Time EMG Classification for Bipedal Robot Control: A Hands-On Educational Platform
authors: Ana V. Cespedes, Diego A. Ramirez, Victoria E. Abarca, Dante A. Elias
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: A hands-on educational platform is presented for teaching biosignal processing, machine learning, and robotics through real-time control of a bipedal robot using electromyo-graphic (EMG) signals. Lower-limb EMG signals are captured using Delsys sensors and processed on a Raspberry Pi, where relevant features are extracted and classified using a K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithm. The recognized movements are then mapped to motor commands and transmitted to an Arduino-based controller that actuates the bipedal robot. The system is designed to create a demonstrative module for hands-on learning in biomedical engineering and robotics education. Experimental results demonstrate reliable physical execution of learned movements with the implemented algorithm. By integrating signal acquisition, real-time classification, and robotic control, this platform provides a practical and engaging approach for students to explore human-machine interfaces.

title: Case Study in Biomechanical Engineering: Finite Element Stress Analysis of a Femur with a Surface Hip Spherical-Joint Implant
authors: Diego A. Rozas Llontop, Ricardo Palomares, Jose Cornejo, Robert Castro, Josue Alata-Rey, Mariela Vargas
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Hip osteoarthritis, or coxarthrosis, is a degenerative disease that disrupts the balance between the formation and degradation of articular cartilage and subchondral bone, causing structural damage, progressive pain, and functional impairment. Its estimated prevalence is 12%, occurring at least twice as often in women as in men. Clinical and radiological evidence shows that approximately 6% of people over 30 years of age and 10% of those over 65 years of age present with symptoms of coxarthrosis. Total hip arthroplasty is the most effective treatment for improving the patient's quality of life, although it carries risks such as an increased likelihood of femoral neck fracture. This study proposes a Finite Element Method (FEM) analysis of a femur model corresponding to an individual under 65 years of age, weighing 90 kg and measuring 175 cm, presenting a normal coxa acetabular morphology with a surface prosthesis, in which its biomechanical performance is evaluated under four scenarios: a static condition (standing) and three dynamic conditions (vertical jump with single-leg landing). Anatomical and biomechanical data were collected, and SolidWorks software was used for modeling and stress analysis. The results showed maximum stresses in biomechanically coherent areas, all below the elastic limits of cortical bone and Ti-6Al-4V; This is consistent with other studies indicating that hip resurfacing arthroplasty is a viable and effective long-term solution for appropriately selected active male patients.

title: Hybrid Algorithm Based on Bidirectional A* and Floodfill Applied to Coverage Path Planning for AGVs
authors: Lucas L. M. Carvalho, Diogo G. Marques, Gabriel G.R. Castro, Thiago M. Tuxi, Milena F. Pinto
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid Coverage Path Plan-ning (CPP) strategy that integrates the Floodfill algorithm with bidirectional A * (BA *) to optimize navigation for Autonomous Ground Vehicles (AGVs) tasked with inspecting photovoltaic farms. The proposed approach leverages the global exploration capabilities of Floodfill with the heuristic efficiency of bidirectional A *, enabling fast and complete area coverage while min-imizing redundant traversal and computational overhead. The framework is validated in a Software-In-the-Loop (SITL) simulation using Gazebo and ROS, and its performance is benchmarked against conventional Floodfill, Floodfill with A *, and Wavefront-based methods. Results demonstrate significant improvements in coverage efficiency, path smoothness, and execution time, highlighting the method's potential for real-world large-scale CPP applications. The proposed method achieved overlap and direction change rates below 1 %, significantly improving path efficiency.

title: The Role of Social Interactions in the Interaction Discovery of Keyboard Shortcuts
authors: Gilles Bailly, Ignacio Avellino, Emeline Brulé, Sylvain Malacria
publish: Proceedings of the 36th Conference on l'Interaction Humain-Machine
abstract: We investigate how the keyboard shortcuts method is discovered, a prerequisite for adopting their use. We designed and distributed a large-scale retrospective survey (N=853) focused on capturing narratives of first-time use of keyboard shortcuts. We find that (1) respondents largely report a social interaction as the event leading to the discovery, with only few reporting the use of computer aids such as tooltips; (2) most respondents discover keyboard shortcuts in elementary or middle school (6–14 years old), although this depends on the local educational policy; (3) the discovery generally occurs with a teacher, a classmate or family member while doing schoolwork; and, (4) respondents often report a strong emotional reaction to this discovery.

title: A Multidimensional Framework to Analyse the Role of Sounds in three Temporalities of Gameplay Loops
authors: Stéphanie Mader, Guillaume Tiger, Cécile Le Prado, Isabelle Ballet
publish: Proceedings of the 36th Conference on l'Interaction Humain-Machine
abstract: Sound plays a fundamental role in gameplay: it informs, illustrates, feedbacks, and gives substance to the virtual world. These functions operate across different temporalities of gameplay, which take the form of nested loops that structure the player’s experience. While existing analytical frameworks help organize the soundscape effectively, they do not explicitly address the temporal dimensions of gameplay loops. Our objective is to advance the understanding of sound’s role in gameplay and to better describe its complexity, in order to provide new tools for collaboration between game designers and sound designers. We propose a theoretical framework for a new four-dimensional analysis grid that considers gameplay, signs and feedback, perception, and technical aspects. We apply this framework to the video game Fortnite (Epic Games) to demonstrate the relevance and potential of our approach.

title: C2-LSM: A Storm -NoC Based Neuromorphic Processor for High-Accuracy Liquid State Machine with Cube-Cluster Topology
authors: Enyi Yao, Zhibin Luo, Zongfan Wu, Dong Jiang, Xin Wu, Yongkui Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Circuits and Systems
abstract: The liquid state machine (LSM), a reservoir computing variant of spiking neural networks (SNNs), has been widely adopted for its low training complexity. In this work, we propose C2-LSM, a neuromorphic processor designed through algorithm–hardware co-design to achieve high accuracy across diverse tasks. At the algorithm level, inspired by the “small-world” structure of the biological brain, we introduce a novel reservoir layer in which neurons are interconnected using a cubecluster topology. For hardware implementation, the customized C2-LSM processor supports runtime configurability of reservoir size and connection sparsity, enabling high classification accuracy across a range of spatiotemporal tasks. Additionally, a Network-on-Chip (NoC) with a Storm routing algorithm is developed to improve the spike event transmission throughput among reservoir neurons. C2-LSM is implemented on an AMD Virtex UltraScale+ VCU129 FPGA running at 250 MHz. With on-chip learning, it achieves accuracies of 98.02%, 94.26%, and 93.00% on MNIST, N-MNIST, and FSDD datasets, respectively, outperforming recently benchmarked LSM neuromorphic processors across all three tasks. For the MNIST task, it achieves an inference speed of 1155 FPS and a learning speed of 1154 FPS, along with a high power efficiency of 103 GSOPS/W.

title: A Tissue-Coupling Body Channel Powering Technique for the Internet of Implanted Things
authors: Cheng Han, Chuer Lin, Shan Yu, Zhiwei Zhang, Jingna Mao
abstract: Body channel powering (BCP) has emerged as a promising method for wirelessly powering the Internet of Implanted Things (IoIT). However, current galvanic-coupling (GC-BCP) and capacitive-coupling (CC-BCP) techniques are limited by short transmission distance and restricted applicability to fully implantable devices, respectively. To address these issues, this paper proposes a tissue-coupling BCP (TC-BCP) technique that employs a floated transmitter (TX) ground electrode to enhance coupling with remote implant-site tissue, thereby enabling more power delivery to the fully implanted receiver (RX). A lumped circuit model is first developed to theoretically analyze three fundamental transmission properties. Experimental validation using a prototype system demonstrates that TC-BCP outperforms conventional BCP in long-range power transfer achieving 8.63 dB higher path gain at a lateral distance of 24 cm, and expands single RX to at least three simultaneous RX nodes with minimal interference. Moreover, the optimization of stacked-up TX electrode configuration, considering three key geometric parameters, yields a path gain enhancement of up to 7.58 dB. These investigations confirm that the proposed TC-BCP can effectively extend the transmission range while supporting multi-node and integrated-TX powering of fully implantable IoIT.

title: Many-Objective Optimized Current Reference Generation Strategy for Inverter-Based Distributed Generators during Unbalanced Voltage Sags
authors: Fankai Wen, Pablo Acuna, Zhige Yuan, Chenggang Cui, Ricardo P. Aguilera, Amer M. Y. M. Ghias
abstract: Traditional Current Reference Generators (CRGs) used in low-voltage ride-through (LVRT) control schemes often optimize a single objective, such as minimizing power oscillations, at the expense of other performance metrics such as total harmonic distortion ($\mathit {THD}$). This paper proposes a many-objective optimized current reference generation strategy (MaO-OCRGS) that yields a set of trade-off solutions, each defined by proposing two decision variables and their associated power quality performance metrics, i.e., power oscillations ($\Delta p$, $\Delta q$), $\mathit {THD}$, and the unbalance index ($\mathit {UI}$). A hybrid physics-based and data-driven (HPD) approach is proposed to construct the performance objective functions of a many-objective optimization (MaOO) problem, where the power oscillations are theoretically derived, and an artificial neural network (ANN) is proposed to model the relationships between the decision variables and current-related metrics ($\mathit {THD}$ and $\mathit {UI}$). A non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm III (NSGA-III) is employed to solve the MaOO problem, yielding a set of optimal decision variables. A subsequent post-optimization selection then identifies feasible solutions that prioritize one performance metric while keeping the others within acceptable limits, thereby avoiding undesirable trade-offs and resulting in three optimized CRGs. Experimental validation demonstrates that the optimized CRGs achieved through the proposed MaO-OCRGS effectively enhance one performance objective without unacceptable degradation in others, as the other metrics are maintained within their predefined limits, thus offering flexibility while enhancing the overall LVRT performance under unbalanced voltage conditions.

title: Real-World Robot Control by Deep Active Inference With a Temporally Hierarchical World Model
authors: Kentaro Fujii, Shingo Murata
abstract: Robots in uncertain realworld environments must perform both goaldirected and exploratory actions. However, most deep learning-based control methods neglect exploration and struggle under uncertainty. To address this, we adopt deep active inference, a framework that accounts for human goal-directed and exploratory actions. Yet, conventional deep active inference approaches face challenges due to limited environmental representation capacity and high computational cost in action selection. We propose a novel deep active inference framework that consists of a world model, an action model, and an abstract world model. The world model encodes environmental dynamics into hidden state representations at slow and fast timescales. The action model compresses action sequences into abstract actions using vector quantization, and the abstract world model predicts future slow states conditioned on the abstract action, enabling low-cost action selection. We evaluate the framework on object-manipulation tasks with a real-world robot. Results show that it achieves high success rates across diverse manipulation tasks and switches between goal-directed and exploratory actions in uncertain settings, while making action selection computationally tractable. These findings highlight the importance of modeling multiple timescale dynamics and abstracting actions and state transitions.

title: Ultrasonic Transit Time Measurement Based on Frequency Doubling Technique
authors: Yining Gao, Hongliang Zhou
abstract: Accurate transit-time measurement is critical for transit-time ultrasonic gas flowmeters. Traditional transit-time measurement methods, such as cross-correlation and threshold detection, are widely employed. Among these, the threshold method exhibits advantages in simplicity and real-time performance. However, under the impact of circuit or pipeline noise, echo signals often undergo distortion, significantly degrading the accuracy of transit-time measurements. To address this challenge, this study proposes a novel frequency-doubling measurement technique based on the principles of threshold detection, aiming to shorten the time interval during which the comparator output is affected by random noise and improve the precision and consistency of transit-time measurements. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared with conventional methods, the proposed approach reduces the mean standard deviation of transit-time measurements by 28.73% under actual operating conditions. The final relative error of flow measurement is constrained within ±2%, with its repeatability better than ±0.2%, and its overall performance is superior to that of traditional methods. This research offers a new direction for optimizing measurement techniques in ultrasonic gas flowmeters, boasting significant theoretical value, substantial engineering application potential, and low cost.

title: High-speed Channel Modeling using Transformer Network
authors: Hyunwook Park, Davit Kharshiladze, Natalia Bondarenko, Hanqin Ye, Brice Achkir, Chulsoon Hwang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal and Power Integrity
abstract: This article proposes a high-speed channel transformer (HSCT) network module to model the S-parameter of traces. To deal with length variation, RLGC matrices are modeled using transformer networks and converted by an RLGC-to-S layer. For validation, the accuracy of predicted RLGC and S-parameters is compared with conventional simulators. As a result, error rates of estimated magnitude and phase achieve 0.76% and 3.62%, respectively. The pre-trained HSCT module is verified to be scalable in terms of the number of frequency points, without redefining weights and additional training. In addition, a precise analysis of the RLGC data distributions depending on preprocessing techniques is performed, hence, to ensure the reproducibility of the proposed method.

title: A Multistage GaAs HBT Sequential LMBA With Tailored Adaptive Biasing and Gain Coordination for Linearity Enhancement
authors: Jianqiang Chen, Jingzhou Pang, Qian Wu, Haoyang Jia, Ruibin Gao, Shuang Liu, Gary Zhang, Anding Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article proposes a novel linearity enhancement approach for sequential load-modulated balanced amplifiers (SLMBAs). The establishment of an analytical model for the SLMBA’s nonlinear behavior forms the basis for the design, which enables precise coordination of multisection gain profiles. Simultaneously, an SLMBA architecture featuring tailored adaptive biasing of driver amplifiers (DAs) is proposed to enhance linearity by dynamically enlarging the current conduction angle (CCA), strategically configuring DAs expansion to compensate for carrier power amplifier (PA) compression and peaking PA expansion deficits, effectively achieving minimal gain deviation characteristics over the entire power range. For validation, an SLMBA operating at 2.5–2.7 GHz was implemented in a gallium arsenide heterojunction bipolar transistor (GaAs HBT) process. Measurements under continuous-wave (CW) excitation demonstrate a saturated output power of 36.3–37.0 dBm with 38.9%–39.2% power-added efficiency (PAE) and PAE of 29.0%–30.7% at 7-dB output back-off. Significantly, measurements confirm ±1-dB gain variation at 2.6 GHz. When driven by a 60-MHz 256-quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM) signal with a 10.6-dB peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR), the SLMBA achieves an adjacent channel power ratio (ACPR) better than −38.58 dBc and an error-vector magnitude (EVM) of 1.58% without digital predistortion (DPD).

title: Shifting Expectations for Encoding Rules Mitigates Misinterpretation of Connected Scatterplots
authors: Wen Xu, Lace Padilla
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Abstract-Connected scatterplots visualize time-series data by connecting the points on a scatterplot based on temporal sequence. Viewers are prone to misinterpret the direction of time in these visualizations, possibly because they encode time with an unexpected rule - along the connected line (TIME IS A LINE) instead of from left to right (RIGHT IS LATER) as conventional in line charts. In this paper, we use the connected scatterplot to illustrate a perspective on visualization comprehension centered around expectations of encoding rules. People have initial expectations of encoding rules for visualizations that can stem from conventional practices or metaphors, and these expectations have been recognized as a potential factor influencing visualization comprehension. We present three preregistered experiments (n = 1429 in total) demonstrating two kinds of design interventions to strengthen the correct expectation for time and testing their effectiveness in reducing errors for understanding realistic connected scatterplots. We found that visual treatments that suppress the incorrect chart-type expectation and directional cues that emphasize the correct expectation both led viewers to expect TIME IS A LINE more. An explicit directional cue (arrows), ideally redundantly encoded with another cue (trace-line effect or animation), was most effective for reducing misinterpretations. Our findings not only provide practical guidelines for designing connected scatterplots but also contribute theoretical insights to inform the design of novel visualizations that challenge interpretability by defying expectations.

title: Efficient Slice-Patch Selection Transformer for Interpretable Alzheimer's Disease Diagnosis Using Structural MRI
authors: Gongpeng Cao, Manli Zhang, Yiping Wang, Yuting Zhang, Jinjie Guo, Jinguo Huang, Guixia Kang
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Structural magnetic resonance imaging (sMRI) plays a crucial role in the early screening of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Recent advances in vision Transformers (ViTs) demonstrate strong potential for sMRI-based computer-aided diagnosis by capturing long-range dependencies. However, their high computational demands and opaque decision-making hinder clinical application. To address these challenges, we explore the inherent structural redundancy in brain sMRI and propose an efficient and interpretable slice-patch selection Transformer (SPSFormer) framework that selectively focuses on task-relevant sMRI slices and patches, significantly reducing the computational overhead of existing ViTs. Specifically, SPSFormer employs lightweight learnable scorers placed before and within the ViT recognizer to estimate the importance of slice and patch candidates. Subsequently, a perturbed-maximum based differentiable Top-k operator is constructed to select the top-scoring elements for end-to-end training. We conduct rigorous cross-dataset validation (NACC, ADNI, AIBL) to evaluate generalizability. Across DeiT and Swin recognizers, SPSFormer reduces required GFLOPs by approximately <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2-4\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> while maintaining diagnostic accuracy. Analysis of learned selection policies highlights key regions (e.g., hippocampus, parahippocampal gyrus, amygdala, thalamus) consistent with established AD neuropathology, supporting interpretability. The model's predicted AD probability shows significant associations with cognitive and biomarker measures, confirming neurobiological validity, and offers prognostic value: higher predicted AD probability is associated with shorter time to conversion from mild cognitive impairment to AD. These findings suggest that coupling high computational efficiency with intrinsic explainability offers a promising direction to clinically deployable, trustworthy artificial intelligence for AD detection.

title: Wideband Patch Antenna Using Higher-Order Modes for SAR Touch Compliant Indoor MIMO Base Stations
authors: Wenfu Fu, Stanislav Stefanov Zhekov, Bo Xu, Carla Di Paola, Sailing He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A multi-mode wideband patch antenna is proposed for indoor base stations, with the antenna achieving a wide impedance bandwidth and the equipment realizing specific absorption rate (SAR) touch compliance with 0.375 W time-averaged accepted power from 3.4 to 3.8 GHz. For comparison, a narrow-band canonical fundamental-mode patch antenna allows only 0.11 W under the same conditions for touch compliance. The wide bandwidth of the proposed antenna is achieved by combining three even modes excited at close frequencies. The use of even modes results in split SAR maxima and thus lower SAR levels compared to odd modes to achieve touch compliance. To further prove the applicability of the antenna, its performance is evaluated using power-dependent multiplexing efficiency based on indoor channel models. The proposed design demonstrates superior performance, e.g., 4.9–6.0 times higher median levels of the power-dependent multiplexing efficiency in various scenarios, over the canonical patch antenna.

title: Fault-Tolerant Wireless Power Transfer System With S/S and LCC/S-Based Input-Series Output-Parallel Hybrid Topology
authors: Zihan Tian, Shihao Cheng, Dengrui Liu, Rong Fan, Shuren Liu, Chenbo Wang, Fuyao Yang, Yang Zhan, Guorui Xu, Haisen Zhao
abstract: Typical faults such as open circuit (OC), short circuit, and abnormal coupling seriously threaten the safety of conventional wireless power transfer (WPT) systems, so fault tolerance is a critical design consideration for WPT systems, especially in high-power applications. This study proposes an S/S and LCC/S-based input-series output-parallel hybrid topology, with which WPT systems can tolerate typical faults and realize zero phase angle under normal operation. Considering common misalignment conditions, a receiver-side control strategy without dual-side communication is also designed for minimum fault current ratios and power sharing between the two subtopologies under normal operation, and a system design method for constant power output is then given. A WPT prototype with the proposed hybrid topology is developed, and the experimental validation is performed. The results show that the steady-state fault current is about two times the normal value under various faults, and the system can even operate with an abnormal close coupling or OC fault at the transmitting coil branch in the LCC/S subtopology.

title: Polarization-Aware CrossGate U-Net for Sea Ice Classification
authors: Nima Ahmadian, Matthew Hamilton, Weimin Huang
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Sea ice monitoring is crucial for climate studies, navigation safety, and sustainable management of Arctic regions. The introduction of the AI4Arctic Sea Ice Challenge dataset, which provides standardized multisource remote sensing data, has significantly facilitated the advancement of automated sea ice mapping techniques. This study introduces the Polarization-Aware CrossGate U-Net (PA-CG-U-Net) model with cross attention designed specifically for sea ice classification using this dataset. The proposed architecture integrates dual-polarization SAR images (HH and HV) and coarse-resolution microwave radiometric data (AMSR2) through separate encoders and cross-attention gates to capture polarization-specific features. The PA-CG-U-Net model reduced classification errors compared to the U-Net model and improved the segmentation accuracy for sea ice concentration (SIC), stage of development (SOD), and floe size (FLOE). Quantitative evaluations demonstrated consistent performance gains, with improved robustness indicated by lower variance across multiple training runs. Visual analyses further confirmed that PA-CG-U-Net produced less noisy classifications, which highlights the effectiveness of polarization-specific encoding and attention mechanisms.

title: A Deep Learning Approach for Classification of Dog Skin Diseases
authors: Priti Pal, Munish Saini
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Skin disease in dogs is among the most common health problems affecting pet animals, often leading to discomfort and severe infections if not diagnosed early. Conventional veterinary diagnosis by visual inspection is susceptible to human error and might be subjective. In the proposed study, the Deep Learning-based methods employing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Transfer Learning are used to classify skin conditions in dogs as either Healthy or Infected. The dog skin disease image-based datasets are categorized into four types: Fungal Infections, Bacterial Dermatosis, Hypersensitivity (allergic dermatosis), and Healthy Skin. Using Transfer Learning approaches, pre-trained deep learning models such as MobileNetV2, EfficientB0, EfficientB3, DenseNet121, and VGG19 were optimized to enhance model performance. With the highest validation accuracy of 76.40%, DenseNet121 was achieved as compared to other state-of-the-art methods. Moreover, this study will help veterinarians by providing an automated system for early disease detection. It can be further integrated into real-time mobile or web-based applications to support practical veterinary diagnosis.

title: Design of an MPPT Algorithm Based on Neural Networks and Fuzzy Logic for Different Photovoltaic Panel Technologies
authors: Wilson Rivera Ccoñas, Diana Fernandez Baca, Carlos Alberto Paragua-Macuri
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: The growing demand for electrical energy driven by global consumption, such as China's 600 TWh in 2023 has reinforced the importance of clean and sustainable sources. The performance of photovoltaic (PV) systems is significantly influenced by panel manufacturing technologies and external environmental conditions, including dust, water droplets, animal waste, and especially partial shading, which can reduce power output. This paper proposes a Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) algorithm based on Fuzzy Logic Control (FLC) and Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), aimed at enhancing the energy extraction efficiency from PV systems under variable and non-stable environmental conditions. A DC-DC boost converter is used to regulate the energy transfer between the PV panel and the load, with its duty cycle dynamically adjusted by the proposed algorithms. The hybrid FL&ANN model is trained using real-world data from different photovoltaic technologies, including HIT, Amorphous Silicon (a-Si), Tandem (a-Si/µc-Si), and Copper Indium Gallium Selenide (CIGS). Simulations are carried out in MATLAB/Simulink under varying irradiance and temperature scenarios. The results demonstrate that the hybrid FL&ANN controller outperforms original FLC in terms of response time and tracking accuracy. Additionally, this approach proves highly effective in electro mobility applications, where PV panels are continuously exposed to dynamic environmental conditions such as partial shading during vehicle movement. The proposed method offers a viable and efficient solution to optimize solar energy usage in modern, mobility-focused energy systems.

title: AI and ML in Sports: Enhancing Performance, Strategy, and Fan Engagement
authors: Gopal K Shyam, Anni Arnav, Priyanka Bharti, Sheelavathy K V, Reddy SaisindhuTheja, Krishnamoorthi S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: In professional sports, there is potential to leverage extensive and detailed datasets generated from various aspects of the sports industry. However, challenges arise from the limited time available for data analysis and the vast amount and diversity of the data to be evaluated. Artificial Intelligence (AI) techniques can significantly aid decision-makers in addressing these challenges. Over the past twenty years, AI has significantly impacted how we analyze and engage with sports. This perspective paper offers solutions to improve sports performance and business analytics. In every metric, the suggested approach performs better than CNN, BDLSTM, and NLP, obtaining the best F1- Score (98.16%), the lowest error (0.94%), and the highest accuracy (98.26%). It is the most efficient answer for the task at hand because of its well-balanced performance, which includes outstanding precision and recall.
