authors: Akey Sungheetha, Rajesh Sharma R, Sheila Mahapatra, John Blake, Oluwasegun Julius Aroba, GS Pradeep Ghantasala
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: This paper presents SUAM-KD, an innovative Smart Underwater Acoustic Monitoring system that leverages ensemble knowledge distillation and dual-attention feature fusion for enhanced marine ecosystem monitoring. Our framework addresses the challenges of underwater data collection and processing through a novel multi-teacher knowledge distillation approach combined with a feature fusion and dual attention mechanism. The system achieves 96.2% accuracy in species identification while reducing model complexity by 73% through our proposed knowledge distillation framework. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements: 42% better detection accuracy in turbid waters, 68% reduced latency in real-time processing, and 51% lower power consumption compared to existing solutions.

title: Hybrid Bayesian Optimization and Neural Network for Enhancing Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Margarat Michael, M.Jayasudha, S.Gopiga
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) are extremely important for communication and monitoring systems but are usually plagued by ineffective routing methods and limited energy resources. Traditional methods such as full opportunistic routing (OR) and LEACH may result in packet loss, delay in networks, and more energy consumption. A novel data-driven routing paradigm is proposed in this paper that combines predictive next-hop routing with a Bayesian Neural Network (BNN) and optimal Cluster Head (CH) selection via Bayesian Optimization (BO). For improving the realism and the reliability of models, a real-world WSN dataset is used. While BNN enables smart routing decisions by learning from historical transmission patterns, BO selects CHs dynamically according to node-specific conditions such as energy and base station distance. Furthermore, partial opportunistic routing is employed to reduce broadcast overhead and improve routing efficiency. MATLAB is used to simulate and implement the system, and results indicate that it is more power and communication efficient than current routing protocols.

title: Blockchain - Powered Smart Contracts for Automated Tax Compliance
authors: Otaxon Khayitboyev Shokirovich, Gulora Yuldasheva, Roxatoy Allayarova, R. Jayasudha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The fast digitalisation of commercial plans brings benefits and troubles to tax presidency, particularly when it comes to guaranteeing that taxes command a price of correctly and on time. This study proposes a new foundation utilizing blockchain electronics and smart contracts to simplify processes for tax agreement. Real-occasion tax calculation is approved by smart contracts in a permission-located blockchain design; auditability is determined by zero-information proofs (ZKPs) accompanying homomorphic encryption; solitude for secure data conversion is maintained. A numerical construction was grown to systematise tax forethoughts using variables like costs, revenue and supervisory necessities. Smart contracts' automatic deductions for taxes were encrypted into their sense for agreement accompanying regulations. Using a fake dataset of 10,000 economic undertakings, investigators conducted an exploratory imitation on a blockchain network established Hyperledger Fabric. Tax computations were proved to be exact to the insignificant value; human engrossment was diminished by 91.3%; and compliance accompanying organizing checks were seamlessly contained, producing nothing wrong a still picture taken with a camera. Average abeyance of 1.6 seconds and 280 TPS throughput verified the scalability of the design. ZKPs and encryption observed dossier secure from unlawful approach. This paper illustrates by what method smart contracts compelled by blockchain might improve tax structure adeptness, transparence and security. The projected model is having to do with various legal atmospheres and commercial environments, in addition to scalable for up-to-date tax presidency.

title: Ergonomic Assessment of Upper Limb Movements in Rose Cultivation Using a Custom Data Acquisition System
authors: Paula Andrade, Mónica Huerta, David Rivas, Juan Inga-Ortega, Esteban Ordoñez, Roger Clotet
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The floriculture sector in Ecuador has grown rapidly in recent decades, becoming one of the country's most important economic sectors. This sector generates a high demand for labor, especially in activities that require repetitive movements, physical effort and prolonged postures, such as harvesting and packing roses. These activities have been associated with an increase in musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs), particularly in the upper extremities. These health problems not only impact workers' quality of life, but also reduce productivity and increase costs associated with absenteeism and medical treatment. Despite the importance of mitigating these risks, real-time ergonomic assessment remains a challenge due to the lack of accessible, accurate and easy-to-implement technologies in the workplace. That is why we implemented technological solutions with smart devices, such as Kinect V2, which helped us to monitor and analyze workers' movements in real time. These tools provided accurate and objective data that supported the identification and prevention of ergonomic risks. The data acquisition system focused on the ergonomic assessment of the upper limbs at relevant points: wrists, shoulder and elbow, during rose harvesting and packing activities. This system used advanced technologies to collect and analyze data automatically, allowing to identify risks and propose corrective measures to optimize working conditions in the floriculture sector.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Digital Identity Management for Enhanced Safety Systems
authors: Sandeep Shenoy Karanchery Sundaresan, Lakiya Ulaganathan, Srinath Muralinathan, Ruchi Mangharamani, Anzar Ahmad, Roosha Shamoon
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Digital identity systems have become essential for trustworthy operational in banking, healthcare and Internet of Things (IoT). Conventional identity systems often illustrate centralised governance, susceptibility to breaches and inadequate user engagement. This study investigates the incorporation of the blockchain system into digital identity network to discuss these constraints. The blockchain employs decentralised designs, cryptographic techniques and intelligent contract automation to ensure privacy protection, user-centric identity verification and detect unauthorised access. Incorporating W3C-compliant Decentralised Identifiers (DIDs) with Verifiable Credentials (VCs) the proposed work simulates and evaluates performance supporting real-world datasets utilising platforms like Hyperledger Indy as well as Ethereum. The results reveal improved flexibility against online assaults and inculcate attacks as well as increased scalability along with reduced costs for authentication of identity. Practical depictions of real-world applications are given by the government's endorsement of decentralised ID systems and investigation with Aadhaar-enabled blockchain in India. Blockchain can uplift digital identity management, despite its limitations of legal compliance and seamless integration.

title: Dependable Code Repair with LLMs: AI-Driven Vulnerability Detection and Automated Patching
authors: Sungmin Han, Hyoungshick Kim, Hojoon Lee, Hyungon Moon, Yuseok Jeon, Ho Bae, Donghyun Yeo, Gail-Joon Ahn, Sangkyun Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE 30th Pacific Rim International Symposium on Dependable Computing (PRDC)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of software vulnerabilities has created an urgent need for intelligent, automated methods to detect and mitigate security flaws at scale. Traditional vulnerability analysis depends heavily on manual inspection and domain-specific expertise, which are increasingly inadequate in the era of generative AI-driven code development. This research proposes an AI-based automated vulnerability detection and secure code generation framework that leverages multi-modal datasets, including source code and binaries, to achieve end-to- end automation across the vulnerability lifecycle: detection, patch generation, and validation. The system integrates explainable AI (XAI)-based vulnerability cause analysis, generative patch synthesis, system-level defensive code generation, Rust-based memory safety transformation, and differential privacy mechanisms for model confidentiality. Developed through a Korea- U.S. joint research initiative, this project aims to establish an internationally deployable platform for trustworthy and privacy- preserving AI -driven software security. The proposed research contributes both foundational methods and operational tools toward self-healing, explainable, and secure-by-design software ecosystems.

title: A hybrid accident prevention framework towards Driver Fatigue and Distraction Detection using YoloV10 architecture
authors: N Karthigavani, S. Christober, S. Dhanesh, P.S.R. Dhanush
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Driver fatigue and distraction represent major causes of road accidents worldwide, and several sensor-based approaches have been proposed to mitigate these risks. However, despite their advantages, existing methods often struggle to accurately detect and generalize the diverse manifestations of fatigue and distraction in real time. To address these challenges, this article introduces a novel hybrid accident prevention framework for Driver Fatigue and Distraction Detection using the YOLOv10 architecture. The proposed model leverages the backbone, neck, and head components of YOLOv10 to process real-time video streams efficiently. Specifically, the backbone employs a convolutional neural network to extract critical facial features and driver gestures, including hand movements and potentially distracting behaviors such as neck orientation. These features are aggregated in the neck component and subsequently analyzed in the head component for object recognition, bounding box generation, and classification through object scores. The framework demonstrates high efficiency in real-time facial behavior analysis and driver monitoring. Experimental evaluation conducted in a Python environment using benchmark datasets confirms that the proposed model achieves superior detection accuracy compared to conventional methods, attaining 98.2% accuracy. Furthermore, the system exhibits reduced latency, ensuring timely detection and response to potential threats. Overall, the proposed YOLOv10-based framework offers a sophisticated, real-time driver assistance system, enhancing road safety by accurately identifying fatigue and distraction while minimizing delays in threat mitigation.

title: Li-Fi in Industrial Environments: Performance Analysis Compared to Wi-Fi and Ethernet
authors: Oscar Andrés Tobar-Rosero, Johan Steven Castro-Fernandez, Octavio David Diaz Mendoza, John E. Candelo-Becerra, Oscar Arias Salamanca, Héctor Andrés Flórez Celis, G. Zapata Madrigal
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The visible light wireless communication technology, known as Li-Fi, is emerging as one of the most promising communication technologies. This technology can transmit data over an often-unused portion of the electromagnetic spectrum. Although some studies have highlighted the complementary value of Li-Fi to current wireless technologies, performance testing and compatibility evaluation with industrial protocols are still needed. This study evaluates the performance of commercial Li-Fi devices, comparing them with current technologies such as Gigabit-Ethernet and Wi-Fi 5G. Tests have been designed and implemented to assess the constant connectivity, bandwidth, latency, and transmission and reception speeds using network protocols such as the Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) and User Datagram Protocol (UDP), and compatibility with industrial protocols such as Generic Object Oriented Substation Event (GOOSE). The study found that Li-Fi and Wi-Fi have speed and transfer time limitations compared to Ethernet. Additionally, one of the Li-Fi technologies studied outperforms Wi-Fi technology in transmission speed and stability, but presents challenges related to signal availability and limited compatibility with industrial protocols, including long transfer and reconnection times. Although Li-Fi can complement existing wireless technologies, significant challenges must be solved before adopting industrial automation systems.

title: Proposals for Performance-Based Hybrid Renewable Energy Systems for Sustainable Rural Electrification
authors: Pablo Parra Rosero, Julio Barzola-Monteses, Juan Lata-García, Francisco Jurado, Lizbeth Flores-Bastidas, Segundo F. Vilema-Escudero
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The development of an isolated community is linked to access to essential services, including electricity. Nowadays, the use of hybrid systems of renewable energies is a feasible solution to the energy problem, an isolated community in the Gulf of Guayaquil that is made up of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2}$</tex> houses is taken as a case study, currently, they have solar panels; however, the energy generated by these equipment is limited for the consumption habits of the inhabitants of the region. The meteorological variables of the place were analyzed to present different configurations between solar panels, wind turbines, diesel generators, and a battery bank. The optimal system consists of an 8 kW photovoltaic generator, a 2.9 kW diesel generator, and a battery bank comprising five units of 95 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{A h} / 12 \mathrm{V}$</tex>. The comparative analysis between the initial configuration made up of GF/GW/GD/BB and the optimal GF/GD/BB results in a difference of $ 23729 in favor of the second proposal, the simulations were carried out in the HOMER software, the total cost of the 25 years of the project is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40,266.95$</tex> dollars, the operating cost is $ 2,483.94, and the cost of energy is $0.47 per kWh, the unsatisfied load is 0 %, with a renewable production of 78.5 %. The proposal offers high reliability of the service and is adapted to the needs of users in isolated communities.

title: Design of the Compliant Mechanism of an Assistive Device for the Knee
authors: Kevin Giraldo, Juan A. Gallego, Uriel Zapata, Fanny L. Casado
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Compliant mechanisms are designed to deform in a controlled manner in response to external forces, using the flexibility of their components to store potential elastic energy during deformation, gradually releasing it upon returning to their original form. This article examines a knee orthosis designed to assist users during the stand-up motion, utilizing a compliant mechanism to balance the user's weight and minimize strain on leg muscles during this motion. The design process for the semi-rigid knee orthosis involved selecting materials and developing a numerical model for the compliant mechanism, which is represented as a spring. Geometric properties are obtained through the numerical modeling of the spring once the desired stiffness and safety factor values have been reached. Subsequently, a 3D finite element analysis was conducted. The study reveals a strong correlation between the maximum stress in the mathematical model (250.22 MPa) and the simulation (239.8 MPa), with an error of 4.16%. Both analyses of safety factors yielded results of 1.02 for the mathematical approach and 1.1 for the simulation, with a consistent margin of error of 7.84%. The spring's stiffness exhibits a 5.62% difference when analytically calculated at 90.82 Nm/rad and 85.71 Nm/rad in the simulation. These results suggest significant potential for the proposed device in helping patients with knee orthopedic restrictions, contributing to ongoing efforts in advancing the understanding and treatment of knee osteoarthritis.

title: Building Generalizable Models for Student Retention: A Multi-Source Validation Framework for the Peruvian Higher Education Context
authors: Giovanny Angelo Egoavil Cardenas, Ivonne Yamille Ruiz Pachamango, Adolfo Jorge Prado Ventocilla, Edwin Jorge Montes Eskenazy
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Addressing student attrition in higher education requires predictive models that are not only accurate but also generalizable across diverse institutional contexts. This study confronts the crisis of external validity in educational data mining by developing and rigorously validating a machine learning framework for predicting undergraduate dropout. Using a public dataset of 4,424 students from a Portuguese university as our primary source, we employ Random Forest and Support Vector Classifier (SVC) models, optimized with Recursive Feature Elimination with Cross-Validation (RFECV), to identify the most salient predictors of dropout. Our analysis identifies a parsimonious set of nine key features, with “curricular units passed in the first semester” and “tuition fee status” emerging as the most powerful predictors. The resulting Random Forest model achieved an accuracy of 0.88 and an AUC of 0.86 on the primary dataset. The core contribution of this research lies in its multi-source validation strategy. We tested the trained model's predictive power on an external dataset from Tecnologico de' Monterrey, Mexico, where it maintained a high accuracy of 0.88, demonstrating exceptional generalizability. Furthermore, we corroborated the identified risk factors against national-level statistics from Peru's Superintendencia Nacional de Educación Superior Universitaria (SUNEDU), confirming their contextual relevance. This research provides a robust, validated model for student retention and, more importantly, offers a methodological blueprint for developing and validating generalizable predictive tools to support evidence-based interventions in higher education systems globally.

title: Artificial Intelligence Systems for the Management of Traffic Lights in Urban Areas
authors: Pradeep Kumar Tiwari, Anshu Tiwari, Naman Jaiswal, Manish Yadav, Sandeep Gupta, Sandeep Kanaujia
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The most significant issue is urban traffic congestion as it impacts mobility, the environment and the safety of commuters. This paper offers a dynamically optimizing signal timing system based on changing traffic circumstances using deep reinforcement learning (DRL) as well as real-time traffic data analysis supported by artificial intelligence. Edge AI devices placed at junctions influence reduced latency, decision-making & multi-agent cooperation among traffic lights throughout the whole network. The suggested model has been developed and assessed in a mimicked smart city design using data from vehicle flow simulations & urban traffic sensors. Results indicate that, when compared to conventional fixed-timing & rule-driven adaptive systems, the AI-driven method reduces average vehicle waiting periods by 35%, increases throughput by 22% & slashes emissions. The results underline the possibility of embedding modern artificial intelligence technologies into urban structures to improve mobility, environmental sustainability & traffic security in real time.

title: AI-Powered Proctoring System using UPOnet Algorithm for Secure Online Examination Environment
authors: Divyashree D, Sana Khan, Bishal Dey, Irshad Ansari
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The growth of distance education raises new challenges such as that of academic ethical preservation. With online schooling, newer tools tend to replace traditional methods of test supervision which are often ineffective. In this paper there is also an invention of the new algorithm UPOnet. In the quest to provide safety and equity during online assessment, this study proposes the implementation of ‘AI Powered Proctoring System for Secure Online Examination Environment’. Modern technologies such as Artificial Intelligence driven computer vision, voice detection and behavior analytics have enabled the system to monitor all exam events in real time. As a result, it prevents any form of misconduct, such as cheating and imitation, and illegal actions. It inspects the honesty of the examination area by utilizing the 360-degree environmental assessment whilst checking the camera and microphone feeds for any potential obstructions. Moreover, the system employs a machine learning system that is capable of self-learning and will always change to remain ahead of the new ways created by learners to cheat. The paper explores one of the challenges faced in AI-driven proctoring in online real-time proctoring examinations of professionals and students, explains the infrastructure of the proctoring systems, and elaborates on the issues faced in developing such systems without ignoring the ethical consequences of deploying AI technologies in this field.

title: Network Administration, and Problem Management in Community Internet Networks Through the Agile Scrum and ITIL V4 Best Practices
authors: Ginna Fernanda Hernández Rachez, Jose David Cely Callejas Samieee
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Community networks are communication systems created and managed by local communities to satisfy their communication needs. This document presents a method based on the development and use of this type of network, focused on services that seek continuous improvement, as well as control and proper management of incidents and requirements that may arise. Thus, this complementary method covers the use, administration of the network, and management of problems/failures in community internet networks through the use of the agile Scrum methodology and the good practices of ITIL V4; in that way, the proposed solution is based on the planning of one that takes ITIL as a reference is complemented by Scrum, thus suggesting a set of best practices for the control, operation, and administration of resources, focusing on the management of Information Technology services and the delivery of IT services.

title: 2D Pose Estimation for Fitness: Automated Technique Assessment with FitMetrics
authors: Siddharth Kannan, Mushtaq Ahmed D.M, Shreya C Shyam, Abhishek Raj, Ankit Pandey, Aryan Srivastava
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The fast-adopted fitness technology brings along the necessity for intelligent solutions that encourage precision and productivity within a training regime. In this context, it introduces FitMetrics as an all-inclusive fitness tracking system powered by the advanced capabilities of the Media-pipe’s Pose Landmark model in real-time posture analysis and exercise tracking.It captures body movements of the user in a 2D plane, analyzes the exercise forms, and provides actionable feedback about further improvements on the technique and safety. Designed to support numerous kinds of workouts, from yoga to squats, push-ups to weightlifting, FitMetrics brings insights into speed, intensity, and alignment. The system will have a database where all the progress is stored, with periodic updates being generated to track developments over time. It will have a user-friendly interface using Stream-lit while in operation and when running with Flask-Mailer, so feedback and visualizations are immediate as it automates the process of sending fitness summaries and reports. FitMetrics combines computer vision, machine learning, and human-computer interaction in a very fluid way that allows the users to reach their fitness goals from the comfort of their homes and reduces the need for physically going to trainers. This system shows how technology can bridge the gap between convenience and precision in fitness, hence making it safer and effective.

title: Integrating Deep Learning and Swarm Intelligence for Cancer Diagnosis
authors: Sushil Dohare, S. Sree Hari Raju, Dr. Narendra Mustare, P. P. Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Deep Learning (DL) and Swarm Intelligence (SI) algorithms are combined in this research to create a strong and smart diagnosis system for finding cancer. The system's hybrid design is its main component, with swarm-based optimization methods like Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), along with Grey Wolf Optimization (GWO) being used for both feature selection and classifier tuning, while deep neural networks (DNNs) are used to extract high-level features. To minimize overfitting and maintain statistical reliability, an extensive evaluation was carried out utilizing the dataset split (80:20) and confirmed by k-fold cross-validation. Swarm integration greatly increased the accuracy of the baseline DL model, which was 85%, to 91%, 89%, and 90% in the DL+PSO, DL+ACO, and DL+GWO combinations, respectively. The hybrid model achieved the highest accuracy of 93% and beat all other models by integrating several SI methods. Precision (0.91), recall (0.94), F1-score (0.92), along with ROC-AUC (0.96), four additional critical measures, improved significantly upon in the subsequent study, indicating balanced and dependable performance. The combination of nature-inspired optimization and deep feature extraction not only improved model generalization, but also made sure that it was easy to understand and worked effectively, which are important for diagnosing cancer in real-life situations. Based on these results, the mixed DL-SI framework represents a beneficial tool for smart medical diagnosis.

title: Vision Assist Navigator: An Android-Based Application for Visually Impaired using TFLite Detections, Monocular Distance Analysis and TTS
authors: Natarajan Venkateswaran, Purab Singh M, R Harini, Reuben Titus R, Siri Rangdale
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: This work aims to develop an application that is based on real-time object detection, distance measurement, and audio feedback for a visually impaired person. It's based on the camera feed capturing the environment and helps to detect and identify the objects by object detection algorithms like YOLO v8 (You Only Look Once). The estimation of distance to objects concerning the user is also included in this application. Then, all the detected objects and their proximity from the user will be conveyed through a text-to-speech (TTS) system to assist in navigation. This lightweight app will be portable, easy to use, and effective at the same time, making it operable on smartphones. By giving real-time feedback, the technology greatly enhances the spatial awareness of and independence from people or guide dogs for the visually impaired, leading to safer movement with reduced dependence on using external help. Focus on the project is harm-free, low-latency solutions that improve the lives of visually challenged users by taking some advances in technology as well as machine learning.

title: Content-Adaptive Join Segmentation with Xception for Stroke Detection Using MRI images
authors: S.E. Viswapriya, D. Rajeswari
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is one of the most critical medical imaging modalities used in diagnostic medicine. It offers detailed anatomical information that aids in detecting and analysing a wide range of diseases. The rich structural insights provided by MRI scans play a vital role in clinical decision-making, enabling healthcare professionals to interpret and assess underlying medical conditions accurately. The gap that arises between high-level and low-level data acquisition. Advanced image segmentation algorithms are essential to convert low-level MRI data into meaningful clinical insights. Preprocessing techniques are typically applied to reduce noise and enhance image quality, facilitating more accurate segmentation and analysis. However, an existing deep joint segmentation can segment the static stroke lesion regions. It is required to focus on dynamic feature learning and segmenting regions. So, a novel Content-Adaptive Joint Segmentation (CAJS) is proposed. This method will represent global features and fusion of attentive weights, which leads to dynamic and effective segmentation. The extracted insights effectively support reliable and clinically relevant classification. The Xception network model has been used for stroke detection. Experimental validation of the proposed method is conducted on the ISLES 2022 dataset. The developed CAJS model is designed by integrating dynamic global features with Deep Joint segmentation and Xception Network algorithm, with the highest specificity of 93%, accuracy of 93%, and sensitivity of 93.2%.

title: Enhance the Network Security in Enterprise Network Using IDPS Tools
authors: G. Shanmugarathinam, Angelin G. Jesudoss, Annie Joseph, Khushi Yadav, Adithya Shashidar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: As cyberattacks continue to evolve in frequency, scope, and sophistication, the demand for robust, layered security systems has never been greater. Enterprises and institutions are increasingly adopting multifaceted strategies to address the weaknesses of traditional point-based security solutions. This paper presents a comprehensive overview of three powerful tools-Suricata, Wazuh, and Splunk, each of which contributes uniquely to a unified real-time threat detection and response architecture. Suricata is used for network-based intrusion detection and monitoring, Wazuh handles host-level security with agent-based analytics, and Splunk serves as a centralized SIEM platform for log aggregation and threat intelligence. By integrating these tools, organizations can achieve visibility, adaptability, and automation across the entire security landscape. This approach aligns with current best practices for layered defense and zero-trust architectures, offering a flexible model that scales from small businesses to large enterprises. We explore each tool in detail, including how they work, how to use them, and their practical advantages when used individually and together.

title: Enhanced RPSO Acoustic Localization Algorithm with Fiber-Optic Fabry-Pérot Self-Calibration Multiplexing Demodulation System
authors: Hewen Chen, Yi Huang, Yuanhang Ma, Chengyong Hu, Chuanlu Deng, Xiaobei Zhang, Qun Li, Jian Shao, Peng Wu, Yuncai Lu, Tingyun Wang
abstract: An enhanced reference particle swarm optimization (RPSO) acoustic localization algorithm with fiber-optic Fabry-Pérot self-calibration multiplexing demodulation system is proposed. The system employs self-calibrating wavelength modulation technology to achieve stable simultaneous demodulation and high-precision time delay measurement for sensors with different cavity lengths. Experimental results demonstrate that the system maintains signal-to-noise ratios (SNR) above 45 dB of the 40-95 kHz frequency range in 4-channel multiplexing scenarios, providing reliable time difference of arrival (TDOA) information for sound source localization (SSL). Building upon this foundation, the proposed RPSO algorithm introduces a reference set mechanism and dynamic inertia weight strategy, effectively addressing the slow convergence and low positioning accuracy of conventional algorithms in complex environments. SSL experiments demonstrate that under identical test conditions, the RPSO algorithm consistently maintains localization errors within 1 cm while reducing required iterations by 80% compared to the traditional particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm, significantly improving the real-time performance and accuracy of the localization system.

title: Approximate MLE of High-Dimensional STAP Covariance Matrices With Banded & Spiked Structure – a Convex Relaxation Approach
authors: Shashwat Jain, Vikram Krishnamurthy, Muralidhar Rangaswamy, Sandeep Gogineni, Bosung Kang, Sean M. O'Rourke
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Estimating the clutter-plus-noise covariance matrix in high-dimensional (stap) is challenging in the presence of Internal Clutter Motion (ICM) and a high noise floor. The problem becomes more difficult in low-sample regimes, where the Sample Covariance Matrix (SCM) becomes ill-conditioned. To capture the ICM and high noise floor, we model the covariance matrix using a “Banded+Spiked” structure. Since the Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE) for this model is non-convex, we propose a convex relaxation which is formulated as a Frobenius norm minimization with non-smooth convex constraints enforcing banded sparsity. This relaxation serves as a provable upper bound for the non-convex likelihood maximization and extends to cases where the covariance matrix dimension exceeds the number of samples. We derive a variational inequality-based bound to assess its quality. We introduce an algorithm to jointly estimate the banded clutter covariance and noise power. Additionally, we establish conditions ensuring the estimated covariance matrix remains positive definite and the bandsize is accurately recovered. Numerical results using the high-fidelity RFView radar simulation environment demonstrate that our algorithm achieves a higher Signal–to–Clutter–plus–Noise Ratio (SCNR) than state–of–the–art methods, including TABASCO, Spiked Covariance Stein Shrinkage, and Diagonal Loading, particularly when the covariance matrix dimension exceeds the number of samples.

title: Efficient Kernel Mapping and Comprehensive System Evaluation of LLM Acceleration on a CGLA
authors: Takuto Ando, Yu Eto, Ayumu Takeuchi, Yasuhiko Nakashima
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) demand substantial computational resources, resulting in high energy consumption on GPUs. To address this challenge, we focus on Coarse-Grained Reconfigurable Arrays (CGRAs) as an effective alternative that provides a trade-off between energy efficiency and programmability. This paper presents the first comprehensive, end-to-end evaluation of a non-AI-specialized Coarse-Grained Linear Array (CGLA) accelerator for the state-of-the-art Qwen LLM family. The architecture has a general-purpose, task-agnostic design, yet its flexible instruction set allows for domain-specific adaptations. This flexibility enables the architecture to achieve high efficiency for sustainable LLM inference. We assess the performance of our architecture on an FPGA prototype using the widely adopted llama.cpp framework. We then project its potential as a 28nm ASIC and compare it against a high-performance GPU (NVIDIA RTX 4090) and an edge AI device (NVIDIA Jetson AGX Orin). While GPUs exhibit lower latency, our non-AI-specific accelerator achieves higher energy efficiency, improving the Power-Delay Product (PDP) by up to 44.4× and 13.6× compared with the RTX 4090 and Jetson, respectively. Similarly, it reduces the Energy-Delay Product (EDP) by up to 11.5× compared to the high-performance GPU, demonstrating a favorable performance-energy trade-off. Critically, our system-level analysis identifies host-accelerator data transfer as the primary performance bottleneck, a factor often overlooked in kernel-level studies. These findings provide design guidance for next-generation LLM accelerators. This work validates CGRAs as a suitable platform for LLM inference in power-constrained environments, without being confined to specific algorithms.

title: Fast Correction for Geometric Distortion in PFA Wavefront Curvature Compensation
authors: Yining Zhang, Jixia Fan, Yanqi Liu, Xinhua Mao
abstract: In large-scene synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imaging, the selection of appropriate algorithms is crucial as it directly impacts processing efficiency and image fidelity. The Polar Format Algorithm (PFA) is widely used for its high-speed image formation capabilities. However, its reliance on the planar wavefront approximation inevitably introduces phase errors. A primary challenge arising from linear components of these errors is geometric distortion, which manifests as space-variant shift from actual positions. Traditional inverse warping correction method based on two-dimensional(2-D) interpolation suffers from high computational costs. To address this limitation, this paper proposes a separable 2-D interpolation framework that decouples the correction process into two one-dimensional (1-D) interpolations along azimuth and range axes. Through inverse solutions of geometric distortion functions, it is demonstrated that applying this framework to geometric distortion correction can effectively reduce the complexity while preserving image precision. Simulations and real-data comparisons validate that the proposed fast geometric distortion correction method significantly improve correction speed thus boosting overall computational efficiency.

title: Rotational Motion Compensation and Sparse ISAR Imaging of Maneuvering Targets Via Deep Unrolling Network
authors: Yue Wang, Xueru Bai, Feng Zhou
abstract: Accurate rotational motion compensation is critical for achieving well-focused inverse synthetic aperture radar (ISAR) imaging of maneuvering targets. However, low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and incomplete echoes often lead to significant performance degradation in conventional methods. Furthermore, these methods rely heavily on manual parameter tuning, which limits their adaptability to varying SNR and data missing rate in practical applications. In this article, a novel deep unrolling network for ISAR imaging of maneuvering targets is proposed. Firstly, an iterative method, termed RMC-PDHG, is proposed for rotational motion compensation and well-focused ISAR imaging based on Primal-Dual Hybrid Gradient (PDHG), enabling accurate imaging of maneuvering targets under low SNR and incomplete echo conditions. On this basis, a rotational motion compensation and imaging network, i.e., RMC-PDHG-Net, is developed by unrolling the RMC-PDHG. This network incorporates a hypernetwork to dynamically generate optimal internal parameters such as the regularization coefficient and step size based on intermediate image features, thereby gaining robustness to varying SNR and data missing rate. Additionally, a two-stage training strategy combining unsupervised and supervised learning is proposed to improve rotation parameter estimation accuracy and image reconstruction quality. Experimental results on simulated and measured data have demonstrated the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed network.

title: Whole-Body Inverse Dynamics MPC for Legged Loco-Manipulation
authors: Lukas Molnar, Jin Cheng, Gabriele Fadini, Dongho Kang, Fatemeh Zargarbashi, Stelian Coros
abstract: Loco-manipulation demands coordinated whole-body motion to manipulate objects effectively while maintaining locomotion stability, presenting significant challenges for both planning and control. In this work, we propose a whole-body model predictive control (MPC) framework that directly optimizes joint torques through full-order inverse dynamics, enabling unified motion and force planning and execution within a single predictive layer. This approach allows emergent, physically consistent whole-body behaviors that account for the system's dynamics and physical constraints. We implement our MPC formulation using open software frameworks (Pinocchio and CasADi), along with the state-of-the-art interior-point solver Fatrop. In real-world experiments on a Unitree B2 quadruped equipped with a Unitree Z1 manipulator arm, our MPC formulation achieves real-time performance at 80 Hz. We demonstrate loco-manipulation tasks that demand fine control over the end-effector's position and force to perform real-world interactions like pulling heavy loads, pushing boxes, and wiping whiteboards.

title: Interpretable Gas Fingerprint Extraction for Toxic Chemicals Using Parameter Fitting of Response Curve
authors: Shouwen Zhang, Zhenyu Yuan, Wei Zhang, Bo Yang, Ruixin Li, Fanli Meng
abstract: Gas fingerprint extraction is critical for pattern recognition and gas sensor calibration. Traditional fingerprint extraction methods primarily focus on statistical approaches and end-to-end feature extractors. However, both the methods themselves and the extracted fingerprints often lack interpretability. This article presents a gas fingerprint extraction method based on parameter fitting of the response curve. It involves extracting fitting parameters from the response curves and selecting features according to their information entropy contribution, thereby obtaining highly compact and interpretable gas fingerprints. Compared to traditional methods, the proposed approach enables the identification of gas fingerprints with clear boundaries in class distribution, characterized by smaller intraclass variance and greater interclass distances. The effective fingerprints significantly enhance identification accuracy in species classification and concentration regression. Furthermore, this method incurs lower computational and development costs, does not require a large sample size, and is suitable for both large and small sample sets. This approach offers a cost-effective solution for dimensionality reduction of gas sensor response data, fingerprint extraction, sensor calibration, gas identification, and lightweight model construction.

title: Study on An Intelligent Screening Method for Polycystic Ovary Syndrome Based on Deep Physics-Informed Neural Network
authors: Yu Gong, Danji Wang, Chao Wu, Man Ni, Shengli Li, Yang Liu, Ziyuan Shen, Zhidong Su, Xiaoxiao Liu, Huiping Zhou, Huijie Zhang
abstract: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) not only causes anovulation in women but also severely affects their physical and mental health. Clinically, diagnostic delays often cause patients to miss optimal treatment windows. As a non-invasive detection technique, Raman spectroscopy has been used for screening this disease. In this letter, the Raman spectra of follicular fluid and plasma from women which PCOS are examined using a deep physics-informed neural network. The results demonstrate that by incorporating physical priors and integrating multi-domain spectral information, the proposed method achieves accuracies of 96.25% in detecting PCOS from plasma samples and 90.00% from follicular fluid samples.

title: Effect Size-Driven Pathway Meta-Analysis for Gene Expression Data
authors: Juan Antonio Villatoro-García, Pablo Pedro Jurado-Bascón, Pedro Carmona-Sáez
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: The proliferation of omics datasets in public repositories has created unprecedented opportunities for biomedical research but has also posed significant challenges for their integration, particularly due to missing genes and platform-specific discrepancies. Traditional gene expression meta-analysis often focuses on individual genes, leading to data loss and limited biological insights when there are missing genes across different studies. To address these limitations, we propose GSEMA (Gene Set Enrichment Meta-Analysis), a novel methodology that leverages single-sample enrichment scoring to aggregate gene expression data into pathway-level matrices. By applying meta-analysis techniques to enrichment scores, GSEMA preserves the magnitude and directionality of effects, enabling the definition of pathway activity across datasets. Using simulated data and case studies on Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and Parkinson's Disease (PD), we demonstrate that GSEMA outperforms other methods in controlling false positive rates while providing meaningful biological interpretations. GSEMA methodology is implemented as an R package available on CRAN repository.

title: Hybrid RIS-Assisted Multi-Hop Indoor-Outdoor Secure Communication in UAV mmWave Networks
authors: Amayika Kakati, Guoquan Li, Elhadj Moustapha Diallo, Mohamed Amine Ouamri, Muhammad Imran Khalid, Abuzar B. M. Adam, Xingwang Li
abstract: Millimeter wave (mmWave) communication is a key enabler for future wireless networks, particularly in the context of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-assisted systems. However, mmWave frequencies suffer from significant propagation loss and coverage limitations, especially in hybrid indoor-outdoor environments in addition to the rising secrecy issues. To address these challenges, we propose a hybrid reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted multi-hop secure communication scheme for UAV mmWave networks, where both simultaneously transmitting and reflecting (STAR)-RISs and traditional RISs are deployed to enhance signal coverage and improve system performance. First, we formulate secrecy energy efficiency (SEE) maximization problem. Next, we develop a novel generative artificial intelligence (GAI) and differential privacy (DP)-enhanced soft actor-critic (GAIDP-SAC) framework to jointly optimize precoding at the UAV, the phase shift profiles of hybrid RISs, and the UAV trajectory. The integration of differential privacy ensures secure communication and privacy preservation, while GAI accelerates convergence and improves policy learning efficiency. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed GAIDP-SAC framework significantly enhances the coverage and security of UAV mmWave networks in hybrid indoor-outdoor environments. Furthermore, the results show that our method effectively handles the complex joint optimization problem, achieving state-of-the-art performance in multi-hop RIS-assisted UAV mmWave communication systems.

title: When Feedback Empowers the Uplink: Integrating Adaptive Coding With Wireless Power Transfer
authors: Zijian Yang, Yulin Shao, Shaodan Ma
abstract: Energy consumption and device lifetime are critical concerns for battery-constrained IoT devices. This paper introduces the Feedback-Aided Coding and Energy Transfer (FACET) framework, which synergistically combines adaptive feedback channel coding with wireless power transfer. FACET leverages the saturation effect of feedback coding, where increasing downlink power yields diminishing returns, to design a dual-purpose feedback mechanism that simultaneously guides uplink coding and replenishes device energy. We characterize the inherent tradeoff between feedback precision and harvested power, and formulate a fairness-constrained min-max optimization problem to minimize worst-case net energy consumption. An efficient algorithm based on alternating optimization and Lagrangian duality is developed, with each subproblem admitting a closed-form solution. Simulations show that FACET nearly triples device lifetime compared to conventional feedback coding architectures, and remains robust across a wide range of power regimes. These results suggest that FACET not only improves communication efficiency but also redefines the role of feedback in energy-constrained IoT systems.

title: Specific Emitter Identification based on Semi-supervised Active Learning
authors: Xin Wang, Chenlong Yue, Yanchu Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Specific emitter identification (SEI) plays a critical role in the security and management of communication systems, particularly within the context of instrumentation and the Internet of Things (IoT). Current deep learning-based SEI approaches rely heavily on large-scale labeled datasets; however, the high cost and expertise required for annotation limit their practical application. To address these challenges, we propose SSAL-SEI, a radiation source identification method that integrates active learning with semi-supervised learning. During the active learning phase, a balanced sampling strategy that considers both uncertainty and diversity is employed to dynamically select the most informative unlabeled samples while maintaining class distribution equilibrium for annotation. In the subsequent semi-supervised phase, unlabeled data are further leveraged to enhance feature representation capabilities. To evaluate the robustness of the proposed method, experiments were conducted on the Automatic Dependent Surveillance Broadcast (ADS-B) dataset with 10, 20, and 30 classes, as well as on a Wi-Fi dataset comprising 16 classes, in conjunction with multiple SOTA models. The results demonstrate that the proposed strategy not only significantly improves the performance of semi-supervised learning but also provides effective guidance for optimizing SEI techniques under limited labeling conditions.

title: Operational Results from the Deep Space Optical Communications (DSOC) Project Ground Laser Transmitter
authors: Angel E. Velasco, Seán M. Meenehan, Malcolm W. Wright, Erik Alerstam, Jason P. Allmaras, Kenneth Andrews, William C. Buehlman, Vachik Garkanian, Carlos Gross Jones, Meera Srinivasan
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: The purpose of the Deep Space Optical Communication (DSOC) project is to demonstrate that free space optical communication technology is mature and capable of supporting future deep space missions. Free space optical communications can provide 10-100x higher data rates as compared to RF technology at Mars distances. In addition, the DSOC team characterized the link budget at Mars ranges (0.3-2.6 AU) demonstrating up to 267 Mbps downlink data rates. DSOC operations began two weeks after the flight terminal hosted by the Psyche spacecraft launched October 2023. Weekly contacts between the two optical ground stations and the flight terminal aboard Psyche are on-going until the DSOC prime mission ends September 2025. This paper provides an overview of the DSOC architecture, the two ground station terminals design, operations, and focusing on ground transmitter tests.

title: Multi-Modal Optical Sensing Fusion for Quantitative Monitoring of Orchid Parameters: Analysis of Commercial Cultivation in Asia
authors: Akey Sungheetha, Rajesh Sharma R, Sreeja B P, Sheila Mahapatra, Rahul Thakur, Karpagalakshmi RC
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: This study examines the integration of advanced optical sensing technologies for real-time quantitative monitoring of orchid growth parameters in commercial cultivation settings. We analyze the complementary capabilities of three primary optical sensing modalities—machine vision systems, fluorescence spectroscopy, and hyperspectral imaging—and demonstrate how their fusion provides comprehensive assessment of key physiological markers including photosynthetic efficiency (±2.3% accuracy), leaf area index (LAI) measurements (r<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> > 0.92), and early stress detection (up to 72 hours before visual symptoms). The proposed integrated approach overcomes limitations of single-sensor methodologies by combining structural, biochemical, and physiological data streams to create a holistic monitoring framework. Two detailed case studies from large-scale commercial orchid producers in Taiwan and India demonstrate implementation efficacy, showcasing 28% reduction in water usage, 17% decrease in fertilizer application, and 22% increase in marketable yield through sensor-guided interventions. Economic analyses reveal a return on investment period of 14-18 months for medium-sized operations (>5,000 plants) with technology adoption costs offset by production efficiency gains. Technical challenges including sensor calibration drift (-0.8%/month), integration complexity, and scalability considerations are addressed with proposed solutions for commercial implementation. This research establishes quantitative benchmarks for multi-modal optical sensor deployment in controlled environment agriculture, with specific applications for high-value ornamental plant production systems.

title: Educational Robotics in a Non-Formal Context: A Comparative Analysis of Attitudes in an NGO (2023–2024)
authors: Carlos Eduardo Ribeiro, Rodrigo H. Cunha Palácios, Eduardo Todt
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: This study investigates the impact of educational robotics interventions on the attitudes of young people in a Non-Governmental Organization (NGO) over two years (2023–2024). Using the Robotics Attitudes Measurement Instrument, four constructs were assessed: willingness to learn, self-confidence, computational thinking, and teamwork. A significant positive progression was observed in the mean scores of all constructs between 2023 and 2024, notably in Willingness to Learn (from 3.06 to 3.61) and Self-Confidence (from 2.76 to 3.24). Analyses, including gender differences, correlations between constructs, and qualitative reports from teachers, demonstrate the potential of robotics to foster engagement and positive attitudes in non-formal educational settings.

title: First Investigation of Deep Learning for Intraoperative Gauze Segmentation in Minimally Invasive Abdominal Surgery
authors: Priya Tomar, Maximilian Broß, Philipp Feodorovici, Jan Arensmeyer, Philipp Leifels, Aditya Parikh, Hanno Matthaei, Christian Bauckhage, Helen Schneider, Rafet Sifa
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Surgical gauze is an essential part of surgical procedures, which is primarily used for controlling bleeding and absorbing bodily fluids. The post-surgical retention of gauze can lead to serious complications in the patient's health and necessitate additional surgery for gauze removal. In the wake of data scarcity, the research on gauze segmentation on the real-world surgical data remains underexplored. In this work, we investigate the use of deep learning methods for gauze segmentation in robotassisted minimally invasive abdominal surgeries, utilizing an inhouse surgical dataset prepared at a university hospital. The training data reflects a realistic surgical setting and extensive diversity in spatial, morphological, and visual attributes of three different gauze categories. We have investigated prevalently used segmentation architectures, including CNN-based, transformer-based, and hybrid architectures, to provide a proof-of-concept for gauze segmentation in a realistic setting. Besides, we investigate the influence of additional sub-optimally annotated, auto-tracked segmentation masks to address the bottleneck of data scarcity and performance optimization. Our results demonstrate the efficacy of real-world data to counter the main challenge reported by prior works - the trade-off between blood presence and gauze detection. The incorporation of auto-track annotations enables performance enhancements, particularly in generic cases. The integration of effective segmentation approaches will benefit robotguided surgical procedures and various downstream applications by providing a precise delineation of foreign objects, enhancing patient safety and surgical outcomes.

title: Advances in Renewable Energy Storage Solutions
authors: Abhijit Garad, Kalpana Chittor S, Aaluri Seenu, Meenakshi Sharma, P Moniya, Narottam Chaubey
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: When green energy sources are added to modern power lines, they need improved energy storage options to deal with intermittent power, changing demand, and goals for sustainability. This study compares lithium-ion, flow batteries, compressed air energy storage (CAES), along with hydrogen systems. It looks at how well they work in terms of cost, lifespan, and CO2 emissions, as well as how well they work in terms of technology. The study looks at how well systems work when seasonal loads change and green inputs change. It does this by using computer models made with MATLAB/Simulink as well as HOMER Pro and checking them against real-world data. A multi-objective optimisation method finds the Pareto-optimal designs that balance cost, speed, and effect on the environment. The results help us figure out how to make energy storage systems that are strong, affordable, and long-lasting, which is very important for a renewable-powered grid that works well.

title: Anomaly Detection Under Contaminated Data: A Weighted Iterative Refinement Framework for Health Monitoring
authors: Stefano Donné, Jesse Davis, Filip Van Utterbeeck, Mathias Verbeke
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Reliable anomaly detection under data contamination remains a major challenge in Prognostics and Health Management, especially when degradation processes are gradual and clean training data are unavailable. This paper introduces a weighted iterative refinement framework with autoencoders for contaminated anomaly detection (WIRACAD) to address this problem. The method, which is based on reconstruction residuals, re-weights training samples across iterations in order to progressively reduce the influence of suspected anomalies. This continuous refinement improves the robustness of health indicator learning from contaminated time series. The proposed approach is evaluated on two public benchmarks: the NASA C-MAPSS dataset and the IMS Bearing dataset. Results show consistent improvements in key metrics related to degradation monitoring. In particular, the overal fit score and the monotonicty are improved when compared to baseline autoencoder training and recent refinement-based methods. These findings suggest that iterative sample weighting can enhance unsupervised anomaly detection with autoencoders in settings where data contamination is assumed.

title: An ISO-Based Model for Evaluating Accessibility in Virtual Learning Environments
authors: Erika Paola Reina-Guaña, Carlos Guillermo Hernández-Cenzano
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Ensuring accessibility in Virtual Learning Environments (VLEs) is critical for inclusive education, particularly for individuals with functional diversity, such as those diagnosed with Asperger syndrome. Although international standards such as ISO/IEC 40500 (WCAG 2.0) provide general accessibility guidelines, many VLEs remain inadequate in addressing the specific cognitive and perceptual needs of neurodivergent users. This study presents an ISObased methodology for evaluating VLE accessibility, integrating ISO/IEC 40500, ISO/IEC 25012, and ISO/IEC 25024 standards. The methodology comprises three phases: (1) a bibliometric analysis to identify research trends and gaps in digital accessibility; (2) the design and validation of specialized accessibility indicators through expert review and user testing with individuals with Asperger syndrome; and (3) the development of ISO-compliant accessibility metrics for objective and quantifiable evaluation. The findings demonstrate that the proposed model offers a structured, replicable, and user-centered framework for assessing and enhancing accessibility in VLEs. By aligning with established standards and incorporating direct user input, the model contributes to the advancement of inclusive digital education practices.

title: IoT Based Health Monitoring System with AI Powered Disease Prediction
authors: Sarvesh Kumar Gupta, Vamsi Krishna Gottipati, Savya Sachi, Ashish Gupta, Sanjeev Kumar Shah, Om Goel
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic wreaked havoc on many people's lives and livelihoods, as well as on many parts of the economy. As the number of patients increased at an exponential rate, the already-stressed healthcare industry encountered new problems. As a result, virtual consultation, telemedicine, and teleconsultation grew in popularity to adhere to social distance standards. This paper aims to grow a new system that uses the most effective machine learning (ML) algorithm to predict a patient's disease based on their signs, recordings of audio, available medical records, and other health histories. The goal is to address the urgent need for more "remote" discussions in the "post-COVID" era, and the Internet of Things (IoT) shows great promise in this regard. Sensors that are based on Arduino and ESP8266 may also be used to measure some of the indications, like fever and low oxygen levels in the blood, among others. It then offers for the suitable treatment and diagnosis of the condition based on its database, which is continually updated and may be designed as a platform that is either based on an application or a website.

title: ADT++: Advanced Adversarial Distributional Training with Class-Wise Robustness
authors: Samer Y. Khamaiseh, Deirdre Jost, Anas Alsobeh, Abdullah Al-Alaj, Honglu Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Adversarial training (AT) is widely regarded as a leading defense strategy for improving the robustness of deep learning models against adversarial attacks. However, existing AT methods often rely on a single attack strategy during training, which limits the exploration of the perturbation space and leads to poor generalization robustness against stronger, unseen, or adaptive adversarial attacks. Moreover, most AT approaches overlook class-wise robustness–the observed variation in robustness across different image classes–by focusing solely on average performance over the entire dataset. In this paper, we present Advanced Distributional Training with Class-wise Robustness (ADT++), a novel adversarial training framework that significantly improves generalization robustness against unseen and sophisticated adversarial attacks. Following the standard adversarial training framework, ADT++ is formulated as a minmax optimization problem, where the inner maximization aims to learn the worst-case adversarial distribution around adversarial examples to further explore the perturbation space. The outer minimization seeks to find model parameters that minimize the expected loss of the maximum inner loss. To further improve the generalization robustness, ADT++ leverages the class-wise robustness phenomenon by targeting the most vulnerable image classes with high-loss adversarial attacks to generate more impactful adversarial examples. Extensive evaluations on benchmark datasets and against various AT defense methods and adversarial attacks confirm the effectiveness of ADT++ in improving model robustness against stronger and adaptive attacks.
