title: Selection of Service Providers: A Comprehensive Review of AI-Driven Decision-Making Techniques
authors: Abhilipsa Sahoo, Shantanu Singh, Somya Jain, Aswathy K Cherian
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The selection of cloud service providers (CSPs) is a crucial decision affecting organizational performance, cost efficiency, and regulatory compliance. Traditional methodologies rely on multi-criteria decision-making (MCDM) techniques, which lack adaptability to dynamic cloud environments. With recent advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), automated CSP selection frameworks have emerged, integrating predictive analytics, reinforcement learning, and federated learning. This review synthesizes current research in AI-driven CSP selection methodologies, evaluating their effectiveness in balancing performance, cost, and regulatory adherence. The study highlights existing research gaps in adaptive decision-making, security risk assessment, and compliance monitoring while proposing future research directions in explainable AI, blockchain-based trust verification, and hybrid optimization models.

title: Proposal for a Soil Erosion Prediction System in Peruvian Territory Using Satellite Imagery
authors: Axel Cuadros-Huachua, Marks Calderón-Niquin
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Soil erosion threatens agricultural and ecosystem stability in Peru, creating the need for efficient and scalable assessment tools beyond traditional monitoring. This research details the development of a soil erosion prediction system for the Piura region by integrating remote sensing, the RUSLE model, and deep learning. Our methodology involved two steps: first, building a multi-temporal geospatial database (2015–2024) on Google Earth Engine with 16 variables from Landsat 8, Sentinel-1, and MODIS. Second, developing two convolutional neural network architectures to predict the RUSLE A-factor. AU-Net model was used for direct spatial prediction, while a ConvL-STM U-Net model was designed for spatio-temporal forecasting. Evaluation in a test data set confirmed the high performance of both models. The U-Net accurately predicted the spatial distribution of erosion (R2=0.9895, MSE=0.0006, MAE=0.0021), and the ConvLSTM U-Net successfully forecasted its evolution (R2=0.7820, MSE=0.0036, MAE=0.0303). We conclude that this integrated system offers a powerful and scalable solution for erosion assessment. The ability to generate precise susceptibility maps and anticipate future behavior provides a valuable tool for land use planning and conservation strategies in vulnerable regions.

title: Integrated Simulation and Validation of A Microwave Resonant Cavity for Food Dehydration Applications
authors: Alejandro Herencia Sullon, Ana Calderon Reto, Justo Oquelis Cabredo, Daniel Marcelo Aldana, Raúl La Madrid Olivares, Abdebel Flores Guerrero, Edilberto Vasquez Diaz
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: The present numerical-experimental research proposes the simulation of a microwave oven to operate as a microwave dehydration system. The purpose is to evaluate the thermal distribution in time and to determine the percentage of energy absorption in the products. The procedure consisted of modeling the geometry of a real microwave oven and configuring the operating parameters through numerical simulation. The results were then experimentally validated, using temperature results measured with a thermographic camera for a potato sample. The numerical results show that in 90 seconds the temperature reached is between 80 and 85 °C. Likewise, the percentage of microwave energy absorption in the potato sample was approximately 44.22%. Therefore, this would allow the future development and implementation of a prototype based on microwave technology with modifications to ensure shorter dehydration times, process safety, optimization of dehydration, and valuable information for the improvement of dehydrated products.

title: Strategic Assessment of Myoelectric Prosthesis Commercialization in Latin America: A Peruvian Case Study
authors: Sebastian Caballa, Consuelo Cano, Carlos Hernández-Cenzano
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: This study presents a strategic and technological assessment for the commercialization of upper-limb myoelectric prostheses in the Latin American context, with Peru as the focal point. The research applies a structured technology surveillance and competitive intelligence methodology, including patent analysis, bibliometric review, and regulatory framework evaluation. The findings reveal a global technological concentration around EMG sensors and gesture recognition algorithms, with the market dominated by established international firms. However, opportunities have been identified for regional innovation, particularly in areas related to accessibility, customization, and anthropometric adaptation. Additionally, an analysis of local startups and academic initiatives highlights emerging capabilities despite limitations in scale and funding. The study emphasizes the importance of aligning product development with international standards and national regulatory requirements to facilitate market entry. It concludes that, through targeted strategies and compliance with technical norms, local enterprises can enhance their competitiveness in assistive medical technologies.

title: Translating Behavior Trees to Petri Nets for Model Checking
authors: Matteo Palmas, Michaela Klauck, Ralph Lange, Enrico Ghiorzi, Armando Tacchella
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems (MODELS)
abstract: Behavior Trees (BTs) have emerged as a convenient approach to encode decision-making policies in robotics. However, the lack of a definitive reference for execution semantics limits their applicability in safety-critical systems. This paper contributes a solution by providing a new translation of BTs to Petri Nets (PNs) to enable verification when the embedding context of the BT is modeled also as a PN. This ensures that safety and response properties about the overall robotic system can be assessed using state-of-the-art model checkers. Our method takes a BT, translates each node to a so-called PN template of the node's type and then composes the templates to obtain a single PN. Additionally, we introduce optimization strategies to reduce the size of the final model, improving computational efficiency while preserving verification accuracy. We report evaluation results on different case studies, including industry-related ones, demonstrating the feasibility and the scalability of our approach.

title: Fuzzy Petri-Net-Based Risk Assessment Model for AI Adoption in SME Auto-Component Clusters
authors: Davidson Salas, Ramakrishnan Raman
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) within Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) in auto-component clusters presents a significant opportunity for enhancing operational efficiency, product quality, and decision-making capabilities. However, the transition to AI-driven processes introduces inherent risks related to financial investment, workforce adaptability, cybersecurity vulnerabilities, and process disruptions. To systematically assess and mitigate these risks, this paper proposes a novel Fuzzy Petri-Net (FPN)-based risk assessment model. The model effectively captures the uncertainties associated with AI adoption by integrating fuzzy logic to quantify imprecise risk factors and employing Petri Nets to model the interdependencies among various risk components. The methodology involves defining risk factors, assigning fuzzy membership values, constructing a Petri Net representation, and executing dynamic risk propagation analysis. The proposed approach is validated through a case study on SME auto-component clusters, demonstrating its effectiveness in identifying high-risk areas and providing structured decision-making insights. Comparative analysis with traditional risk assessment models highlights the advantages of the FPN framework in terms of adaptability, uncertainty handling, and practical applicability. The findings suggest that the proposed model can serve as a reliable decision-support tool, aiding SMEs in developing strategic AI implementation roadmaps while minimizing potential risks. Future research will focus on real-time risk assessment enhancements and adaptive learning-based optimizations.

title: Transforming Avocado Seeds into Bioethanol: a Sustainable Energy Solution
authors: Juan Sebastián Sánchez-Gómez, Jesus Berrio, Lia Fonseca, Carla Gonzalez, Paula Lora, Tania Ortiz, Luis Alberto Cruz Salazar, Libis Valdez
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Colombia, the world's third-largest producer of Hass avocados, generates substantial agricultural waste, particularly from seeds and peels. This study explores the sustainable transformation of avocado seeds into bioethanol as a renewable energy source. With avocado production rising-especially in rural regions like Cundinamarcamanaging agro-industrial waste is critical. Avocado seeds, comprising approximately 55.67 % starch, present a valuable raw material for bioethanol production. The research employed a systematic literature review and developed a multi-step conversion process: starch extraction using alkaline solutions, enzymatic hydrolysis into fermentable sugars, fermentation with yeast, and ethanol recovery through distillation. Aspen Plus V11 simulation software was used to optimize production parameters, such as temperature and reagent concentration, ensuring efficiency and cost-effectiveness. The results demonstrated that bioethanol derived from avocado seeds is a feasible alternative fuel. Although the production cost is slightly higher than gasoline, the environmental advantages-including reduced greenhouse gas emissions and decreased dependency on fossil fuels-outweigh the economic drawbacks. The process also holds potential for rural economic development by generating employment and diversifying income in avocado-growing regions. Despite limitations like seasonal raw material availability and the lower energy density of bioethanol compared to conventional fuels, the approach supports Colombia's goals in sustainability and energy diversification. Future research will focus on enhancing yield, reducing costs, and scaling infrastructure. Overall, converting avocado seeds into bioethanol represents a promising circular economy strategy that aligns with environmental, economic, and energy-transition objectives, offering a practical model for renewable energy generation from agricultural residues in Colombia.

title: Detection (Reconstruction) of Long-Lived Particle Tracks in LHCb Experiment, CERN
authors: Piotr Kulczycki, Grzegorz Gołaszewski, Tomasz Szumlak, Szymon Łukasik
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: The LHCb (Large Hadron Collider beauty) experiment is one of the main research areas carried out by the European Organization for Nuclear Research CERN in Geneva. The presented paper describes a novel procedure for the detection of long-lived particles provided for the needs of the above experiment. A problem that is investigated mainly relies on the determination of tracks (trajectories) of such particles based on observations obtained from measurement modules placed far apart; thus, such kind of detection is alternatively named a reconstruction. The main intention of the algorithm presented here constitutes the elimination of erroneously created tracks, the so-called ghost-tracks. The presented concept is based on elements of mathematical statistics (nonparametric estimation) as well as computational intelligence (neural networks, fuzzy approach). In order to measure the obtained effectiveness, an appropriate performance index which does not require information if the given track is real or only a ghost (as it occurs in practice) is defined. Finally, the number of ghost-tracks is reduced threefold in comparison to prior methods used. Illustrative interpretations make the presented concept easy to adopt in similar problems connected with detection/reconstruction of tracks/trajectories of elementary physical particles.

title: CA-HIL: A Competency-Aware Framework for Bridging Automation and Human Expertise in Data Science Projects
authors: Maike Holtkemper, Christian Beecks
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA)
abstract: Automation frameworks support data science projects by automating tasks such as data preprocessing, feature engineering, model selection, and deployment. These frameworks reduce manual workload but create challenges for maintaining trustworthy, fair, and responsible analytics. Trustworthy analytics require human competencies to ensure explainability, fairness auditing, and ethical compliance, particularly where automation alone is insufficient. Existing taxonomies classify frameworks by technical scope but ignore the human competencies necessary for critical oversight. This paper addresses the gap by proposing a Competency-Aware Human-in-the-Loop (CA-HIL) Framework. The CA-HIL Framework systematically maps automation stages to intervention points, defines the associated risks, and identifies the specific human competencies required to mitigate these risks. Following the PRISMA methodology, a systematic literature review (SLR) of 2241 research articles supports the framework's development. The evaluation applies CA-HIL to leading automation systems such as TPOT, Auto-Prep, and AutoDS to identify in-dispensable human interventions. The findings demonstrate how competency-aware intervention enhances transparency, fairness, and accountability in automated workflows. This study provides a structured, evidence-based approach for designing responsible data science automation systems that bridge technical efficiency with human ethical responsibility.

title: Machine Learning-Based Anomaly Detection Framework for Fraud Detection in Medical Billing
authors: P. Sathish, Channabasava, Sonali Ponnappa
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Fraudulent activities in medical billing significantly impact healthcare costs and patient care quality. Traditional fraud detection methods, such as rule-based systems, struggle to identify emerging fraud patterns and require constant updates. This paper proposes a machine learning-based anomaly detection framework to efficiently detect fraudulent claims in medical billing. By leveraging supervised and unsupervised learning techniques, the framework analyzes healthcare transactions and identifies anomalies indicative of fraud. The study evaluates the performance of Random Forest, Support Vector Machines (SVM), Autoencoders, and K-Means Clustering on real-world datasets. Experimental results demonstrate that Random Forest achieved the highest accuracy (95%), making it highly effective for detecting fraudulent transactions, while Autoencoders excelled at uncovering unknown fraud patterns. The framework offers a scalable, automated solution to fraud detection, reducing manual efforts and improving detection rates across diverse billing scenarios. The findings highlight the potential of machine learning in enhancing fraud detection accuracy and securing healthcare financial systems.

title: Surge Protection Against Lightning in a 33 kV Transmission Line
authors: Jeancarlo Videla, Carlos Ito, Angelo Limache
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Overvoltages caused by lightning strikes are one of the main sources of failure in electric power distribution systems, especially in overhead lines that lack shield wires. This study evaluates the vulnerability of a 33 kV line segment without lightning protection or shield wires, through the simulation of a detailed electrical model of direct lightning strikes. It was identified that lightning currents as low as 3 kA can cause disruptive discharges (flashovers) on phase conductors. As a mitigation measure, surge arresters were installed between towers 009 and 018, thus preventing the propagation of the lightning wave. Simulation results showed that, with this solution, the line can withstand lightning currents of up to 76 kA without producing flashover, representing a 91% probability of not exceeding the failure threshold. Furthermore, the use of surge arresters avoids the need to install shield wires, which would be costly and structurally complex in existing lines. Overall, the study confirms the effectiveness of strategically placed surge arresters as a technical and economic solution to improve service continuity under severe atmospheric conditions.

title: Intelligent Frameworks for Enhancing Disaster Response through AI-Driven Predictive Modeling and Resource Allocation Optimization
authors: Muhammad Saleem
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: Natural disasters increasingly strain emergency systems, necessitating smarter, predictive response mechanisms. However, current frameworks lack integration between real-time AI-driven forecasting and dynamic resource allocation. This study proposes an intelligent framework that unifies LSTM-based disaster prediction with mixed integer linear programming (MILP) for resource optimization, which is enhanced through adaptive feedback loops. Simulations using multi-hazard data reveal the model achieves high predictive accuracy (RMSE = 7.24, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex> = 0.946), over 99% resource coverage, and reduced response time (6.48 hours' average). The framework was validated using a multi-hazard synthetic dataset incorporating flood, wind, and seismic variables across diverse urban zones. The adaptive feedback mechanism triggers retraining in <1% of scenarios, indicating robustness. Notably, stakeholder satisfaction scores exceeded 0.75, validating practical trust in the system. This research contributes a novel, real-time decision-support architecture that bridges AI forecasting with logistical optimization, outperforming static and heuristic baselines. It advances disaster informatics by integrating predictive learning with adaptive operations under uncertainty, offering scalable global emergency response planning solutions.

title: Temporal Heterogeneous Causal Effects in Organizational Mining via Multiview Autoencoders
authors: Fernando Montoya, Gonzalo Rivera-Lazo, Mauricio Hidalgo, Manuel Goyo, Hernán Astudillo
publish: 2025 IEEE Technology and Engineering Management Society (TEMSCON LATAM)
abstract: Temporal variability in business processes represents a significant challenge in organizational mining, driven by changes in demand, regulatory requirements, or internal restructuring. These factors reconfigure the causal relationships among process roles, altering their interaction patterns. Detecting such changes in a timely manner is crucial to maintaining operational efficiency. Analyzing roles in temporally dynamic processes requires incorporating multiple perspectives to capture complex patterns in their evolving interactions. Interventions applied to these roles yield heterogeneous effects depending on their groupings and temporal contexts. To address this complexity, we propose an approach based on multiview autoencoders that capture diverse interaction perspectives among roles and enable clustering based on their latent patterns. This methodology uncovers specific causal relationships and estimates heterogeneous effects, supporting adaptive interventions for the roles involved. Validation was carried out using data from a payment services company, which revealed clusters of roles with similar patterns and identified their distinct causal relationships between temporal scenarios. This insight guided the design of targeted and focused interventions. This work contributes to organizational mining in temporally variable contexts through the integration of multiview autoencoders and causal inference techniques, thereby enabling adaptive interventions aligned with role-interaction patterns and their operational context.

title: An Efficient Storage of Network Logs Using Blockchain Technology
authors: Nandini G, Kavya N L, Divyashree S R, Roopashree C S
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Network security is crusial for organizations handling sensitive data in today’s digital world. While essential for tracking network activities, traditional logging systems often face challenges related to tampering, unauthorized access, and lack of transparency. Blockchain Technology provides a groundbreaking solution by offering an immutable, decentralized, and transparent method for securing network logs. Even with the vast advancements in cybersecurity, hackers can still perform spoofing and sniffing attacks. Hackers use different IP and MAC addresses every time, leading to a problematic situation in identifying the IP address used to perform the attack next time. However, analyzing these IP addresses is very important for cyber forensics. The logs are vital in providing information about the originator’s protocol, IP address, and MAC address that needs to be stored for analysis. This article proposes using Blockchain concepts to store the network log data and discusses its advantages over the existing methods.Anovel

title: AI-Enhanced Credit Scoring Method for Immediate Assessment
authors: Renu Vij, Divya Kumar, Atul Aggarwal, Neha Saini
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The cutting-edge technology, which employs artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms to drastically transform the credit card approval procedure within the banking sector, is the AI-driven Credit Scoring technology that uses real-time credit card approval in banking. The latest technology simplifies and automates the prior methods of evaluating credit, which means it can give you a correct credit card acceptance in real time. Later on, it applies machine learning algorithms to analyse the data, which includes the applicant's spending patterns, financial history, and credit, and then it generates a personalised credit score. The assessment is always revised, consequently, their decision may be based on the most current data available. The system runs a risk profile for an application. Using artificial intelligence, it determines their creditworthiness, hence avoiding human examination and reducing the time and effort required to authorise a credit card. This enhances and accelerates the decision-making process for clients as well as bank personnel. The AI-powered Credit Scoring System also keeps learning and improving on newly collected information, enabling banks to constantly offer current credit scoring to properly represent market trends. Furthermore, for the banks, this technology reduces trust risk (i.e., decreases defaulting chance) as well as improves consumer experience.

title: Experimental Analysis of Service Performance of a Novel Copper-Aluminum Bonded High-Voltage Disconnect Switch Based on Cold Spray Technology
authors: Lei Xia, Yongfu Li, Xiping Jiang, Fei Huang, Qinglong Liao, Hong Xiang, Wen Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Equipment and Industrial Design (IEID)
abstract: In modern power systems, the contact materials of high-voltage disconnect switches have long relied on copper-based materials, which are costly, and traditional copper-aluminum connection technologies (such as flash welding and brazing) are prone to failure due to stress concentration and corrosion. Therefore, this study proposes the use of cold spray technology to fabricate copper-aluminum bonded high-voltage disconnect switch contact blades, systematically investigating the effects of coating thickness (0.15 mm and 0.35 mm) and surface roughness (Ra0.8 and Ra3.2) on their service performance. Through mechanical switching tests (1200 cycles) and neutral salt spray tests (120 hours), the temperature rise, loop resistance, and wear characteristics of the contact blades were evaluated. The results indicate that surface roughness significantly affects mechanical lifespan. For instance, the Ra0.8 samples exhibited a temperature rise of only 44.2 °C after mechanical switching with the lowest increase in loop resistance (3.69 μΩ) and minimal contact wear (scratch depth of 4 μm). In contrast, the Ra3.2 samples showed a temperature rise of 54.7 °C with the highest increase in loop resistance (20.01 μΩ) and severe groove formation on the contacts (maximum depth of 215 μm). Under neutral salt spray conditions, the Ra0.8 samples demonstrated stable temperature rise (44 °C), outperforming traditional pure copper contact blades. This study validates the feasibility of replacing pure copper contacts with cold-sprayed copper-aluminum bonded contact blades, providing technical support for the low-cost, high-performance design of high-voltage disconnect switches.

title: Wind Power Generation in Peru: Exploratory Analysis and Prediction Using Outlier Detection and Supervised Learning Algorithms
authors: Elmer Arellanos-Tafur, Joaquin Villalba-Castro-Cuba, Julio Cangahuala Jara, Flavia Diaz Follegatti, Jose Ostos Marquez, Marcelo Damas-Niño
publish: 2025 IEEE XXXII International Conference on Electronics, Electrical Engineering and Computing (INTERCON)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive analysis of wind power generation forecasting in Peru using machine learning algorithms and outlier detection techniques. The research employed Random Forest Regression, Gradient Boosting Regression, and Support Vector Regression (SVR) to predict wind power generation across 13 companies using a two-year dataset (May 2023 - April 2025). A 7-day sliding window approach was implemented to forecast daily generation, with models trained on temporal features, lagged values, and rolling statistics. Exploratory data analysis revealed significant variability in generation capacity across companies, with monthly generation ranging from 359 GWh to 825 GWh, showing 42.0% growth between study years. The capacity factor decreased from 33.0% in Year 1 to 22.5% in Year 2, indicating rapid capacity expansion. Random Forest demonstrated superior performance with R2 = 0.438, MAE = 3,700.43 MWh, and RMSE = 4,734.9 MWh, followed by SVR (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.423). Company-specific analysis showed heterogeneous performance, with ENGIE facilities achieving the highest predictability (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> > 0.45), while some companies exhibited negative R2 values. Outlier detection using IQR methods improved model stability by reducing RMSE = 226.63 to 198.51 MWh, though slightly decreasing R2 = 0.418 to 0.327.

title: Robotics Education and its Role in Enhancing Academic Persistence and Achievement in the Triângulo Mineiro Region
authors: Aline Fernanda Furtado Silva, Artur de Almeida Rios, Danielli Araújo Lima
publish: 2025 Brazilian Symposium on Robotics (SBR) and 2025 Workshop on Robotics in Education (WRE)
abstract: This article investigates the impacts of higher education students' participation in robotics projects on their academic retention and success. Drawing on the analysis of experiences and project proposals developed in the Triangulo Mineiro region of Brazil, the study discusses how educational robotics can enhance student engagement, motivation, and the development of essential skills, thereby contributing to reduced dropout rates and improved academic performance. The distinctions between educational and pedagogical robotics, as well as the historical context of their application in Brazil, are examined. Recent experiences employing machine learning and data visualization to assess the impacts of robotics initiatives-including those aimed at increasing female participation-underscore the relevance and the need for more in-depth analyses. Although direct statistical data to quantify causal effects remain limited in publicly available databases for this specific region, qualitative evidence and practical examples based on local initiatives indicate a significant positive impact. The study highlights the importance of such initiatives for the comprehensive education of students in engineering and technology programs.

title: Hybrid Models and Causal Inference Techniques for Optimizing Climate Science: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Geetanjali R, Evangelin Geetha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: Climate change presents a complex global challenge, demanding models that not only deliver accurate forecasts but also unpack the causal mechanisms behind observed phenomena. This paper provides a comprehensive review of hybrid models, causal inference techniques, and entropy-guided metaheuristic optimization approaches used in climate science, emphasizing interpretability and adaptability. Focusing on temperature anomalies and atmospheric CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> data, we examine how physics-informed neural networks and machine learning methods can integrate domain knowledge for improved interpretability. Causal inference frameworks—from structural causal models to counterfactual analysis—help separate true causal drivers (such as anthropogenic emissions) from confounding environmental variables. Concurrently, metaheuristics (e.g., genetic algorithms, particle swarm optimization) address multi-objective problems, enabling efficient resource allocation and emissions mitigation strategies. Recent studies demonstrate that synergy among these methods leads to robust climate predictions, actionable scientific advisory group insights, and adaptable frameworks for resilience planning. By spotlighting real-world case studies—from flood susceptibility mapping to renewable energy optimization—the review underscores the importance of bridging empirical data, physical laws, and computational heuristics for integrated climate solutions. While challenges persist in data quality, model scalability, and the interpretability of advanced AI architectures, ongoing interdisciplinary work promises to refine both the accuracy and transparency of climate models. This paper concludes by outlining future research directions that emphasize hybrid causal modeling, real-time data assimilation, and socioeconomic feedback loops, ultimately aiming to strengthen science-driven responses to the climate crisis.

title: Partial Homomorphic Cryptosystems for Cloud Security: Comparative Analysis of RSA and Goldwasser-Micali Approaches
authors: D. Hemila Rexline, X.Anita
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The primary goals of advanced cryptographic systems are data security and privacy protection. Protecting sensitive information has always been critical, especially with the frequent use of cloud service platforms. Traditional encryption solutions have the disadvantage of requiring data to be decrypted before processing. Data must be protected when at rest in the cloud. Encryption is essential when using public cloud services at both processing and storage levels, i.e., in motion. It is feasible to process encrypted data using a modern cryptographic technique known as homomorphic encryption. This paper discusses the background knowledge needed to understand homomorphic encryption techniques. Based on their efficiency, key generation, encryption, decryption, computation time, and homomorphic functionality, the two partial homomorphic approaches: Rivest-Shamir-Adleman (RSA) and Goldwasser-Micali (GM) Cryptosystem are examined and contrasted. The results indicate that while the GM Cryptosystem offers higher security due to probabilistic encryption, it is computationally inefficient for large-scale cloud applications. In contrast, RSA provides a balance between security and performance, making it more suitable for practical cloud security implementations.

title: Mobile App for Direct Market Access for Farmers
authors: Aniket Chauhan, Kalpana K Harish, Utkarsh Kumar, Raunak
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on New Frontiers in Communication, Automation, Management and Security (ICCAMS)
abstract: The proposed mobile application is designed to revolutionize the agricultural marketplace by providing farmers with a direct-to-consumer selling platform, eliminating the need for intermediaries. The app features a user-friendly interface, ensuring that farmers, regardless of their technical knowledge, can easily list their products, update inventory, and manage transactions. A real-time price negotiation system allows direct communication between farmers and buyers, fostering transparent and fair pricing. To ensure seamless financial transactions, the app integrates secure payment gateways, supporting multiple payment options such as UPI, digital wallets, and bank transfers.Furthermore, the integration of multilingual support broadens accessibility, ensuring that farmers from various linguistic and regional backgrounds can seamlessly navigate the platform. The application leverages AI-driven price recommendations, which analyze historical market data, demand fluctuations, and seasonal trends to assist farmers in determining optimal pricing strategies. To enhance supply chain efficiency, the app incorporates a logistics and transportation network, connecting farmers with local delivery services for cost-effective and timely distribution. Additionally, real-time weather forecasting and market analytics empower farmers with data-driven insights, aiding in strategic decision-making for planting, harvesting, and selling their produce at the most favorable times. A built-in rating and review system fosters transparency and credibility, allowing buyers to assess sellers based on quality, reliability, and past transactions. Moreover, digital payment integration ensures secure, hassle-free transactions, reducing the risks associated with cash dealings. By incorporating these advanced features, the mobile application enhances direct market access, optimizes profitability, and minimizes reliance on intermediaries, ultimately revolutionizing the agricultural marketplace.

title: Inversely Designed High-Efficiency Achromatic Slanted Metagratings for Augmented Reality Waveguide Displays
authors: Xiangyu Zhang, Zhanhua Huang, Lin Zhang
abstract: Waveguide displays are promising for augmented reality or mixed reality, but chromatic dispersion in conventional diffractive elements limits full-color display performance. Although promising, achromatic metagratings’ diffraction efficiency needs to be improved. We propose an inverse design method using a quantum genetic algorithm for achromatic slanted metagratings. Two designs with 20° and 40° fields of view exhibit diffraction efficiencies as high as 29% ± 1% for RGB wavelengths at normal incidence and excellent angular and spectral uniformity. The proposed single-layer manufacturable structures offer a promising route to future full-color waveguide displays.

title: A Stitch in Time Saves Nine: Progressive Information Bottleneck for Incremental Multiview Clustering
authors: Xiaoqiang Yan, Fengshou Han, Yiqiao Mao, Zhen Tian, Witold Pedrycz, Hui Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Incremental multiview clustering (IMVC) leverages consistent information between historical and new views to benefit the clustering task. However, existing IMVC approaches ignore the redundant information in individual views, leading to an accumulation of irrelevance. Besides, with the continuous arrivals of new views, the knowledge learned from historical views is often forgotten, which hinders the learning models from achieving long-term dependencies across incremental views. In this study, we propose a novel progressive information bottleneck (PIB), which is capable of removing redundant information in a timely manner and selectively updating historical knowledge based on information gain of new views. Specifically, to facilitate the knowledge transfer from historical views to incoming one, an information-aware knowledge library is built to store the representative samples of historical views. With the emergence of new views, we first devise a matrix-based mutual information (MI) constraint on an encoder to compress redundant information, which facilitates the training of a neural network with analyzable gradients and obtain a compact yet discriminative representation. Then, a dual-selective updating strategy is proposed to preserve historical knowledge in time when it contributes more to the information gain of the knowledge library than the new view. Finally, relevant samples to the new view in knowledge library are migrated to maximize the cross-level consistency between historical and new views. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that designs a gradient-analyzable MI measurement for incremental multiview learning and employs information gain to guide the selective update of the knowledge library. Empirical evaluations on six benchmark datasets show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art baseline methods by an average of 8.1%, 7.6%, and 7.8% on clustering accuracy (ACC), normalized mutual information (NMI), and adjusted Rand index (ARI) metrics, respectively.

title: Remote Vital Sign Monitoring Through Glass Barrier Using 77 GHz FMCW Radar
authors: Ashi Singhal, Fatima Sami, Adeeba Khan, Mohd Wajid, Mohammed Usman, Hemant Kumar Meena, Abhishek Srivastava
abstract: This study presents a novel sensor-based system for human vital sign estimation through a glass barrier using Texas Instruments (TI) 77 GHz AWR1843BOOST Frequency Modulated Continuous Wave (FMCW) radar. To improve signal fidelity and ensure precise extraction of physiological parameters, the signal processing pipeline incorporates beamforming, Variational Mode Decomposition (VMD), and Recursive Bayesian Estimation (RBE). Experiments were conducted across distances of 0.4 m to 0.7 m through glass barrier. The system achieved an Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 1.93 breaths per minute for respiratory rate and 8.47 beats per minute for HR, with average accuracies of 83.74% and 91.41%, respectively. The results highlight the system's potential for reliable, hygienic, non-invasive monitoring in sensitive settings like neonatal intensive care units (NICUs) and infection control wards, where contact-based methods are risky.
